HowTo: Begin in a standing position, drop into a squat with your hands on the plate, kick your feet back into a push-up position, perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to the squat and explode upwards into a jump.

Title: Holman Plate Elbow Plank Reach
Desc: The Holman Plate Elbow Plank Reach is a core stability exercise. Start in an elbow plank position with a plate under one arm. Reach forward with the opposite arm while maintaining a stable core, then return to the plank position.
HowTo: Start in an elbow plank position with a plate under one arm. Reach forward with the opposite arm while keeping your core stable, then return to the elbow plank position.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank to Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank to Renegade Row is a challenging exercise that targets the back and core. Begin in an elbow plank position, then transition to a high plank and perform a row with a dumbbell or plate in each hand, alternating sides.
HowTo: Begin in an elbow plank position, transition to a high plank, and perform a row with a dumbbell or plate in each hand, alternating sides.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Weighted Hand Hill Climber
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Weighted Hand Hill Climber is a core and cardio exercise. Start in a straight plank position with a weight on your back. Alternate driving your knees towards your chest in a climbing motion while maintaining a strong plank.
HowTo: Start in a straight plank position with a weight on your back. Alternate driving your knees towards your chest in a climbing motion while maintaining a strong plank.

Title: Holman Weighted Left Side Diagonal Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Left Side Diagonal Pike is a core exercise that engages the obliques. Begin in a plank position, then lift your hips and bring your left knee towards your left elbow while holding a weight in your right hand.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position, lift your hips, and bring your left knee towards your left elbow while holding a weight in your right hand.

Title: Holman Weighted Right Side Diagonal Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Right Side Diagonal Pike is similar to the left side but targets the right side. Start in a plank position, then lift your hips and bring your right knee towards your right elbow while holding a weight in your left hand.
HowTo: Start in a plank position, lift your hips, and bring your right knee towards your right elbow while holding a weight in your left hand.

Title: Holman Weighted W-Boat to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted W-Boat to Overhead Press is a full-body exercise that combines core strength and shoulder stability. Sit in a W-Boat position with a weight, then extend your legs and press the weight overhead while maintaining balance.
HowTo: Sit in a W-Boat position with a weight. Extend your legs and press the weight overhead while maintaining balance.

Title: Holman Weighted Kneeling Lift
Desc: The Holman Weighted Kneeling Lift is an exercise that targets the core and shoulders by lifting a weight while in a kneeling position, engaging stability and strength.
HowTo: Kneel on the ground with a weight in one hand. Engage your core and lift the weight overhead while maintaining stability. Lower the weight back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Hips-Up Weighted Pull-Over
Desc: The Holman Hips-Up Weighted Pull-Over involves lying on your back and lifting a weight overhead while raising your hips, focusing on the core and upper body strength.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Hold a weight above your chest. Raise your hips towards the ceiling while pressing the weight overhead, then lower back down.

Title: Holman Weighted Cross Punch
Desc: The Holman Weighted Cross Punch is a dynamic exercise that combines a cross punch motion with added weight, enhancing core stability and upper body strength.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in each hand. Rotate your torso to the right as you punch forward with your right arm, then return to the center and repeat on the left side.

Title: Holman Straight-Leg Boat Hover Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Straight-Leg Boat Hover Chest Press is a challenging core exercise that combines a boat position with a chest press, targeting the abs and chest.
HowTo: Sit in a boat position with your legs straight and elevated. Hold a weight in both hands at chest level. Press the weight overhead while keeping your core engaged, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Weighted Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Pike is an advanced core exercise where you lift your legs into a pike position while holding a weight, engaging the entire abdominal region.
HowTo: Lie on your back and hold a weight in both hands. Lift your legs into a pike position while simultaneously raising the weight towards your feet, engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Wax-On Wax-Off
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Wax-On Wax-Off is a dynamic exercise that combines a feet-elevated position with a rotational movement, targeting the obliques and core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your feet elevated on a surface. Hold a weight in both hands and rotate your torso to one side, bringing the weight towards the ground beside you, then return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Elbow Plank to Towel Pike
Desc: The Holman Elbow Plank to Towel Pike is a core stability exercise that transitions from a plank position to a pike, using a towel for added challenge.
HowTo: Start in an elbow plank position with a towel under your feet. Engage your core and slide your feet towards your hands, lifting your hips into a pike position, then return to the plank.

Title: Holman Seated Killer Abs Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Seated Killer Abs Overhead Press is a seated exercise that combines an overhead press with core engagement, focusing on building strength in the abs and shoulders.
HowTo: Sit on a bench or chair with your feet flat on the ground. Hold a weight in both hands at shoulder height. Engage your core and press the weight overhead, then lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: Holman Straight Plank Alternating Weighted Open
Desc: The Holman Straight Plank Alternating Weighted Open is an advanced core exercise that involves holding a plank position while alternating the lifting of weights. This exercise targets the abdominal muscles, shoulders, and stabilizes the core.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your body in a straight line from head to heels. Hold a weight in one hand. Alternate lifting the weight towards the ceiling while maintaining the plank position, engaging your core and stabilizing your hips.

Title: Holman Weighted Killer Abs with Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Killer Abs with Overhead Press combines an overhead press with a core workout. This exercise engages the abs while also strengthening the shoulders and arms, providing a full-body challenge.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position holding weights at shoulder height. Press the weights overhead while simultaneously engaging your core. Lower the weights back to shoulder height while maintaining a strong abdominal contraction.

Title: Holman Weighted Split-Leg Pike
Desc: The Holman Weighted Split-Leg Pike is a dynamic exercise that focuses on the core and hamstrings. By lifting one leg while piking the hips, this move enhances flexibility and strength in the lower body.
HowTo: Start in a split stance with one leg forward and the other leg back. Bend at the hips to pike your body while lifting the back leg towards the ceiling. Engage your core throughout the movement to maintain balance.

Title: Holman Towel Reverse Plank Heel Pull-in
Desc: The Holman Towel Reverse Plank Heel Pull-in is a unique variation of the reverse plank that incorporates a towel for added resistance. This exercise targets the core, glutes, and hamstrings while improving stability.
HowTo: Begin in a reverse plank position with your hands on the ground and your body in a straight line. Use a towel under your feet to pull your heels towards your glutes while keeping your hips lifted. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Stick Twist
Desc: The Stick Twist is a rotational exercise that engages the core and improves flexibility. By twisting the torso while holding a stick or bar, this move enhances spinal mobility and strengthens the obliques.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a stick or bar across your shoulders. Rotate your torso to one side while keeping your hips facing forward. Return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Roc Everest
Desc: The Roc Everest is a challenging exercise that mimics the motion of climbing. It engages multiple muscle groups, particularly the core and legs, while improving cardiovascular endurance and coordination.
HowTo: Start in a high plank position. Drive one knee towards your chest, then quickly switch legs in a running motion, engaging your core and maintaining a steady rhythm.

Title: Standing cable low-to-high twist
Desc: The standing cable low-to-high twist is a core exercise targeting the upper abdominals and the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding the cable handle with both hands. Rotate your torso from low to high, engaging your core and keeping your hips stable. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired reps.

Title: Single-arm high-cable side bend
Desc: The single-arm high-cable side bend is an exercise targeting the obliques using a cable stack machine.
HowTo: Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set high. Grasp the handle with one hand and step away from the machine. Bend sideways at the waist, then return to the starting position, engaging your obliques throughout the movement.

Title: Kneeling cable oblique crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable oblique crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor with a rope attachment from a cable stack. Grasp the rope with both hands and pull it down towards your knees while contracting your obliques. Focus on crunching your torso down towards your knees, then return to the starting position. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Kneeling cable crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor with a rope attachment from a cable stack. Hold the rope with both hands at your head level. Engage your core and pull the rope down towards your knees, focusing on contracting your rectus abdominis. Return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Rope Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor with a rope attachment from a cable stack. Hold the rope with both hands at head level. Engage your core and pull the rope down towards your knees, focusing on contracting your rectus abdominis. Return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing cable crunch
Desc: The standing cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a rope attachment from a cable stack above your head. Engage your core and bend forward at the waist, pulling the cable down towards your knees while contracting your rectus abdominis. Return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Bosu Ball Cable Crunch With Side Bends
Desc: The Bosu Ball Cable Crunch with Side Bends is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles while incorporating a twisting motion to engage the obliques. Start by kneeling on a Bosu ball with a cable attached at a high position. Hold the cable handles and perform a crunch while twisting to one side, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Kneel on a Bosu ball with a cable attached at a high position. Hold the cable handles and perform a crunch while twisting your torso to one side, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. Aim for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Standing Cable Wood Chop
Desc: The standing cable high-to-low twist is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals and the obliques.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a cable handle with both hands at shoulder height. Engage your core and twist your torso downwards, pulling the cable diagonally across your body from high to low. Return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable reverse crunch
Desc: The cable reverse crunch is performed on the ground facing away from a high pulley, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically.
HowTo: Lie on your back on the ground facing away from a high pulley. Attach the cable to your feet and hold onto the cable. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground while pulling your knees towards your chest. Lower back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable Russian Twists
Desc: Cable Russian Twists are a dynamic exercise that targets the core, particularly the obliques. Begin seated on the floor with your legs bent and feet flat. Hold a cable handle with both hands, lean back slightly, and rotate your torso to one side, then to the other, while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs bent and feet flat. Hold a cable handle with both hands and lean back slightly. Rotate your torso to one side, then to the other, while keeping your core engaged. Perform for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Pallof press with rotation
Desc: The Pallof press with rotation is a dynamic variation of the Pallof press that incorporates weighted rotation away from the torso using resistance from a cable pulley. It is intended to build abdominal strength and teach proper bracing. It can be performed for time or for reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the cable handle with both hands. Engage your core and press the handle away from your torso. As you press, rotate your torso away from the cable machine, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cable Seated Crunch
Desc: The Cable Seated Crunch is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. Sit on a cable machine with your feet secured, grasp the cable handle, and crunch your torso down towards your knees while keeping your back straight.
HowTo: Sit on the cable machine with your feet secured. Grasp the cable handle with both hands and pull it down towards your chest. Crunch your torso down towards your knees while keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cable Judo Flip
Desc: The Cable Judo Flip is a dynamic exercise that mimics the motion of a judo throw. Stand facing a cable machine, grasp the handle with both hands, and pull it across your body while pivoting on your feet, engaging your core and upper body.
HowTo: Stand facing the cable machine with feet shoulder-width apart. Grasp the handle with both hands. Engage your core, pivot on your feet, and pull the cable across your body while rotating your torso. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Exercise Ball Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. Hold the cable handle with both hands above your head. Crunch your torso forward, bringing your elbows towards your knees while keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing cable high-to-low twist
Desc: The standing cable high-to-low twist is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals and the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the cable handle with both hands at shoulder height. Engage your core and twist your torso downwards, pulling the cable handle across your body towards your hip. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps on each side.

Title: Bent-Over Reverse Cable Fly
Desc: The Bent-Over Reverse Cable Fly is a great exercise for targeting the rear deltoids and upper back. Stand bent over with your back straight, hold the cable handles with both hands, and pull them out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Stand bent over with your back straight, holding the cable handles with both hands. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the rope attachment with both hands above your head. Engage your core and crunch downwards, bringing your elbows towards your knees. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Cable Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor in front of the cable machine, holding the rope attachment with both hands. Engage your core and crunch downwards, bringing your elbows towards your knees while keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Tyler Holt Weighted Knee-To-Chest Crunch
Desc: The Tyler Holt Weighted Knee-To-Chest Crunch is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. To perform this exercise, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a weight plate or dumbbell against your chest, then lift your knees towards your chest while engaging your core. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a weight plate or dumbbell against your chest. Lift your knees towards your chest while engaging your core. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Standing cable twist
Desc: The standing cable twist is a core exercise that targets the abdominals, particularly the obliques. Take care to perform it with control, as opposed to violent twisting which can injure the back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 per side, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the cable handle with both hands. Rotate your torso to one side while keeping your hips stable. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch sides.

Title: 30 Cable Rope Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed early in an ab workout, usually in moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Kneel in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. Grasp the rope and pull it down towards your knees while contracting your abs. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Cable Rope Oblique Crunch
Desc: The kneeling cable oblique crunch is a popular core isolation exercise using a rope attachment and cable stack while kneeling on the floor. It primarily targets the obliques and rectus abdominus or "six-pack" muscles, but also strengthens the deep core muscles. It is most commonly performed for moderate to high reps like 8-12 reps per set or higher.
Muscles: Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: Kneel in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. Grasp the rope and perform a crunch by bringing your elbow towards your knee, focusing on the obliques. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Cable lying twist on ball
Desc: The cable lying twist on ball is an exercise targeting the core and obliques with the added challenge of stability to keep from losing position on the unstable surface.
Muscles: Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: Lie on a stability ball with your back supported and hold the cable handle with both hands. Rotate your torso to one side, keeping your hips stable, then return to the center and rotate to the other side. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Cable Pallof Press
Desc: The pallof press is an anti-rotation, isometric exercise that trains core stability. It is most often seen in programs for athletes who compete in sports that test strength, power, and functional movements.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the cable handle with both hands at your chest. Press the handle straight out in front of you while engaging your core, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Cable Reverse Crunch On Ball
Desc: The cable reverse crunch on a BOSU is performed on top of a BOSU ball between two cable pulleys, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically and is more proprioceptively challenging than a cable reverse crunch on the floor.
HowTo: Lie on a BOSU ball with your back supported and hold the cable handle with both hands. Pull your knees towards your chest while engaging your lower abs, then lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Cable Reverse Crunch
Desc: The cable reverse crunch is performed on the ground facing away from a high pulley, which helps target the lower abdominals specifically.
HowTo: Lie on your back on the floor facing away from a high pulley. Grasp the cable handle and pull your knees towards your chest while engaging your lower abs. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Tyler Holt Cable Torso Twist
Desc: The Tyler Holt Cable Torso Twist is an effective exercise for targeting the oblique muscles. It involves using a cable machine to perform a twisting motion that engages the core and improves rotational strength.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable machine to a low position and attach a handle. 2. Stand with your side to the machine, grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Step away from the machine to create tension in the cable. 4. Rotate your torso away from the machine while keeping your hips stable. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-Arm Cable Outward-Facing Biceps Curl
Desc: The Biceps Rope Curl is a popular exercise that targets the biceps brachii. Using a rope attachment on a cable machine, this exercise allows for a full range of motion and helps to build muscle size and strength in the arms.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope to the low pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the rope with one hand, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Curl the rope upward while rotating your wrist outward. 5. Lower the rope back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Biceps Rope Curl
Desc: Kneeling Cable Crunches are a core-strengthening exercise performed on a cable machine. By kneeling and pulling the cable down towards the ground, this exercise effectively targets the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and pull it down to your chest. 3. Engage your core and lean forward slightly. 4. Crunch your torso down towards your knees, pulling the cable down. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Kneeling Cable Crunches
Desc: The AM Ab Machine is designed to isolate and strengthen the abdominal muscles. This machine allows users to perform controlled crunching motions, making it easier to target the core and improve overall abdominal strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the AM Ab Machine to ensure proper alignment. 2. Sit down and place your feet under the foot pads. 3. Grasp the handles or place your hands on the designated area. 4. Engage your core and perform a controlled crunch by bringing your torso down towards your hips. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Ab Crunch Machine
Desc: The machine crunch is a machine-based exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. It involves sitting upright in the machine and curling the torso down toward the chest against some pre-set level of resistance. On some machines, the knees also curl up torward the torso. Crunch machines usually use extra resistance in the form of selectorized weight stacks or plate loading, and are often performed for moderate to high reps, like 8-12 reps per set or higher, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit in the machine with your back against the pad and feet secured under the foot pads. 2. Adjust the weight to your desired resistance level. 3. Engage your core and curl your torso down towards your chest. 4. Hold for a moment at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine straight-legged hip raise
Desc: The Smith machine straight-legged hip raise is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. Because of the potential awkwardness of getting into position, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more. If your Smith machine has safety bars, set them at a height that allows you a full range of motion while giving adequate protection from the weight potentially falling.
HowTo: 1. Set the safety bars on the Smith machine to a height that allows for full range of motion. 2. Lie on your back on the floor or a bench with your legs extended straight. 3. Position your feet under the bar, keeping your legs straight. 4. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 5. Lower your hips back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine crunch
Desc: The machine crunch is a machine-based exercise targeting the abdominal muscles. It involves sitting upright in the machine and curling the torso down against a pre-set level of resistance. On some machines, the knees also curl up toward the torso. Crunch machines usually use extra resistance in the form of selectorized weight stacks or plate loading, and are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit in the machine with your back against the pad and feet secured under the foot pads. 2. Adjust the weight to your desired resistance level. 3. Engage your core and curl your torso down towards your chest. 4. Hold for a moment at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Ab Machine
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the AM Ab Machine to ensure proper alignment. 2. Sit down and place your feet under the foot pads. 3. Grasp the handles or place your hands on the designated area. 4. Engage your core and perform a controlled crunch by bringing your torso down towards your hips. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine V-up
Desc: The smith machine V-up is a weighted abdominal exercise that involves pressing a weighted bar upward while performing a V-up. Performing it in a Smith machine eliminates the balance challenge of a free weight. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps in the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height. 2. Lie on the floor with your back against the bench and your legs extended. 3. Grasp the bar with both hands, shoulder-width apart. 4. Engage your core and lift your legs to form a V shape while simultaneously pressing the bar upward. 5. Lower your legs and the bar back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Elbow plank
Desc: The elbow plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise. It is common in all types of exercise programs, as well as in group fitness and yoga classes. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It is also often prescribed for time to help back pain or to teach proper bracing.
HowTo: 1. Start in a forearm plank position with your elbows directly beneath your shoulders and your body in a straight line. 2. Engage your core and keep your hips level. 3. Hold this position for the desired amount of time, focusing on maintaining proper form.

Title: Bottoms Up
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs extended and your arms at your sides. 2. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight. 3. Slowly lower your legs back down without touching the ground. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Spider crawl
Desc: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring your right knee towards your right elbow while keeping your hips high. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired duration.

Title: Cocoons
Desc: The cocoon crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing your knees to your chest and your arms from overhead to center. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and your legs straight. 2. Simultaneously bring your knees towards your chest while lifting your arms to meet them in the center. 3. Return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cross-Body Crunch
Desc: The elbow-to-knee crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. 3. Lift your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 4. Switch sides, bringing your left elbow towards your right knee. 5. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Elbow-to-knee crunch
Desc: The elbow-to-knee crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. 3. Lift your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 4. Switch sides, bringing your left elbow towards your right knee. 5. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Decline Crunch
Desc: The decline crunch is an effective core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 4. Lower back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hanging toes-to-bar
Desc: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement (strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent) each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms straight and your body in a straight line. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs towards the bar, keeping them straight or slightly bent. 3. Aim to touch your toes to the bar, then lower your legs back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hanging Oblique Knee Raise
Desc: The hanging oblique crunch an abdominal exercise that targets both the rectus abdominus or “six-pack” muscles, and the oblique muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulder, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another)
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar or use ab straps for support. 2. Engage your core and lift your knees towards one side, bringing them towards your chest while twisting your torso. 3. Lower your legs back down and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Gorilla Chin/Crunch
Desc: The Gorilla Chin/Crunch is a compound exercise that targets the upper body and core. It combines the pulling motion of a chin-up with the crunching motion of a sit-up, engaging the biceps, back, and abdominal muscles. This exercise can be performed using a pull-up bar or a similar apparatus, and it is effective for building strength and stability in the upper body while also working the core.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms straight. 2. Pull your body up while simultaneously bringing your knees towards your chest, engaging your core. 3. As you reach the top of the movement, crunch your abs to maximize the contraction. 4. Lower your body back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hanging leg raise
Desc: The hanging leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs, but which also works the lats and hip flexors. Instead of resting your forearms on the pads of a captain's chair, you perform these hanging from a bar. Experienced lifters make these look easy, but beginners may need time to build up to sets of 8-12 reps.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms straight. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs straight up towards the bar, keeping them together. 3. Lower your legs back down to the starting position without swinging. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Mountain climber
Desc: The mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It involves lifting one knee to the chest at a time from a straight-arm plank position. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Quickly switch legs, bringing the opposite knee to your chest. 4. Continue alternating legs at a fast pace for the desired duration or number of reps.

Title: Ab bicycle
Desc: The ab bicycle is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and your legs lifted off the ground. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while straightening your right leg. 3. Switch sides, bringing your left elbow towards your right knee while straightening your left leg. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: 3/4 sit-up
Desc: The 3/4 sit-up is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core. It is similar to a sit-up, but stops short of the top position. This keeps constant tension on the abs, making it more difficult than traditional sit-ups. It can be performed for time or for reps, with the feet anchored or free, as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, stopping short of a full sit-up. 4. Lower back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse crunch
Desc: The reverse crunch is a popular exercise targeting the abdominals, particularly the lower half. It’s easy to perform on either the floor or a flat bench. Many lifters think of this as a companion to the crunch, which targets the upper abdominals more than the lower.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor or resting on a bench. 2. Place your hands at your sides or behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground, curling your knees towards your chest. 4. Lower your hips back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Crunches
Desc: The crunch is a popular core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques. It has been the centerpiece of many ab-focused workouts, due to both its simplicity and the intense burn and mind-muscle connection it produces. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform crunches, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head or across your chest. Engage your core and lift your shoulder blades off the ground, curling your torso towards your knees. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dead bug reach
Desc: The dead bug reach is an exercise for strengthening the core in which you alternate lowering your opposing arm and leg simultaneously, controlling the movement with the abdominal muscles. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up to activate the core for other athletics or lifting, or be performed in a circuit or on its own in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the dead bug reach, lie on your back with your arms extended towards the ceiling and your knees bent at 90 degrees. Slowly lower your right arm and left leg towards the floor while keeping your back flat. Return to the starting position and alternate sides, ensuring controlled movement throughout.

Title: Crunch - Hands Overhead
Desc: The Crunch with Hands Overhead is an abdominal exercise that targets the rectus abdominis. To perform this exercise, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Extend your arms overhead, keeping them straight. Engage your core and lift your shoulder blades off the ground, curling your torso towards your knees while keeping your arms extended. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: To perform the Crunch with Hands Overhead, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Extend your arms overhead, keeping them straight. Engage your core and lift your shoulder blades off the ground, curling your torso towards your knees while keeping your arms extended. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: V-up
Desc: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform a V-up, lie flat on your back with your arms extended overhead. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body off the ground, reaching your hands towards your feet to form a 'V' shape. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Stomach Vacuum
Desc: The Stomach Vacuum is an isometric exercise that focuses on strengthening the transverse abdominis, the deep core muscles. To perform this exercise, stand or kneel with a straight back. Exhale completely, pulling your belly button in towards your spine as much as possible. Hold this position for a few seconds while breathing normally, then release. Repeat for several sets, focusing on maintaining tension in the core.
HowTo: To perform the Stomach Vacuum, stand or kneel with a straight back. Exhale completely and pull your belly button in towards your spine as much as possible. Hold this position for a few seconds while breathing normally, then release. Repeat for several sets, focusing on maintaining tension in the core.

Title: Russian twist
Desc: The Russian twist is an exercise targeting the abdominals and the obliques. Beginning from a position that resembles stopping midway through a sit-up, it involves twisting side to side. It can be performed with body weight alone or while holding a weight plate or other object. It is performed by alternating sides with each rep and can be done for time or for a specific number of reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the Russian twist, sit on the ground with your knees bent and feet flat. Lean back slightly and lift your feet off the ground, balancing on your sit bones. Hold your hands together or a weight in front of you, and twist your torso to the right, then to the left, alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise, lie flat on your back on a bench with your legs extended. Keeping your legs straight, lift them towards the ceiling while engaging your core. Lower them back down slowly without touching the bench and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Knees tucked crunch
Desc: The knees tucked crunch is a core exercise that involves performing a crunch while keeping the knees bent in a 90-degree position. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: To perform the knees tucked crunch, lie on your back with your knees bent at a 90-degree angle and feet off the ground. Place your hands behind your head or across your chest. Engage your core and lift your shoulder blades off the ground, curling your torso towards your knees. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Butt-Ups
Desc: Butt-Ups are an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. To perform Butt-Ups, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes, then lower back down.
HowTo: To perform Butt-Ups, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes, then lower back down.

Title: Feet-elevated oblique crunch
Desc: The feet-elevated oblique crunch is a variation on the crunch exercise that targets the obliques as well as the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. Resting the feet on a bench takes some of the hip flexor activation out of the movement, focusing the stress more on the abs.
HowTo: To perform the feet-elevated oblique crunch, lie on your back with your feet resting on a bench. Place your hands behind your head, engage your core, and lift your shoulders off the ground while twisting your torso to bring your elbow towards the opposite knee. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Bent-knee reverse crunch
Desc: The bent-knee reverse crunch is a popular bodyweight core exercise. It targets the lower portion of the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any ab-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the bent-knee reverse crunch, lie on your back with your knees bent at 90 degrees and feet off the ground. Engage your core and curl your hips off the floor, bringing your knees towards your chest. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Alternating heel-touch
Desc: The alternating heel-touch is a popular bodyweight exercise that targets the obliques, as well as the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: To perform the alternating heel-touch, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your shoulders off the ground and reach your right hand towards your right heel, then return to the starting position and repeat on the left side.

Title: Suspended Reverse Crunch
Desc: The Suspended Reverse Crunch is an advanced core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. To perform this exercise, hang from a suspension trainer or similar equipment, engage your core, and pull your knees towards your chest while keeping your back straight.
HowTo: To perform the suspended reverse crunch, hang from a suspension trainer or similar equipment with your arms extended. Engage your core and pull your knees towards your chest while keeping your back straight. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Lying bench reverse crunch
Desc: The lying bench reverse crunch is a popular ab exercise performed by bringing the knees toward the chest while lying on a bench. It is largely similar to the same exercise performed on the floor, but being able to press the lower back into the bench pad can help reinforce proper form and increase the burn in the abs. Like most crunch variations, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: To perform the lying bench reverse crunch, lie on a bench with your legs hanging off the end. Bring your knees towards your chest while pressing your lower back into the bench. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Sit-up
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: To perform a sit-up, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: Side Bridge
Desc: The side plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It is sometimes paired with the curl up and bird dog as the “McGill big three” for core strength and stability. It is performed for time and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform a side bridge, lie on your side with your legs straight and stacked on top of each other. Prop yourself up on your forearm, keeping your body in a straight line from head to heels. Hold this position for time, engaging your core and glutes.

Title: Lying oblique crunch
Desc: The lying oblique crunch is a bodyweight exercise targeting the oblique muscles. It can be performed for a specific number of reps or to fatigue or failure as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the lying oblique crunch, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Place your hands behind your head for support. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground while rotating your torso to one side, bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch sides.

Title: Janda Sit-Up
Desc: The Janda Sit-Up is a core exercise that emphasizes the use of the abdominal muscles while minimizing hip flexor involvement. To perform this exercise, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees while keeping your feet elevated and resting on a bench or an exercise ball.
HowTo: To perform the Janda Sit-Up, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet elevated on a bench or exercise ball. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees while keeping your feet elevated. Focus on using your abdominal muscles rather than your hip flexors. Lower back down slowly and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Leg Pull-In
Desc: The reverse crunch is a popular exercise targeting the abdominals, particularly the lower half. It’s easy to perform on either the floor or a flat bench. Many lifters think of this as a companion to the crunch, which targets the upper abdominals more than the lower.
HowTo: To perform the Leg Pull-In, lie on your back on a flat surface or bench with your legs extended. Engage your core and lift your legs towards your chest while simultaneously curling your hips off the ground. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your legs back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Side Jackknife
Desc: The Side Jackknife is a dynamic core exercise that targets the obliques. To perform this exercise, lie on your side with your legs extended and stacked on top of each other. Raise your legs and upper body simultaneously, bringing your elbow towards your knees. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: To perform the Side Jackknife, lie on your side with your legs extended and stacked on top of each other. Place one hand behind your head for support. Engage your core and raise your legs and upper body simultaneously, bringing your elbow towards your knees. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch sides.

Title: Scissor Kick
Desc: The Scissor Kick is an effective exercise for strengthening the lower abdominal muscles. To perform this exercise, lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate crossing them over each other in a scissor-like motion while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: To perform the Scissor Kick, lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches while keeping your core engaged. Alternate crossing your legs over each other in a scissor-like motion, ensuring to keep your lower back pressed into the ground. Continue for the desired duration or number of repetitions.

Title: Toe Touchers
Desc: The toe-touch is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the Toe Touchers, lie on your back with your legs extended towards the ceiling. Reach your arms towards your toes, lifting your shoulder blades off the ground. Engage your core and aim to touch your toes with your fingers. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lower Back Curl
Desc: The Lower Back Curl is an exercise designed to strengthen the lower back and improve spinal stability. To perform this exercise, lie face down on a mat with your arms extended in front of you. Lift your chest and legs off the ground simultaneously while keeping your neck neutral. Hold for a moment before lowering back down.
HowTo: To perform the Lower Back Curl, lie face down on a mat with your arms extended in front of you. Engage your core and lift your chest and legs off the ground simultaneously while keeping your neck neutral. Hold this position for a moment, then lower back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise ball torso rotation
Desc: The exercise ball torso rotation is a rotational abdominal exercise performed while holding a yoga or exercise ball between the hands. It focuses on the rotational muscles of the core, including the obliques, glutes, and hip muscles. It can be performed one side at a time or alternating, either for time or reps. To make it more difficult, wrap a light exercise band around the ball and anchor it to a solid object.
HowTo: To perform the exercise ball torso rotation, sit on a mat while holding a yoga or exercise ball between your hands. Lean back slightly and engage your core. Rotate your torso to one side, bringing the ball with you, then return to the center and rotate to the other side. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions or duration.

Title: Seated Overhead Stretch
Desc: Sit on a mat with your back straight. Raise both arms overhead, reaching for the ceiling. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your shoulders and upper back.
HowTo: Sit on a mat with your back straight. Raise both arms overhead, reaching for the ceiling. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your shoulders and upper back.

Title: Overhead Stretch
Desc: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise both arms overhead and lean to one side, feeling the stretch along your side. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise both arms overhead and lean to one side, feeling the stretch along your side. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.

Title: Seated Scissor Kick
Desc: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs off the ground while keeping them straight, and alternate crossing them over each other in a scissor motion. Perform for 30 seconds.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs off the ground while keeping them straight, and alternate crossing them over each other in a scissor motion. Perform for 30 seconds.

Title: Partner resistance standing twist
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your shoulders off the ground and bring one elbow towards the opposite knee, alternating sides in a twisting motion.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your shoulders off the ground and bring one elbow towards the opposite knee, alternating sides in a twisting motion.

Title: Cross Crunch
Desc: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Lift your arms and legs simultaneously towards the ceiling, creating a 'full moon' shape with your body. Hold for a few seconds and lower.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Lift your arms and legs simultaneously towards the ceiling, creating a 'full moon' shape with your body. Hold for a few seconds and lower.

Title: Full Moon
Desc: Lie on your back with your legs straight. Lift both legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the floor. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs straight. Lift both legs towards the ceiling while keeping them straight, then lower them back down without touching the floor. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.

Title: Hanging knee raise with manual resistance
Desc: The hanging knee raise with manual resistance is a more advanced version of the hanging knee raise that utilizes a partner. The partner applies enough resistance to make the movement more difficult, while still allowing the lifter to perform multiple reps.
HowTo: Hang from a bar with your arms extended. With your partner providing manual resistance, lift your knees towards your chest while engaging your core. Lower back down and repeat for multiple reps.

Title: Straight-Legged Hip Raise
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Raise your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top, then lower back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.

Title: Wall mountain climber
Desc: A challenging exercise that combines flexibility and strength, where the individual hangs from a bar and rotates their body through the arms before transitioning into a push-up position.
HowTo: Start in a hanging position from a bar. Engage your core and pull your knees towards your chest while rotating your body through your arms. Transition into a push-up position by extending your legs back and lowering your body into a push-up.

Title: Skin The Cat To Push-Up
Desc: An advanced bodyweight exercise that involves hanging from a bar, tucking the knees to the chest, and then extending the body into a push-up position, enhancing upper body strength and core stability.
HowTo: Begin by hanging from a bar. Tuck your knees to your chest, then extend your legs back out while maintaining a strong core. Transition into a push-up position by pushing your body down and back up.

Title: Partner lying leg raise with lateral throw down
Desc: The partner lying leg raise with lateral throw down is a core exercise in which one partner performs a leg raise while the other partner pushes their legs back down at a lateral angle. The partner performing the exercise has to use core strength and stability to keep their legs from falling to the ground.
HowTo: One partner lies on their back and raises their legs towards the ceiling while the other partner stands or kneels beside them. The standing partner pushes the raised legs down at a lateral angle while the lying partner uses their core to resist and maintain control.

Title: Hanging leg raise with throw down
Desc: The hanging leg raise with throw down is a more advanced version of the hanging knee raise that utilizes a partner to make the movement more difficult. The partner pushes down at the top of each rep, forcing the lifter to "fight back" with their abs.
HowTo: Hang from a bar and lift your legs towards your chest. At the top of the movement, have your partner push your legs down while you engage your core to resist the downward force and bring your legs back up.

Title: Partner sit-up with high-five
Desc: The partner sit-up with high-five is a full-body exercise targeting the core. Partners each perform a sit-up and high-five each other mid rep.
HowTo: Both partners lie on their backs with their knees bent. As they perform a sit-up, they reach towards each other and high-five at the top of the movement before lowering back down.

Title: Exercise ball knee roll-in
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring a fair amount of core strength.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands on an exercise ball. Engage your core and roll the ball towards your chest by drawing your knees in, then extend your legs back out to the starting position.

Title: Partner lying leg raise with throw down
Desc: The partner lying leg raise with throw down is a core exercise in which one partner performs a leg raise while the other partner pushes their legs back down. The partner performing the exercise has to use core strength and stability to keep their legs from falling to the ground.
HowTo: One partner lies on their back and raises their legs towards the ceiling while the other partner stands beside them. The standing partner pushes the raised legs down, and the lying partner must use their core strength to keep their legs from falling.

Title: Crab toe-touch
Desc: The crab toe-touch is a full-body exercise targeting the glutes, hamstrings, quads, and core. It is a challenging move that trains balance, core strength, and many muscle groups, making it work well in a time-efficient bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: Start in a crab position with your hands and feet on the ground, hips lifted. Reach one hand to touch the opposite foot while balancing on the other hand and foot. Alternate sides to complete the exercise.

Title: Side kick-through
Desc: The side kick-through is a full-body movement that involves isometric holds and moving the body through different ranges of motion, beginning in a bear crawl position. The difference between a side kick-through and a sit-through is that your butt stays off the ground throughout the entire rep. It is commonly performed in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work for reps on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your right leg and kick it through to the left side, extending it while keeping your butt off the ground. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Partner target sit-up
Desc: The partner target sit-up is a core exercise where one partner performs sit-ups, while the other uses his or her hands to create a target for them to reach for. This increases the challenge of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: One partner lies on their back and performs a sit-up, while the other partner stands or kneels at their feet, holding their hands out as a target. The sit-up partner reaches for the target with each repetition.

Title: Suspended Crunch
Desc: The Suspended Crunch is an advanced abdominal exercise that targets the core muscles. It involves hanging from a bar or suspension straps while performing a crunch motion, engaging the abs and stabilizing muscles.
HowTo: Hang from a bar or suspension straps with your arms extended. Engage your core and perform a crunch by bringing your knees towards your chest while keeping your upper body stable.

Title: Jump Lunge
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward. Jump explosively, switching your legs in mid-air, and land in a lunge position with the opposite leg forward. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Side plank hip dip
Desc: The side plank hip dip is a dynamic version of the side plank exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It can be performed for time or reps and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Begin in a side plank position with your elbow directly under your shoulder. Lower your hip towards the ground, then lift it back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Elbow plank jack
Desc: The elbow plank jack is an isometric abdominal exercise with a dynamic lower-body component. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Start in an elbow plank position with your body in a straight line. Jump your feet out wide and then back together while maintaining the plank position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Exercise ball V-up
Desc: The exercise ball V-up is a popular movement to target the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It involves passing an exercise ball or yoga ball back and forth between the hands and feet while performing V-ups. It can be performed for reps or time as part of any ab-focused workout or bodyweight circuit.
HowTo: Lie on your back holding an exercise ball between your feet. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously to perform a V-up, passing the ball from your feet to your hands at the top of the movement. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Standing torso twist stretch
Desc: The standing torso twist stretch is a stretching exercise targeting the lats and core, particularly the obliques. It’s great before a workout or any sporting event that involves a lot of twisting of the upper body.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Twist your torso to the right, reaching your arms out to the sides, then twist to the left. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Slalom jumps
Desc: The slalom jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Performed for reps, it also provides a serious cardiovascular challenge. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with feet hip-width apart. Bend your knees and jump laterally to one side, landing softly on the balls of your feet. Immediately jump to the other side, repeating for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Bear crawl
Desc: The bear crawl is a popular bodyweight crawling exercise. While it looks simple, the bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a quadruped position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Lift your knees off the ground and crawl forward, moving opposite hand and foot together. Keep your back flat and core engaged. Continue crawling for the desired distance or time.

Title: Crab single-arm reach
Desc: The crab single-arm reach is a full-body exercise that requires maintaining a tabletop position while alternating arm raises. It is an excellent movement to include in a dynamic warm-up, a bodyweight circuit, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: Begin in a tabletop position with hands and feet on the ground. Keep your hips lifted and back flat. Raise one arm straight up towards the ceiling while maintaining balance. Alternate arms for the desired number of reps.

Title: Side lunge cross-body heel-touch
Desc: The side lunge cross-body heel-touch is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The heel-touch adds a slight rotational challenge.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Step to the side with one leg into a lunge position, bending the knee while keeping the other leg straight. As you lunge, reach down to touch the heel of the extended leg with the opposite hand. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alligator Crawl
Desc: The spider crawl is a bodyweight exercise that involves crawling on the floor with the knees outside of the elbows. It is different from a leopard crawl in that the hips are higher, and it's different from a bear crawl because the knees are wider. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a quadruped position with knees wider than shoulders. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and crawl forward, keeping your hips elevated. Move your right hand and left foot forward, then switch to the left hand and right foot. Continue crawling for the desired distance or time.

Title: Lying cross-over lower back stretch
Desc: The lying cross-over lower back stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and torso. It involves rotating the legs while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with arms extended out to the sides. Bend your knees and rotate them to one side, keeping your shoulders flat on the ground. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch to the other side.

Title: Half bird dog
Desc: The half bird dog is a core exercise designed to strengthen the posterior chain. In the half bird dog, you will raise one arm or one leg at a time, rather than both at once as you would for a regular bird dog.
HowTo: Start on all fours in a tabletop position. Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg backward, keeping your hips level. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Shoulder tap
Desc: The shoulder tap is an exercise targeting the abdominals and core. The basic stance matches the top of a push-up position. From there, one hand is raised to tap its opposing shoulder. A tap with each hand to each opposing shoulder equals one rep.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with hands under shoulders. Keeping your core tight, lift one hand and tap the opposite shoulder. Return the hand to the ground and repeat with the other hand. Alternate sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Double crunch
Desc: The double crunch is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It's a very simple exercise that involves "crunching" the knees and elbows toward each other using the abdominal muscles, while keeping the back flat against the ground.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Place your hands behind your head. Simultaneously lift your knees towards your chest while curling your upper body off the ground, bringing your elbows towards your knees. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Flutter kick
Desc: The flutter kick is a core exercise where the legs are held off the ground as you flutter your feet over and under each other in small motions. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended and your arms at your sides. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged. Continue for a set amount of time or repetitions.

Title: Sprawl
Desc: The sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but without a jump at the top and with a plank instead of a push-up at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, then drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a plank position. From the plank, jump your feet back towards your hands and stand up. Repeat for time or reps.

Title: Spider plank jack
Desc: The spider plank jack is a bodyweight core exercise that begins in a straight-arm plank, then combines a spider crunch and a plank jack into a single sequence. It can be performed as bodyweight core training or for conditioning in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit.
HowTo: Begin in a straight-arm plank position. Bring your right knee towards your right elbow (spider crunch) while simultaneously jumping your feet out to the sides (plank jack). Return to the starting plank position and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: Pillar-To-Plank
Desc: Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line. Engage your core and hold this position, then transition to a side plank by rotating your body to one side, stacking your feet. Hold for a few seconds before returning to the plank position and repeating on the other side.
HowTo: Start in a forearm plank position with your body in a straight line. Engage your core and hold this position. Rotate your body to one side to transition into a side plank, stacking your feet. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the forearm plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: Alternating High Knee Raise
Desc: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Lift your right knee towards your chest while simultaneously raising your left arm. Lower your right leg and left arm, then repeat on the opposite side. Continue alternating sides at a quick pace to elevate your heart rate.
HowTo: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Lift your right knee towards your chest while simultaneously raising your left arm overhead. Lower your right leg and left arm, then switch and lift your left knee and right arm. Continue alternating sides quickly.

Title: Sumo Squat Pulse
Desc: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and lower into a squat. While in the squat position, pulse up and down slightly for a set number of repetitions before standing back up. Focus on keeping your chest up and your knees behind your toes.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body into a squat position, keeping your chest up. While in the squat, pulse up and down slightly for a set number of repetitions before standing back up.

Title: Line-Drill Foot Work
Desc: Set up a series of cones or markers in a straight line. Start at one end and quickly move laterally from side to side, touching each marker with your foot. Focus on quick footwork and maintaining balance as you navigate through the drill.
HowTo: Set up a series of cones or markers in a straight line. Start at one end and quickly move laterally from side to side, touching each marker with your foot. Focus on maintaining balance and quick footwork as you navigate through the drill.

Title: Plank Fire Hydrants
Desc: The Plank Fire Hydrant is an exercise that targets the core, glutes, and hips. Begin in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Keeping your core engaged, lift one leg out to the side while maintaining a stable upper body. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. This exercise helps improve stability and strength in the lower body.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Engage your core and lift one leg out to the side while keeping your upper body stable. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Banded jumping jack
Desc: The banded jumping jack takes a classic plyometric exercise and adds an extra degree of difficulty in the form of a band surrounding the thighs, just above the knees. It can be performed for time or reps and is a great way to warm up for athletics or lower-body lifting.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together and a resistance band around your thighs. Jump your feet out to the sides while raising your arms overhead, then jump back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Shin hug
Desc: The shin hug is a bodyweight exercise focused on the muscles of the core. It shares characteristics with V-ups and crunches, but finishes with the ribs touching the thighs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, bringing your knees towards your chest and hugging them with your arms. Finish with your ribs touching your thighs, then lower back down.

Title: FYR Bear Crawl Fire Feet
Desc: Bear crawl fire feet is a variation of the bear crawl that involves running in place while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and full-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands and feet on the ground. While maintaining this position, run in place by alternating lifting your knees towards your chest. Keep your core engaged and maintain a stable upper body.

Title: Bear crawl up-down
Desc: The bear crawl up-down is a variation of the bear crawl that involves lowering the forearms to the ground in an alternating rhythm while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and upper-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position. Lower one forearm to the ground, followed by the other, then raise one arm back up to the starting position, alternating sides. Maintain a steady rhythm while keeping your core engaged.

Title: FYR Crab Kick
Desc: The crab toe-touch is a full-body exercise targeting the glutes, hamstrings, quads, and core.
