HowTo: Sit in a crab position with your hands behind you and feet flat on the ground. Lift your hips off the ground and kick one leg out while reaching for your toes with the opposite hand. Alternate sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bear crawl hold
Desc: The bear crawl hold is a static variation of the bear crawl exercise performed for time. It looks simple, but it demands full-body tension and is taxing to the shoulders, core, and legs. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow, or as a build-up to the traditional bear crawl.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position and hold for time. Keep your knees off the ground and maintain tension in your core, shoulders, and legs. Focus on breathing and maintaining stability.

Title: Traveling bear crawl
Desc: The traveling bear crawl is a more advanced version of the bear crawl exercise that moves side to side rather than front to back. While it looks simple, the traveling bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position. Move laterally by shifting your weight from one hand and foot to the other, keeping your knees off the ground. Maintain a steady pace and engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: Single-leg V-up
Desc: The single-leg V-up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the abdominals and the hip flexors, working one side of the body at a time. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one leg extended and the other leg bent at the knee. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body and the bent leg simultaneously, reaching towards your toes with your hands. 3. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Bear Crawl Shoulder Tap
Desc: The bear crawl shoulder tap is a variation of the bear crawl that involves touching the opposing shoulder while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and core challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. While maintaining a stable core, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. 3. Alternate sides, tapping each shoulder while keeping your hips as stable as possible. 4. Continue for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Alternating single-leg sprawl
Desc: The alternating single-leg sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It differs from a standard sprawl by including a single-leg plank instead of a regular plank at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop into a sprawl by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back into a single-leg plank position. 3. From the plank, return to the standing position and switch legs. 4. Repeat the movement, alternating legs for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Wide mountain climber
Desc: The wide mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It is different from a traditional mountain climber because you bring the knee to the outside of the elbow rather than the inside. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring one knee towards the outside of the corresponding elbow while keeping your core tight. 3. Return the leg back to the starting position and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Plank leg raise
Desc: The plank leg raise is an isometric abdominal exercise that targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It also targets the muscles of the glutes and hips. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your body in a straight line. 2. Keeping your core engaged, lift one leg towards the ceiling. 3. Lower the leg back down without touching the ground and repeat with the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Glute bridge step-out
Desc: The glute bridge step-out is a lower-body bodyweight exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It differs from a glute bridge by the addition of a step-out, which increases stress on the hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps and works perfectly in a dynamic warm-up for lower-body training, but can also be performed for glute activation anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a glute bridge position with your back on the ground and feet flat on the floor. 2. Lift your hips into a bridge position. 3. From this position, step one foot out to the side and then back to the starting position. 4. Alternate sides for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Knee up-down
Desc: The knee up-down is a bodyweight exercise that mimics getting up and down from a kneeling position on the floor. It combines the low position of a squat with lunges, bringing some of the benefits of both. It can be done for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or as part of a bodyweight circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a kneeling position. 2. Shift your weight to one leg and stand up, bringing the other knee up. 3. Lower back down to the kneeling position and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Sprawl
Desc: The sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the core, upper body, and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but without a jump at the top and with a plank instead of a push-up at the bottom. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position. 2. Drop down into a sprawl by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back into a plank position. 3. From the plank, quickly return to the standing position without jumping. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Reach crunch
Desc: The reach crunch is a bodyweight core exercise that involves keeping the arms raised toward the ceiling while performing a crunch. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: To perform the reach crunch, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Raise your arms straight up toward the ceiling. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground while reaching your arms forward, as if trying to touch your toes. Hold for a moment, then lower back down. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Push-Up Plank Hold
Desc: The straight-arm plank is an exercise targeting the core muscles. It is basically the top of a push-up position, with elbows fully extended and palms on the floor. The position is held for time to target the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders.
HowTo: To perform the FYR Push-Up Plank Hold, start in a push-up position with your arms straight and your body in a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and hold this position for the desired amount of time, keeping your shoulders directly above your wrists and avoiding sagging or arching your back.

Title: FYR Hollow-Body Rock
Desc: The hollow-body rock is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It starts with a hollow-body hold and adds a back-and-forth rock that challenges core stability and increases the difficulty of the movement. It can be performed for time or for reps, either in an ab-focused portion of a workout or as part of a circuit workout.
HowTo: To perform the FYR Hollow-Body Rock, begin by lying on your back and creating a hollow-body hold by lifting your legs and shoulders off the ground. Keep your lower back pressed into the floor. From this position, gently rock back and forth while maintaining the hollow shape. Perform for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: V-up plus knee-to-chest combo
Desc: The V-up plus knee-to-chest combo is a core exercise that targets the abdominals and hip flexors by combining two movements into a single sequence. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the V-up plus knee-to-chest combo, lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body to form a 'V' shape, reaching your hands toward your toes. Then, lower your legs and upper body slightly and pull your knees toward your chest, curling your torso. Repeat this sequence for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Side plank lateral raise
Desc: The side plank lateral raise is an exercise that combines an isometric side plank hold with a dumbbell raise to target both the core and the shoulders. You probably won't be able to use much weight without disrupting your balance, but even at light weight, this is a movement that can help address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient workout.
HowTo: To perform the side plank lateral raise, start in a side plank position with your body in a straight line and your elbow directly under your shoulder. Hold a dumbbell in your top hand and raise it straight up toward the ceiling while maintaining the side plank. Lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time, then switch sides.

Title: Superhero burpee
Desc: The superhero burpee is an advanced variation of the burpee exercise. The main difference between this and the standard burpee is that while on the floor, the hands are extended in front of the body like Superman taking flight. This increases the challenge to the upper back and shoulders. These can be performed for time or reps as part of any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout or circuit.
HowTo: To perform the superhero burpee, start standing and drop into a squat position, placing your hands on the floor. Jump your feet back into a plank position. From here, extend your arms forward like Superman. Jump your feet back to your hands and explosively jump up, reaching your arms overhead. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Hollow-body abduction
Desc: The hollow-body abduction is an isometric core exercise that includes leg abductions for an added challenge to the core and abductors. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the hollow-body abduction, start in a hollow-body hold position with your back flat on the ground, legs straight, and arms overhead. While maintaining this position, lift your legs slightly off the ground and spread them apart into an abduction. Bring your legs back together and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Hollow Hold
Desc: The FYR Hollow Hold is an isometric core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. To perform this exercise, lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and your legs straight. Lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, creating a 'hollow' position with your body. Hold this position while keeping your lower back pressed into the floor.
HowTo: To perform the FYR Hollow Hold, lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, creating a 'hollow' position with your body. Keep your lower back pressed into the floor and hold this position for the desired amount of time.

Title: Tip-toe crunch
Desc: The tip-toe crunch is a variation on the crunch exercise that involves placing the toes on or near the ground. This can help isolate the abs from the hip flexors. The tip-toe crunch can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused component of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Place your toes on or near the ground, keeping your heels lifted. 3. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground, crunching towards your knees. 4. Hold the position briefly at the top, then lower back down. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Knee-to-nose pulse
Desc: The knee-to-nose pulse is a bodyweight exercise that targets the core by pulsing your knee toward your nose. It starts in a straight-arm plank position, and is similar to a mountain climber, but with a hold or pause in the bent-knee position.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a straight-arm plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Bring your right knee towards your nose, holding it in a bent position for a moment. 3. Return your right foot back to the plank position. 4. Repeat with the left knee. 5. Continue alternating knees for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Plank walk-out
Desc: The plank walk-out is an advanced plank variation targeting the core and shoulders. From a standing position, the lifter descends into a plank-type position but “walks” the hands forward until they are out in front of the head. This is far more challenging to the core than having the arms directly under the shoulders. Beginners will need to progress to this exercise.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and place your hands on the ground, walking them forward into a plank position. 3. Keep your core engaged and your body in a straight line from head to heels. 4. Walk your hands back towards your feet to return to standing. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR V-Up
Desc: The V-up is a bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It is similar to a suitcase crunch, but the lower back lifts off the ground at the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your arms and legs off the ground, forming a 'V' shape with your body. 3. Hold the position briefly at the top, then lower back down. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Long sit-up
Desc: The long sit-up is an advanced version of the sit-up exercise that is performed with the hands reaching over the head. This lengthens the torso, making it harder for the abs to contract and lift the upper body. Long sit-ups can be performed for time or for reps, with the feet anchored or free.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees while keeping your arms extended. 3. Lower back down slowly, maintaining control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Breakdancer
Desc: The side kick-through is a full-body movement that involves isometric holds and moving the body through different ranges of motion, beginning in a bear crawl position. The difference between a side kick-through and a sit-through is that your butt stays off the ground throughout the entire rep. It is commonly performed in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work for reps on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift your right leg and kick it through to the side while rotating your torso. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the left side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated leg lift
Desc: The seated leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core and hip flexors. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Lean back slightly while keeping your back straight. 3. Lift both legs off the ground, engaging your core. 4. Hold the position for the desired amount of time or perform for reps.

Title: Gorilla burpee
Desc: The gorilla burpee is a variation of the burpee exercise that consists of a reverse lunge on each leg, a full squat, then a standard burpee. It is extra challenging for the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Start standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step back into a reverse lunge with your right leg, then return to a full squat position. 3. From the squat, place your hands on the ground and kick your feet back into a plank position. 4. Perform a push-up if desired, then jump your feet back towards your hands. 5. Stand up and repeat the sequence for the desired number of reps.

Title: Knee-in to V-out
Desc: The knee-in to V-out is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to both the reverse crunch and the V-up exercise, but combines elements of both. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
HowTo: Start in a lying position with your back on the floor and your knees bent. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground. Bring your knees towards your chest while simultaneously extending your legs out to form a 'V' shape. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Bear crawl push-up
Desc: The bear crawl push-up is a variation of the bear crawl hold with a push-up added. It adds an extra coordination and shoulder challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lower your body into a push-up, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push back up to the starting position and then move forward a few steps in the bear crawl position. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Front Step
Desc: The FYR Front Step is a dynamic exercise that targets the lower body, improving strength and stability. It involves stepping forward with one leg while maintaining balance and control, making it ideal for enhancing functional movement patterns.
HowTo: Stand tall and step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Keep your back straight and your core engaged. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position and alternate legs for the desired number of reps.

Title: Plank reach
Desc: The plank reach is an exercise targeting the entire core, particularly the oblique muscles. It resembles a plank exercise, but the primary difference is that the lifter extends their arms forward, one at time. The core, especially the obliques, must work hard to maintain stability. It can be performed for time, with holds in the reaching position, or for reps.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your arms straight and body in a straight line. Reach forward with one arm while maintaining stability in your core and hips. Alternate arms, reaching forward one at a time, for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Eiffel Tower leg raise
Desc: The Eiffel Tower leg raise is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It is similar to a V-up, but with the added challenge of “drawing” a pyramid shape in the air with the legs during each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs off the ground and raise your torso, reaching your arms towards your feet to form a 'V' shape. As you lift, draw your legs apart to create a pyramid shape in the air. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Straight-arm plank
Desc: The straight-arm plank is an exercise targeting the core muscles. It is basically the top of a push-up position, with elbows fully extended and palms on the floor. The position is held for time to target the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your arms straight and body in a straight line. Engage your core and hold this position for the desired amount of time, keeping your body rigid and avoiding sagging or arching.

Title: Plank up-down
Desc: The plank up-down is a variation of the plank push-up that ends in an elbow plank rather than with the chest on the ground. It involves transitioning between the two positions one arm at a time, rather than two. It puts more stress on the triceps and core than traditional planks. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position on your hands. Lower one arm to your elbow to transition into an elbow plank, then push back up to the starting position one arm at a time. Alternate arms for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Frog kick
Desc: The frog kick is an explosive bodyweight movement that involves hopping the rear legs up and forward from a straight-arm plank position. It targets the legs, core, and shoulders, but is also a high-intensity conditioning movement that will raise core body temperature and burn serious calories. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any athleticism-focused or fat-loss circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position. Jump your feet forward towards your hands while keeping your arms straight, then jump back to the plank position. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: FYR Knees to Chest
Desc: The hollow-body alternating knee-to-chest is a core exercise that involves bending the legs while holding the hips and shoulder blades off the ground. It targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Start in a hollow-body position with your hips and shoulder blades off the ground. Bend one knee and bring it towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. Alternate legs in a controlled manner, focusing on engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: Front kick-through
Desc: The front kick-through is a full-body movement that involves moving the legs from a bear crawl position to a balanced one-legged stance. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Kick one leg through to the side while rotating your torso, landing on one foot in a balanced position. Return to the bear crawl position and repeat on the other side.

Title: FYR Sit-Up
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down. You can anchor your feet or keep them free for variation.

Title: FYR Leg Lift
Desc: The seated leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core and hip flexors. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. Lean back slightly while keeping your back straight. Lift both legs off the ground, engaging your core, and hold the position for time or perform for reps.

Title: TBS Toes-to-bar
Desc: The hanging toes-to-bar is an advanced abdominal exercise in which the lifter touches their feet to a pull-up bar. There are many ways to perform this movement: strict or swinging, arms completely straight or slightly bent, legs straight or bent, each providing unique benefits and challenges. Initially, it may be a difficult move to do for a single rep, but once you build the requisite core, lat, and shoulder strength, it can be performed for higher reps.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Engage your core and lift your legs towards the bar, aiming to touch your toes to it. Lower your legs back down with control and repeat for desired reps.

Title: FYR Mountain Climber
Desc: The mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It involves lifting one knee to the chest at a time from a straight-arm plank position. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position. Drive one knee towards your chest, then return it to the starting position. Alternate legs rapidly while maintaining a strong plank position.

Title: Roman Chair Side Ups
Desc: The Roman Chair Side Ups target the oblique muscles and help improve core stability. To perform this exercise, position yourself on a Roman chair with your body supported and your legs hanging off the edge. Engage your core and lift one side of your body towards your hip, then lower back down. Alternate sides for a complete set.
HowTo: Sit on a Roman chair with your back supported and legs hanging off the edge. Engage your core and lift one side of your body towards your hip, then lower back down. Alternate sides for a complete set.

Title: Push-Up Roll Out - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Push-Up Roll Out - Gethin Variation combines the traditional push-up with a roll-out to engage the core and upper body. Start in a push-up position with a stability ball or roller in front of you. As you lower into the push-up, roll the ball or roller forward, extending your body. Push back to the starting position while rolling the ball back towards you. This exercise enhances strength and stability.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with a stability ball or roller in front of you. Lower into a push-up while rolling the ball forward. Push back to the starting position while rolling the ball back towards you, engaging your core throughout.

Title: Cross-Body Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cross-body sit-up is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing the opposite-side knee and elbow together, usually alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. 3. Alternate sides, bringing your left elbow towards your right knee while extending your left leg. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Decline leg lift with twist
Desc: The decline leg lift with twist is a bodyweight core exercise targeting the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particularly the lower abs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused portion of any workout or circuit.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your legs hanging off the end. 2. Lift your legs towards your chest while twisting your hips to bring your knees towards your right elbow. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat, twisting towards your left elbow. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Hanging Leg Raise - Variation Gethin
Desc: The hanging leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs and hip flexors. Instead of resting the forearms on the pads of apparatus, hang from a bar. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs towards your chest while keeping them straight. 3. Lower your legs back down without swinging. 4. Perform for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Butterfly crunch
Desc: The butterfly crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise that targets the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles. It gets its name from the position of the elbows and knees, both of which are bent out like wings. It can be performed for time or reps as part of any abs-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with the soles of your feet together and knees bent out to the sides. 2. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. 3. Curl your upper body towards your knees, engaging your abs. 4. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Cross-body mountain climber
Desc: The cross-body mountain climber is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the core, as well as the shoulders, hips, and cardiovascular system. It is different from a traditional mountain climber because you bring the knee to the opposite side of the body rather than simply to the chest. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, for bodyweight cardio or conditioning, or as no-equipment dynamic core training.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Shoulders, Hip Flexors
HowTo: 1. Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Quickly bring your right knee towards your left elbow, twisting your torso. 3. Return to the plank position and switch legs, bringing your left knee towards your right elbow. 4. Continue alternating for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Flat Bench Lying Leg Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back on a bench with your legs hanging off the end. 2. Keep your legs straight and lift them towards the ceiling while engaging your core. 3. Lower your legs back down without touching the bench. 4. Perform for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Lying leg lift
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your legs straight. 2. Keep your hands under your glutes for support. 3. Lift your legs towards the ceiling while engaging your abs. 4. Lower your legs back down without touching the ground. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Hanging alternating single-leg raise
Desc: The hanging alternating single-leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs, but which also works the lats and hip flexors. Rather than performing both legs at a time, you lift one and alternate with each rep. Leg raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training. However, this difficult variation may require some time to build up to those rep ranges.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift one leg towards your chest while keeping the other leg hanging. 3. Lower the raised leg back down and switch to the other leg. 4. Continue alternating legs for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Plank Walk
Desc: The Plank Walk is a core-strengthening exercise that involves transitioning between a plank position and a walking motion. It engages multiple muscle groups, including the abs, shoulders, and legs, while improving stability and endurance.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and glutes. Step your right hand out to the side, followed by your left hand, moving into a high plank position. Then, step your right hand back to the starting position, followed by your left hand. Repeat this movement, alternating sides.

Title: Sit-Up - Gethin Variation
Desc: The sit-up is a popular bodyweight exercise focused on the abdominal muscles. It has also been used as part of military, tactical, and scholastic fitness tests for many years. It can be performed for time or reps, with the feet anchored or free, on flat ground or a bench.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, exhaling as you rise. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Plank Push-Up
Desc: The plank up-down is a variation of the plank push-up that ends in an elbow plank rather than with the chest on the ground. It involves transitioning between the two positions one arm at a time, rather than two. It puts more stress on the triceps and core than traditional planks. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Start in a high plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Lower your body down to your elbows one arm at a time, maintaining a straight line from head to heels. Then, push back up to the high plank position one arm at a time. Repeat this movement for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Decline crunch-
Desc: The decline crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particular the upper abs. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. Place your hands behind your head or crossed over your chest. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, focusing on the contraction of your abs. Lower back down with control and repeat for 10-15 reps or more.

Title: Alternating lying leg raise
Desc: The alternating lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with your legs extended. Lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the other leg hovering just above the ground. Alternate lifting each leg, engaging your core throughout the movement. Perform for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Decline leg lift
Desc: The decline leg lift is a popular bodyweight core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, particularly the lower abs. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of the core-focused portion of any workout or circuit.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench with your legs extended and your feet secured. Engage your core and lift your legs towards the ceiling, keeping them straight. Slowly lower your legs back down without touching the ground. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The crunch is a popular core exercise targeting the rectus abdominis, or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques. It has been the centerpiece of many ab-focused workouts, due to both its simplicity and the intense burn and mind-muscle connection it produces. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head or across your chest. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, focusing on the contraction of your abs. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Plank - Gethin Variation
Desc: The elbow plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise. It is common in all types of exercise programs, as well as in group fitness and yoga classes. It targets the muscles of the core, the deep core or transversus abdominis in particular. It is also often prescribed for time to help back pain or to teach proper bracing.
HowTo: Start in an elbow plank position with your forearms on the ground and your body in a straight line from head to heels. Engage your core and hold the position for the desired amount of time, focusing on maintaining a straight line and proper form.

Title: Barbell floor wiper
Desc: The barbell floor wiper is a core exercise in which the barbell is held in the locked-out position of a floor press, and the hips and legs are rotated side to side. It targets the oblique muscles of the lateral abdomen, but is also seriously challenging to the deep core and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles.
HowTo: Lie on your back with the barbell held above your chest in a locked-out position. Rotate your hips and legs side to side, engaging your core and obliques throughout the movement.

Title: Prison Push-Up
Desc: The Prison Push-Up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It is performed by placing your hands behind your head, keeping your elbows wide, and lowering your body to the ground before pushing back up.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands behind your head and elbows wide. Lower your body towards the ground, keeping your elbows flared out, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: McGill Modified Curl-Up
Desc: The McGill Modified Curl-Up is an abdominal exercise designed to strengthen the core while minimizing stress on the lower back. It involves lying on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight, and lifting your head and shoulders off the ground while keeping your lower back pressed down.
HowTo: Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight. Keep your lower back pressed into the ground as you lift your head and shoulders off the floor, engaging your core.

Title: Cross-body toe-touch
Desc: The cross-body toe-touch is a version of the toe-touch stretch where instead of both hands reaching down toward both feet, one hand at a time reaches for the opposing foot. It's a common component in dynamic warm-ups for training or sports, but can also be performed for simple flexibility work anytime.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at the waist and reach one hand towards the opposite foot, alternating sides to stretch your hamstrings and lower back.

Title: Toy soldier
Desc: The toy soldier is a calisthenics exercise targeting the hip flexors and legs, which are kicked up one at a time. When each leg is at the top of the kick, the opposing hand touches that foot. It's a common warm-up exercise before athletics, but can also help raise core temperature and mobilize a wide range of muscles and joints prior to training.
HowTo: Stand tall and kick one leg straight up in front of you while reaching the opposite hand to touch your foot. Alternate legs in a controlled manner, keeping your core engaged.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise with Stability Ball
Desc: The Natural Glute Ham Raise with Stability Ball is an exercise that targets the hamstrings and glutes. It involves kneeling on the ground with your feet anchored, rolling a stability ball away from your body while lowering your torso, and then using your hamstrings to pull yourself back up.
HowTo: Kneel on the ground with your feet anchored. Roll the stability ball away from your body while lowering your torso towards the ground, then use your hamstrings to pull yourself back up to the starting position.

Title: Lateral ape
Desc: The lateral ape is an exercise focused on the lower body that involves staying in a low squat position as you hop laterally. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, to improve hip mobility, or as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: Begin in a low squat position. Jump laterally to the side while maintaining your squat, landing softly and immediately jumping to the other side.

Title: Hollow-body knee tuck
Desc: The hollow-body knee tuck is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to both the hollow-body hold and the knee tuck or reverse crunch, combining elements of both. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Engage your core and simultaneously tuck your knees towards your chest while lifting your shoulders off the ground, then return to the starting position.

Title: HM Air Jumping Rope
Desc: The HM Air Jumping Rope exercise involves jumping over a rope repeatedly, which improves cardiovascular fitness, coordination, and agility.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together and hold the handles of the rope. Swing the rope over your head and jump over it as it comes down. Repeat this motion continuously.

Title: HM Alternating Lunge Reach
Desc: The HM Alternating Lunge Reach is a dynamic exercise that combines lunges with a reach to enhance flexibility, balance, and lower body strength.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward with one leg into a lunge while reaching your arms overhead. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Alternating Side Plank Reach
Desc: The HM Alternating Side Plank Reach targets the core and obliques, requiring you to hold a side plank while reaching your arm towards the ceiling.
HowTo: Begin in a side plank position with your body in a straight line. Reach your top arm towards the ceiling, then lower it to reach under your body before returning it to the starting position.

Title: HM Superman Plank
Desc: The HM Superman Plank is an exercise that engages the core, back, and glutes by holding a plank position while extending opposite arm and leg.
HowTo: Get into a plank position on your hands and toes. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back simultaneously, then return to the plank and switch sides.

Title: HM Table Pose
Desc: The HM Table Pose is a yoga-inspired position that strengthens the back and core while promoting stability and balance.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. Lift your hips to create a tabletop position with your body, keeping your shoulders over your wrists and your knees over your ankles.

Title: HM Toe Touch
Desc: The HM Toe Touch exercise involves reaching down to touch your toes, enhancing flexibility in the hamstrings and lower back.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Bend at the hips and reach down towards your toes, keeping your legs straight. Hold for a moment before returning to standing.

Title: HM Right Side Bird-Dog
Desc: The HM Right Side Bird-Dog is a stability exercise that engages the core, back, and glutes by extending opposite arm and leg while on all fours.
HowTo: Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Extend your right arm forward and your left leg back, keeping your hips level. Return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Right Side Crunch
Desc: The HM Right Side Crunch focuses on the oblique muscles, performed by lying on your side and lifting your torso towards your hips.
HowTo: Lie on your right side with your legs stacked. Place your right hand behind your head and lift your torso towards your hips, engaging your oblique muscles. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: HM Bicycle
Desc: The HM Bicycle is an exercise that targets the core muscles, particularly the abdominals. It involves lying on your back, lifting your legs, and simulating a cycling motion while engaging your core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs off the ground and simulate a cycling motion while engaging your core.

Title: HM Bird-Dog Plank
Desc: The HM Bird-Dog Plank is a stability exercise that engages the core, back, and glutes. It involves balancing on hands and knees while extending one arm and the opposite leg, then alternating sides.
HowTo: Start on hands and knees. Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg back, keeping your core engaged. Alternate sides.

Title: HM Boat Pose
Desc: The HM Boat Pose is a yoga pose that strengthens the core and improves balance. It involves sitting on the floor, lifting your legs, and holding your arms parallel to the ground while maintaining a straight back.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs lifted and bent at the knees. Extend your arms parallel to the ground and maintain a straight back.

Title: HM Bottoms Up
Desc: The HM Bottoms Up is an exercise that focuses on core stability and strength. It typically involves lying on your back and lifting your legs and hips off the ground while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Lift your legs and hips off the ground while keeping your core engaged.

Title: HM Bridge
Desc: The HM Bridge is a glute-strengthening exercise that also engages the core. It involves lying on your back with knees bent and feet flat on the floor, then lifting your hips towards the ceiling.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes.

Title: HM Running Man Crunch
Desc: The HM Running Man Crunch is a dynamic core exercise that combines a crunch with a running motion. It involves lying on your back and bringing your knees towards your chest while alternating lifting your shoulders off the ground.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent. Bring your knees towards your chest while alternating lifting your shoulders off the ground.

Title: HM Seated Twist
Desc: The HM Seated Twist is a stretching exercise that improves spinal mobility and engages the core. It involves sitting on the floor with legs extended and twisting the torso to one side while keeping the spine straight.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended. Twist your torso to one side while keeping your spine straight.

Title: HM Side-Bend Pose
Desc: The HM Side-Bend Pose is a yoga pose that stretches the sides of the body and improves flexibility. It involves standing or sitting and reaching one arm overhead while bending to the opposite side.
HowTo: Stand or sit with one arm overhead. Bend to the opposite side, stretching the side of your body.

Title: HM Side-Plank Arm Wrap
Desc: Start in a side plank position with your elbow directly under your shoulder. Wrap your top arm around your waist and then extend it back up towards the ceiling, engaging your core throughout.
HowTo: Start in a side plank position with your elbow directly under your shoulder. Wrap your top arm around your waist and then extend it back up towards the ceiling, engaging your core throughout.

Title: HM Side-Plank with Hip Touch
Desc: Begin in a side plank position. Reach your top arm down to touch your hip, then return it to the starting position while maintaining balance and engaging your core.
HowTo: Begin in a side plank position. Reach your top arm down to touch your hip, then return it to the starting position while maintaining balance and engaging your core.

Title: HM Side-Plank with Kick
Desc: Start in a side plank position. Lift your top leg and kick it forward, then return it to the starting position while keeping your body straight and core engaged.
HowTo: Start in a side plank position. Lift your top leg and kick it forward, then return it to the starting position while keeping your body straight and core engaged.

Title: HM Side V-Up
Desc: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, reaching for your toes while keeping your core tight.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended overhead. Lift your legs and upper body simultaneously, reaching for your toes while keeping your core tight.

Title: HM Crab Crunch
Desc: Sit with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lean back slightly and lift your feet off the ground, then crunch your torso towards your knees while engaging your core.
HowTo: Sit with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lean back slightly and lift your feet off the ground, then crunch your torso towards your knees while engaging your core.

Title: HM Cross-Over Crunch
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. Cross one shoulder towards the opposite knee while extending the other leg, alternating sides in a controlled manner.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. Cross one shoulder towards the opposite knee while extending the other leg, alternating sides in a controlled manner.

Title: HM Crunch Pulse
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. Lift your shoulders off the ground slightly and pulse up and down in small movements, engaging your core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. Lift your shoulders off the ground slightly and pulse up and down in small movements, engaging your core.

Title: HM Dead Bug
Desc: Lie on your back with your arms extended and legs raised. Lower one arm and the opposite leg towards the ground while keeping your back flat, then return to the starting position and switch sides.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Transverse Abdominis, Hip Flexors
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended and legs raised. Lower one arm and the opposite leg towards the ground while keeping your back flat, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Single-Leg Inchworm
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Inchworm is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and improves flexibility. Start in a standing position, hinge at the hips, and walk your hands forward into a plank position while keeping one leg raised. Then, walk your hands back to standing.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Hinge at the hips and walk your hands forward into a plank position while keeping one leg raised. Then, walk your hands back to standing.

Title: HM Floor Jack
Desc: The HM Floor Jack is a full-body exercise that combines a jumping jack with a plank. Begin in a standing position, jump out to the sides while lowering your body into a plank position, then jump back to standing.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Jump out to the sides while lowering your body into a plank position. Then, jump back to standing.

Title: HM Floor Wiper
Desc: The HM Floor Wiper is an ab exercise that targets the obliques. Lie on your back with your arms extended to the sides. Lift your legs to a 90-degree angle and lower them side to side, keeping your shoulders on the ground.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended to the sides. Lift your legs to a 90-degree angle and lower them side to side, keeping your shoulders on the ground.

Title: HM Floor Kick
Desc: The HM Floor Kick is a lower body exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. Start on all fours, extend one leg straight back, and then kick it up towards the ceiling while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Start on all fours. Extend one leg straight back and then kick it up towards the ceiling while keeping your core engaged.

Title: HM Sit-Up
Desc: The HM Sit-Up is a classic core exercise. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: HM Slow Mountain Climber
Desc: The HM Slow Mountain Climber is a core stability exercise. Start in a plank position and slowly bring one knee towards your chest, then return it to the starting position and alternate legs.
HowTo: Start in a plank position. Slowly bring one knee towards your chest, then return it to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: HM Slow Sit-Up
Desc: The HM Slow Sit-Up is a controlled version of the sit-up that emphasizes form. Lie on your back with knees bent, and slowly lift your torso towards your knees, focusing on engaging your core throughout the movement.
HowTo: Lie on your back with knees bent. Slowly lift your torso towards your knees, focusing on engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: HM Half-Up
Desc: The HM Half-Up is a core exercise that targets the upper abs. Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Lift your shoulders off the ground halfway and hold for a moment before lowering back down.
HowTo: Lie on your back with knees bent and feet flat. Lift your shoulders off the ground halfway and hold for a moment before lowering back down.

Title: HM Hollow-Body Pulse
Desc: The HM Hollow-Body Pulse is an exercise that engages the core while maintaining a hollow-body position. Perform this exercise by lying on your back, lifting your legs and shoulders off the ground, and pulsing your arms up and down to create tension in the core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs and shoulders lifted off the ground. Keep your arms extended and pulse them up and down to create tension in your core.

Title: HM Hollow Hold
Desc: The HM Hollow Hold is a core-strengthening exercise where you lie on your back and lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, holding the position to engage your abdominal muscles. Focus on keeping your lower back pressed into the floor.
HowTo: Lie on your back and lift your legs and shoulders off the ground. Hold this position, ensuring your lower back is pressed into the floor to engage your abdominal muscles.

Title: HM Inchworm
Desc: The HM Inchworm is a dynamic stretching and strengthening exercise that involves bending at the waist, walking your hands out to a plank position, and then walking your feet towards your hands. This movement warms up the entire body and engages the core.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, bend at the waist, and walk your hands out to a plank position. Then, walk your feet towards your hands and return to standing.

Title: HM Right Side Hollow Hold with Pulse
Desc: The HM Right Side Hollow Hold with Pulse is a variation of the hollow hold that targets the obliques. Lie on your back, lift your legs and shoulders, and pulse your arms while holding the position on your right side.
HowTo: Lie on your back, lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, and hold this position on your right side. Pulse your arms up and down while maintaining the hold.

Title: HM Reverse Crunch with Frisbee
Desc: The HM Reverse Crunch with Frisbee is an exercise that targets the lower abs. Lie on your back, hold a frisbee between your feet, and lift your hips off the ground while bringing your knees towards your chest.
HowTo: Lie on your back and hold a frisbee between your feet. Lift your hips off the ground while bringing your knees towards your chest.

Title: HM Left Side Bird-Dog
Desc: The HM Left Side Bird-Dog is a stability exercise that engages the core and improves balance. From a tabletop position, extend your left arm forward and your right leg back, keeping your body stable.
HowTo: Start in a tabletop position. Extend your left arm forward and your right leg back while keeping your core engaged and your body stable.

Title: HM Left Side Crunch
Desc: The HM Left Side Crunch is an abdominal exercise that targets the obliques. Lie on your back, bend your knees, and crunch to the left side, bringing your shoulder towards your hip.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent. Crunch to the left side, bringing your left shoulder towards your left hip.

Title: HM Left Side Hollow Hold With Pulse
Desc: The HM Left Side Hollow Hold With Pulse is a core exercise that combines the hollow hold with pulsing movements. Lie on your back, lift your legs and shoulders, and pulse your arms while maintaining the position on your left side.
HowTo: Lie on your back, lift your legs and shoulders off the ground, and pulse your arms while maintaining the hollow hold position on your left side.

Title: HM Reverse Crunch
Desc: The HM Reverse Crunch is an abdominal exercise that targets the lower abs. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your legs so your thighs are perpendicular to the floor and your knees are bent at a 90-degree angle. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground, curling your pelvis towards your belly button. Lower back down and repeat.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your legs so your thighs are perpendicular to the floor and your knees are bent at a 90-degree angle. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground, curling your pelvis towards your belly button. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: HM Low Lunge With External Twist And Arm Reach
Desc: The HM Low Lunge With External Twist And Arm Reach is a dynamic stretch that opens the hips and improves flexibility. Start in a low lunge position with your right foot forward and your left knee on the ground. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot and twist your torso to the right, reaching your right arm up towards the ceiling. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.
HowTo: Start in a low lunge position with your right foot forward and your left knee on the ground. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot and twist your torso to the right, reaching your right arm up towards the ceiling. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: HM Mountain Climber
Desc: The HM Mountain Climber is a full-body exercise that increases your heart rate while strengthening your core. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Quickly drive one knee towards your chest, then switch legs, bringing the opposite knee forward. Continue alternating legs at a rapid pace.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Quickly drive one knee towards your chest, then switch legs, bringing the opposite knee forward. Continue alternating legs at a rapid pace.

Title: HM Prison Sit-Up
Desc: The HM Prison Sit-Up is a core strengthening exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and your knees bent. Engage your core and sit up while keeping your hands behind your head, then lower back down with control. Avoid pulling on your neck.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your hands behind your head and your knees bent. Engage your core and sit up while keeping your hands behind your head, then lower back down with control. Avoid pulling on your neck.

Title: HM Plank Alternating Hip-Dip
Desc: The HM Plank Alternating Hip-Dip is an exercise that targets the core and obliques. Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground. Rotate your hips to one side, dipping them towards the floor, then return to the center and dip to the other side. Keep your body in a straight line throughout the movement.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your forearms on the ground. Rotate your hips to one side, dipping them towards the floor, then return to the center and dip to the other side. Keep your body in a straight line throughout the movement.

Title: HM Tuck-Up Get-Up
Desc: The HM Tuck-Up Get-Up is a challenging exercise that combines a tuck-up with a standing position. Start seated with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core, lean back slightly, and lift your feet off the ground, tucking your knees towards your chest. From this position, roll back and then use your momentum to stand up.
HowTo: Start seated with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core, lean back slightly, and lift your feet off the ground, tucking your knees towards your chest. From this position, roll back and then use your momentum to stand up.

Title: HM Flutter Kick
Desc: The HM Flutter Kick is an effective exercise for the lower abs and hip flexors. Lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged.

Title: HM Plank
Desc: The HM Plank is a fundamental core exercise that strengthens the entire body. Start in a push-up position with your arms straight and hands shoulder-width apart. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core and glutes. Hold this position for as long as possible while maintaining proper form.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your arms straight and hands shoulder-width apart. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core and glutes. Hold this position for as long as possible while maintaining proper form.

Title: McGill Pull-Up
Desc: The McGill Pull-Up is an upper body exercise that targets the back, shoulders, and arms. It involves pulling your body up towards a bar while maintaining proper form and engaging your core.
HowTo: 1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and pull your body up towards the bar, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Focus on using your back and shoulders to lift, rather than just your arms. 4. Pull until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down with control.

Title: AM Leg Lift
Desc: The captain's chair leg raise is an exercise that targets the abs and hip flexors. It involves an apparatus that allows the forearms to rest on pads and the upright torso to hang freely. Unlike the Captain’s chair knee raise, the legs are straight here.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the captain's chair with your forearms resting on the pads. 2. Keep your back against the backrest and your legs hanging straight down. 3. Engage your core and lift your legs straight up towards your chest, keeping them together. 4. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position without swinging.

Title: AM Decline Abs
Desc: The decline sit-up is a core exercise that works the iliopsoas, quads, hip flexors, and adductors. The rectus abdominis and obliques are the stabilizers in this movement.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Iliopsoas, Hip Flexors, Obliques, Quadriceps, Adductors
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and curl your torso up towards your knees. 4. Lower your torso back down in a controlled manner, keeping tension in your abs.

Title: Hanging crunch
Desc: The hanging crunch an abdominal exercise that targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed hanging from a bar, on a dip station or parallel bars, or if grip strength is a limitation, by placing the elbows in ab straps. If hanging from a straight bar is uncomfortable to the wrists or shoulders, you can also perform them hanging with a neutral grip (palms facing one another). It is similar to a hanging knee raise, but with more spinal curling and a more pronounced "crunch" at the top.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended and your grip shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and lift your knees towards your chest, curling your spine to create a crunch. 3. Focus on using your abdominal muscles to lift, rather than swinging your legs. 4. Lower your legs back down with control and repeat.

Title: Tyler Holt Hanging Toes-To-Bar
Desc: The Tyler Holt Hanging Toes-To-Bar is a dynamic core exercise that involves hanging from a pull-up bar and raising your legs to touch the bar with your toes. This movement engages the abdominal muscles and improves grip strength.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, arms fully extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs straight up towards the bar. 3. Aim to touch the bar with your toes while keeping your legs straight. 4. Lower your legs back down to the starting position with control.

Title: Side plank
Desc: The side plank is a popular isometric abdominal exercise focusing on the oblique muscles, as well as the transversus abdominis or deep core muscles. It is sometimes paired with the curl up and bird dog as the “McGill big three” for core strength and stability. It is performed for time and can work in a warm-up or in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your side with your legs straight and stacked on top of each other. 2. Prop yourself up on your forearm, ensuring your elbow is directly under your shoulder. 3. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground, forming a straight line from head to heels. 4. Hold this position for a set amount of time, then lower back down.

Title: Bird dog-
Desc: The bird dog is a core exercise designed to help strengthen and stabilize the posterior chain. It involves lifting an opposite-side arm and leg while in a bent-leg tabletop position. It is most commonly performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for mobility and muscle activation anytime.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees. 2. Engage your core and extend your right arm forward while simultaneously extending your left leg back. 3. Keep your hips level and your back straight. 4. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Single-leg curl up
Desc: The single-leg curl up is a bodyweight abdominal movement that teaches and reinforces abdominal “bracing” for strength training. It is usually performed along with variations of the bird dog and side plank as the “McGill big three.” The curl up can be performed for time or for reps, with or without pauses at the top position, as part of a warm-up or the core-focused component of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one knee bent and the other leg straight. 2. Place your hands behind your head or cross them over your chest. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards the bent knee, keeping the other leg straight on the ground. 4. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Single-kettlebell windmill
Desc: The single-kettlebell windmill is a dynamic kettlebell exercise emphasizing core strength and shoulder and hip mobility and stability. It is often used as a functional warm-up or for multi-directional strength work. It doesn't work as well in a metcon or conditioning setting, and shouldn't be performed under intense fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Press the kettlebell overhead with your arm fully extended. 3. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso towards the floor while keeping your eyes on the kettlebell. 4. Rotate your torso and reach down towards the floor with your free hand, maintaining a straight line from your extended arm to your opposite foot. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Thigh
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Thigh exercise involves using a foam roller to release tension in the thigh muscles, improving flexibility and reducing soreness.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Place the foam roller under your thighs. 3. Using your hands for support, lift your hips off the ground and roll the foam roller up and down your thighs. 4. Focus on areas of tightness or soreness, spending extra time on those spots. 5. Roll for 1-2 minutes on each thigh.

Title: UNS Inverted row
Desc: The UNS Inverted Row is a bodyweight exercise that targets the upper back, biceps, and core by pulling the body up towards a bar while lying underneath it.
HowTo: 1. Set a bar at waist height and lie underneath it. 2. Grab the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Keep your body straight and engage your core. 4. Pull your chest towards the bar by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UNS T-spine rotation with reach
Desc: The UNS T-spine rotation with reach focuses on improving thoracic spine mobility and shoulder flexibility by rotating the upper body while reaching with one arm.
HowTo: 1. Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Place one hand behind your head, keeping your elbow bent. 3. Rotate your upper body towards the ceiling, opening up your chest and extending your elbow. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: UNS Quadruped thoracic rotation
Desc: The UNS Quadruped thoracic rotation is an exercise that enhances spinal mobility and stability by rotating the upper body while in a quadruped position.
HowTo: 1. Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Place one hand behind your head. 3. Rotate your upper body towards the ceiling while keeping your hips stable. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: UNS Pec stretch
Desc: The UNS Pec stretch is designed to stretch the pectoral muscles, promoting better posture and shoulder mobility.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a doorway or next to a wall. 2. Place your forearm against the wall or door frame at a 90-degree angle. 3. Step forward with one foot, feeling a stretch in your chest and shoulder. 4. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, then switch arms.

Title: UNS Lat stretch
Desc: The UNS Lat stretch targets the latissimus dorsi muscles, helping to improve flexibility and range of motion in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Reach both arms overhead, clasping your hands together. 3. Lean to one side, feeling a stretch along the side of your body. 4. Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch to the other side.

Title: UNS Foam Roll
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll exercise is a self-myofascial release technique that helps alleviate muscle tightness and improve blood flow.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Place the foam roller under your back. 3. Use your legs and arms to roll the foam roller up and down your back, focusing on tight areas. 4. Roll for 1-2 minutes, adjusting your position to target different muscle groups.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Lats
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Lats exercise involves using a foam roller to target the latissimus dorsi muscles. Lie on your side with the foam roller under your armpit, and gently roll back and forth to release tension.
HowTo: Lie on your side with the foam roller positioned under your armpit. Gently roll back and forth to release tension in the latissimus dorsi muscles.

Title: UNS Rocking Adductor Stretch
Desc: The UNS Rocking Adductor Stretch is a dynamic stretch that targets the inner thigh muscles. Start in a kneeling position, then shift your weight side to side while keeping your hips low to stretch the adductors.
HowTo: Begin in a kneeling position with your hips low. Shift your weight from side to side to stretch the inner thigh muscles.

Title: UNS Bird Dog
Desc: The UNS Bird Dog exercise is a core stability move that involves extending one arm and the opposite leg while on all fours. This helps improve balance and strengthen the back and core.
HowTo: Start on all fours, then extend one arm forward and the opposite leg back. Hold for a moment, then switch sides to improve balance and strengthen your core.

Title: UNS Jumping Jack
Desc: The UNS Jumping Jack is a full-body exercise that involves jumping while spreading your legs and arms out to the sides, then returning to a standing position. It's great for cardiovascular fitness and coordination.
HowTo: Stand upright, then jump while spreading your legs and arms out to the sides. Return to the starting position and repeat for a set number of repetitions.

Title: Ab wheel roll-out
Desc: The ab wheel roll-out is an exercise targeting the abdominals using an inexpensive wheel device with a handle on either side. Many trainers and strength coaches claim it's one of the best exercises for developing strength in the midsection. Beginners may have to start with a limited range of motion or just wheel planks.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor and grip the ab wheel handles. Roll the wheel forward, extending your body while keeping your core engaged. Roll back to the starting position. Beginners may start with a limited range of motion.

Title: Bench mountain climber
Desc: The bench mountain climber is a bodyweight exercise that works the core, shoulders, and lower body while burning a lot of calories. Placing the hands on an elevated surface such as a bench decreases the challenge to the shoulders, allowing lifters to focus their work on the other body parts. Mountain climber variations are usually performed at a fast pace for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg or more.
HowTo: Place your hands on a bench and assume a plank position. Quickly bring one knee towards your chest, then switch legs in a running motion. Perform for a set number of repetitions or time.

Title: Feet-elevated bench side plank
Desc: The feet-elevated bench side plank is an advanced version of the side plank performed with the feet elevated on a bench. It targets the same muscles as the side plank, including the obliques, shoulders, and lateral hips, but the body angle makes it more difficult than side planks on the floor. Most lifters will need to progress to this version after mastering the basic side plank first.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your feet elevated on a bench. Lift your hips off the ground, supporting your body with your forearm. Hold this position to engage your obliques and shoulders.

Title: Cross-body sit-up
Desc: The cross-body sit-up is a bodyweight exercise targeting the ab muscles, the obliques and rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles in particular. It involves bringing the opposite-side knee and elbow together, usually alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent. Bring your right elbow towards your left knee while extending your right leg. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: Decline kayak
Desc: The decline kayak is a core exercise targeting the obliques. It involves making a paddling motion on a decline bench with the feet anchored, using a bar or pipe for weight. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per side, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout or circuit.
HowTo: To perform the decline kayak, lie on a decline bench with your feet anchored. Hold a bar or pipe for weight above your chest. Engage your core and perform a paddling motion by twisting your torso to one side, then the other, while keeping your legs stable. Aim for 8-12 reps per side.

Title: 30 Decline Reverse Crunch
Desc: The decline reverse crunch is a core exercise targeting the lower abdominals.
HowTo: To perform the decline reverse crunch, lie on a decline bench with your head at the lower end. Grab the bench for support, and bring your knees towards your chest while curling your hips off the bench. Lower your legs back down without letting them touch the bench. Perform for 10-15 reps.

Title: Decline sit-up twist
Desc: The decline sit-up twist is a bodyweight core exercise that targets the obliques, as well as the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. Sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the decline sit-up twist, lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. Start in a sit-up position and as you rise, twist your torso to one side, bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee. Lower back down and repeat on the other side. Perform 10-15 reps per side.

Title: 30 Flat Bench Leg Raise
Desc: The lying leg lift is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the abs, the rectus abdominis or “six-pack” muscles in particular. It can be performed for time or reps in the core-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the flat bench leg raise, lie flat on your back on a bench with your legs extended. Keeping your legs straight, raise them towards the ceiling until your hips come off the bench. Lower your legs back down just above the bench without touching it. Perform for 10-15 reps.

Title: 30 Flutter Kick
Desc: The flutter kick is a core exercise where the legs are held off the ground as you flutter your feet over and under each other in small motions. It targets multiple muscles of the core, but particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the flutter kick, lie on your back with your legs extended and your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion. Keep your core engaged and perform for 30 seconds to 1 minute.

Title: Chin-up crunch
Desc: The chin-up crunch is an exercise targeting the core and overall upper-body strength. It combines a chin-up with a knee raise or crunch to give extra emphasis to the core.
HowTo: To perform the chin-up crunch, hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Pull your body up while simultaneously raising your knees towards your chest, engaging your core. Lower back down to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Gorilla Chin Oblique Crunch
Desc: The 30 Gorilla Chin Oblique Crunch is a challenging core exercise that targets the oblique muscles while also engaging the upper body. To perform this exercise, start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head, and as you lift your shoulders off the ground, twist your torso to bring your elbow towards the opposite knee. Alternate sides for a total of 30 repetitions, focusing on controlled movements and engaging your core throughout.
HowTo: To perform the Gorilla Chin Oblique Crunch, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place your hands behind your head. Lift your shoulders off the ground and twist your torso to bring your elbow towards the opposite knee. Alternate sides for a total of 30 repetitions, focusing on controlled movements.

Title: Half Turkish get-up
Desc: The half Turkish get-up is a kettlebell movement that focuses on the first portion of the Turkish get-up exercise.
