Desc: The MetaBurn Side Plank Oblique Crunch is a combination of a side plank and a crunch, targeting the oblique muscles and improving lateral core strength.
HowTo: Begin in a side plank position. Lower your hip toward the ground, then lift it back up while bringing your top knee toward your chest in a crunch motion.

Title: MetaBurn Sit-Through
Desc: The MetaBurn Sit-Through is a dynamic movement that involves transitioning from a seated position to a plank and back, engaging the core and improving overall mobility.
HowTo: Start seated with your legs extended. Transition to a plank position by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back. Reverse the motion to return to seated.

Title: MetaBurn Sit-Up To V-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Sit-Up To V-Up is an effective core exercise that combines a traditional sit-up with a V-up movement, targeting the upper and lower abdominal muscles for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Perform a traditional sit-up by lifting your upper body towards your knees. 3. As you reach the top of the sit-up, extend your legs straight out and lift them off the ground to perform a V-up. 4. Lower your upper body and legs back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Sit-Up With Rotation
Desc: The MetaBurn Sit-Up With Rotation adds a rotational twist to the standard sit-up, engaging the obliques and enhancing core stability while improving overall strength.
HowTo: 1. Begin lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Perform a sit-up, but as you lift your torso, twist your body to one side, bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee. 3. Lower back down and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Split-Leg Crunch
Desc: The MetaBurn Split-Leg Crunch is designed to isolate the abdominal muscles by performing a crunch with one leg elevated, increasing the intensity and focus on the core.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with one leg elevated and the other leg bent at a 90-degree angle. 2. Perform a crunch by lifting your shoulders off the ground, focusing on the elevated leg. 3. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch legs.

Title: MetaBurn Tabletop Hip Thrust
Desc: The MetaBurn Tabletop Hip Thrust targets the glutes and hamstrings while engaging the core, performed from a tabletop position to maximize muscle activation.
HowTo: 1. Start in a tabletop position with your shoulders over your wrists and hips over your knees. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. 3. Lower back down to the tabletop position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Tabletop With Russian Kick
Desc: The MetaBurn Tabletop With Russian Kick combines a tabletop position with a kicking motion, effectively working the core and hip flexors while promoting balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a tabletop position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Extend one leg back while simultaneously kicking it forward in a controlled motion. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Toe Driver Abs
Desc: The MetaBurn Toe Driver Abs is a dynamic exercise that involves driving the toes towards the chest while lying on your back, effectively targeting the lower abdominal muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms at your sides. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs towards your chest while simultaneously raising your shoulders off the ground. 3. Lower back down without letting your feet touch the floor and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn-V-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn-V-Up is a challenging core exercise that combines a V-up movement with a focus on engaging both the upper and lower abs, promoting overall core strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on your back with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. 2. Simultaneously lift your arms and legs off the ground, forming a V shape with your body. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: X-body V-up
Desc: The X-body V-up is a bodyweight abdominal exercise performed on the floor. It is similar to the popular V-up exercise, but is performed with the arms and legs out wide in an X-shape. It primarily targets the muscles of the rectus abdominis, or “six-pack” muscles. It can be performed for reps or time, either as part of an ab-focused workout or as a component of a circuit workout.
HowTo: 1. Start lying on your back with your arms and legs extended out wide in an X-shape. 2. Engage your core and lift your upper body and legs simultaneously, bringing them together in the center. 3. Return to the X position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Swivel Crunch
Desc: The MetaBurn Swivel Crunch is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles by incorporating a twisting motion. Start by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground, twisting your torso to one side while bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee. Alternate sides for a complete set.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Engage your core and lift your shoulders off the ground, twisting your torso to one side while bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee. Alternate sides for a complete set.

Title: Robertson Core-Engaged Dead Bug
Desc: The Robertson Core-Engaged Dead Bug is a stability exercise that focuses on engaging the core while moving the limbs. Lie on your back with your arms extended towards the ceiling and your knees bent at 90 degrees. Slowly lower one arm and the opposite leg towards the ground while keeping your back flat against the floor. Return to the starting position and alternate sides.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended towards the ceiling and your knees bent at 90 degrees. Slowly lower one arm and the opposite leg towards the ground while keeping your back flat against the floor. Return to the starting position and alternate sides.

Title: FYR2 Double-Under
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Under is a jump rope exercise that involves swinging the rope twice under your feet for each jump. Begin with a standard jump rope and practice timing your jumps to allow the rope to pass under you twice before landing. This exercise enhances coordination, speed, and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: Begin with a standard jump rope. Swing the rope over your head and jump, timing your jumps to allow the rope to pass under your feet twice before landing. Practice to enhance coordination, speed, and cardiovascular endurance.

Title: FYR2 Fire Feet with Burpee Tuck Jump Drill
Desc: The FYR2 Fire Feet with Burpee Tuck Jump Drill combines agility and strength. Start in a standing position and quickly move your feet in and out as if running in place. After a set number of seconds, drop into a burpee, completing the push-up and then jumping up with your knees tucked towards your chest. This drill improves explosive power and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: Start in a standing position and quickly move your feet in and out as if running in place for a set number of seconds. Then drop into a burpee, complete the push-up, and jump up with your knees tucked towards your chest.

Title: FYR2 Flutter Kick
Desc: The FYR2 Flutter Kick is a core strengthening exercise that targets the lower abdominal muscles. Lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged and your back pressed into the floor.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Hip Flexors, Transverse Abdominis
HowTo: Lie on your back with your hands under your hips for support. Lift your legs off the ground a few inches and alternate kicking them up and down in a fluttering motion while keeping your core engaged and your back pressed into the floor.

Title: FYR2 Half-Moon
Desc: The FYR2 Half-Moon is a dynamic core exercise that involves a side plank position. Start in a side plank with your feet stacked and your elbow directly under your shoulder. Lift your top leg while reaching your top arm overhead, creating a crescent shape with your body. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.
HowTo: Start in a side plank with your feet stacked and your elbow directly under your shoulder. Lift your top leg while reaching your top arm overhead, creating a crescent shape with your body. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: FYR2 Leopard Crawl
Desc: The FYR2 Leopard Crawl is a full-body exercise that emphasizes core stability and mobility. Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and crawl forward by moving opposite hand and foot together, maintaining a flat back and engaged core throughout the movement.
HowTo: Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and crawl forward by moving opposite hand and foot together, maintaining a flat back and engaged core throughout the movement.

Title: FYR2 Plank Alternating Front Step
Desc: The FYR2 Plank Alternating Front Step is a core and stability exercise. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Step one foot forward towards your hands, then return it to the plank position. Alternate feet, maintaining a strong core and flat back throughout the exercise.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis, Shoulders
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Step one foot forward towards your hands, then return it to the plank position. Alternate feet, maintaining a strong core and flat back throughout the exercise.

Title: FYR2 Shoulder Tap
Desc: The FYR2 Shoulder Tap is an exercise that targets the shoulders, core, and stability. Begin in a plank position and alternate tapping each shoulder with the opposite hand while maintaining a strong core and avoiding hip rotation.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. Alternate tapping each shoulder with the opposite hand while maintaining a strong core and avoiding hip rotation.

Title: Hand shift plank
Desc: The hand shift plank is a progression of the straight-arm plank exercise where you maintain a plank position as you shift your hands side to side. The additional movement forces the core muscles to work harder to stabilize.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis, Shoulders
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to one side and move your hand laterally to the side, then return to the starting position. Repeat by shifting to the other side, maintaining a stable core throughout.

Title: Cross-body plank march
Desc: The cross-body plank march is an exercise targeting the entire core but especially the obliques. It’s more difficult than a standard plank, with the extra stabilization challenge of bringing one knee at a time off the ground toward the opposing elbow. This will increase the challenge to the core and shoulder muscles, but also present a coordination and balance challenge.
Muscles: Rectus Abdominis, Obliques, Transverse Abdominis, Shoulders
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Lift one knee towards the opposite elbow while maintaining a strong core and balance. Return the foot to the ground and alternate sides, ensuring to keep the hips stable.

Title: Bent-knee Copenhagen hip adduction
Desc: The bent-knee Copenhagen hip adduction is an advanced exercise that combines the isometric stabilization of the Copenhagen plank with dynamic adductions to challenge the core stabilizers and adductors. This exercise targets the same muscles as the side plank, including the obliques, shoulders, and lateral hips, but places extra emphasis on the adductors and is more difficult than side planks on the floor. Most lifters will need to progress to this version after mastering the basic side plank or Copenhagen plank first.
HowTo: Start in a Copenhagen plank position with one foot on a bench and the other foot on the ground. Lower your hips towards the ground while keeping your body in a straight line, then lift back up to the starting position. Focus on engaging your core and adductors throughout the movement.

Title: Copenhagen plank
Desc: The Copenhagen plank is an advanced version of the side plank performed with one foot on a bench and the other foot hovering under it. This exercise targets the same muscles as the side plank, including the obliques, shoulders, and lateral hips, but places extra emphasis on the adductors and is more difficult than side planks on the floor. Most lifters will need to progress to this version after mastering the basic side plank or feet-elevated side plank first.
HowTo: Begin in a side plank position with one foot on a bench and the other foot hovering below. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. Hold the position, engaging your obliques and adductors, and maintain stability.

Title: ACFT Hanging leg tuck
Desc: The hanging leg tuck is an exercise targeting the entire body, including the arms, upper back, abs, and hip flexors. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. It is performe while hanging from a bar and combines elements of a pull-up with a leg raise. Experienced lifters make these look easy, but beginners may need time to build up to sets of 8-12 reps.
Muscles: Arms, Upper Back, Abdominals, Hip Flexors
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. Engage your core and pull your knees towards your chest, tucking them in as you lift. Lower your legs back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Alternating hanging knee raise
Desc: The alternating hanging knee raise is an exercise targeting the abs, but which also works the lats and hip flexors. Rather than performing both legs at a time, you lift one knee at a time and alternate with each rep as if marching in place. Knee raises are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of ab-focused training.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. Engage your core and lift one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg hanging. Alternate legs with each rep, as if marching in place, for 8-12 reps.

Title: Plank To Sphinx
Desc: The Plank To Sphinx is a dynamic exercise that transitions from a plank position to a sphinx pose. Start in a forearm plank and then push up to the sphinx position, engaging the core and maintaining proper alignment throughout.
HowTo: Start in a forearm plank position with your elbows under your shoulders. Push up onto your hands to transition into the sphinx position, engaging your core and maintaining proper alignment. Return to the forearm plank and repeat.

Title: Twisting Mountain Climbers
Desc: Twisting Mountain Climbers are a dynamic exercise that combines the benefits of mountain climbers with a twisting motion to engage the core, obliques, and improve overall stability and endurance.
HowTo: Start in a high plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. Engage your core and keep your body in a straight line. Bring your right knee towards your left elbow while twisting your torso. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side, bringing your left knee towards your right elbow. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Jack Knives
Desc: Jack Knives are a core-strengthening exercise that targets the abdominal muscles by lying on your back and simultaneously raising your legs and torso to form a 'V' shape.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended and arms overhead. Simultaneously lift your legs and torso off the ground, bringing them together to form a 'V' shape. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Hanging Leg Raises
Desc: Hanging Leg Raises are an effective exercise for building core strength, where you hang from a bar and lift your legs towards your chest, engaging the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms fully extended. Engage your core and lift your legs towards your chest, keeping them straight. Focus on using your abdominal muscles to lift your legs rather than swinging. Lower your legs back down with control and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell suitcase crunch
Desc: The dumbbell suitcase crunch is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise. The simple addition of a weight makes the suitcase crunch far more difficult, helping build the "six pack" muscles and providing a different stimulus to the core during training.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a dumbbell in both hands above your chest. As you crunch up, bring the dumbbell towards your knees while lifting your shoulders off the ground. Lower back down with control and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball rotational throw
Desc: The medicine ball rotational throw is an explosive exercise targeting the abdominals, including the obliques, as well as the hips and upper back. It involves standing sideways to the wall and twisting the torso to hurl a medicine ball into the wall, then catching the ball on the ricochet. It can be performed for lower reps with a focus on power, or for higher reps with a focus on fat loss and conditioning.
HowTo: Stand sideways to a wall, holding a medicine ball. Rotate your torso away from the wall and then explosively twist back towards the wall, throwing the ball against it. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Hollow-hold ball toss
Desc: The hollow-hold ball toss is a more difficult version of the hollow-body hold exercise. It involves tossing a ball to a partner while maintaining an isometric hold in the hollow-body position. It can be done for reps or time in any ab-focused workout, or in an "I go, you go" format.
HowTo: Lie on your back in a hollow-body position, with your arms extended overhead and legs straight. Hold a ball in your hands. While maintaining the hollow position, toss the ball to a partner and catch it as they throw it back. Continue tossing for the desired number of repetitions or time.

Title: Partner front Russian twist and pass
Desc: The partner front Russian twist and pass is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise that also utilizes a training partner to add another dynamic component. It targets the oblique muscles, as well as the deep muscles of the core and the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. It can be done for reps or time in an ab-focused portion of any workout.
Muscles: Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: Sit back in a Russian twist position with your feet off the ground and a weight in your hands. Twist your torso to one side and pass the weight to your partner, then twist to the other side to receive the weight back. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions or time.

Title: Sit-up with single-arm overhand throw
Desc: The sit-up with single-arm overhand throw is an exercise targeting the core muscles, but the inclusion of the throw also brings in other upper-body muscles. When you come to the top of the sit-up position, you throw a medicine ball using one arm to a partner who then throws it right back to you to be caught with both hands. It can be performed for time or reps as part of the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent. Perform a sit-up by lifting your torso towards your knees. At the top of the sit-up, throw a medicine ball with one arm to a partner. Catch the ball with both hands as it comes back and lower back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball partner twist
Desc: The medicine ball partner twist is a plyometrics exercise targeting the core muscles, particularly the obliques. You and a partner stand back to back and rotate in unison to pass a medicine ball back and forth on alternating sides.
HowTo: Stand back to back with your partner, holding a medicine ball. Rotate your torso to one side to pass the ball to your partner, who will rotate to receive it. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Partner side Russian twist and pass
Desc: The partner side Russian twist and pass is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise that also utilizes a training partner to add another dynamic component. It primarily targets the oblique muscles, as well as the deep muscles of the core and the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. It can be done for reps or time in an ab-focused portion of any workout.
Muscles: Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your partner, both holding a medicine ball. Lean back slightly and twist your torso to one side to pass the ball to your partner, who will twist to receive it. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball half moon
Desc: The medicine ball half moon is a dynamic core exercise performed around and over a medicine ball or other short, stationary object. It is similar in some ways to a V-up or reverse crunch, and targets both the obliques and the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for reps or for time, usually in dedicated ab training or as part of a medicine ball and bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended and a medicine ball positioned near your feet. Lift your legs and torso simultaneously to reach for the ball, then lower back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise ball roll-out
Desc: The exercise ball roll-out is an exercise that strengthens the core, shoulders and upper- back muscles. It starts in a plank-style position, with the arms resting on a ball. Then, roll the ball out in front of you as far as you can while maintaining a strong, neutral spinal position. The lack of stability from the ball increases the degree of difficulty. This is a difficult movement, and beginners may need to use a limited range of motion.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your arms resting on an exercise ball. Engage your core and roll the ball forward, extending your arms while keeping your body straight. Roll back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball pass
Desc: The medicine ball pass is a simple partner-based exercise that involves throwing a weighted ball back and forth. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up for lifting or athletics, but can also work as active rest or as a component of circuit training.
HowTo: Stand facing your partner, each holding a medicine ball. Throw the ball to your partner, who will catch it and throw it back. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Partner medicine ball sit-up
Desc: The partner medicine ball sit-up is a more difficult version of the traditional abdominal exercise. Two partners pass a medicine ball back and forth at the top of each rep, so each one must alternate a weighted rep with an unweighted rep. This technique can be done for reps or time in any ab-focused workout, in an "I go, you go" format.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and a medicine ball held above your chest. Perform a sit-up, passing the ball to your partner at the top of the movement. Alternate passing the ball at the top of each rep for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball Russian twist
Desc: The medicine ball Russian twist is a weighted version of a popular abdominal training exercise. It targets the oblique muscles, as well as the deep muscles of the core and the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. It can be done for reps or time in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
Muscles: Obliques, Rectus Abdominis, Deep Core Muscles
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your knees bent and feet flat. Hold a medicine ball with both hands. Lean back slightly and rotate your torso to one side, tapping the ball on the ground, then rotate to the other side. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Medicine Ball Slam
Desc: The medicine ball slam is an explosive exercise for developing power, strength, and speed. Muscles worked include the abdominals, legs, triceps, shoulders, and lats. The slams are usually done in rapid succession to complete one set. It can also be a component of a power or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball overhead. Forcefully slam the ball down to the ground in front of you, bending your knees and engaging your core. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Medicine ball twist
Desc: The medicine ball twist is an exercise targeting the abdominal muscles, particularly the obliques. It is similar in many ways to a Russian twist exercise. The ball is held tight to the chest throughout the movement, and then the torso is rotated from side to side for the desired number of reps or a set amount of time.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your knees bent and feet flat. 2. Hold a medicine ball close to your chest. 3. Lean back slightly while keeping your back straight. 4. Rotate your torso to the right, bringing the medicine ball beside your hip. 5. Return to the center and rotate to the left. 6. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Medicine Ball Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Medicine Ball Complex is a dynamic workout that combines multiple movements using a medicine ball to enhance strength, coordination, and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball. 2. Perform a squat while keeping the ball at chest level. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the ball overhead. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Medicine Ball Fire-Feet Drill
Desc: The FYR2 Medicine Ball Fire-Feet Drill focuses on rapid foot movement and agility, using a medicine ball to increase intensity and challenge coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a medicine ball. 2. Quickly lift your feet off the ground, alternating them in a running motion while keeping the ball in front of you. 3. Maintain a fast pace to increase intensity. 4. Continue for a set amount of time or reps.

Title: FYR2 Medicine Ball Knees-to-Chest
Desc: The FYR2 Medicine Ball Knees-to-Chest exercise targets core strength and flexibility, utilizing a medicine ball to engage the abdominal muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a medicine ball above your chest. 3. Engage your core and lift your knees towards your chest while simultaneously raising the ball towards your knees. 4. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Medicine Ball Mountain Climber
Desc: The FYR2 Medicine Ball Mountain Climber is a high-intensity exercise that combines cardiovascular training with core strengthening, using a medicine ball to add resistance and stability.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the medicine ball. 2. Drive one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Alternate legs quickly, simulating a running motion. 4. Maintain a strong core and continue for a set amount of time or reps.

Title: Decline oblique crunch
Desc: The decline oblique crunch is a popular bodyweight exercise targeting the obliques and the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the ab-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 4. Lower back down with control and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Decline sit-up
Desc: The decline sit-up is a bodyweight core exercise that works the rectus abdominis or "six pack" muscles. Sit-up variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of the core-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. 2. Cross your arms over your chest or place your hands behind your head. 3. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees. 4. Lower back down with control and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Hanging Windshield Wiper
Desc: The hanging windshield wiper is an advanced abdominal training exercise that is also extremely challenging to other muscles of the upper body, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, and grip. It requires—and builds—great strength in the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles, as well as the obliques and deep core muscles. If you can't perform it hanging from a bar, the lying windshield wiper on the floor provides some of the same benefits.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with your legs extended. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs to one side, rotating your hips. 3. Lower your legs back down and repeat on the other side. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of reps.

Title: Exercise Ball Pull-In
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands on the ground and your feet on an exercise ball. Engage your core and draw your knees in towards your chest, rolling the ball towards you. Extend your legs back out to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise ball crunch
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. Lean back slightly while keeping your back straight. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, contracting your abs. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Feet-elevated crunch
Desc: The feet-elevated crunch is a variation on the basic crunch, a very popular ab move. Resting the feet on a bench takes some of the hip flexor activation out of the movement, focusing the stress more on the abs. It may have a small range of motion, but this movement produces a major burn.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet elevated on a bench. Place your hands behind your head. Engage your core and lift your upper body towards your knees, squeezing your abs at the top. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Weighted Ball Side Bend
Desc: The Weighted Ball Side Bend is an exercise that targets the oblique muscles and helps improve core strength and stability. To perform this exercise, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart while holding a weighted ball in one hand. Slowly bend to the side, bringing the weighted ball down towards your knee, and then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weighted ball in one hand. Slowly bend to the side, bringing the weighted ball down towards your knee. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Swiss Ball Ab Roll-Out
Desc: The exercise ball roll-out is an exercise that strengthens the core, shoulders and upper- back muscles. It starts in a plank-style position, with the arms resting on a ball. Then, you roll the ball out in front of you as far as you can while maintaining a strong, neutral spinal position. The lack of stability from the ball increases the degree of difficulty. This is a difficult movement, and beginners may need to use a limited range of motion.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your arms resting on an exercise ball. Engage your core and roll the ball forward, extending your arms as far as you can while maintaining a neutral spine. Roll the ball back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise Ball Cable Crunch - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the floor. Hold a cable or resistance band above your head. Engage your core and crunch down, bringing your elbows towards your knees while keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise ball squat and twist
Desc: The exercise ball squat and twist is a combination exercise targeting the quads, but also the obliques because of the twisting motion with each repetition. The exercise ball is held close to the chest throughout. Because it is a lightweight movement, it is usually performed for high reps or for time, and can be a great part of a bodyweight and exercise ball circuit.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an exercise ball close to your chest. Perform a squat by bending your knees and lowering your hips. As you rise, twist your torso to one side, bringing the ball across your body. Alternate sides and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Swiss Ball V-Up With Foot Pass
Desc: The exercise ball V-up is a popular movement to target the abdominal muscles, particularly the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It involves passing an exercise ball or yoga ball back and forth between the hands and feet while performing V-ups. It can be performed for reps or time as part of any ab-focused workout or bodyweight circuit.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms and legs extended, holding an exercise ball between your feet. Simultaneously lift your legs and upper body, passing the ball from your feet to your hands. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Exercise ball pike
Desc: The exercise ball pike is a challenging move that targets the core. It involves thrusting the hips into full flexion over a ball, then extending out to a foot-elevated plank with the feet on the ball. It's a challenging move from a strength perspective, but also for balance. It can be the centerpiece of an ab workout or go along with other body weight or ball movements in an ab circuit.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your feet on the exercise ball. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips towards the ceiling, rolling the ball towards you. 3. Hold the pike position briefly, then lower your hips back down and extend your body back to the starting position.

Title: Exercise ball bird dog
Desc: The exercise ball bird dog is a dynamic movement focusing on the glutes and the postural muscles of the upper back. When performing it, use an exercise ball that is tall enough to support your chest and core, but short enough to allow your hands and knees to reach the ground. It is slightly easier than a bodyweight bird dog and can work as a regression for that movement. It can be done for time or reps as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as a mobility or recovery exercise.
Muscles: Glutes, Erector Spinae, Upper Back Muscles
HowTo: 1. Begin on your hands and knees with your hands on the exercise ball. 2. Extend one arm forward and the opposite leg back, keeping your core engaged. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Exercise ball superman
Desc: The exercise ball superman is a slightly more advanced variation of the bodyweight superman exercise. It targets many muscles along the posterior or backside of the body, including the rear deltoids, trapezius, spinal erectors, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be done for time or reps as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as a mobility or recovery exercise.
Muscles: Rear Deltoids, Trapezius, Spinal Erectors, Glutes, Hamstrings
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on the exercise ball with your feet on the ground and your hands extended in front of you. 2. Lift your arms and legs off the ground simultaneously, engaging your back and glutes. 3. Hold for a few seconds, then lower back down.

Title: BOSU cross-body crunch
Desc: The BOSU cross-body crunch is a dynamic abdominal exercise performed on a BOSU ball or other stability training device. It targets several of the muscles in the core, including the obliques and the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It is usually performed in alternating reps, either for time or a number of reps, as part of an ab-focused workout or a circuit involving body weight or the BOSU ball.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the BOSU ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Lean back slightly and engage your core. 3. Twist your torso to one side, bringing your elbow towards the opposite knee, then return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Exercise Ball Knee Tuck - Gethin Varation
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the exercise ball. 2. Draw your knees towards your chest while keeping your back straight. 3. Extend your legs back to the starting position.

Title: Alternating Exercise Ball Knee Tucks - Gethin Variation
Desc: The exercise ball knee roll-in is an abdominal exercise that involves supporting yourself with your hands in a plank or push-up position and drawing the knees in toward the chest. This is a fairly advanced abdominal move requiring core strength.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands on the exercise ball. 2. Alternate drawing one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended. 3. Return to the plank position and switch legs.

Title: AM Ball Crunch
Desc: The exercise ball crunch is a popular gym exercise targeting the abdominals. Unlike crunches on the floor or a bench, by using a ball, you can increase the range of motion and both stretch and contract the abs on every rep. The ball crunch can be performed for low reps with a slower tempo, focusing on a hard contraction, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the exercise ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Lean back slightly and engage your core. 3. Curl your torso forward, bringing your shoulders towards your knees, then lower back down.

Title: 30 Bosu Cable Reverse Crunch
Desc: The 30 Bosu Cable Reverse Crunch is an effective core exercise that targets the abdominal muscles. Using a Bosu ball and cable machine, this exercise involves lying on your back with your feet on the Bosu, pulling your knees towards your chest while engaging your core. It helps improve stability, strength, and overall core conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your feet on the BOSU ball and hold the cable handles. 2. Engage your core and pull your knees towards your chest while keeping your feet on the ball. 3. Slowly lower your legs back to the starting position.

Title: BOSU knee tuck
Desc: The BOSU knee tuck is a dynamic abdominal movement performed on a BOSU ball or other stability training device. It primarily targets the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles of the core. It can be performed for time or reps as part of an ab-focused workout or a circuit involving body weight or the BOSU ball.
HowTo: 1. Start by kneeling on the BOSU ball with your hands placed on the sides for support. 2. Engage your core and tuck your knees towards your chest while balancing on the ball. 3. Extend your legs back out to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: 30 Side Plank On Ball
Desc: The feet-elevated side plank on ball is a more advanced version of a traditional bodyweight side plank. The feet are balanced on an exercise ball, providing a balance challenge but also increasing the load placed upon the obliques and shoulder muscles. It is usually performed for timed holds, either one side at a time or alternating sides. If a ball is unavailable, some of the benefits of the movement can be obtained by performing side planks with the feet elevated on a couch, chair, bench, or other stable object.
HowTo: 1. Start in a side plank position with your feet elevated on a stability ball. 2. Engage your core and maintain a straight line from head to heels. 3. Hold this position for the desired time, or alternate sides if performing timed holds.

Title: Hanging exercise ball leg raise
Desc: The hanging exercise ball leg raise is an exercise targeting the abs and hip flexors. Instead of resting the forearms on the pads of an apparatus, it's performed hanging from a bar with an exercise ball held between the legs.
HowTo: 1. Hang from a pull-up bar with an exercise ball held between your legs. 2. Engage your core and lift your legs, bringing the ball towards your chest. 3. Lower your legs back down while maintaining control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Taylor Exercise Ball Stir-The-Pot
Desc: The Taylor Exercise Ball Stir-The-Pot is a core stability exercise that involves sitting on an exercise ball and rotating your torso in a circular motion, engaging your core muscles to maintain balance.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an exercise ball with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Engage your core and rotate your torso in a circular motion, as if stirring a pot. 3. Perform the rotation in both directions for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Air Ball
Desc: The FYR2 Air Ball is a dynamic stability exercise that utilizes an air-filled ball to enhance balance and coordination, often performed by sitting or lying on the ball and engaging various muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Sit or lie on the air-filled ball, ensuring it is stable. 2. Engage your core and maintain balance while performing various movements, such as reaching out with your arms or lifting one leg at a time. 3. Focus on engaging different muscle groups throughout the exercise.

Title: Feet-elevated plank on ball
Desc: The feet-elevated plank is a variation on the straight-arm plank, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated on a ball to align the body parallel to the floor and provide a greater stabilization challenge. This makes it more difficult than straight-arm planks on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It is often used as a shoulder and core warm-up, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a straight-arm plank position with your feet elevated on a stability ball. 2. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core. 3. Hold this position for the desired time or perform additional movements like shoulder taps.

Title: Band Hip Adductions
Desc: Band Hip Adductions are performed using a resistance band to strengthen the inner thigh muscles. Stand with the band around your ankles and move one leg outward while keeping the other leg stable.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a resistance band around your ankles. 2. Shift your weight onto one leg and lift the other leg outward, keeping it straight. 3. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: Lateral Band Walk
Desc: Lateral Band Walks involve placing a resistance band around your legs and stepping sideways to strengthen the hip abductors and improve lateral stability.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and engage your core. 3. Step sideways, keeping tension on the band, and then step back to the starting position. 4. Repeat in the opposite direction for the desired number of steps.

Title: FYR2 Standing Banded Leg Abduction
Desc: Stand with a resistance band around your legs, just above your knees. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart and engage your core. Slowly lift one leg out to the side, keeping your knee straight and your foot flexed. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching legs.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a resistance band around your legs, just above your knees. 2. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart and engage your core. 3. Slowly lift one leg out to the side, keeping your knee straight and your foot flexed. 4. Return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching legs.

Title: Iliotibial band SMR
Desc: Iliotibial band self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the IT band along the side of the upper leg, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." IT band SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the glute or quad muscles, or by stretches that target the glutes or quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor or lie on your side with a foam roller or massage tool positioned under your upper leg. 2. Apply pressure to the IT band by rolling back and forth along the side of your thigh. 3. Focus on any tight or painful areas, holding pressure as needed. 4. Incorporate SMR on the glute or quad muscles, or perform stretches targeting the glutes or quads.

Title: Adductor SMR
Desc: Adductor self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the adductor muscles in the inner thigh region, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Adductor SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the iliotibial (IT) band or glutes (TFL muscles), or by stretches that target the adductors.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor or lie on your side with a foam roller or massage tool positioned under your inner thigh. 2. Apply pressure to the adductor muscles by rolling back and forth along the inner thigh. 3. Focus on any tight or painful areas, holding pressure as needed. 4. Incorporate SMR on the IT band or glutes, or perform stretches targeting the adductors.

Title: Lying Bent Leg Groin
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Allow your knees to fall out to the sides, feeling a stretch in your inner thighs. Hold this position for a few seconds, then bring your knees back together. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. 2. Allow your knees to fall out to the sides, feeling a stretch in your inner thighs. 3. Hold this position for a few seconds. 4. Bring your knees back together. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lateral box jump
Desc: The lateral box jump is a plyometric exercise targeting lateral agility and lower-body strength. It's a great move for athletes in many sports, including basketball, skiing, and tennis.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a box or platform. 2. Bend your knees slightly and jump laterally onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. 3. Step back down and repeat. 4. Perform for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Thigh adductor
Desc: The thigh adductor machine is a lower-body exercise that targets the muscles of the inner thighs. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the thigh adductor machine and adjust the seat if necessary. 2. Place your legs against the pads provided. 3. Squeeze your legs together to move the pads inward. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Perform for 8-12 reps or more as part of your workout.

Title: Thigh abductor
Desc: The thigh abductor is a lower-body exercise that targets the muscles of the outer hips and glutes. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the thigh abductor machine and adjust the seat if necessary. 2. Place your legs against the pads provided. 3. Push your legs outward to move the pads apart. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Perform for 8-12 reps or more as part of your workout.

Title: Standing Hip Circles
Desc: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Lift one leg off the ground and begin to make small circles with your knee, keeping your core engaged. Perform circles in one direction for a set number of repetitions, then switch directions. Repeat with the other leg.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Lift one leg off the ground. 3. Begin to make small circles with your knee, keeping your core engaged. 4. Perform circles in one direction for a set number of repetitions. 5. Switch directions and repeat with the other leg.

Title: Groiners
Desc: Groiners are a dynamic exercise that involves a deep squat position while alternating leg movements to engage the hips and core.
HowTo: Start in a deep squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Place your hands on the ground in front of you. Jump your feet forward to your hands, then jump back to the starting position. Alternate legs as you move.

Title: Fire Hydrant
Desc: The Fire Hydrant exercise targets the glutes and hip muscles by lifting one leg while on all fours, mimicking a dog at a fire hydrant.
HowTo: Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift one leg out to the side, keeping the knee bent at 90 degrees. Hold for a moment, then lower the leg back down. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Windmills
Desc: Windmills are a stretching exercise that involves rotating the torso while reaching down to touch the opposite foot, enhancing flexibility and core stability.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Rotate your torso to the right while reaching down with your right hand to touch your left foot. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Side Leg Raises
Desc: Side Leg Raises strengthen the hip abductors by lifting the leg sideways while lying on your side, improving balance and stability.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs straight. Lift your top leg upwards while keeping it straight, then lower it back down without letting it touch the bottom leg. Repeat for several repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Lateral hop
Desc: The lateral hop is an explosive bodyweight exercise that consists of a two-legged hop to the side. It targets the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Performed for reps, it also provides a serious cardiovascular challenge. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Jump to the side with both feet, landing softly and immediately jumping back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Monster Walk
Desc: Monster Walks are a resistance band exercise that involves lateral movement while maintaining a squat position, targeting the glutes and legs.
HowTo: Place a resistance band around your thighs and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat position and step sideways, keeping tension in the band. Step back to the starting position and repeat in the opposite direction.

Title: Side Lying Groin Stretch
Desc: The Side Lying Groin Stretch involves lying on your side and stretching the top leg over the bottom leg to open up the hip and groin area.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs straight. Lift your top leg and stretch it over the bottom leg, allowing it to rest on the ground. Hold the stretch to feel it in your hip and groin area.

Title: IT Band and Glute Stretch
Desc: The IT Band and Glute Stretch targets the iliotibial band and glutes by crossing one leg over the other while seated or lying down, promoting flexibility.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your legs extended in front of you. Cross one leg over the other, placing the foot flat on the ground. Gently lean forward to deepen the stretch in your glutes and IT band. Hold for a few breaths, then switch sides.

Title: Single-leg lying cross-over stretch
Desc: The single-leg lying cross-over stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and glutes. It involves rotating a single leg over the body while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with your legs extended. Bend one knee and rotate that leg across your body, allowing it to rest on the ground while keeping the opposite shoulder on the floor. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Carioca quick step
Desc: The carioca quick step is a lateral bodyweight exercise targeting the adductors but also promoting agility and overall conditioning. It’s a favorite of football players, particularly defensive backs, because it mimics the way they have to track wide receivers downfield. It can also help mobilize the hips for athletes and lifters of all ability levels.
HowTo: Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step laterally with your right foot, crossing it behind your left foot. Then step to the left with your left foot, bringing it back to the starting position. Repeat this motion quickly, alternating sides.

Title: Standing hip circle
Desc: The standing hip circle is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hips and abductor muscles. It is a classic way to "limber up" after sitting for a long period or before a lower-body workout or sports. It requires no equipment and can be helpful for everyone from beginners to advanced fitness enthusiasts.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and lift the other leg slightly off the ground. Move the lifted leg in a circular motion, making sure to engage your core for balance. Perform 10-15 circles in one direction, then switch to the other leg.

Title: Lateral cone hop
Desc: The lateral cone hop is an agility drill that involves jumping over cones or other short hurdles side to side rather than front to back. It can be performed for reps or for time and can be beneficial for track athletes, basketball players, or any other athletes who need explosive lateral power.
HowTo: Set up cones or markers about 2-3 feet apart. Stand next to the first cone, then jump laterally over it to the other side, landing softly. Immediately jump back to the starting side. Repeat for a set number of reps or for a timed duration.

Title: Side-To-Side Adductor Stretch
Desc: The Side-To-Side Adductor Stretch targets the inner thigh muscles. To perform this stretch, stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to one side, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch to the other side. This exercise helps improve flexibility and mobility in the hips.
HowTo: Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to your right side, bending your right knee while keeping your left leg straight. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch to the left side.

Title: Dynamic pigeon stretch
Desc: The dynamic pigeon stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is influenced by the pigeon pose from yoga, but involves moving in and out of the pose. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees. Bring your right knee forward towards your right wrist, placing your foot near your left hip. Lower your body into the stretch, then push back to the starting position. Alternate legs for a series of reps.

Title: Cross-over jack
Desc: The cross-over jack is a variation on the jumping jack, a popular calisthenics exercise used to improve overall conditioning. The difference between the jumping jack and the cross-over jack is that with the latter, the feet don't just come together each rep, they cross over each other. It's a great way to add variety to your warm-up or conditioning work.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Jump up and spread your legs while crossing one foot in front of the other. As you land, cross your feet back together. Repeat this motion in a rhythmic manner for a set number of reps.

Title: Traveling thigh killa
Desc: The traveling thigh killa is a challenging lower-body bodyweight exercise that builds muscular endurance with a series of hops forward and backward, as well as bodyweight squats. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a circuit workout or as a lower-body finisher.
HowTo: Begin standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Perform a squat, then jump forward, landing softly. After landing, immediately perform a squat and jump backward to the starting position. Repeat this sequence for time or a set number of reps.

Title: FYR Thigh Killa
Desc: The thigh killa is a challenging lower-body bodyweight exercise that builds muscular endurance with a series of hops and bodyweight squats. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a circuit workout or as a lower-body finisher.
HowTo: Perform a series of hops followed by bodyweight squats. Repeat for a set time or number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining good form and control.

Title: HM Straddle Stretch
Desc: The HM Straddle Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the inner thighs and hamstrings. To perform this stretch, sit on the floor with your legs extended wide apart. Keep your back straight and lean forward gently, reaching towards your toes or the floor to deepen the stretch.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended wide apart. Keep your back straight and lean forward gently, reaching towards your toes or the floor to deepen the stretch. Hold the position for 15-30 seconds.

Title: HM Right Leg Swing
Desc: The HM Right Leg Swing is a dynamic movement that helps improve hip flexibility and mobility. Stand next to a wall or support, and swing your right leg forward and backward in a controlled manner. Aim for a full range of motion while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Stand next to a wall or support. Swing your right leg forward and backward in a controlled manner, aiming for a full range of motion. Keep your core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: HM Right Side-Kick
Desc: The HM Right Side-Kick is a strength and mobility exercise that targets the hip abductors and glutes. Stand on your left leg and lift your right leg out to the side, keeping it straight. Control the movement as you lower your leg back down.
HowTo: Stand on your left leg and lift your right leg out to the side, keeping it straight. Control the movement as you lower your leg back down. Repeat for a set number of repetitions.

Title: HM Frog Stretch
Desc: The HM Frog Stretch is a deep hip opener that stretches the inner thighs and groin. Start on all fours, then spread your knees wide apart while keeping your feet in line with your knees. Lower your hips back towards your heels to deepen the stretch.
HowTo: Start on all fours, then spread your knees wide apart while keeping your feet in line with your knees. Lower your hips back towards your heels to deepen the stretch. Hold for 15-30 seconds.

Title: HM Kick-Out
Desc: The HM Kick-Out is a dynamic exercise that engages the core and improves hip stability. Start in a standing position, then lift one leg and extend it forward while maintaining balance. Alternate legs for a complete workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Lift one leg and extend it forward while maintaining balance. Alternate legs, ensuring to engage your core and maintain stability throughout the exercise.

Title: HM Left Leg Swing
Desc: The HM Left Leg Swing is similar to the right leg swing, focusing on improving hip mobility. Stand next to a wall for support and swing your left leg forward and backward, ensuring a smooth and controlled motion.
HowTo: Stand next to a wall for support. Swing your left leg forward and backward in a controlled manner, ensuring a smooth motion. Focus on maintaining balance and control.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Adductor
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Adductor is a self-myofascial release technique that targets the inner thigh muscles. Sit on the floor with a foam roller positioned under your inner thigh. Roll slowly back and forth to release tension and improve flexibility.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with a foam roller positioned under your inner thigh. Roll slowly back and forth, applying gentle pressure to release tension and improve flexibility. Spend about 1-2 minutes on each side.

Title: MetaBurn Groiner
Desc: The MetaBurn Groiner is a dynamic exercise that targets the groin and hip flexors while improving flexibility and strength. It involves a deep lunge position with a groin stretch, promoting mobility and stability.
HowTo: Start in a deep lunge position with one foot forward and the other leg extended back. Lower your hips towards the ground to feel a stretch in the groin and hip flexors. Hold the position for a few seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Side-lying leg adduction scissor
Desc: The side-lying leg adduction scissor is a dynamic core exercise that combines the isometric hold of a side-lying leg lift with leg adductions to further challenge the core and adductors. It targets multiple muscles of the core, primarily the rectus abdominis or "six-pack" muscles. It can be performed for time or reps in the ab-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs straight. Lift your top leg towards the ceiling while keeping your bottom leg on the ground. Lower your top leg back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions. You can also add a scissor motion by crossing the top leg over the bottom leg and back.

Title: Groin and Back Stretch
Desc: The Groin and Back Stretch is a gentle exercise designed to enhance flexibility in the groin and lower back areas. It involves stretching the legs apart while leaning forward to alleviate tension and improve range of motion.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs spread apart. Lean forward gently, reaching towards your toes or the ground, while keeping your back straight. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then relax and repeat.

Title: Adductor/Groin
Desc: The Adductor/Groin exercise focuses on strengthening and stretching the adductor muscles located in the inner thigh. This exercise helps improve hip stability and flexibility, making it essential for athletes and active individuals.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to one leg and slowly lift the other leg out to the side, keeping it straight. Hold for a moment, then lower it back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch legs.

Title: Incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle, which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Let your arms hang straight down. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the weights back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Banded biceps curl in squat position
Desc: The banded biceps curl in squat position is an exercise targeting the biceps, although it also works the core and lower body.
HowTo: Stand in a squat position with a resistance band under your feet and held in both hands. Curl the band up towards your shoulders while maintaining the squat position. Lower the band back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Banded Hammer Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
HowTo: Sit at the machine with your back against the pad. Grasp the handles and press them forward until your arms are fully extended. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Band standing concentration curl
Desc: The band standing concentration curl is a variation of a popular biceps-focused exercise utilizing a band instead of a dumbbell. It allows you to focus on one biceps at a time and really squeeze out intense peak contractions. Band concentration curls are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the band secured under one foot. Hold the band with one hand, elbow bent, and curl it towards your shoulder. Focus on squeezing the bicep at the top of the movement. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: Brachialis SMR
Desc: Brachialis self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the biceps or brachialis muscles of the upper arm, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Brachialis SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the triceps muscles or pectorals, or by stretches that target the biceps or pecs.
HowTo: To perform the Brachialis SMR, lie on your back or sit comfortably. Place a foam roller or lacrosse ball under your upper arm, targeting the biceps or brachialis muscle. Apply pressure by leaning into the roller or ball, moving slowly to find tight spots. Hold the pressure on tight areas for 20-30 seconds to help release tension.

Title: Wide-grip barbell curl
Desc: The wide-grip barbell curl is a variation of the classic barbell curl with the grip wider than shoulder width. It is thought that this helps build the inner or "short" head of the biceps muscles. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: To perform the wide-grip barbell curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with your hands wider than shoulder-width. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: EZ-bar spider curl
Desc: The EZ-bar spider curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face down on either an incline bench or on the flat side of a preacher bench. The EZ-bar makes for a more comfortable wrist position, while the angle helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: To perform the EZ-bar spider curl, lie face down on an incline bench with your chest against the pad. Grip the EZ-bar with an underhand grip and let your arms hang straight down. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on isolating the biceps. Lower the bar back down slowly. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Barbell Curl
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: To perform the barbell curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with an underhand grip. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Close-grip EZ-bar curl
Desc: The close-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps, particularly the long head. The main difference between this exercise and standard EZ-bar curls is that the hands are positioned closer together on the bar. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: To perform the close-grip EZ-bar curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the EZ-bar with your hands close together. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, focusing on the outer biceps head. Lower the barbell back down slowly. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Preacher Curl
Desc: The EZ-bar preacher curl is a classic exercise for building bigger biceps. This move is all about isolation. With the back of the upper arms against the pad, it’s next to impossible to cheat. Go light, get a great pump, and build that peak!
HowTo: To perform the preacher curl, sit on a preacher bench with your upper arms resting against the pad. Grip the EZ-bar with an underhand grip and curl the bar towards your shoulders, isolating the biceps. Lower the bar back down slowly, maintaining control. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Barbell Curls Lying Against An Incline
Desc: Barbell curls lying against an incline target the biceps while minimizing the use of momentum. This exercise involves lying back on an incline bench and curling a barbell towards your shoulders, focusing on controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: To perform barbell curls lying against an incline, lie back on an incline bench with a barbell in your hands. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell towards your shoulders, focusing on controlled movements. Lower the barbell back down slowly. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated Close-Grip Concentration Barbell Curl
Desc: The seated close-grip concentration barbell curl is designed to isolate the biceps while providing stability. By sitting down and using a close grip on the barbell, this exercise emphasizes the peak contraction of the biceps, helping to build strength and size.
HowTo: To perform the seated close-grip concentration barbell curl, sit on a bench and grip the barbell with a close grip. Rest your upper arms against your thighs for stability. Curl the barbell towards your shoulders, emphasizing the peak contraction of the biceps. Lower the barbell back down slowly. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Close-grip barbell curl
Desc: The close-grip barbell curl is a curl variation where the hands are closer than shoulder width. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: To perform the close-grip barbell curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with your hands closer than shoulder width. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell up towards your chest while squeezing your biceps. Lower the barbell back down with control and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Drag curl
Desc: The drag curl is a biceps exercise that attempts to remove the influence of the front deltoids on the classic curl. With the elbows kept back, the barbell "drags" up the torso. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the drag curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with an underhand grip. Keep your elbows back and close to your body as you curl the barbell up along your torso, dragging it upwards. Focus on using your biceps to lift the weight, and lower it back down with control. Perform for 8-15 reps.

Title: Reverse-grip barbell curl
Desc: The reverse-grip barbell curl is a variation on the biceps curl where the palms face downward. The switch from an underhand to an overhand grip brings the forearm and brachialis muscles more into the exercise. If it is uncomfortable to the wrists, try performing it on the angles of an EZ-curl bar.
HowTo: To perform the reverse-grip barbell curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down). Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, focusing on contracting your biceps and forearms. Lower the barbell back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying High Bench Barbell Curl
Desc: The Lying High Bench Barbell Curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. It involves lying on a high bench while curling a barbell, which helps to emphasize the peak of the biceps and minimize the use of momentum.
HowTo: To perform the lying high bench barbell curl, lie back on a high bench with your feet flat on the ground. Grip the barbell with an underhand grip and curl it towards your forehead, focusing on isolating your biceps. Avoid using momentum and control the weight as you lower it back down. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl
Desc: The seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl is a variation on the classic seated dumbbell curl. It is thought that wide-grip curls target the inner head of the biceps more, while close-grip curls target the outer head or peak. This variation allows you to get the benefits of both.
HowTo: To perform the seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl, sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Start with a wide grip and perform a curl, focusing on the inner head of the biceps. After completing the desired reps, switch to a close grip and perform another set of curls to target the outer head of the biceps. Alternate between grips for the desired number of sets.

Title: Seated Straigh-Bar Curl Superset
Desc: The seated wide-grip curl to close-grip curl is a variation on the classic seated dumbbell curl. The variation is that the range of motion changes in alternating fashion—one more traditional, one where you’re bringing the weight in more from the side.
HowTo: To perform the seated straight-bar curl superset, sit on a bench with a straight barbell. Start with a traditional curl, bringing the barbell up towards your shoulders. After completing the desired reps, switch to a side grip and curl the barbell in a more lateral motion, targeting different angles of the biceps. Alternate between these two styles for the desired number of sets.

Title: Dave Draper Forehead Curl
Desc: The Dave Draper Forehead Curl is a variation of the bicep curl that focuses on the biceps brachii. In this exercise, the lifter curls a barbell or dumbbells towards their forehead, promoting peak contraction and muscle growth.
HowTo: To perform the Dave Draper Forehead Curl, stand or sit with a barbell or dumbbells. Curl the weight towards your forehead, keeping your elbows stationary and focusing on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. Lower the weight back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse-grip EZ-bar curl
Desc: The reverse-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and forearms. Because grip strength is a limitation with this move, it is often performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the reverse-grip EZ-bar curl, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the EZ-bar with an overhand grip. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, focusing on your biceps and forearms. Lower the barbell back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: EZ-Bar Spider Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The EZ-bar spider curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps and performed face-down on an incline bench. The EZ-bar makes for a more comfortable wrist position.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a comfortable angle. 2. Lie face down on the bench with your chest against it. 3. Hold the EZ-bar with an underhand grip, arms extended towards the floor. 4. Curl the bar towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 5. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Barbell curl-
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and your back straight. 3. Curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top. 4. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Curl
Desc: The barbell curl is an arm exercise that is also one of the most recognizable movements in all of bodybuilding and fitness. It helps build sleeve-popping biceps and allows heavier loading than many other curl variations. It is usually performed in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of the arm-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and your back straight. 3. Curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, focusing on contracting your biceps. 4. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. 5. Perform 8-12 reps as part of your arm workout.

Title: Standing band biceps curl
Desc: The standing band biceps curl is an arm-focused exercise using a band for resistance. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an arms-focused or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band with both hands. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and your palms facing up. 3. Curl the band towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top. 4. Slowly lower the band back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for moderate to high reps.
