Title: Close-Grip EZ-Bar Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The close-grip EZ-bar curl is an exercise targeting the biceps, particularly the long head. The main difference between this exercise and standard barbell curls is that the hands are positioned closer together on the bar. It is thought that this helps build the outer biceps head and the peak. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with a close grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and your back straight. 3. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on the contraction of the outer biceps head. 4. Lower the bar back down in a controlled manner. 5. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated Barbell Curl
Desc: The Seated Barbell Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the biceps. It is performed while seated, using a barbell to curl the weight towards your shoulders, focusing on maintaining proper form and control throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and your feet flat on the ground. 3. Curl the barbell towards your shoulders while keeping your upper arms stationary. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top, then lower the barbell back down. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Standing Barbell Curl
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is an immenselyp popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and your back straight. 3. Curl the barbell up towards your shoulders, focusing on your biceps. 4. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. 5. Perform for moderate to high reps.

Title: EZ-bar preacher curl
Desc: The EZ-bar preacher curl is a classic exercise for building bigger biceps. This move is all about isolation. With the back of the upper arms against the pad, it's next to impossible to use momentum which forces the muscles to work harder.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a preacher bench, resting your upper arms against the pad. 2. Hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip, arms fully extended. 3. Curl the bar towards your face, keeping your upper arms against the pad. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top, then lower the bar back down slowly. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Barbell Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Barbell Curl is a strength training exercise that targets the biceps. It involves standing while holding a barbell with both hands, curling the weight towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the barbell towards your chest, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Incline Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Incline Biceps Curl is performed on an incline bench, which helps isolate the biceps. You hold dumbbells in each hand and curl them upwards while keeping your back against the bench.
HowTo: Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your back against the bench and let your arms hang down. Curl the dumbbells upwards towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bicep Curls "21s"
Desc: Bicep Curls '21s' is a unique bicep exercise that consists of performing 7 half curls from the bottom to the halfway point, 7 half curls from the halfway point to the top, and then 7 full curls.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell or dumbbells. Perform 7 half curls from the bottom to the halfway point, then 7 half curls from the halfway point to the top, and finally 7 full curls from the bottom to the top. This completes one set.

Title: Incline Hammer Curls
Desc: Incline Hammer Curls are performed on an incline bench with dumbbells held in a neutral grip. This variation targets the brachialis and brachioradialis muscles in addition to the biceps.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Hammer Curls
Desc: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls are done on an incline bench, focusing on the flexor muscles of the forearm and biceps. The neutral grip helps to engage different muscle fibers compared to traditional curls.
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat.

Title: Biceps curl to shoulder press
Desc: The biceps curl to shoulder press is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the biceps and shoulders or deltoids. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit two crucial upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a bicep curl by lifting the dumbbells towards your shoulders. Once at the top, press the dumbbells overhead into a shoulder press. Lower the dumbbells back down to the shoulders and then back to the starting position. Repeat.

Title: Concentration curl
Desc: The concentration curl is a classic exercise for building the biceps one arm at a time. It can be performed bent over or kneeling, but is more often performed seated on a bench. It's great for emphasizing the biceps peak and is often used to finish a biceps workout. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your legs spread. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and rest your elbow against the inside of your thigh. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on squeezing the bicep at the top. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat for the desired reps before switching arms.

Title: Flexor Incline Dumbbell Curls
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing up. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Bicep Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your torso, curl the weights while contracting your biceps. 3. Raise the dumbbells until your biceps are fully contracted and the dumbbells are at shoulder level. 4. Hold the contracted position for a moment, then slowly lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Cross-body hammer curl
Desc: The cross-body hammer curl is a dumbbell exercise that targets the biceps, brachialis, and forearm muscles. Rather than lifting the weights directly in front of the body, you lift them across the torso. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. This helps isolate the brachialis muscles on each arm. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, lift one dumbbell across your body towards the opposite shoulder. 3. Ensure your wrist remains neutral throughout the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat with the other arm.

Title: Dumbbell Alternate Bicep Curl
Desc: The alternating biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps one arm at a time. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended at your sides. 2. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm stationary. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat with the opposite arm. 4. Alternate arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell preacher curl
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell preacher curl is an exercise that focuses on building the biceps, particularly the biceps peak. Most people will go light on this movement, performing it for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a preacher bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Rest your upper arm on the bench and let the dumbbell hang down. 3. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on contracting your biceps. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Alternate Incline Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 rep per arm or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above you. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing concentration curl
Desc: The standing concentration curl is a variation on the more common seated concentration curl, which is a staple of bodybuilding arm routines. It can serve as a substitute for preacher curl variations if a preacher bench is unavailable and is also a classic way to focus in on the biceps peak. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on strict form and controlled tempo.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, arm fully extended. 2. Keep your elbow stationary and curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder. 3. Focus on a slow and controlled movement, squeezing your biceps at the top. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The alternating incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face up on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 rep per arm or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above you. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while the other remains stationary. 3. Alternate arms for each repetition, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position after each curl.

Title: Alternate Hammer Curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Keeping your wrists neutral, curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm stationary. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position and repeat with the opposite arm. 4. Alternate arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The seated dumbbell biceps curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. While curls can effectively be performed standing as well, performing them seated can enforce strict form and perhaps boost the mind-muscle connection. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the ground. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms fully extended and palms facing forward. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The Preacher Hammer Dumbbell Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the biceps, particularly the brachialis and brachioradialis muscles. It is performed by sitting on a preacher bench and curling a dumbbell with both hands, keeping the upper arms stationary to maximize tension on the biceps.
HowTo: Sit on a preacher bench with your upper arms resting against the pad. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your upper arms stationary. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell preacher curl
Desc: The dumbbell preacher curl is an exercise that focuses on building the biceps, particularly the biceps peak. All you need is a pair of dumbbells and a preacher bench. It's usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: Sit on a preacher bench with your upper arms resting against the pad. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing up. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders, focusing on squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The Lying Supine Dumbbell Curl is a variation of the traditional dumbbell curl performed while lying on your back. This position helps to isolate the biceps and minimize the use of momentum. The exercise is performed by holding a dumbbell in each hand and curling them towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Lie on your back on a flat bench or the floor. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms extended above your chest. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Reverse Curl
Desc: With the reverse-grip dumbbell curl, the palms face down, not up. This unorthodox wrist position simultaneously targets the biceps while also building forearm and grip strength. The move can performed standing or seated.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing down. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Palms-out incline biceps curl
Desc: The palms-out incline biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps. It is largely similar to the incline dumbbell curl, but the palms-out position targets the long head of the biceps, which is responsible for the biceps "peak." This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with your back against the pad. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing outwards. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Straight-arm plank with biceps curl
Desc: The straight-arm plank with biceps curl is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and biceps muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing an additional cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: Start in a straight-arm plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Hold a dumbbell in each hand. While maintaining the plank position, curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder, keeping your elbow close to your body. Lower it back down and alternate arms for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Face-down incline dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The face-down incline dumbbell biceps curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face down on an incline bench. This creates a vertical arm angle, which helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with your arms hanging down. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing up. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Inner Biceps Curl
Desc: The Seated Dumbbell Inner Biceps Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the inner part of the biceps. It is performed while seated, using dumbbells to enhance muscle engagement and minimize momentum.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended and palms facing inward. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Standing Inner-Biceps Curl
Desc: The Standing Inner-Biceps Curl is a variation of the biceps curl that focuses on the inner biceps. This exercise is performed standing, allowing for a greater range of motion and engagement of stabilizing muscles.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended and palms facing inward. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Focus on squeezing the biceps at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Seated hammer curl
Desc: The seated hammer curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps and forearms. The movement resembles hammering a nail—hence the name. While curls can effectively be performed standing as well, performing them seated can enforce strict form and perhaps boost the mind-muscle connection. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the weights back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Paul Carter Incline Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended and palms facing forward. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. Squeeze the biceps at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Concentration Curl
Desc: The concentration curl is a classic exercise for building the biceps one arm at a time. It can be performed bent over or kneeling, but is more often performed seated on a bench. It's great for emphasizing the biceps peak and is often used to finish a biceps workout. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, resting your elbow against your inner thigh. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction of the biceps. Lower the weight back down slowly and repeat for the desired reps before switching arms.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended at your sides. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the weights back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Dumbbell biceps curl to upright row
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl to upright row is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the biceps, traps, and the middle head of the deltoids. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit multiple upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: Start with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Perform a biceps curl to bring the weights up to your shoulders, then transition into an upright row by lifting the dumbbells towards your chin, keeping them close to your body. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Hammer Curl
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while keeping your wrists neutral. Lower the weights back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Dumbbell overhead hold with single-arm curl
Desc: The dumbbell overhead hold with single-arm curl combines an isometric overhead hold with a curl for the other arm. The two movements collectively target the muscles of the shoulders and arms, while providing a surprising core challenge. Expect to be challenged, even with light weight.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended overhead. 2. With the other arm, perform a bicep curl. 3. Keep your core engaged and maintain balance. 4. Switch arms after completing the desired reps.

Title: FYR Kneeling Biceps
Desc: The kneeling concentration curl allows you to target the biceps without having the ability to use momentum from the rest of your body to move the weight.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the floor with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Keep your elbow close to your body and curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Lunge hold dumbbell curl
Desc: The lunge hold dumbbell curl is a challenging complex that combines an isometric hold at the bottom of a lunge with a dumbbell biceps curl. The two exercises combine to target the legs, core, and biceps. The curl will determine the amount of weight you can use, but even a light weight will make the lunge hold seriously challenging.
HowTo: 1. Start in a lunge position with one leg forward and the other leg back, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower into the lunge while keeping your back straight and core engaged. 3. At the bottom of the lunge, perform a bicep curl with both arms. 4. Hold the lunge for a moment before returning to the starting position.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. 2. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Alternating dumbbell snatch
Desc: The alternating dumbbell snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. Performing it by alternating arms gives each arm the chance to recover, allowing you to do a greater amount of quality work. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower the dumbbell to the ground between your feet in a squat position. 3. Explosively lift the dumbbell overhead while standing up, switching arms at the top. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, alternating arms.

Title: TBS Incline Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Let your arms hang straight down, palms facing up. 3. Curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows stationary. 4. Squeeze at the top and lower back down slowly. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Hammer Curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides, palms facing each other. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Maintain a neutral wrist position throughout the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse-grip dumbbell curl
Desc: With the reverse-grip dumbbell curl, the palms face down, not up. This unorthodox wrist position simultaneously targets the biceps while also building forearm and grip strength. The move can be performed standing or seated. Because grip is a limiting factor, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing down. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the dumbbells towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell biceps curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps. This variation targets the long head of the biceps more than a traditional curl and there is more overall tension to this muscle.
HowTo: 1. Sit back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Hammer curl
Desc: The hammer curl is a dumbbell movement that focuses on the biceps, brachialis, and forearm muscles. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing each other. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while maintaining a neutral wrist position. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The seated dumbbell biceps curl is a standard exercise for building bigger biceps. While dumbbell biceps curls can be performed standing, this version involves sitting on a bench.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then slowly lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Hammer Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing each other. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders without rotating your wrists. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm seated dumbbell curl
Desc: The single-arm seated dumbbell curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. Performing it one arm at a time may allow you to use slightly heavier weight, while focusing on really feeling the mind-muscle connection in the working arm. Like most curl variations, these are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, the other arm resting at your side. 2. Keeping your elbow close to your body, curl the dumbbell up towards your shoulder. 3. Squeeze at the top, then lower the weight back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Lying Cable Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying cable biceps curl is an isolation exercise that eliminates the possibility of using momentum from the lower body to raise the weight.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench face up with a cable attachment set at the lowest position. 2. Grab the cable handle with one hand and extend your arm fully. 3. Keeping your elbow stationary, curl the cable handle towards your shoulder. 4. Squeeze at the top, then slowly lower the handle back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell biceps curl
Desc: The dumbbell biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended down at your sides. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: Seated Biceps Hammer Curl
Desc: The Seated Biceps Hammer Curl is an effective exercise for targeting the biceps and forearms. To perform this exercise, sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the floor. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing each other. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the weights up towards your shoulders, then slowly lower them back to the starting position. This exercise helps build strength and size in the biceps while also engaging the brachialis and brachioradialis muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the floor, holding a dumbbell in each hand with palms facing each other. 2. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders. 3. Squeeze at the top, then slowly lower the weights back to the starting position.

Title: HM Alternating Reverse Lunge With Biceps Curl
Desc: The HM Alternating Reverse Lunge with Biceps Curl is a compound exercise that targets the legs and arms. Begin in a standing position, holding weights at your sides. Step back with one leg into a lunge while simultaneously curling the weights up towards your shoulders. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with weights at your sides. Step back with one leg into a reverse lunge while curling the weights towards your shoulders. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: AM Hammer Curls
Desc: This curl is performed simultaneously with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Keeping your wrists neutral, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders simultaneously, then lower them back down.

Title: AM Seated Hammer Curls
Desc: The seated hammer curl is a popular exercise for building bigger biceps. The movement resembles hammering a nail—hence the name. While hammer can be performed standing, this version involves sitting on a bench.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Keeping your wrists neutral, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, then lower them back down.

Title: Seated alternating biceps curl
Desc: The seated alternating biceps curl is an exercise that builds bigger and stronger biceps. The alternating technique allows one arm to rest briefly while the other arm lifts. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Alternately curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, allowing one arm to rest while the other lifts.

Title: Alternating hammer curl
Desc: The alternating hammer curl is performed with dumbbells but without wrist supination. Throughout each rep, the wrists remain neutral, like a carpenter hammering a nail. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Keeping your wrists neutral, alternate curling the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, then lower them back down.

Title: Alternating biceps curl
Desc: The alternating biceps curl is a single-joint exercise for building bigger and stronger biceps one arm at a time. Popular among gym goers of all experience levels, this move can be done seated or standing. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Alternately curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Holman Slow Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Slow Biceps Curl focuses on building strength in the biceps. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Slowly curl the weights up towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the weights back down in a controlled manner.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Slowly curl the weights up towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Holman Biceps Curl to Chest Punch
Desc: The Holman Biceps Curl to Chest Punch combines a biceps curl with a punching motion. Start by holding dumbbells at your sides. Perform a biceps curl, bringing the weights to your shoulders, then punch forward with both arms, extending them fully. Return to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: Start by holding dumbbells at your sides. Perform a biceps curl to bring the weights to your shoulders, then punch forward with both arms, extending them fully. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Right Arm Heavy Biceps Curl
Desc: Perform the Holman Right Arm Heavy Biceps Curl by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

Title: Holman Left Arm Heavy Biceps Curl
Desc: Perform the Holman Left Arm Heavy Biceps Curl by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement.

Title: Holman Alternating Front Lunge Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Alternating Front Lunge Biceps Curl combines a lunge with a biceps curl. Step forward with one leg into a lunge while simultaneously curling a dumbbell in the opposite hand towards your shoulder. Alternate sides with each repetition.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward with one leg into a lunge while simultaneously curling a dumbbell in the opposite hand towards your shoulder. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: Holman Weighted Double-Time Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Weighted Double-Time Biceps Curl involves performing biceps curls at a faster pace while holding weights. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and curl both dumbbells simultaneously, focusing on maintaining form and control.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in each hand. Curl both dumbbells simultaneously at a faster pace, focusing on maintaining form and control throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Heavy Right Arm Biceps Curl
Desc: Perform the Holman Heavy Right Arm Biceps Curl by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a heavy dumbbell in your right hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, ensuring your elbow remains stationary.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a heavy dumbbell in your right hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, ensuring your elbow remains stationary throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Heavy Left Arm Biceps Curl
Desc: Perform the Holman Heavy Left Arm Biceps Curl by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a heavy dumbbell in your left hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, ensuring your elbow remains stationary.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a heavy dumbbell in your left hand. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, ensuring your elbow remains stationary throughout the movement.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Drag Curl
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Drag Curl is performed by holding a dumbbell in each hand and dragging the weights up along your body as you curl. Keep your elbows tucked in and focus on engaging your biceps throughout the movement.
HowTo: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and drag the weights up along your body as you curl. Keep your elbows tucked in and focus on engaging your biceps throughout the movement.

Title: MetaBurn Hammer Curl to Overhead Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Hammer Curl to Overhead Press starts with a hammer curl position, palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells to shoulder height, then press them overhead, extending your arms fully before lowering back to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a hammer curl position with palms facing each other. Curl the dumbbells to shoulder height, then press them overhead, extending your arms fully before lowering back to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn Biceps Curl To Lateral Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn Biceps Curl To Lateral Raise combines a biceps curl with a lateral raise to target both the biceps and shoulders, enhancing upper body strength and coordination.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a biceps curl by bending your elbows and lifting the weights towards your shoulders. As you lower the weights, transition into a lateral raise by lifting the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. Alternate between the two movements.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Dumbbell Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Dumbbell Curl is a classic exercise that targets the biceps by alternating curls with each arm, promoting muscle balance and strength.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm at your side. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat with the other arm. Continue alternating arms.

Title: FYR2 Pulse Biceps Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Pulse Biceps Curl focuses on the biceps by performing small, controlled pulses at the top of the curl, increasing time under tension for muscle growth.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Perform a biceps curl, but instead of fully lowering the weights, stop just before your arms are fully extended and pulse the weights up and down in small movements at the top of the curl.

Title: FYR2 Seesaw Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Seesaw Dumbbell Biceps Curl involves a seesaw motion between both arms, allowing for continuous engagement of the biceps and improving muscle endurance.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while simultaneously lowering the other dumbbell. Alternate the motion in a seesaw fashion, ensuring continuous engagement of the biceps.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Biceps Curl
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Biceps Curl is performed with one dumbbell, allowing for unilateral training that helps to correct muscle imbalances in the arms.
HowTo: Stand with one dumbbell in one hand at your side. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction of the bicep. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat. Switch arms after completing the desired repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Curl-Row Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Curl-Row Complex combines a bicep curl with a bent-over row, effectively targeting both the biceps and back muscles in one fluid movement.
HowTo: Start by holding a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a biceps curl to lift the weights towards your shoulders. After the curl, hinge at your hips and bend over slightly, then perform a row by pulling the dumbbells towards your torso. Alternate between the curl and the row.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Dumbbell Hammer Curl 21s
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Dumbbell Hammer Curl 21s is a variation that combines hammer curls and traditional curls in a 21-rep format, targeting the biceps and forearms.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. Perform 7 hammer curls (lifting the weights to shoulder height), followed by 7 traditional biceps curls (palms facing up), and then finish with 7 more hammer curls. This completes one set of 21s.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Biceps Curl is a straightforward exercise that focuses on building bicep strength and size through a series of controlled curls.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders in a controlled manner. Lower the weights back down slowly and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Alternating Hammer Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Alternating Hammer Curl is an exercise that targets the biceps and forearms. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down and alternate with the other arm.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down. Alternate with the other arm.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Alternating Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Alternating Biceps Curl focuses on building bicep strength. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand. Curl one arm up towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm down, then switch arms in a controlled manner.
HowTo: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand. Curl one arm up towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm down, then switch arms in a controlled manner.

Title: 30 Arms Single-Arm Hammer Preacher Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Single-Arm Hammer Preacher Curl isolates the biceps and forearms. Sit at a preacher bench and hold a dumbbell in one hand. With your upper arm resting on the bench, curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Sit at a preacher bench and hold a dumbbell in one hand. With your upper arm resting on the bench, curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, then lower it back down.

Title: 30 Arms Single-Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Single-Arm Dumbbell Preacher Curl is designed to target the biceps. Sit on a preacher bench with a dumbbell in one hand. Curl the weight towards your shoulder while keeping your upper arm stationary against the bench.
HowTo: Sit on a preacher bench with a dumbbell in one hand. Curl the weight towards your shoulder while keeping your upper arm stationary against the bench.

Title: 30 Arms Seated Dumbbell Concentration Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Seated Dumbbell Concentration Curl is an effective exercise for building bicep mass. Sit on a bench, spread your legs, and rest one arm against your inner thigh. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction.
HowTo: Sit on a bench, spread your legs, and rest one arm against your inner thigh. Curl the dumbbell towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction.

Title: 30 Arms Seated Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Seated Biceps Curl is a fundamental exercise for bicep development. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Curl both dumbbells simultaneously towards your shoulders, then lower them back down.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Curl both dumbbells simultaneously towards your shoulders, then lower them back down.

Title: 30 Arms Seated Alternating Biceps Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Seated Alternating Biceps Curl targets the biceps while providing stability. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm down, then alternate.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Curl one dumbbell towards your shoulder while keeping the other arm down, then alternate arms.

Title: 30 Arms Incline Hammer Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Incline Hammer Curl focuses on the biceps and forearms. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging down. Curl the weights up towards your shoulders with a neutral grip, then lower them back down.
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging down. Curl the weights up towards your shoulders with a neutral grip, then lower them back down.

Title: 30 Arms Incline Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The 30 Arms Incline Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps. By lying on an incline bench and extending the dumbbells overhead, you can isolate the triceps muscles and improve strength.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Extend your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. Slowly lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Hammer Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Hammer Curl is a bicep exercise that targets both the biceps and forearms. By holding the dumbbells with a neutral grip and curling them towards your shoulders, you can build muscle and enhance grip strength.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides and palms facing each other. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders while maintaining the neutral grip.

Title: Reverse Plate Curls
Desc: Reverse Plate Curls are a variation of the traditional bicep curl that emphasizes the brachialis and forearm muscles. By holding a weight plate with both hands and curling it towards your chest, you engage different muscle fibers for balanced arm development.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands in front of you. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the plate towards your chest, squeezing your biceps at the top.

Title: Standing Biceps Stretch
Desc: The Standing Biceps Stretch is a flexibility exercise that helps to elongate the biceps and improve range of motion. By extending your arms behind you and gently pulling, you can relieve tension and enhance muscle recovery.
HowTo: Stand tall and extend your arms straight behind you, palms facing up. Gently pull your arms back to feel a stretch in your biceps, holding the position for a few seconds.

Title: Suspended Curl
Desc: Suspended Curls are a unique exercise that utilizes suspension training to engage the biceps while also activating the core. By performing curls with your hands in suspension straps, you challenge stability and strength simultaneously.
HowTo: Adjust the suspension straps to a suitable height. Stand facing the anchor point, grab the straps, and lean back slightly. Pull your hands towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Plate hammer curl
Desc: The plate hammer curl is an exercise that targets the long head of the biceps as well as the brachialis and brachioradialis muscles. Typically hammer curls are done with dumbbells, but in this case, holding a weight plate places the hands in the same neutral position.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands at your sides. Keeping your elbows close to your body, curl the plate up towards your shoulders, maintaining a neutral grip.

Title: Barbell spider curl
Desc: The barbell spider curl is an exercise targeting the biceps and performed face down on either an incline bench or on the flat side of a preacher bench. The vertical bench angle helps to isolate the biceps and limit involvement of the shoulder muscles. This curl variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or arm-focused training.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench or preacher bench, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. Keeping your elbows stationary, curl the barbell towards your forehead, squeezing your biceps at the top.

Title: Barbell forehead curl
Desc: The barbell forehead curl is a classic movement from the Golden Age of bodybuilding and is often associated with Dave "The Blond Bomber" Draper. The barbell is brought up to your forehead instead of to your chest, emphasizing the squeeze and peak contraction. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. Raise the barbell towards your forehead, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your biceps at the peak of the movement.

Title: Overhead cable curl
Desc: Also known as a crucifix curl, the overhead cable curl is a biceps-focused exercise performed between two cable stacks, using a pair of D-handles. The arms and elbows are held at shoulder height throughout the movement, and both hands curl in toward the ears. This position is designed to eliminate shoulder involvement and momentum, while targeting the biceps peak. This movement is generally done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with two cable stacks and attach D-handles to the cables. 2. Stand between the stacks and grasp a handle in each hand, with your arms extended out to the sides at shoulder height. 3. Keep your elbows stationary and curl the handles in towards your ears, focusing on contracting your biceps. 4. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing One-Arm Cable Curl
Desc: The single-arm cable biceps curl is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the biceps. This move is intended to be strict and deliberate; this is not an exercise for using momentum or otherwise cheating.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a single cable and attach a handle. 2. Stand next to the machine and grasp the handle with one hand, keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Curl the handle towards your shoulder, focusing on using your bicep without swinging or using momentum. 4. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Reverse Cable Curl
Desc: The Reverse Cable Curl is an exercise that targets the biceps and forearms. It is performed using a cable machine, where you stand facing away from the machine and curl the cable handle towards your forehead, emphasizing the contraction of the biceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cable handle in one hand. 2. With your elbow close to your body, curl the handle towards your forehead, keeping your wrist straight. 3. Focus on squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. 4. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing Biceps Cable Curl
Desc: The cable straight-bar biceps curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the standing barbell curl, and replaces the barbell with a handle attached to a cable. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a straight bar attachment. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing up. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on contracting your biceps. 4. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable rope hammer curl
Desc: The cable rope hammer curl is a popular arm-focused exercise performed with a rope handle attached by a cable to a weight stack. It uses a neutral (palms facing one another) grip, which targets the forearms and brachialis muscles in addition to the biceps. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to a cable machine at the lowest setting. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the rope towards your shoulders, focusing on squeezing your biceps and forearms. 4. Slowly lower the rope back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Lying cable biceps curl
Desc: The lying cable biceps curl is a cable exercise that targets the biceps. It is performed lying on the back, either on a bench or the ground, with the feet facing toward a cable stack. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a handle attached to the low pulley. 2. Lie on your back on a bench or the ground, facing the cable stack. 3. Grasp the handle with both hands, arms extended above your head. 4. Curl the handle towards your forehead, keeping your elbows stationary. 5. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable rope preacher hammer curl
Desc: The cable rope preacher hammer curl is a single-joint arm exercise that builds strength and size in the biceps using a cable stack, a preacher bench, and a rope grip. The neutral or "hammer" grip amplifies activation of both the grip and the brachialis muscles, building arm thickness. The angle of the bench also effectively removes the shoulders from the movement, largely isolating the biceps. It is generally performed for higher reps, at least 8-15 per set.
HowTo: 1. Set up a preacher bench in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment. 2. Sit on the bench and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Rest your arms on the preacher bench and curl the rope towards your shoulders, focusing on your biceps. 4. Slowly lower the rope back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: Lying Close-Grip Bar Curl On High Pulley
Desc: The lying high-cable biceps curl is an unusual move for building the biceps—but it’s a highly effective one. Lying prone and curling down toward you provides a different stimulus than more standard approaches allow.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a handle attached to the high pulley. 2. Lie face down on a bench or the ground, positioning yourself so that the cable is above you. 3. Grasp the handle with both hands, arms extended towards the cable. 4. Curl the handle down towards your chest, focusing on contracting your biceps. 5. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable EZ-Bar Preacher Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable preacher curl is a single-joint arm exercise that builds strength and size in the biceps using a cable stack and a preacher bench. It is popular in muscle-building arm workouts because the angle of the bench effectively removes the shoulders from the movement, largely isolating the biceps. It is generally performed for higher reps, at least 8-15 per set.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with an EZ-bar attachment at the low pulley. 2. Adjust the preacher bench so that your upper arms are resting comfortably on the pad. 3. Grasp the EZ-bar with an underhand grip and sit on the bench. 4. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position with control. 6. Repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: Squatting cable EZ-bar biceps curl
Desc: The squatting cable EZ-bar biceps curl is an exercise that builds and strengthens the biceps while the lower body is in a static squat position. It is usually performed for higher rep sets, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, in combination with other curls or arm training. It is most similar in arm positioning to a preacher curl, but has some unique benefits to the lower body, as well.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with an EZ-bar attachment at the low pulley. 2. Stand in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the EZ-bar with an underhand grip, arms extended downwards. 4. While maintaining the squat, curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on contracting your biceps. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable straight-bar biceps curl
Desc: The cable straight-bar biceps curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the standing barbell curl, and replaces the barbell with a handle attached to a cable. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the straight bar with an underhand grip, arms fully extended. 4. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position with control. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing reverse-grip cable curl
Desc: The standing reverse-grip cable curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the reverse barbell curl, and tweaks it by using a handle attached to a cable stack instead. It targets the forearm muscles and brachialis to a greater degree than underhand biceps curl variations. Because grip is a limitation, this move is commonly performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. 2. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the straight bar with an overhand grip, arms extended down. 4. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on using your forearms and brachialis. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Lying high-cable biceps curl
Desc: The lying high-cable biceps curl is a single-joint exercise targeting the biceps in a prone (face-up) position. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a high pulley and attach a handle. 2. Lie face-up on a bench positioned under the cable. 3. Grasp the handle with an underhand grip, arms extended above your head. 4. Curl the handle towards your forehead, squeezing your biceps at the top. 5. Lower the handle back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for moderate to high reps.

Title: High-Pulley Cable Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: Also known as a crucifix curl, the overhead cable curl is a biceps-focused exercise performed between two cable stacks, using a pair of D-handles. The arms and elbows are held at shoulder height throughout the movement, and both hands curl in toward the ears. This position is designed to eliminate shoulder involvement and momentum, while targeting the biceps peak. This movement is generally done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of arm-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set up two cable machines with D-handles attached to high pulleys. 2. Stand between the machines with your arms extended out to the sides at shoulder height. 3. Grasp the handles and curl them in towards your ears, keeping your elbows high. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the handles back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing High Cable Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable straight-bar biceps curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the standing barbell curl, and replaces the barbell with a handle attached to a cable. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. 2. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the straight bar with an underhand grip, arms extended down. 4. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: High Cable Curls
Desc: The lying high-cable biceps curl is a single-joint exercise targeting the biceps in a prone (face-up) position. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a cable machine with a high pulley and attach a handle. 2. Lie face-up on a bench positioned under the cable. 3. Grasp the handle with an underhand grip, arms extended above your head. 4. Curl the handle towards your forehead, squeezing your biceps at the top. 5. Lower the handle back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for moderate to high reps.

Title: Seated cable biceps curl
Desc: The seated cable biceps curl is a single-joint arm exercise intended to isolate the biceps. The seated position helps eliminate the use of momentum. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the floor. Grasp the cable handles with an underhand grip. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the handles towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Lying Close-Grip Bar Curl On High Pulley - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying high-cable biceps curl is an unusual move for building the biceps—but it’s a highly effective one. Lying prone and curling down toward you provides a different stimulus than more standard approaches allow.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench with your head at the edge and grasp the high pulley bar with an underhand grip. Keep your elbows stationary and curl the bar down towards your chest, focusing on contracting the biceps. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Standing Cable Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable straight-bar biceps curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the standing barbell curl, and replaces the barbell with a handle attached to a cable. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip, keeping your elbows close to your sides. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Double Arm Cable Biceps Curl
Desc: The Double Arm Cable Biceps Curl is an effective exercise for targeting the biceps. Stand in the center of a cable machine with a handle in each hand. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the handles towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: Stand in the center of a cable machine with a handle in each hand. Keep your elbows close to your torso and curl the handles towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top of the movement. Slowly lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: AM Cable Biceps Curl
Desc: The cable straight-bar biceps curl takes a classic bodybuilding exercise, the standing barbell curl, and replaces the barbell with a handle attached to a cable. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip, keeping your elbows close to your sides. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable biceps curl
Desc: The single-arm cable biceps curl is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the biceps. This move is intended to be strict and deliberate; this is not an exercise for using momentum or otherwise cheating. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand next to a cable machine with a handle attached at the low pulley. Grasp the handle with one hand and keep your elbow close to your torso. Curl the handle towards your shoulder, focusing on the contraction of the biceps. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat. Switch arms after completing the set.

Title: UP Cable Curl With Straight Bar
Desc: The UP Cable Curl With Straight Bar is designed to isolate the biceps while providing constant tension. Stand facing a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip and curl it towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: Stand facing a cable machine with a straight bar attachment at the low pulley. Grasp the bar with an underhand grip and keep your elbows stationary at your sides. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, focusing on isolating the biceps. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Rope Hammer Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Cable Rope Hammer Curl targets the brachialis and brachioradialis muscles in addition to the biceps. Attach a rope handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the rope with a neutral grip. Curl the rope towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down and repeat.
HowTo: Attach a rope handle to a low pulley on a cable machine. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the rope with a neutral grip. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the rope towards your shoulders, squeezing the biceps at the top. Lower the rope back down and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms Squatting Cable Straight-Bar Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Squatting Cable Straight-Bar Curl combines a squat with a bicep curl using a cable machine, targeting both the lower body and the biceps for a comprehensive workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the cable machine to a suitable height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the straight bar with both hands. 3. Lower into a squat while keeping your back straight and core engaged. 4. As you rise from the squat, curl the bar towards your shoulders, engaging your biceps. 5. Lower the bar back down as you descend into the next squat. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Arms High Cable Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms High Cable Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the biceps, performed by pulling the cable from a high position down towards the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the cable machine to a high position. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the cable handle with both hands. 3. Pull the cable down towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Straight-Bar Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Cable Straight-Bar Curl is a bicep exercise using a cable machine with a straight bar attachment, focusing on building arm strength and size.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the cable machine at the lowest setting. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing up. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and curl the bar towards your shoulders. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Arms Cable Concentration Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Cable Concentration Curl is an isolation exercise that emphasizes the biceps, performed by curling a cable while seated to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a cable machine beside you. 2. Attach a single handle to the cable and adjust it to a low position. 3. Grasp the handle with one hand and rest your elbow on your inner thigh. 4. Curl the handle towards your shoulder, focusing on your bicep contraction. 5. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: 30 Arms BFR High Cable Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms BFR High Cable Curl utilizes blood flow restriction techniques while performing high cable curls to enhance muscle growth and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Set up the cable machine with the pulley at a high position. 2. Use blood flow restriction bands and place them on your upper arms. 3. Grasp the cable handles and pull them down towards your shoulders. 4. Focus on controlling the movement and squeezing your biceps. 5. Return to the starting position slowly. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, ensuring to use lighter weights.

Title: BFR cable rope hammer curl
Desc: The blood flow restriction (BFR) cable rope hammer curl is an arm movement that builds biceps size and strength using a cable stack, rope grip, and blood flow restriction bands. It is popular in high-rep "pump"-style arm workouts. The bands should be placed as high as possible on your arms, at a tightness of no greater than 8 on a scale of 10. Most BFR workouts recommend using a far lighter weight than usual, perhaps as low as 25-50 percent of a normal working weight.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable stack to a light weight and attach the rope grip. 2. Place the blood flow restriction bands on your arms, ensuring they are tight but not painful. 3. Stand or sit with your arms at your sides, holding the rope grip. 4. Curl the rope towards your shoulders, keeping your elbows close to your body. 5. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 6. Lower the rope back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Machine Bicep Curl
Desc: The Machine Bicep Curl is a strength training exercise that isolates the biceps, performed on a machine designed to provide support and stability during the curl motion.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine seat height so that your arms are comfortable on the support. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with an underhand grip. 3. Keep your elbows stationary and curl the handles towards your shoulders. 4. Squeeze your biceps at the top of the movement. 5. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Machine Preacher Curls
Desc: The machine preacher curl is an isolation exercise targeting the biceps.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the preacher curl machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place your upper arms on the preacher pad. 3. Grasp the handles with an underhand grip. 4. Curl the handles towards your shoulders, focusing on your biceps. 5. Squeeze at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm machine preacher curl
Desc: The single-arm machine preacher curl is a popular exercise to build size and strength in the biceps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight preacher curl, but uses a selectorized weight stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines offer different grips and grip widths. Machine biceps curls are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit at the preacher curl machine and adjust the seat height so that your upper arms rest comfortably on the padded surface. Grasp the handles or bar with one arm, keeping your elbow close to your body. Curl the weight upward by flexing your elbow, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine preacher curl
Desc: The machine preacher curl is a popular exercise to build size and strength in the biceps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight preacher curl, but uses a selectorized weight stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines offer different grips and grip widths. Machine biceps curls are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit at the preacher curl machine and adjust the seat height so that your upper arms rest comfortably on the padded surface. Grasp the handles or bar with both hands, keeping your elbows close to your body. Curl the weight upward by flexing your elbows, squeezing your biceps at the top of the movement. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine drag curl
Desc: The Smith machine drag curl is a biceps-focused exercise using the bar in a Smith machine. It is usually trained in moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 reps per set, and can work in the biceps-focused portion of any workout.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. Stand facing the bar and grasp it with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. Step back and position your body so that your elbows are close to your sides. Curl the bar up towards your chest by flexing your elbows, keeping your elbows stationary. Lower the bar back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Arms BFR Machine Preacher Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms BFR Machine Preacher Curl is an exercise designed to isolate and strengthen the biceps using blood flow restriction techniques. This exercise is performed on a preacher curl machine, where the arms are supported on a padded surface, allowing for a focused contraction of the biceps.
HowTo: Adjust the preacher curl machine to fit your height. Secure the blood flow restriction bands around your upper arms. Sit down and place your arms on the padded surface. Grasp the handles or bar and curl the weight upward, focusing on contracting your biceps. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated Biceps
Desc: The Seated Biceps exercise targets the biceps brachii while seated, providing stability and allowing for a full range of motion. This exercise can be performed with dumbbells or a barbell, focusing on controlled movements to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms fully extended at your sides. Keep your back straight and core engaged. Curl the dumbbells up towards your shoulders by flexing your elbows, squeezing your biceps at the top. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position in a controlled manner and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Chin-Up
Desc: The a chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body, in an underhand position, with a grip that is narrower than shoulder-width. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand pull-ups. It can be used as a more shoulder-friendly alternative to straight-bar pull-ups, or to help perform more reps than you can perform overhand.
HowTo: Grip the chin-up bar with your palms facing you and your hands closer than shoulder-width apart. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended. Pull your body up towards the bar by bending your elbows and squeezing your biceps, until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Pull-up - Gethin Variation
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of “relative strength” which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: Grip the pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you and hands shoulder-width apart. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended. Pull your body up towards the bar by bending your elbows and engaging your upper back and biceps, until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UN Pull-Up Supinated
Desc: The UN Pull-Up Supinated is a variation of the traditional pull-up, performed with an underhand grip. This exercise primarily targets the biceps and the upper back, promoting strength and muscle development in the pulling motion.
