HowTo: Grip the pull-up bar with your palms facing you in an underhand grip. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended. Pull your body up towards the bar by bending your elbows, focusing on using your biceps and upper back, until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UN Pull-Up Pronated
Desc: The UN Pull-Up Pronated is an upper body exercise that targets the back, biceps, and shoulders. It involves pulling the body up towards a bar with a pronated (overhand) grip, emphasizing the latissimus dorsi and improving upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start by grasping the pull-up bar with a pronated (overhand) grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Hang with your arms fully extended and your body straight. 3. Engage your core and pull your body up towards the bar, focusing on using your back muscles. 4. Continue pulling until your chin is above the bar. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position with control.

Title: UN Pull-Up Neutral
Desc: The UN Pull-Up Neutral is an upper body exercise that targets the back and biceps. It involves pulling the body up towards a bar with a neutral (palms facing each other) grip, which can reduce strain on the shoulders and emphasize the brachialis.
HowTo: 1. Begin by gripping the pull-up bar with a neutral grip (palms facing each other), hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Hang with your arms fully extended and your body straight. 3. Engage your core and pull your body up towards the bar, focusing on your biceps and back. 4. Pull until your chin is above the bar. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Title: EZ-Bar Curl
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is an immensely popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright while holding the EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing up, and hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and your back straight. 3. Curl the bar upward by bending your elbows, focusing on contracting your biceps. 4. Lift the bar until your biceps are fully contracted and the bar is at shoulder level. 5. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Reverse Barbell Preacher Curls
Desc: The reverse-grip barbell curl is a variation on the biceps curl where the palms face downward. The switch from an underhand to an overhand grip brings the forearm and brachialis muscles more into the exercise. If it is uncomfortable to the wrists, try performing it on the angles of an EZ-curl bar.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a preacher bench and grasp the barbell with an overhand grip (palms facing down). 2. Rest your arms on the preacher pad, keeping your elbows in line with your shoulders. 3. Curl the barbell upward by bending your elbows, focusing on your forearms and brachialis. 4. Raise the bar until your forearms are vertical. 5. Lower the bar back down to the starting position with control.

Title: Close-Grip EZ-Bar Curl with Band
Desc: The Close-Grip EZ-Bar Curl with Band is a bicep exercise that focuses on the brachialis and biceps brachii. By using an EZ-bar and a resistance band, this exercise enhances muscle engagement and provides additional tension throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright and hold the EZ-bar with a close grip (hands shoulder-width apart). 2. Attach a resistance band to the bar for added tension. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and your back straight. 4. Curl the bar upward by bending your elbows, focusing on your biceps and brachialis. 5. Lift until your biceps are fully contracted, then lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: Standing EZ-Bar Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is an immenselyp popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing up. 2. Keep your elbows close to your sides and your back straight. 3. Curl the bar upward while contracting your biceps, ensuring your elbows remain stationary. 4. Raise the bar until your biceps are fully contracted. 5. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: TBS EZ-Bar Curl
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is an immenselyp popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing up. 2. Keep your elbows close to your body and maintain a straight back. 3. Curl the bar upward by bending your elbows, focusing on your biceps. 4. Lift the bar until your biceps are fully contracted. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Title: Standing EZ-bar curl
Desc: The standing EZ-bar curl is a popular exercise targeting the biceps. It is commonly performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout. Many gyms even have EZ-bars at fixed weights, allowing for easy weight changes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing up. 2. Keep your elbows close to your sides and your back straight. 3. Curl the bar upward by bending your elbows, focusing on your biceps. 4. Raise the bar until your biceps are fully contracted. 5. Slowly lower the bar back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Standing Overhand EZ-Bar Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing Overhand EZ-Bar Curl is an exercise that targets the biceps and forearms. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an overhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an overhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: 30 Arms EZ-Bar Spider Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms EZ-Bar Spider Curl is a bicep isolation exercise performed on an incline bench. Lie face down on the bench and hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your forehead, squeezing the biceps at the top, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench and hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your forehead, squeezing the biceps at the top, then lower it back down.

Title: 30 Arms EZ-Bar Preacher Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms EZ-Bar Preacher Curl is designed to isolate the biceps. Sit on a preacher bench and hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms stationary, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Sit on a preacher bench and hold an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders, keeping your upper arms stationary, then lower it back down.

Title: 30 Arms Standing EZ-Bar Curl
Desc: The 30 Arms Standing EZ-Bar Curl is a classic bicep exercise. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding an EZ-bar with an underhand grip. Curl the bar towards your shoulders while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Calf Raises - With Bands
Desc: Calf Raises with Bands is an exercise that targets the calf muscles. Stand on a flat surface with a resistance band under the balls of your feet. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, then slowly lower back down.
HowTo: Stand on a flat surface with a resistance band under the balls of your feet. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, then slowly lower back down.

Title: Peroneals Stretch
Desc: The Peroneals Stretch is designed to stretch the peroneal muscles located on the outside of the lower leg. Sit on the floor with one leg extended and the other bent. Gently pull the toes of the extended leg towards you while keeping the knee straight.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with one leg extended and the other bent. Gently pull the toes of the extended leg towards you while keeping the knee straight.

Title: Posterior Tibialis Stretch
Desc: The Posterior Tibialis Stretch targets the posterior tibialis muscle. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Cross one leg behind the other and lean towards the side of the back leg, feeling the stretch along the inner ankle and calf.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Cross one leg behind the other and lean towards the side of the back leg, feeling the stretch along the inner ankle and calf.

Title: Calf SMR
Desc: Calf self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the calf muscles of the lower leg, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Calf SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the quadriceps muscles, or by stretches that target the calves.
HowTo: Use a foam roller or lacrosse ball to apply pressure to the calf muscles. Roll over the tight areas, focusing on any painful spots, to help release tension.

Title: Rocking Standing Calf Raise
Desc: The Rocking Standing Calf Raise is an exercise that targets the calf muscles by raising the heels off the ground while standing, using a rocking motion to engage the muscles effectively.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your heels elevated on a step or platform. Shift your weight onto the balls of your feet and raise your heels as high as possible using a rocking motion, then lower back down.

Title: Standing barbell calf raise
Desc: The Barbell Seated Calf Raise is performed while seated, using a barbell placed across the thighs to add resistance, focusing on building strength in the calf muscles.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. Place a barbell across your thighs. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, then lower back down.

Title: Barbell Seated Calf Raise
Desc: The Calf Raise On A Dumbbell involves standing on a dumbbell to elevate the heels, allowing for a greater range of motion and increased resistance to strengthen the calves.
HowTo: Stand on a dumbbell with your heels hanging off the edge. Raise your heels as high as possible, then lower them back down to maximize the range of motion.

Title: Smith machine standing calf raise
Desc: The Smith machine standing calf raise is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the calves, particularly the gastrocnemius or upper calf muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: Position yourself under the Smith machine bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, then lower back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Calf Raise On A Dumbbell
HowTo: Stand on a dumbbell with your heels hanging off the edge. Raise your heels as high as possible, then lower them back down to maximize the range of motion.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Calf Raise
Desc: The standing dumbbell calf raise is a popular exercise to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, and in particular the gastrocnemius muscles. It can be performed for time or for reps, either two dumbbells, or one if balance is a problem and you would like to use your free hand to hold a fixed object.
HowTo: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, then lower back down.

Title: Single-leg standing dumbbell calf raise
Desc: The single-leg standing dumbbell calf raise is a popular exercise to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the gastrocnemius muscle. It can be performed for time or for reps, either with two dumbbells or with one if balance is a problem and you would like to use your free hand to hold a fixed object.
HowTo: Stand on one leg with a dumbbell in the opposite hand. Raise your heel off the ground by pushing through the ball of your foot, then lower back down. Switch legs after completing the set.

Title: Dumbbell walking calf raise
Desc: The dumbbell walking calf raise is a dynamic exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the gastrocnemius muscle. It can be performed for distance or for reps.
HowTo: Hold a dumbbell in each hand and walk forward on your toes, raising your heels off the ground with each step. Continue for a set distance or number of reps.

Title: Balance Board
Desc: The Balance Board is a versatile training tool used to improve balance, stability, and core strength. It engages various muscle groups and enhances proprioception.
HowTo: Stand on the balance board with feet shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and maintain a slight bend in your knees. Shift your weight from side to side and front to back to improve balance and stability.

Title: Weighted donkey calf raise
Desc: The weighted donkey calk raise is a strength and muscle-building exercise focused on the muscles of the lower leg, most prominently the gastrocnemius muscle. While traditional donkey calf raises involved either a specific machine or carrying another person on one's back, this method uses a weight belt. It can be done in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, or for higher reps as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: Attach a weight belt securely around your waist. Position yourself on all fours, with your hips elevated. Lower your heels towards the ground and then raise them back up, focusing on squeezing your calves at the top of the movement. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Anterior Tibialis-SMR
Desc: The Anterior Tibialis-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) exercise focuses on releasing tension in the anterior tibialis muscle, which is crucial for ankle dorsiflexion and overall lower leg function.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your legs extended. Place a foam roller or massage ball under your anterior tibialis muscle (front of your shin). Gently roll back and forth to release tension for 1-2 minutes.

Title: Foot-SMR
Desc: Foot-SMR is a self-myofascial release technique aimed at relieving tension in the muscles and fascia of the foot, promoting better mobility and reducing pain.
HowTo: Sit comfortably and place a massage ball or foam roller under your foot. Roll the ball or roller back and forth across the arch and heel of your foot for 1-2 minutes to relieve tension.

Title: Agility Ladder
Desc: The Agility Ladder is used for agility training, enhancing foot speed, coordination, and overall athletic performance through various footwork drills.
HowTo: Lay the agility ladder flat on the ground. Perform various footwork drills such as high knees, lateral shuffles, and in-and-out steps, focusing on speed and coordination.

Title: Single-leg machine seated calf raise
Desc: The single-leg machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, but occasionally for higher reps of 20 per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on the calf raise machine with one leg positioned on the platform. Adjust the weight as needed. Push through the ball of your foot to raise your heel as high as possible, then lower back down. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith Machine Calf Raise
Desc: The Smith machine standing calf raise is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the calves, particularly the gastrocnemius or upper calf muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart under the bar. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels, then lower back down. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing Calf Raises
Desc: The standing calf raise is a popular movement to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, and in particular the gastrocnemius muscles. When unweighted, it is usually performed for high reps or for time.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your heels off the ground as high as possible while keeping your knees straight. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. Perform high reps or hold for time.

Title: Seated Calf Raise
Desc: The machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, and occasionally for very high burnout-focused sets of 50-100 total reps.
HowTo: Sit on the seated calf raise machine with your knees under the pads. Position your feet on the platform with the balls of your feet on the edge and your heels hanging off. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible, then lower your heels back down towards the ground. Perform 8-12 reps for moderate to high intensity, or up to 50-100 reps for burnout sets.

Title: Calf Press On The Leg Press Machine
Desc: The leg press calf raise is an exercise that uses the leg press machine to work the calves. With the toes and balls of your feet on the platform but heels off, you push forward to work the calves.
HowTo: Sit on the leg press machine and place the balls of your feet on the platform, ensuring your heels are off. Push the platform away using your calves while keeping your knees slightly bent. Lower the platform back down to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps or more for higher intensity.

Title: Calf Press
Desc: The standing calf raise is a popular movement to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, and in particular the gastrocnemius muscles. When unweighted, it is usually performed for high reps or for time.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet, contracting your calf muscles. Hold the top position briefly, then lower your heels back down. Perform high reps or time-based sets for maximum effectiveness.

Title: Smith Machine Reverse Calf Raises
Desc: The Smith Machine Reverse Calf Raises is an effective exercise targeting the calf muscles, specifically the soleus and gastrocnemius. This exercise is performed on a Smith machine, allowing for a controlled movement. Stand on the platform with your heels hanging off the edge, and lower your heels towards the ground before pushing through the balls of your feet to raise your heels back up. This exercise helps improve calf strength and stability.
HowTo: Stand on the platform of the Smith machine with your heels hanging off the edge. Lower your heels towards the ground in a controlled manner, feeling the stretch in your calves. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels back up to the starting position. Repeat for desired reps.

Title: Seated Single-Leg Calf Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-leg machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, but occasionally for higher reps of 20 per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on the single-leg calf press machine with one foot on the platform. Push through the ball of your foot to raise your heel as high as possible, then lower it back down. Perform 8-12 reps per leg, or increase to 20 reps for higher intensity.

Title: Seated Calf Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, and occasionally for very high burnout-focused sets of 50-100 total reps.
HowTo: Sit on the seated calf raise machine with your knees under the pads. Position your feet on the platform with the balls of your feet on the edge and your heels hanging off. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible, then lower your heels back down towards the ground. Perform 8-12 reps for moderate to high intensity, or up to 50-100 reps for burnout sets.

Title: Donkey Calf Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The donkey calk raise is a strength and muscle-building exercise focused on the muscles of the lower leg, most prominently the gastrocnemius muscle. While traditional donkey calf raises involved either a specific machine or carrying another person on one's back, this method uses a weight belt. It can be done in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, or for higher reps as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: Bend at the hips and position a weight belt around your waist. With your feet shoulder-width apart, lower your heels towards the ground while keeping your knees straight. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels back up. Perform in traditional muscle-building rep ranges or higher reps.

Title: Standing Calf Raise Facing Hack Squat Machine - Gethin Variation
Desc: The reverse hack squat calf raise is a varation of the standing calf raise to target them in a different manner.
HowTo: Stand facing the hack squat machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Place the balls of your feet on the platform and lower your heels towards the ground. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels back up. This variation targets the calves differently, so adjust your rep range accordingly.

Title: Calf Press On A Hack Squat Machine - Gethin Variation
Desc: The hack squat calf raise is a variation of the standing calf raise to target them in a different manner than seated or fully standing.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat of the hack squat machine so that your knees are aligned with the pivot point of the machine. 2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible. 4. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith Machine Standing Calf Raises - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Smith machine standing calf raise is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the calves, particularly the gastrocnemius or upper calf muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, positioned under the bar. 3. Place the balls of your feet on the platform, with your heels hanging off. 4. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible. 5. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 6. Perform for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hack squat calf raise
Desc: The hack squat calf raise is a variation of the standing calf raise performed in a hack squat machine. This allows for heavy loading, but also shoulder comfort from the pads of the hack squat. Calf raise variations are often performed for relatively high reps, such as 10-20 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the hack squat machine to your height. 2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as you can. 4. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated Calf Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, and occasionally for very high burnout-focused sets of 50-100 total reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the seated calf raise machine and adjust the seat so your knees are aligned with the machine. 2. Place your feet on the platform with your heels hanging off. 3. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible. 4. Slowly lower your heels back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Leg press calf raise
Desc: The leg press calf raise is a variation of the standing calf raise performed in a leg press machine. This allows for heavy loading, but also shoulder comfort from the pads of the leg press. Calf raise variations are often performed for relatively high reps, such as 10-20 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place your feet on the platform, shoulder-width apart. 3. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as you can. 4. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 5. Perform for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine seated calf raise
Desc: The machine seated calf raise is an exercise targeting the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the soleus muscle. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set, and occasionally for very high burnout-focused sets of 50-100 total reps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and adjust the seat if necessary. 2. Place your feet on the platform with your heels hanging off. 3. Push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels as high as possible. 4. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Legs Seated Calf Raise
Desc: The seated calf raise primarily targets the calf muscles while seated. This exercise is performed by sitting on a bench with your feet on a platform, allowing for a full range of motion as you raise and lower your heels.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet on a platform. 2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Raise your heels as high as possible by pushing through the balls of your feet. 4. Lower your heels back down for a full stretch. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Legs Standing Calf Raise
Desc: The standing calf raise focuses on strengthening the calf muscles while standing. This exercise is performed by standing on the balls of your feet on a raised platform, lifting your heels off the ground, and then lowering them back down.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a raised platform with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lift your heels off the ground by pushing through the balls of your feet. 3. Hold the position briefly at the top. 4. Lower your heels back down slowly to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Peroneals-SMR
Desc: The Peroneals-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) focuses on releasing tension in the peroneal muscles located on the outer side of the lower leg. This technique involves using a foam roller or similar tool to apply pressure to these muscles, helping to improve flexibility and reduce pain.
HowTo: To perform the Peroneals-SMR, sit on the floor with your legs extended. Place a foam roller under your outer lower leg, just above the ankle. Use your body weight to apply pressure on the roller and slowly roll it up and down the outer side of your leg, focusing on any tight spots. Spend 1-2 minutes on each leg.

Title: Knee Circles
Desc: Knee Circles are a dynamic mobility exercise that involves moving the knees in circular motions to improve joint mobility and flexibility. This exercise can help warm up the knee joints and surrounding muscles, making it beneficial before workouts.
HowTo: To perform Knee Circles, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and place your hands on your hips. Begin to move your knees in a circular motion, making small circles. Gradually increase the size of the circles. Perform 10 circles in one direction, then switch to the other direction.

Title: Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch
Desc: The Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch is performed by standing and placing one foot behind the other, keeping the back leg straight and the heel on the ground. This stretch targets the gastrocnemius muscle in the calf, promoting flexibility and reducing tightness.
HowTo: To perform the Standing Gastrocnemius Calf Stretch, stand with one foot behind the other. Keep your back leg straight and your heel on the ground. Lean forward slightly, bending your front knee until you feel a stretch in the calf of your back leg. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Wall calf stretch
Desc: The Seated Calf Stretch is done by sitting on the floor with one leg extended and the other bent. The foot of the extended leg is flexed to stretch the calf muscles. This stretch helps improve flexibility in the calves and can relieve tension.
HowTo: To perform the Wall Calf Stretch, stand facing a wall and place your hands on it for support. Step one foot back, keeping it straight with the heel on the ground. Bend your front knee and lean towards the wall until you feel a stretch in the calf of the back leg. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Seated Calf Stretch
Desc: HM Left Calf-Spike Sumo Pulse is a dynamic exercise that combines a sumo squat position with pulsing movements to engage the left calf muscles. This exercise focuses on building strength and endurance in the calves while also improving overall lower body stability.
HowTo: To perform the Seated Calf Stretch, sit on the floor with one leg extended and the other bent. Flex the foot of the extended leg by pulling your toes towards you. Reach towards your toes to deepen the stretch in your calf. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Standing Calf Raise
Desc: The standing calf raise is a popular movement to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, and in particular the gastrocnemius muscles. When unweighted, it is usually performed for high reps or for time.
HowTo: To perform the Standing Calf Raise, stand with your feet hip-width apart. Slowly rise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting your heels off the ground. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.

Title: Standing calf raise-
Desc: The standing calf raise is a popular movement to target the calf muscles of the lower leg, particularly the gastrocnemius muscle. When unweighted, it is usually performed for high reps or for time.
HowTo: To perform the Standing Calf Raise, stand with your feet hip-width apart. Slowly rise up onto the balls of your feet, lifting your heels off the ground. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. Repeat for 10-15 repetitions.

Title: HM Left Calf-Spike Sumo Pulse
HowTo: To perform the HM Left Calf-Spike Sumo Pulse, start in a sumo squat position with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed out. Lower your body into the squat, then pulse up and down slightly while keeping your core engaged. Focus on engaging your left calf throughout the movement. Perform for 30 seconds.

Title: Ankle Circles
Desc: Ankle circles are a mobility exercise that involves rotating the ankle joint in circular motions to improve flexibility and range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand comfortably. 2. Lift one foot off the ground. 3. Rotate your ankle in a circular motion, making 10 circles in one direction. 4. Switch directions and make 10 circles the other way. 5. Repeat with the other ankle.

Title: Calf Stretch Elbows Against Wall
Desc: The calf stretch with elbows against the wall involves placing your hands on a wall and leaning forward to stretch the calf muscles, promoting flexibility and reducing tightness.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing a wall with your hands placed on it at shoulder height. 2. Step back with one foot, keeping it straight. 3. Bend the front knee and lean your body towards the wall. 4. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds. 5. Switch legs and repeat.

Title: Standing Soleus And Achilles Stretch
Desc: The standing soleus and Achilles stretch targets the calf muscles, specifically the soleus and Achilles tendon, by bending the knees while keeping the heels on the ground.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Keep your heels on the ground and bend your knees slightly. 3. Lean forward slightly to feel the stretch in your calves. 4. Hold the position for 15-30 seconds. 5. Repeat as needed.

Title: Cross Over - With Bands
Desc: Cross over with bands is an exercise that uses resistance bands to strengthen the upper body, focusing on the chest and shoulders through a crossing motion.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Deltoids, Triceps
HowTo: 1. Attach resistance bands to a sturdy anchor. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the bands in each hand. 3. Pull the bands across your body, engaging your chest and shoulders. 4. Return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Bench Press - With Bands
Desc: The bench press with bands involves performing a traditional bench press while using resistance bands to increase the difficulty and improve strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold the resistance bands in each hand, with the bands anchored at the ends of the bench. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping tension on the bands. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Bench Press With Short Bands
Desc: The bench press with short bands is a variation of the bench press that utilizes shorter resistance bands for added resistance during the lift.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. 2. Attach short resistance bands to the ends of the barbell. 3. Hold the barbell with both hands and lower it to your chest. 4. Press the barbell back up while maintaining tension from the bands. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Feet-Elevated TRX Push-Up
Desc: The feet-elevated TRX push-up is a bodyweight exercise that combines a push-up with TRX suspension straps, elevating the feet to increase the challenge and engage the core.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the TRX straps to mid-length. 2. Place your feet in the foot cradles and get into a push-up position. 3. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Band-suspended kettlebell bench press
Desc: The band-suspended kettlebell bench press is a bench press variation where kettlebells or weight plates are hung from the ends of a barbell by looped bands. The suspended weights can be in addition to normally loaded weight plates, or in the place of them. Because the instability of the weights makes the lift difficult, this bench press variety is a popular accessory movement for building the traditional bench press in powerlifting training.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Deltoids, Stabilizing Muscles
HowTo: 1. Set up a bench and attach the bands to the ends of the barbell. 2. Lie on the bench and hold the kettlebells or weight plates. 3. Lower the weights towards your chest while keeping the bands taut. 4. Press the weights back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Banded Cross-Over Pull
Desc: The HM Banded Cross-Over Pull is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. It involves using a resistance band to perform a cross-over motion, engaging the lats and rear deltoids.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band around a sturdy anchor point. 2. Stand facing away from the anchor, holding the band with both hands. 3. Step back to create tension in the band. 4. Pull the band across your body in a cross-over motion, engaging your lats and rear deltoids. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Rusin Band Pull-Apart
Desc: The Rusin Band Pull-Apart is a shoulder and upper back exercise that focuses on improving posture and shoulder stability. It involves pulling a resistance band apart while keeping the arms extended.
Muscles: Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Trapezius, Pectoralis Major
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band with both hands. 2. Extend your arms straight in front of you at shoulder height. 3. Pull the band apart by moving your arms out to the sides, keeping them straight. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UNS Banded Push-Up
Desc: The UNS Banded Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates a resistance band for added difficulty. It targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps while providing support and resistance.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band across your upper back and hold the ends with your hands. 2. Get into a push-up position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Push back up to the starting position, feeling the resistance from the band. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Taylor Band-Assisted One-Arm Push-Up
Desc: The Taylor Band-Assisted One-Arm Push-Up is an advanced exercise that uses a resistance band to assist in performing a one-arm push-up. It helps build strength in the chest, shoulders, and core while improving balance.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Deltoids, Core Stabilizers
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band to a low anchor point. 2. Get into a push-up position with one hand on the ground and the other gripping the band. 3. Lower your body towards the ground while using the band for assistance. 4. Push back up to the starting position, engaging your chest and core. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Incline band bench press
Desc: The incline band bench press is variation of the incline press, a popular upper-body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a resistance band secured under the bench. 2. Hold the ends of the band with both hands at chest level. 3. Press the band upwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the band back to the starting position at chest level. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band push-up
Desc: The band push-up is a progression of the popular bodyweight version of the exercise commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. Adding the dynamic resistance of the band matches the strength curve of the push-up and helps build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band across your upper back and hold the ends with your hands. 2. Get into a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body towards the ground while the band provides resistance. 4. Push back up to the starting position, maintaining tension in the band. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band chest fly
Desc: Similar to the cable chest fly, the band chest fly is a single-joint movement that works the pectoral muscles. The fly is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, and the band variation works well as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout or a finishing movement at the end. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band to a sturdy anchor point at chest height. 2. Stand facing away from the anchor, holding the band with both hands extended out to the sides. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, bring your hands together in front of you in a wide arc. 4. Squeeze your chest at the peak of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Close-grip bench press
Desc: The close-grip bench press is a popular exercise targeting the triceps and chest. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the hands and elbows are placed closer together, which places more of an emphasis on the triceps. The close-grip bench press is often used as an accessory movement for the traditional bench press, or as a triceps builder for arm training. Similar to the bench press, it can be trained in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle or strength endurance.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a bench with a barbell or resistance band secured. 2. Grip the barbell or band with your hands closer than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower the barbell or band towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Press back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell Bench Press - Medium Grip
Desc: The bench press is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest and triceps. When many people think of listing, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with your feet firmly on the ground. Grip the barbell with a medium grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

Title: Decline barbell bench press
Desc: The decline barbell bench press is a popular upper-body exercise targeting the lower pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: Set up on a decline bench and grip the barbell with a shoulder-width grip. Lower the barbell to your lower chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Wide-grip bench press
Desc: The wide-grip bench press is a compound exercise targeting the chest and, to a lesser extent, the triceps. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the hands are placed farther apart on the bar. Many lifters find they can handle more weight going wide than with narrower grips, although it's also worth noting that plenty of banged-up lifters have said benching with a wide grip may also have contributed to their shoulder injuries and pain. The wide-grip bench is often used as a chest-building movement in chest or upper-body workouts, or as an accessory movement for the traditional bench press.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell with a wide grip. Lower the barbell to your chest, ensuring your elbows are flared out. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. Be cautious of shoulder strain.

Title: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Bench Press
Desc: The Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Bench Press is an effective exercise for targeting the lower part of the pectoral muscles. By using a wide grip, you engage more of the chest and shoulders while performing the press on a decline bench, which can help in building strength and mass in the upper body.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench and grip the barbell with a wide grip. Lower the barbell to your lower chest, keeping your elbows flared out. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. Focus on engaging your chest and shoulders.

Title: Barbell Incline Bench Press Medium-Grip
Desc: The incline bench press is an upper body compound movement that targets the upper chest.
HowTo: Set up on an incline bench and grip the barbell with a medium grip. Lower the barbell to your upper chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms.

Title: Neck Press
Desc: The Neck Press is a variation of the bench press that emphasizes the shoulders and upper chest. It involves pressing a barbell or dumbbells from the neck level, which requires stability and control, making it a great exercise for developing shoulder strength and hypertrophy.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench and position the barbell at neck level. Grip the barbell with a shoulder-width grip. Press the barbell upward while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the barbell back to neck level with control.

Title: Front Raise And Pullover
Desc: The Front Raise and Pullover is a compound exercise that combines the front raise, targeting the anterior deltoids, with the pullover, which works the lats and chest. This exercise is excellent for building upper body strength and improving shoulder mobility.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height for the front raise. Then, lie on a bench and perform a pullover by lowering the dumbbells behind your head and bringing them back over your chest.

Title: Board bench press
Desc: The board bench press is an upper-body exercise that is commonly performed as an assistance movement for the bench press. It targets the same muscles as the bench press, including the chest and shoulders, but really focuses on the triceps. Because you can load it more heavily than a full bench press, it allows you to overload the triceps and lock out of the bench press.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench and place a board on your chest. Grip the barbell with a shoulder-width grip. Lower the barbell to the board, then press it back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps.

Title: Barbell Bench Press-Wide Grip
Desc: The wide-grip bench pressis a compound exercise targeting the chest, primarily. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the hands are placed wider apart on the bar.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with your feet firmly on the ground. Grip the barbell with a wide grip, wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Push the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Pullover
Desc: The Wide-Grip Decline Barbell Pullover is an exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and back. It involves lying on a decline bench and using a barbell to perform a pullover motion, which helps in developing upper body strength and muscle definition.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench with your feet secured. Hold a barbell with a wide grip above your chest. Lower the barbell behind your head in a pullover motion, then bring it back to the starting position, focusing on engaging your chest, shoulders, and back.

Title: Barbell Guillotine Bench Press
Desc: The Barbell Guillotine Bench Press is a variation of the traditional bench press that emphasizes the upper chest and shoulders. In this exercise, the barbell is lowered to the neck level, which requires careful control and stability, making it an effective movement for building strength and mass in the upper body.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell slowly to your neck while keeping your elbows flared out. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, focusing on your upper chest and shoulders.

Title: Band-suspended kettlebell bench press
Desc: The band-suspended kettlebell bench press is a bench press variation where kettlebells or weight plates are hung from the ends of a barbell by looped bands. The suspended weights can be in addition to normally loaded weight plates, or in the place of them. Because the instability of the weights makes the lift difficult, this bench press variety is a popular accessory movement for building the traditional bench press in powerlifting training.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Anterior Deltoids, Stabilizer Muscles
HowTo: Set up a barbell on a bench with kettlebells or weight plates suspended from the ends using bands. Lie on the bench and grip the barbell. Lower the barbell to your chest while controlling the suspended weights, then press back up to the starting position.

Title: Paul Carter Incline Bench Press
Desc: The incline bench press is an upper body compound movement that targets the upper chest.
HowTo: Set an incline bench to a 30-45 degree angle. Lie back on the bench and grip the barbell with a shoulder-width grip. Lower the barbell to your upper chest, then press it back up to the starting position, focusing on your upper chest.

Title: Incline bench press
Desc: The incline bench press is a popular barbell exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the upper pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with the barbell above your chest. Grip the barbell with a shoulder-width grip. Lower the barbell to your upper chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle, then press it back up.

Title: Bench press
Desc: The bench press is a popular barbell exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It is a popular way to measure overall upper-body strength, and is contested in the sport of powerlifting. When many people think of lifting, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind. It can be performed for low reps for strength, higher reps for muscle, or for higher reps to build or measure strength endurance, like in the 225-pound bench press rep test in the NFL combine.
HowTo: Lie flat on a bench with your feet on the ground. Grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping your elbows tucked at about a 45-degree angle, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: TBS Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The close-grip bench pressis a compound exercise targeting the triceps and chest. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the hands and elbows are placed closer together.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell with a close grip, hands closer than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. Press the barbell back up to the starting position, focusing on your triceps and chest.

Title: AM Flat Bench Barbell Press
Desc: The bench press is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest and triceps. When many people think of listing, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet firmly on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Bench Press
Desc: The bench press is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest and triceps. When many people think of listing, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet planted on the floor. 2. Grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest, ensuring your elbows are tucked in. 4. Push the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The close-grip bench pressis a compound exercise targeting the triceps and chest. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the hands and elbows are placed closer together.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet on the floor. 2. Grip the barbell with hands closer than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Barbell Bench Press
Desc: The bench press is a compound exercise that builds strength and muscle in the chest and triceps. When many people think of listing, the bench press is often the first exercise that comes to mind
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Incline Barbell Bench Press
Desc: The incline bench press is an upper body compound movement that targets the upper chest.
HowTo: 1. Set the bench to an incline position. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet flat on the ground. 3. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower the barbell to your upper chest. 5. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Barbell Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Barbell Bench Press is an effective exercise targeting the upper chest muscles. It involves lying on an incline bench and pressing a barbell upwards, engaging the pectoral muscles, shoulders, and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Set the bench to a 30-degree incline. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet flat on the ground. 3. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower the barbell to your upper chest. 5. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Barbell Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Barbell Bench Press is a fundamental exercise for building overall chest strength. It involves lying flat on a bench and pressing a barbell away from the chest, primarily working the pectoral muscles, shoulders, and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Lie flat on a bench with your feet on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Lower the barbell to your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Press
Desc: The 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Press is an excellent exercise for targeting the upper chest. It requires lying on a bench set at a 30-degree angle and pressing dumbbells upward, which helps to develop strength and size in the upper pectoral region.
HowTo: 1. Set the bench to a 30-degree incline. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet flat on the ground. 3. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 4. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height.

Title: Spoto press
Desc: The Spoto press is a variation of the popular barbell exercise the bench press that builds strength and muscle in the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It differs from the bench press in that the lifter pauses for a few seconds at the bottom of the movement before pressing the bar back up. This pause removes all momentum and increases the time under tension for the chest and shoulder muscles to help develop upper-body musculature and strength.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell. Lower the barbell to your chest, pause for a few seconds, and then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell plyo push-up
Desc: The kettlebell plyo push-up is an explosive upper-body movement that uses a kettlebell primarily as a platform for the hands. A short step, dumbbell, or other stationary object could also be used in place of the kettlebell. It can be performed for reps or time, either for low reps to build explosive power or for higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your hands on kettlebells. Perform a push-up, then explosively push off the kettlebells to lift your hands off the ground, and land back into the push-up position.

Title: Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
Desc: The Extended Range One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press is a strength training exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It involves lying on your back with one kettlebell in one hand, pressing it upwards while keeping the other arm extended along the floor for stability. This variation increases the range of motion and engages the core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with one kettlebell in one hand. Press the kettlebell upwards while keeping your other arm extended along the floor for stability.

Title: Kettlebell alternating floor press
Desc: The kettlebell alternating floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a dumbbell or kettlebell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to build strength in the top portion of the lift, overload the triceps, and work on strengthening the shoulder stabilizers.
HowTo: Lie on your back with a kettlebell in each hand. Press one kettlebell up while keeping the other kettlebell at your side, alternating sides.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Floor Press is a unilateral exercise that focuses on building strength in the chest, shoulders, and triceps. Perform this exercise by lying on your back, holding a kettlebell in one hand, and pressing it straight up while keeping your elbow close to your body.
HowTo: Lie on your back with a kettlebell in one hand. Press the kettlebell straight up while keeping your elbow close to your body.

Title: Leg-Over Floor Press
Desc: The Leg-Over Floor Press is a unique variation of the floor press that incorporates leg movement to enhance core stability and strength. While lying on your back, press a weight upwards with both hands while simultaneously lifting your legs over to one side, engaging your obliques.
HowTo: Lie on your back with a weight in both hands. Press the weight upwards while simultaneously lifting your legs over to one side, engaging your obliques.

Title: Band-suspended kettlebell bench press
Desc: The band-suspended kettlebell bench press is a bench press variation where kettlebells or weight plates are hung from the ends of a barbell by looped bands. The suspended weights can be in addition to normally loaded weight plates, or in the place of them. Because the instability of the weights makes the lift difficult, this bench press variety is a popular accessory movement for building the traditional bench press in powerlifting training.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell. Attach kettlebells or weight plates to the ends of the barbell using bands. Lower the barbell to your chest and press it back up, controlling the unstable weights.

Title: FYR2 Push-Up to Kettlebell Hike Combo
Desc: The FYR2 Push-Up to Kettlebell Hike Combo is a dynamic exercise that combines a push-up with a kettlebell hike. Start in a push-up position, perform a push-up, and then explosively hike a kettlebell back towards your hips, engaging your core and shoulders throughout the movement.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then explosively hike a kettlebell back towards your hips, engaging your core and shoulders throughout the movement.

Title: Pushups
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
HowTo: To perform a push-up, start in a plank position with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your body in a straight line from head to heels. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, keeping them close to your body. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Incline Push-Up
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The hands are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: To perform an incline push-up, place your hands on an elevated surface, such as a bench or a step, and walk your feet back until your body is in a straight line from head to heels. Lower your chest towards the elevated surface by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the classic push-up where the hands are placed on a bench or other elevated surface. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than push-ups on the floor, but also puts the emphasis more on the triceps. It can be used as a substitute for floor push-ups or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: To perform a hands-elevated push-up, place your hands on a bench or other elevated surface and walk your feet back into a plank position. Lower your chest towards the elevated surface by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position. This variation emphasizes the triceps.

Title: Decline Push-Up
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The feet are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: To perform a decline push-up, place your feet on an elevated surface and your hands on the ground. Walk your hands out into a plank position. Lower your chest towards the ground by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position. This variation emphasizes the upper chest and shoulders.

Title: Single-Arm Push-Up
Desc: The Single-Arm Push-Up is a challenging variation of the traditional push-up that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps while also engaging the core for stability. To perform this exercise, start in a plank position with one arm extended directly beneath your shoulder and the other arm resting behind your back. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core tight and your body in a straight line, then push back up to the starting position.
HowTo: To perform a single-arm push-up, start in a plank position with one arm extended directly beneath your shoulder and the other arm resting behind your back. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your core tight and your body in a straight line. Push back up to the starting position using only the working arm.

Title: Close push-up to wide push-up
Desc: The close push-up to wide push-up combines two variations of a push-up to emphasize the strengthening of different muscles. The close push-up emphasizes the triceps, while the wide push-up emphasizes the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: To perform a close push-up to wide push-up, start in a close push-up position with your hands close together. Perform a push-up, then transition to a wide push-up position by moving your hands farther apart. Perform another push-up, then return to the close position. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Wide-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The wide-grip hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the elevated push-up performed with the hands farther apart than with a standard push-up. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than wide-grip push-ups on the floor, but the extra width also puts more emphasis on the chest muscles. It can be used as a substitute for wide-grip floor push-ups, or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: To perform a wide-grip hands-elevated push-up, place your hands on an elevated surface with a wider-than-shoulder-width grip. Walk your feet back into a plank position. Lower your chest towards the elevated surface by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position. This variation emphasizes the chest muscles.

Title: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball
Desc: Push-Ups With Feet On An Exercise Ball are an advanced variation of the standard push-up that increases instability and engages the core muscles more effectively. To perform this exercise, place your feet on an exercise ball and your hands on the ground in a push-up position. Lower your body towards the ground while maintaining a straight line from your head to your heels, then push back up to the starting position. This exercise challenges balance and strengthens the chest, shoulders, and triceps.
HowTo: To perform push-ups with feet on an exercise ball, place your feet on the ball and your hands on the ground in a push-up position. Lower your body towards the ground while maintaining a straight line from your head to your heels. Push back up to the starting position. This exercise increases instability and engages the core.

Title: Feet-elevated push-up
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel. This makes it more difficult than push-ups on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It is often used as a bodyweight substitute for incline presses, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. 2. Keep your body straight from head to heels. 3. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Isometric Wipers
Desc: The typewriter push-up is an advanced push-up variation where the hands are extra wide and you lower toward each hand in alternating reps. It is more challenging to each working arm than traditional push-ups and also stretches and challenges the chest.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower your body towards the ground, shifting your weight to one hand. 3. Push back up and alternate to the other hand. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Clock push-up
Desc: The clock push-up is a series of regular push-ups performed one at a time, moving your hands one step to the side between each one until you've completed a full circle. It targets the same muscles as traditional push-ups, such as the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but adds an endurance and core challenge to traditional push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position. 2. Perform a push-up, then move your hands one step to the side. 3. Perform another push-up, then move your hands again. 4. Continue this pattern until you complete a full circle. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Incline Push-Up Depth Jump
Desc: The Incline Push-Up Depth Jump combines the upper body strength of an incline push-up with the explosive power of a depth jump. Start in an incline push-up position with your hands on a raised surface. Lower your body into the push-up, then explosively push off the surface, landing softly back on your feet. This exercise enhances upper body strength, coordination, and explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Begin in an incline push-up position with your hands on a raised surface. 2. Lower your body into a push-up. 3. Explosively push off the surface. 4. Land softly back on your feet. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Push-Up Wide
Desc: The wide push-up is a variation of the push-up with the hands wider than shoulder-width apart. It targets upper-body muscle groups including the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but has more of a chest emphasis than narrower-grip push-up variations. If wide push-ups lead to pain in the front of your shoulder, opt for a narrower version.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. If you experience shoulder pain, switch to a narrower grip. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Sphinx push-up
Desc: The sphinx push-up is a difficult variation of the push-up that ends with the forearms on the ground in front of the body, rather than with the chest on the ground. It puts more stress on the triceps than traditional push-ups. It can be performed for time or reps in any bodyweight workout or during any arms-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your forearms on the ground. 2. Push your body up by extending your arms, lifting your chest off the ground. 3. Lower back down to the forearm position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Close-Hands Push-Up
Desc: The close push-up is an upper-body exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. The close hand position places more emphasis on the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands close together, under your chest. 2. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Tiger-bend push-up
Desc: The tiger-bend push-up is an advanced push-up variation where you shift onto your forearms at the bottom position and then back onto your hands and up again. It targets the triceps far more than regular push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position. 2. Lower your body down, shifting onto your forearms at the bottom. 3. Push back up onto your hands. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Plyo push-up
Desc: The plyo push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, keeping your body straight. 3. Push through your palms to return to the starting position. 4. For added power, explode off the ground at the top of the push-up.

Title: Close-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The close-grip hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the classic push-up where the hands are placed on a bench or other elevated surface. Having the hands higher than the feet makes it easier than close-grip push-ups on the floor, but also puts the emphasis more on the triceps. It can be used as a substitute for floor push-ups or close-grip push-ups, or as a mechanical dropset after maxing out on floor push-ups.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a plank position with your hands on an elevated surface. 2. Position your hands closer together than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body towards the elevated surface by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps.

Title: Suspended push-up
Desc: The suspended push-up is a bodyweight pushing exercise performed on a suspension strap system or gymnastic rings. It targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but is also challenging to the core and upper back. It can work in traditional strength and muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps.
Muscles: Chest, Shoulders, Triceps, Core, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Adjust the suspension straps or gymnastic rings to a suitable height. 2. Grab the handles and extend your body into a plank position. 3. Lower your chest towards the ground by bending your elbows. 4. Push back up to the starting position, maintaining core stability throughout.

Title: Push Up to Side Plank
Desc: The push-up to side plank is an upper-body and core-focused exercise combining two popular bodyweight movements. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders with the push-up, and the obliques and hip external rotator muscles with the side plank. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or any bodyweight strength-training workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a push-up by lowering your chest towards the ground. 3. As you push back up, rotate to one side and lift your arm towards the ceiling into a side plank position. 4. Return to the plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: Isometric Chest Squeezes
Desc: Isometric chest squeezes are a strength training exercise that targets the chest muscles. To perform this exercise, stand or sit comfortably, press your palms together in front of your chest, and squeeze tightly for a set duration. This exercise helps improve muscle endurance and stability in the chest area.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably with your back straight. 2. Press your palms together in front of your chest at heart level. 3. Squeeze your palms together as hard as you can for a set duration, typically 10-30 seconds. 4. Release and repeat for the desired number of sets.

Title: Side-to-side push-up
Desc: The side-to-side push-up is a variation of the push-up exercise where you side-step the opposite hand and foot and perform a push-up.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standard push-up position. 2. Shift your weight to one side and move your opposite hand and foot towards that side. 3. Perform a push-up while in this position. 4. Return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Typewriter push-up
Desc: The typewriter push-up is an advanced push-up variation where the hands are extra wide and you lower toward each hand in alternating reps. It is more challenging to each working arm than traditional push-ups and also stretches and challenges the chest.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a wide push-up position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards one hand while keeping the other hand straight. 3. Push back up and lower towards the other hand. 4. Alternate sides for each rep.

Title: Diamond push-up
Desc: The diamond push-up is an advanced variation of the push-up exercise performed with the hands in a diamond shape. It increases the challenge to the triceps, but also targets the chest and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands forming a diamond shape under your chest. 2. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, keeping them close to your body. 3. Push back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps.

Title: Judo push-up
Desc: The judo push-up is an advanced push-up variation that blends elements of the yoga poses downward- and upward-facing dog. This movement increases the demands on the shoulders, but also has mobility benefits. It can work in a dynamic warm-up or mobility-focused workout, but also in bodyweight strength training.
HowTo: To perform the judo push-up, start in a standard push-up position. As you lower your body, shift your weight forward and then push back up while transitioning into a downward-facing dog position. Flow into an upward-facing dog position by arching your back and lifting your chest. Repeat the movement, focusing on fluid transitions and maintaining control.

Title: Superman Push-Up
Desc: The Superman Push-Up is a challenging variation of the traditional push-up that engages the core, chest, and shoulders. To perform this exercise, start in a standard push-up position. As you lower your body, lift one arm and the opposite leg off the ground, extending them outward. Hold for a moment at the bottom, then push back up while returning your arm and leg to the starting position. Alternate sides with each repetition.
HowTo: To perform the Superman Push-Up, start in a standard push-up position. As you lower your body, lift one arm and the opposite leg off the ground, extending them outward. Hold for a moment at the bottom, then push back up while returning your arm and leg to the starting position. Alternate sides with each repetition, ensuring to engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: Wide push-up
Desc: The wide push-up is a variation of the push-up with the hands wider than shoulder-width apart. It targets upper-body muscle groups including the chest, shoulders, and triceps, but has more of a chest emphasis than narrower-grip push-up variations. If wide push-ups lead to pain in the front of your shoulder, opt for a narrower version.
HowTo: To perform a wide push-up, start in a push-up position with your hands placed wider than shoulder-width apart. Keep your body straight and lower your chest towards the ground while maintaining the wide hand position. Push back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your chest and shoulders.

Title: One-Arm Push-Up
Desc: The One-Arm Push-Up is an advanced bodyweight exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders while also engaging the core for stability. To perform this exercise, start in a push-up position but with one arm placed behind your back. Lower your body towards the ground using the strength of your working arm, then push back up to the starting position. Keep your body straight and avoid twisting your torso.
HowTo: To perform the One-Arm Push-Up, start in a push-up position with one arm placed behind your back. Lower your body towards the ground using the strength of your working arm while keeping your body straight. Push back up to the starting position, avoiding any twisting of your torso.

Title: Clapping Push-Up
Desc: Also known as a plyo push-up, the clapping push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: To perform the clapping push-up, start in a standard push-up position. Lower your body towards the ground, then explosively push up so that your hands leave the ground. Clap your hands together before landing back in the push-up position. Ensure to land softly and maintain control.

Title: Staggered push-up
Desc: The staggered push-up is a variation of the push-up exercise where your hand position is staggered, with one hand forward and one back. It targets the same muscles as a traditional push-up, including the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but is more difficult to the rear arm and core.
HowTo: To perform a staggered push-up, start in a push-up position with one hand positioned forward and the other hand back. Lower your body towards the ground, keeping your core engaged and your body straight. Push back up to the starting position, focusing on the rear arm and maintaining balance.

Title: Reverse-grip hands-elevated push-up
Desc: The reverse-grip hands-elevated push-up is a bodyweight exercise performed on a Smith machine or other elevated surface. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. It can work as a regression of floor reverse-grip push-ups, or in a progressive mechanical dropset moving the bar up once you reach failure at a lower height.
HowTo: To perform the reverse-grip hands-elevated push-up, set up a Smith machine or elevated surface. Position your hands in a reverse grip (palms facing you) on the elevated surface. Lower your body towards the surface, then push back up to the starting position. This exercise targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders.

Title: Triple Clap Push-Up
Desc: The Triple Clap Push-Up is a dynamic and explosive variation of the push-up that enhances upper body strength and coordination. Begin in a standard push-up position. As you push up from the ground, explode upwards and clap your hands three times before landing back in the push-up position. Ensure to land softly and maintain control to prevent injury. This exercise can be modified by reducing the number of claps or performing it on your knees.
HowTo: To perform the Triple Clap Push-Up, start in a standard push-up position.
