As you push up from the ground, explode upwards and clap your hands three times before landing back in the push-up position. Ensure to land softly and maintain control to prevent injury. You can modify this by reducing the number of claps or performing it on your knees.

Title: Side kick-through push-up
Desc: The side kick-through push-up is a full-body movement that begins in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side, with a push-up performed between kick-throughs. It is commonly performed for reps or timed bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees off the ground. Perform a push-up, then kick one leg out to the side while rotating your torso. Return to the starting position and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: Swimming
Desc: Swimming is a water-based exercise that involves moving through water using various strokes. It is an excellent full-body workout that improves cardiovascular fitness, builds strength, and enhances flexibility.
HowTo: Enter the water and choose a stroke (freestyle, breaststroke, backstroke, or butterfly). Use your arms and legs to propel yourself through the water, maintaining a steady rhythm and proper technique.

Title: FYR Push-Up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Frog push-up
Desc: The frog push-up is an advanced push-up variation that is performed with the legs bent and butt in the air. It heavily targets the triceps and shoulders, but is also quite challenging to the core.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with your legs bent and your butt raised. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your sides. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Wide push-up plank hold
Desc: The wide push-up plank hold is a full-body exercise targeting the core. Because the arms aren't directly under the body, it can be more difficult than traditional push-up planks, especially for the upper back and chest, but also for the core.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands wider than shoulder-width apart. Hold your body in a straight line from head to heels, engaging your core. Maintain this position for the desired duration.

Title: Close push-up
Desc: The close push-up is an upper-body exercise that targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. The close hand position places more emphasis on the triceps.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with your hands placed close together, directly under your shoulders. Lower your body towards the ground, focusing on using your triceps. Push back up to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Push-Up - Gethin Variation
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body towards the ground, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push back up to the starting position, emphasizing a controlled movement. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Incline Push-Up On Chair
Desc: The HM Incline Push-Up On Chair is a modified push-up exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. By using a chair for elevation, it reduces the intensity compared to standard push-ups, making it suitable for beginners and those looking to build upper body strength.
HowTo: Position a chair behind you and place your hands on the seat, shoulder-width apart. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Push-Up
Desc: The HM Push-Up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. To perform this exercise, start in a plank position with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.
HowTo: To perform the HM Push-Up, start in a plank position with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the floor, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: HM Push-Plank
Desc: The HM Push-Plank is a core stability exercise that combines the push-up position with a plank hold. Begin in a push-up position, keeping your body straight from head to heels. Hold this position for a set duration, engaging your core and maintaining proper alignment.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position, keeping your body straight from head to heels. Hold this position for a set duration, engaging your core and maintaining proper alignment.

Title: AM Chest Dips
Desc: The chest dip is a chest-building exercise in which the lifter hangs between two parallel handles. Leaning the torso slightly forward shifts the emphasis from the triceps to the chest.
HowTo: To perform chest dips, hang between two parallel handles with your arms straight. Lean your torso slightly forward and lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Chest, Triceps, Shoulders, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: UN Push-Up
Desc: The UN Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that focuses on upper body strength. Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Lower your body until your chest is close to the ground, then push back up to the starting position. This exercise can be modified by performing it on your knees.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Lower your body until your chest is close to the ground, then push back up to the starting position. You can modify this exercise by performing it on your knees.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Pecs
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Pecs is a self-myofascial release exercise that targets the pectoral muscles. Lie face down on a foam roller positioned under your chest. Gently roll back and forth to release tension in the pecs, improving flexibility and reducing soreness.
HowTo: Lie face down on a foam roller positioned under your chest. Gently roll back and forth to release tension in the pectoral muscles, improving flexibility and reducing soreness.

Title: UN Hands Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The UN Hands Elevated Push-Up is a variation of the push-up that increases the range of motion and targets the upper chest. Place your hands on an elevated surface, such as a bench or step, and perform a push-up by lowering your chest towards the surface and pushing back up.
HowTo: Place your hands on an elevated surface, such as a bench or step. Perform a push-up by lowering your chest towards the surface and pushing back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Seal Drag to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Seal Drag to Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a seal drag motion with a push-up. Start in a plank position, drag your body forward using your arms, then perform a push-up before returning to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a plank position. Drag your body forward using your arms, then perform a push-up. Return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Hand-Elevated Push-Up with Hand Row
Desc: The Holman Hand-Elevated Push-Up with Hand Row is an advanced variation of the push-up where one hand is elevated on a platform. Perform a push-up, then row a weight with the elevated hand before switching sides.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with one hand elevated on a platform. Perform a push-up, then row a weight with the elevated hand. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: Holman Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Push-Up is a fundamental upper body exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. Begin in a plank position, lower your body to the ground, and push back up to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a plank position. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Slow Hips-Up Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Hips-Up Chest Press is a strength exercise that combines a chest press with a hip lift. Lie on your back, press weights overhead while lifting your hips off the ground, then lower both your hips and weights.
HowTo: Lie on your back with weights in hand. Press the weights overhead while lifting your hips off the ground. Lower your hips and weights back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Jump-Out Push-Up with Hand Hop Back
Desc: The Holman Jump-Out Push-Up with Hand Hop Back is a plyometric exercise that involves jumping out into a push-up position and then hopping back to the starting position after completing the push-up.
HowTo: Jump out into a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then hop back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Froggy Push-Up to Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Froggy Push-Up to Donkey Kick is a fun variation where you perform a push-up and then transition into a donkey kick, engaging your core and glutes.
HowTo: Perform a push-up, then transition into a donkey kick by lifting one leg towards the ceiling while engaging your core and glutes.

Title: Holman Push-Up to Sit Back
Desc: The Holman Push-Up to Sit Back is a compound movement that combines a push-up with a sit back into a child’s pose. This exercise enhances flexibility and strength in the upper body.
HowTo: Perform a push-up, then sit back into a child’s pose by pushing your hips back towards your heels.

Title: Holman Sit Back Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Sit Back Push-Up is a modified push-up where you lower your body and then sit back into your heels, engaging your core and stretching your back.
HowTo: Lower your body into a push-up, then sit back into your heels while engaging your core and stretching your back.

Title: Holman Alternating Staggered Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Alternating Staggered Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that involves alternating the position of your hands to engage different muscle groups. Start in a standard push-up position, then stagger your hands by moving one hand forward and the other back. As you lower your body, push back up and switch hand positions with each rep.
HowTo: Start in a standard push-up position. Stagger your hands by moving one hand forward and the other back. Lower your body, then push back up and switch hand positions with each rep.

Title: Holman Foot-Up Diving Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Foot-Up Diving Push-Up is an advanced push-up variation that targets the upper chest and shoulders. Begin in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. As you lower your body, dive forward, bringing your chest towards the ground, then push back up to the starting position.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. Lower your body while diving forward, bringing your chest towards the ground. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Holman Narrow Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Narrow Push-Up focuses on the triceps and inner chest. Place your hands close together, directly under your shoulders, and perform a push-up. Keep your elbows close to your body as you lower and raise yourself.
HowTo: Place your hands close together, directly under your shoulders. Perform a push-up while keeping your elbows close to your body as you lower and raise yourself.

Title: Holman Dynamo Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Dynamo Push-Up is a dynamic push-up variation that incorporates explosive movements. Start in a push-up position, lower your body, then push up with enough force to lift your hands off the ground, clapping them together before landing back in the push-up position.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Lower your body, then push up with enough force to lift your hands off the ground. Clap your hands together before landing back in the push-up position.

Title: Holman Jump to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Jump to Push-Up combines a jump with a push-up for a full-body workout. Begin standing, jump down into a push-up position, perform a push-up, then jump back to your feet and repeat.
HowTo: Begin standing, then jump down into a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then jump back to your feet and repeat.

Title: Holman Foot-Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Foot-Elevated Push-Up increases the difficulty of the standard push-up by elevating your feet on a surface. This variation targets the upper chest and shoulders more intensely. Start in a push-up position with your feet elevated and perform the push-up as usual.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your feet elevated on a surface. Perform the push-up as usual, focusing on maintaining form.

Title: Holman Feet-Elevated Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Feet-Elevated Push-Up is similar to the foot-elevated version but emphasizes the positioning of the feet. With your feet on an elevated surface, lower your body into a push-up, ensuring to maintain proper form and engage your core throughout the movement.
HowTo: With your feet on an elevated surface, lower your body into a push-up. Maintain proper form and engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: Total Fitness Plyo Push-Up
Desc: The plyo push-up is a bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It targets the muscles of the chest, triceps, and shoulders, and can be trained in low reps for power and strength, or higher reps for conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Lower your body, then explosively push up, lifting your hands off the ground. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Scapular push-up
Desc: The scapular push-up is an upper-body exercise aimed at increasing the stability of the scapulae and mobility in the shoulders. It is often performed as part of a dynamic warm-up before an upper-body workout, or as part of a mobility session.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your arms straight. Lower your body by retracting your shoulder blades together, keeping your elbows slightly bent. Push back up to the starting position by protracting your shoulder blades.

Title: King Maker Push-up
Desc: The push-up is a popular bodyweight exercise that is commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a classic movement to build upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Anterior Deltoids, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Begin in a standard push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Warrior push-up
Desc: The warrior push-up is a series of push-up and plank variations combined into a single sequence. They include a Judo push-up, plank, side plank, mountain climber, diamond push-up, and regular push-up. Done together, they tax the upper-body muscles from different angles and increase time under tension for the entire body.
HowTo: Start in a plank position. Perform a Judo push-up, then transition into a side plank on one side. Return to the plank position, perform a mountain climber, then switch to a diamond push-up, followed by a regular push-up. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Taylor Roll-Over Push-Up
Desc: The Taylor Roll-Over Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines a traditional push-up with a roll-over movement. Start in a push-up position, perform a push-up, and then roll your body to one side, transitioning into a side plank before rolling back and repeating.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then roll your body to one side into a side plank. Hold for a moment, then roll back to the push-up position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Taylor One-Arm Push-Up Slow Negative
Desc: The Taylor One-Arm Push-Up Slow Negative focuses on building strength and control. Begin in a one-arm push-up position, lower your body slowly to the ground, and then push back up using both arms. This exercise emphasizes the eccentric phase of the movement.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Anterior Deltoids, Core
HowTo: Start in a one-arm push-up position. Lower your body slowly towards the ground, focusing on control. Once at the bottom, use both arms to push back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Push-Up To Isometric Hold
Desc: The 30 Chest Push-Up To Isometric Hold involves performing 30 standard push-ups followed by holding the push-up position at the bottom for a specified duration. This exercise builds endurance and strength in the chest, shoulders, and triceps.
HowTo: Perform 30 standard push-ups in succession. After completing the push-ups, hold the push-up position at the bottom for a specified duration, keeping your body straight and engaged.

Title: 30 Chest Push-Up
Desc: The 30 Chest Push-Up is a classic strength exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps. Perform 30 repetitions of the push-up, maintaining proper form with a straight back and engaged core.
HowTo: Assume a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body until your chest is just above the ground, then push back up to the starting position. Complete 30 repetitions.

Title: 30 Chest Bench Push-Up
Desc: The 30 Chest Bench Push-Up is a variation of the standard push-up where your hands are elevated on a bench. This modification reduces the intensity while still engaging the chest, shoulders, and triceps. Aim for 30 repetitions.
HowTo: Position your hands on a bench, shoulder-width apart, and lower your body towards the bench in a controlled manner. Push back up to the starting position. Aim for 30 repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn 3-Phase Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn 3-Phase Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It involves three distinct phases: a standard push-up, a wide push-up, and a close-grip push-up, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: Start in a standard push-up position. Perform a standard push-up, then transition to a wide push-up by placing your hands wider than shoulder-width apart. Finally, move to a close-grip push-up by bringing your hands closer together under your chest. Repeat the cycle to enhance strength and stability.

Title: MetaBurn Fast Feet To Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Fast Feet To Push-Up combines agility and strength. Start in a standing position, quickly shuffle your feet, then drop into a push-up. This exercise improves cardiovascular endurance and upper body strength.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Quickly shuffle your feet in place for a few seconds, then drop down into a push-up. After completing the push-up, return to the standing position and repeat the shuffling.

Title: MetaBurn Judo Push-Up To Pike Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Judo Push-Up To Pike Push-Up is a compound movement that transitions from a judo push-up, which incorporates a wide stance and explosive movement, into a pike push-up, targeting the shoulders and upper chest.
HowTo: Start in a wide stance push-up position. Perform a judo push-up by lowering your body explosively, then push back up and transition into a pike push-up by raising your hips and lowering your head towards the ground. Repeat the sequence.

Title: MetaBurn Pike Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Pike Push-Up focuses on the shoulders and upper chest. Begin in a downward dog position, then lower your head towards the ground while keeping your hips high, engaging your core throughout the movement.
HowTo: Begin in a downward dog position with your hips high. Lower your head towards the ground while keeping your hips elevated, then push back up to the starting position. Engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up To Frogger
Desc: The MetaBurn Push-Up To Frogger combines a traditional push-up with a dynamic frogger movement. After completing a push-up, jump your feet forward to your hands, engaging your core and legs for a full-body workout.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet forward towards your hands in a frogger motion. Engage your core and legs as you return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand Side-Step
Desc: The MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand Side-Step adds lateral movement to the standard push-up. As you lower your body, step one hand to the side, alternating sides to enhance shoulder stability and engage the core.
HowTo: Begin in a standard push-up position. As you lower your body, step one hand to the side, then push back up. Alternate sides with each push-up to enhance shoulder stability and engage your core.

Title: MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand-Up Rotation
Desc: The MetaBurn Push-Up With Hand-Up Rotation incorporates a rotation of the torso. After each push-up, lift one hand off the ground and rotate your body, reaching towards the ceiling, which engages the obliques and improves balance.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then lift one hand off the ground and rotate your torso, reaching towards the ceiling with that hand. Return to the push-up position and alternate sides.

Title: MetaBurn Sphinx Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Sphinx Push-Up targets the triceps and chest. Start in a forearm plank position, then push up onto your hands, lowering back down to your forearms, focusing on controlled movements to build strength.
HowTo: Begin in a forearm plank position. Push up onto your hands, then lower back down to your forearms. Focus on controlled movements, engaging your triceps and chest throughout the exercise.

Title: MetaBurn Spiderman Push-Up
Desc: The MetaBurn Spiderman Push-Up combines traditional push-up mechanics with a dynamic movement that engages the core and improves stability. As you lower into the push-up, bring one knee towards the elbow on the same side, mimicking a Spiderman crawl. Alternate sides with each repetition.
HowTo: 1. Start in a traditional push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. As you lower down, bring your right knee towards your right elbow, mimicking a Spiderman crawl. 4. Push back up to the starting position. 5. Alternate sides with each repetition, bringing your left knee towards your left elbow on the next push-up.

Title: Roberston Push-up to Down Dog
Desc: The Robertson Push-up to Down Dog is a fluid movement that transitions from a push-up position to a Downward Dog pose. Start in a push-up position, perform a push-up, then push back into Down Dog, stretching the hamstrings and shoulders. This exercise enhances upper body strength and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands under your shoulders. 2. Perform a standard push-up by lowering your body until your chest nearly touches the ground. 3. After pushing back up, shift your hips up and back into a Downward Dog position, stretching your hamstrings and shoulders. 4. Hold for a moment, then return to the push-up position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Push-Up-Breakdancer-Shoulder-Tap Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Push-Up-Breakdancer-Shoulder-Tap Complex is a challenging full-body exercise that combines push-ups, breakdancer movements, and shoulder taps. Begin in a push-up position, perform a push-up, then rotate into a side plank while tapping the opposite shoulder. Return to push-up position and repeat, alternating sides.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a push-up. 3. As you push back up, rotate your body to the right into a side plank position while tapping your left shoulder with your right hand. 4. Return to the push-up position. 5. Repeat the push-up and then rotate to the left side, tapping your right shoulder with your left hand. 6. Continue alternating sides.

Title: ACFT Hand-release push-up
Desc: The hand-release push-up is a variation of the push-up, a popular bodyweight exercise commonly used in military and tactical physical fitness tests. It’s a movement to build upper-body strength and endurance, emphasizing the chest, triceps, and shoulders, but also working the upper back and core. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standard push-up position with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower your body down until your chest touches the ground. 3. Release your hands off the ground briefly before pushing back up to the starting position. 4. Ensure to engage your core and maintain a straight body line throughout the movement.

Title: 1.5-rep push-up
Desc: The 1.5-rep push-up is a more difficult variation of the push-up, commonly used to train for military and tactical physical fitness tests. It builds upper-body muscle and strength, emphasizing the chest, core, upper back, triceps, and shoulders.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Triceps Brachii, Deltoids, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body down into a push-up until your chest nearly touches the ground. 3. Push back up halfway, stopping before your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower back down to the starting position. 5. Push back up to the starting position to complete one rep.

Title: ACFT Triple-clap push-up
Desc: The triple-clap push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, core, and shoulders.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Deltoids, Core
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body down into a push-up. 3. As you push back up, explode off the ground and clap your hands together three times before landing back in the push-up position. 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: ACFT Superman push-up
Desc: The Superman push-up is an explosive bodyweight exercise aimed at increasing upper-body power and strength. It is an advanced exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, triceps, shoulders, and core that involves pressing up off the floor and lifting the hands and feet off the ground simultaneously at the top of the movement.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Deltoids, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands placed slightly wider than shoulder-width. 2. Lower your body down into a push-up. 3. As you push back up, simultaneously lift your hands and feet off the ground, creating a 'Superman' position at the top. 4. Land back down in the push-up position and repeat.

Title: Cross-over push-up
Desc: The cross-over push-up is a variation of the push-up that adds a degree of difficulty by stepping over a small box or step between repetitions. It can be performed for time or for reps and creates a greater core stabilization challenge by forcing the core muscles to maintain the a neutral spine throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a push-up, lowering your body towards the ground. 3. After pushing back up, step one hand and foot over a small box or step to the opposite side. 4. Perform another push-up, then step back to the starting position. 5. Continue alternating sides with each repetition.

Title: Leverage Incline Chest Press
Desc: The Leverage Incline Chest Press is a strength training exercise that targets the upper pectoral muscles. It involves pressing a weighted lever away from the body while seated on an incline bench, promoting muscle growth and stability.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit back against the bench with your feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the handles with a firm grip. 4. Press the handles away from your body until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position, keeping control of the weight. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Butterfly
Desc: The machine chest fly is an exercise targeting the chest. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. In chest workouts, this exercise often follows compound moves such as the bench press.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that your arms are parallel to the floor when holding the handles. 2. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the handles with a firm grip. 4. Open your arms wide, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 5. Bring the handles together in front of your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles. 6. Slowly return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Leverage Chest Press
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Triceps Brachii
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit back against the bench with your feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the handles with a firm grip. 4. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position, controlling the weight. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Decline Smith Press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the bench to a decline position and adjust the barbell height accordingly. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet secured. 3. Grasp the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 5. Press the barbell back up to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith machine bench press
Desc: The Smith machine bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Triceps Brachii
HowTo: 1. Adjust the barbell height on the Smith machine. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower the barbell to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 5. Press the barbell back up to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Leverage Decline Chest Press
Desc: The Leverage Decline Chest Press is a strength training exercise designed to target the lower pectoral muscles. This exercise involves pressing a weighted lever away from the body while seated on a decline bench, enhancing muscle definition and strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at the lower chest level. 2. Sit back against the bench with your feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the handles with a firm grip. 4. Press the handles away from your body until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position, keeping control of the weight. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Machine chest press
Desc: The machine chest press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a bench press but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. Many machines offer multiple grip options, such as overhand, neutral (palms facing), or underhand. The chest press is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Triceps Brachii
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit upright with your back against the pad and feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the handles with a firm grip. 4. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith Machine Incline Bench Press
Desc: The Smith machine incline bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest, particularly the upper chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the bench to an incline position and set the barbell height accordingly. 2. Lie back on the bench with your feet flat on the floor. 3. Grasp the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower the barbell to your upper chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 5. Press the barbell back up to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith Machine Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The Smith machine close-grip bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest and triceps. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest, arms, or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to the appropriate height. 2. Lie on the bench with your back flat and feet firmly on the ground. 3. Grip the bar with a close grip, hands slightly narrower than shoulder-width. 4. Unrack the bar and lower it slowly to your chest. 5. Press the bar back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith Machine Decline Press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the Smith machine bench to a decline position. 2. Lie on the bench with your back flat and feet secured. 3. Grip the barbell with a grip slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Unrack the bar and lower it to your lower chest. 5. Press the bar back up to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith machine bench press throw
Desc: The Smith machine bench press throw is an exercise that helps develop pushing power that carries over to the traditional bench press. It involves pushing a relatively light weight (such as 30-50 percent of your 1RM) explosively and actually letting go at the top of the rep. It can work as power or speed-style training in a strength or athleticism-focused workout plan.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine to a suitable height. 2. Load a light weight (30-50% of your 1RM) on the bar. 3. Lie on the bench and grip the bar with a shoulder-width grip. 4. Lower the bar to your chest. 5. Explosively push the bar upward and release it at the top of the movement. 6. Catch the bar as it comes back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine chest fly
Desc: The machine chest fly is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a dumbbell fly or cable fly, but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. The chest fly is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height and sit down with your back against the pad. 2. Grip the handles with your arms extended out to the sides. 3. Slowly bring the handles together in front of your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles. 4. Return to the starting position with control. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Machine bench press
Desc: The machine bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest and upper body. It approximates the motion of a bench press, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine-based presses are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or chest-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height on the machine so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit down with your back against the pad and feet flat on the ground. 3. Grip the handles with your hands shoulder-width apart. 4. Push the handles away from your chest until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Machine Seated Chest Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine chest press is an upper body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height on the machine to align with your chest. 2. Sit down with your back against the pad and feet flat on the ground. 3. Grip the handles with your hands shoulder-width apart. 4. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine weighted push-up
Desc: The Smith machine weighted push-up is a pushing movement performed with a plate resting on the back or shoulders. It is performed most safely with a foot or so of space at the bottom to minimize the risk of getting "pinned" under the bar. It targets all the same muscles as a push-up, including the chest, triceps, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a height that allows you to perform push-ups comfortably. 2. Place a weight plate on your back or shoulders. 3. Position yourself in a push-up stance with your hands on the bar, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Lower your body towards the ground while keeping your elbows close to your sides. 5. Push back up to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine incline bench press-
Desc: The Smith machine incline bench press is a machine-based movement targeting the chest, particularly the upper chest. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to an incline position. 2. Lie on the bench with your back flat and feet firmly on the ground. 3. Grip the bar with a shoulder-width grip. 4. Unrack the bar and lower it to your upper chest. 5. Press the bar back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith machine decline bench press
Desc: The Smith machine decline bench press is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest muscles, particularly the lower pectoral muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height. 2. Lie on the decline bench and grip the bar with a shoulder-width grip. 3. Lower the bar to your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position, engaging your lower pectoral muscles. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: AM Pec Dec
Desc: The pec deck is a machine-based exercise targeting the chest. It approximates the motion of a dumbbell fly or cable fly, but is usually performed facing forward and seated upright. The motion is often compared to bear-hugging a tree trunk. The chest fly is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a pre-exhaust or muscle-building upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the pec deck machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 3. Grasp the handles and bring them together in front of your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position, maintaining control. 5. Perform for 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Flat Chest Press
Desc: The flat chest press on the chest machine targets the pectoral muscles, providing a controlled movement to build strength and size in the chest. Adjust the seat height and weight to ensure proper form.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height on the chest machine so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended, keeping your elbows slightly bent. 4. Slowly return to the starting position, feeling the stretch in your chest. 5. Complete 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith machine push-up
Desc: The Smith machine push-up is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It is similar in form to bodyweight push-ups, but with the hands on the bar of the Smith machine. This allows you to vary the height to increase or decrease difficulty, or to perform a mechanical dropset by raising the bar after hitting failure at a certain height.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a height that allows you to perform push-ups comfortably. 2. Position your hands on the bar, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body towards the bar by bending your elbows, keeping your body straight. 4. Push back up to the starting position. 5. Adjust the bar height to increase or decrease difficulty as needed. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest Smith Machine Incline Chest Press
Desc: The incline chest press on the Smith machine emphasizes the upper part of the pectoral muscles. This exercise helps in developing a well-rounded chest and can be adjusted for weight and incline to suit your fitness level.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height and set the incline of the bench. 2. Sit on the bench and grip the bar with a shoulder-width grip. 3. Lower the bar to your upper chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the bar back up to the starting position, focusing on your upper pectoral muscles. 5. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest Smith Machine Chest Press
Desc: The Smith machine chest press is a compound exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It allows for a stable movement pattern, making it ideal for building strength in the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height on the Smith machine chest press so that the handles are at chest level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Push the handles forward until your arms are fully extended, keeping your elbows slightly bent. 4. Slowly return to the starting position, feeling the stretch in your chest. 5. Complete 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Incline Chest Press
Desc: The incline chest press on the machine focuses on the upper chest and shoulders. It provides a guided motion that helps in isolating the chest muscles while minimizing the risk of injury.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height on the incline chest press machine so that the handles are at upper chest level. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Push the handles upward and together, focusing on your upper chest and shoulders. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Perform for 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest Machine Fly
Desc: The chest fly machine is designed to isolate the pectoral muscles, allowing for a greater stretch and contraction. This exercise is essential for developing chest width and definition.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the chest fly machine with your back against the pad. 2. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at chest level. 3. Grasp the handles and open your arms wide to the sides, feeling the stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the handles back together in front of your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Smith Machine Press
Desc: The 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Smith Machine Press is an effective exercise for targeting the upper chest muscles. Set the Smith machine bar at a 30-degree incline, lie back on a bench, and press the bar upwards while keeping your feet firmly on the ground.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar at a 30-degree incline. Lie back on a bench and grasp the bar with both hands. Keep your feet firmly on the ground, lower the bar to your chest, and then press it upwards until your arms are fully extended.

Title: Low-cable cross-over
Desc: The low-cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with presses or flyes from other angles to target all portions of the chest.
HowTo: Stand in the center of the cable machine with the pulleys set at a low position. Grasp the handles with both hands, step forward slightly, and pull the cables together in front of your chest while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Return to the starting position.

Title: Incline cable chest fly
Desc: The incline cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Set the incline bench at a 30-degree angle and adjust the cable pulleys to a low position. Lie back on the bench, grasp the cable handles, and with a slight bend in your elbows, open your arms wide to the sides. Bring the handles together above your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles.

Title: Cable Crossover
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Stand in the center of the cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles with both hands, step forward slightly, and pull the cables together in front of your chest while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Return to the starting position.

Title: Incline cable chest press
Desc: The incline cable chest press is a pressing movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles, similar to an incline dumbbell press. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, where it can be effective as a primary movement in classic hypertrophy rep ranges, as a pre-exhaust, or as a high-rep finisher. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Set the incline bench at a 30-degree angle and adjust the cable pulleys to a low position. Sit on the bench, grasp the cable handles, and press the cables forward until your arms are fully extended. Return to the starting position.

Title: Cable Chest Press
Desc: The Cable Chest Press is a great exercise for building chest strength and muscle definition. Stand between two cable machines, grab the handles, and press them forward until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Stand between two cable machines with the pulleys set at chest height. Grasp the handles with both hands and press them forward until your arms are fully extended. Slowly return to the starting position, keeping tension in the cables.

Title: Single-arm cable cross-over
Desc: The single-arm cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on the balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Stand beside a cable machine with the pulley set at a high position. Grasp the handle with one hand, step away from the machine, and pull the cable down and across your body, focusing on contracting your chest. Return to the starting position.

Title: Cable cross-over
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout or a finishing movement at the end. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Stand in the center of the cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles with both hands, step forward slightly, and pull the cables together in front of your chest while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Return to the starting position.

Title: Standing Cable Chest Press
Desc: The Standing Cable Chest Press is an effective exercise for targeting the chest muscles, particularly the pectoralis major. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cables at shoulder height. Grasp the handles and step forward to create tension in the cables. With your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees, press the handles forward until your arms are fully extended, then return to the starting position. This exercise helps improve upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine with the cables at shoulder height. 2. Grasp the handles and step forward to create tension in the cables. 3. With your feet shoulder-width apart and a slight bend in your knees, press the handles forward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Return to the starting position.

Title: Lying cable chest fly
Desc: The lying cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a flat bench to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout or as a finishing movement at the end. It is often used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with a cable stack on either side. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms extended above your chest. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the handles out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the handles back together above your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles.

Title: Paul Carter Cable Cross-Over
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with pulleys set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms extended out to the sides. 3. Pull the handles down and together in front of your body, focusing on contracting your chest muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: One-Arm Cable Crossover - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between sides of your chest, and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand beside a cable machine with the pulley set at a low position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and step away to create tension. 3. With your arm slightly bent, pull the handle across your body, focusing on your chest contraction. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Incline Cable Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an incline bench to target the upper portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a cable stack on either side. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms extended above your chest. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the handles out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your upper chest. 4. Bring the handles back together above your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles.

Title: Cable Cross-Over - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Stand in the center of a cable machine with pulleys set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms extended out to the sides. 3. Pull the handles down and together in front of your body, focusing on contracting your chest muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Seated cable chest fly
Desc: The seated cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and an upright bench to target the pectoral muscles. Being able to brace against a seat can help you stabilize your torso and focus on isolating the pecs, feeling them stretch and contract. It is usually used in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an upright bench with a cable stack on either side. 2. Grasp the handles with your arms extended out to the sides. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, bring the handles together in front of your chest, focusing on squeezing your pectoral muscles. 4. Slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm incline cable cross-over-
Desc: The single-arm incline cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a bench to target the upper part of the pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a cable stack on either side. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and step away to create tension. 3. With your arm slightly bent, pull the handle across your body, focusing on your upper chest contraction. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: High-to-low cable chest fly
Desc: The high-to-low cable chest fly is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to target the lower portion of the pectoral muscles. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often after pressing movements like the barbell or dumbbell bench press or as a finishing movement at the end of the workout. It is often used in combination with other flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Stand in the center of a cable machine with the pulleys set high. Grasp the handles with your palms facing down. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables down and together in a wide arc, focusing on squeezing the lower portion of your chest at the end of the movement.

Title: UP Cable Cross-Over
Desc: The cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack to build bigger and stronger pectoral muscles. Since it's done using adjustable pulleys, you can target different parts of your chest by setting the pulleys at different levels. It is common in upper body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often as a pre-exhaust at the beginning of a workout, or a finishing movement at the end. It is often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: Stand in the center of a cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles with your palms facing each other. Step forward slightly and pull the cables across your body in a wide arc, engaging your chest muscles as you bring the handles together in front of you.

Title: UP Cable Fly
Desc: The UP Cable Fly is an isolation exercise targeting the chest muscles, performed using a cable machine. Stand between the cable pulleys and pull the cables upward and inward, mimicking a fly motion to engage the upper chest.
HowTo: Stand between the cable pulleys with the cables set at a low position. Grasp the handles with your palms facing each other. Pull the cables upward and inward in a wide arc, mimicking a fly motion, while focusing on engaging your upper chest.

Title: 30 Chest Low-To-High Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Low-To-High Cable Fly is designed to target the upper chest and shoulders. Using a cable machine, pull the cables from a low position to a high position, focusing on squeezing the chest at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with the pulleys set low. Grasp the handles and pull them from a low position to a high position, focusing on squeezing your chest at the top of the movement while keeping your elbows slightly bent.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Cable Fly targets the upper chest and is performed on an incline bench. With cables set at a low position, pull the handles upward and outward to stretch and contract the chest muscles.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with the cables set at a low position. Grasp the handles and pull them upward and outward, stretching your chest muscles at the bottom and contracting them at the top of the movement.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Cable Chest Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Cable Chest Press is an effective exercise for building upper chest strength. While lying on an incline bench, press the cable handles upward from shoulder height, engaging the chest and triceps.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with the cable handles set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles and press them upward, engaging your chest and triceps as you extend your arms fully while keeping your elbows slightly bent.

Title: 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Press
Desc: The 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Press focuses on the lower chest. Stand with the cables set high and press downwards, keeping your elbows slightly bent and squeezing the chest at the bottom of the movement.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with the cables set high. Grasp the handles and press them downward, keeping your elbows slightly bent and focusing on squeezing your lower chest at the bottom of the movement.

Title: 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest High-To-Low Cable Fly is an exercise that targets the lower chest. Pull the cables from a high position to a low position in a fly motion, emphasizing the stretch and contraction of the chest muscles.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with the pulleys set high. Grasp the handles and pull the cables down and outward in a fly motion, emphasizing the stretch of your chest at the top and the contraction at the bottom.

Title: 30 Chest Shoulder-Height Cable Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Shoulder-Height Cable Fly is an exercise that targets the chest muscles by using a cable machine. Stand in the center of the machine, adjust the pulleys to shoulder height, and perform the fly movement by bringing the cables together in front of you while keeping a slight bend in your elbows.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Stand in the center of the cable machine with the pulleys adjusted to shoulder height. Grasp the handles with a slight bend in your elbows. Pull the cables together in front of you, focusing on squeezing your chest muscles, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Cable Pec Fly
Desc: The Cable Pec Fly is an isolation exercise that focuses on the pectoral muscles. Using a cable machine, set the pulleys to a high position, grab the handles, and pull them together in front of your chest while maintaining a slight bend in your elbows.
HowTo: Set the pulleys of the cable machine to a high position. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grab the handles, and pull them together in front of your chest while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Focus on engaging your pectoral muscles throughout the movement.

Title: Chest Push (multiple response)
Desc: The Chest Push (multiple response) is a compound exercise that engages the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It can be performed using various equipment such as a bench press, push-up, or machine press, allowing for multiple variations and responses in muscle engagement.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Choose your equipment (bench press, push-up, or machine press). For bench press, lie on the bench with feet flat on the floor, grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width, lower the bar to your chest, and press it back up. For push-ups, start in a plank position, lower your body until your chest is close to the ground, and push back up. For machine press, adjust the seat and grips, push the handles away from your chest, and return to the starting position.

Title: Medicine Ball Chest Pass
Desc: The Chest Push (single response) is a focused exercise that primarily targets the chest muscles. Typically performed with a barbell or dumbbells, this exercise involves pushing the weight away from the chest while lying on a bench.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell or dumbbells in hand. Start with the weight above your chest, then lower it towards your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Push the weight back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your chest muscles.

Title: Medicine ball sprawl to chest press
Desc: The Chest Push with Run Release combines a chest push movement with a running release. Start with a push-up position, perform a push-up, and then immediately transition into a running motion, alternating legs to engage the core and increase cardiovascular intensity.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid, Core Muscles
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your hands on the medicine ball. Perform a push-up, then roll the ball towards your chest as you push up. After the push-up, quickly transition into a running motion, alternating legs to engage your core and increase cardiovascular intensity.

Title: Medicine ball push-up
Desc: The medicine ball push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. The addition of the medicine ball adds a degree of difficulty and can increase chest and triceps activation.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid, Core Muscles
HowTo: Place one hand on a medicine ball and the other on the floor to start in a push-up position. Lower your body as you would in a standard push-up, then push back up. Switch the ball to the other hand and repeat. Focus on maintaining balance and engaging your chest and triceps.

Title: Chest Push (single response)
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell or dumbbells in hand. Start with the weight above your chest, lower it towards your chest while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle, then push the weight back up to the starting position, focusing on your chest.

Title: Chest Push with Run Release
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoid
HowTo: Start in a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then as you push back up, jump forward into a running motion, alternating legs. This combines the chest push movement with a cardio element, engaging your core throughout.

Title: Chest Push from 3 point stance
Desc: The Chest Push from a 3 point stance is an exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. Start in a 3 point stance with one hand on the ground and the other hand pushing forward as if performing a chest press. This exercise enhances upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: Start in a 3 point stance with one hand on the ground and the other hand pushing forward. Engage your chest, shoulders, and triceps as you perform the movement, mimicking a chest press. Focus on maintaining stability and control throughout the exercise.

Title: Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. It’s a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, it’s often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: Lie back on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Press the dumbbells up above your chest with your arms fully extended. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows at about a 45-degree angle. Press the weights back up to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The dumbbell chest fly is a popular exercise that targets the pectoral or chest muscles. It attempts to isolate the chest muscles, stretching and contracting them while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Unlike a press, where the elbows bend and flex, flyes should keep a relatively consistent elbow angle. The motion is sometimes compared to "hugging a tree." Dumbbell flyes are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your chest with a slight bend in your elbows. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, feeling a stretch in your chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest while keeping the elbows at a consistent angle.

Title: Incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is a popular upper-body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Press the dumbbells up above your upper chest with your arms fully extended. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your upper chest, keeping your elbows at a slight angle. Press the weights back up to the starting position.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The decline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower chest. It will require less weight than a decline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your chest with a slight bend in your elbows. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, focusing on the stretch in your lower chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest while maintaining the elbow angle.

Title: Reverse-grip incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The reverse-grip incline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles. Pressing with a reverse grip targets the upper chest in particular, especially when performed on an incline. This press variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand using a reverse grip (palms facing you). Press the dumbbells up above your upper chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your upper chest, keeping your elbows at a slight angle. Press the weights back up to the starting position.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Flyes
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your chest with a slight bend in your elbows. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, focusing on the stretch in your upper chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest while maintaining the elbow angle.

Title: Neutral-grip dumbbell bench press
Desc: The neutral-grip dumbbell bench press is a variation on a classic chest-building exercise where the palms face each other instead of forward. This shift puts the elbows closer to the sides, placing more emphasis on the triceps, and perhaps also the inner chest. The neutral-grip press can be performed in lower reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: Lie back on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. Press the dumbbells up above your chest with your arms fully extended. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. Press the weights back up to the starting position.

Title: Decline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The decline dumbbell bench press is a popular upper-body exercise targeting the lower pectoral muscles. While it can be a strength-focused movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: Lie back on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest while keeping your elbows slightly tucked. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell row
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell row is a popular muscle- and strength-building exercise that works the muscles of the back and core simultaneously. It has all the same benefits as a single-arm dumbbell row, but some people find a kettlebell more comfortable to hold during the movement.
HowTo: Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the ground. Hold a kettlebell in the opposite hand. Pull the kettlebell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press
Desc: The Hammer Grip Incline DB Bench Press targets the upper chest and shoulders. Perform this exercise by lying on an incline bench with dumbbells held in a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Press the dumbbells upward while keeping your elbows slightly tucked, then lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to the sides of your chest.

Title: Straight-arm dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The straight-arm dumbbell pull-over is an exercise that targets the muscles of the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Performing this movement with straight arms makes it more difficult, increases the stretch on the serratus muscles and lats, and forces the core to work harder. Old-school bodybuilders would perform pull-overs with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but they are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Latissimus Dorsi, Serratus Anterior
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a dumbbell held in both hands above your chest, arms straight. Lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping your arms straight, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Bench With Palms Facing In
Desc: The Incline Dumbbell Bench With Palms Facing In focuses on the upper chest and triceps. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inwards. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to the sides of your chest.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing inwards. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to the sides of your chest.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Flyes - With A Twist
Desc: Incline Dumbbell Flyes - With A Twist is an exercise that targets the chest muscles. Start by lying on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc. As you bring the dumbbells back together, twist your wrists so that your palms face each other at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc. As you bring the dumbbells back together, twist your wrists so that your palms face each other at the top of the movement.

Title: Bent-arm dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The bent-arm dumbbell pull-over was a staple exercise of the "Golden Era" of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise targets the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Old-school bodybuilders would perform them with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but pull-overs are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Latissimus Dorsi, Serratus Anterior
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a dumbbell held in both hands above your chest, arms bent at 90 degrees. Lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping your arms bent, then pull it back to the starting position.

Title: Close-grip dumbbell bench press
Desc: The close-grip dumbbell bench press is a popular variation of the dumbbell bench press in which the dumbbells are held closer than shoulder width. This places more emphasis on the triceps, and perhaps also the inner chest. The close-grip dumbbell bench press can be performed in lower reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: Lie back on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held closer than shoulder width. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Single-dumbbell push-up
Desc: The single-dumbbell push-up is a more difficult push-up variation where you balance your hands on the ends of a dumbbell. This simple change makes many muscle groups work harder, helping encourage muscle and strength gains across the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with your hands on the ends of a dumbbell. 2. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows while keeping your body straight. 3. Push back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye
Desc: The One-Arm Flat Bench Dumbbell Flye is an isolation exercise that targets the chest muscles, particularly the pectorals. To perform this exercise, lie on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell above your chest. Lower the dumbbell out to the side in a controlled manner, keeping your elbow slightly bent, until you feel a stretch in your chest. Return to the starting position by contracting your chest muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a flat bench with one arm holding a dumbbell above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell out to the side in a controlled manner, keeping your elbow slightly bent, until you feel a stretch in your chest. 3. Return to the starting position by contracting your chest muscles. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Floor Chest Fly
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Floor Chest Fly is a chest exercise that focuses on the pectoral muscles. To perform this exercise, lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. Extend your arms straight above your chest, palms facing each other. Slowly lower the dumbbells out to the sides until your elbows touch the floor, then bring them back together over your chest, squeezing your pectorals.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend your arms straight above your chest, palms facing each other. 3.
