Slowly lower the dumbbells out to the sides until your elbows touch the floor. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together over your chest, squeezing your pectorals. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Traveling Push-Up
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Traveling Push-Up is a dynamic exercise that combines push-ups with a lateral movement. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a push-up, and as you push back up, move one hand and the corresponding foot to the side, shifting your body laterally. Alternate sides with each push-up to engage the chest, shoulders, and core while enhancing stability and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a push-up by lowering your body towards the ground. 3. As you push back up, move one hand and the corresponding foot to the side, shifting your body laterally. 4. Alternate sides with each push-up. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Incline dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest. Performing it at an incline helps to target the upper chest in particular, while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Fly variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Extend your arms above your chest, palms facing each other. 3. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a controlled manner, feeling a stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest. 5. Repeat for 8-12 repetitions.

Title: Paul Carter Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It’s a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keeping your arms straight, raise your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing your trapezius muscles. 3. Lower your shoulders back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell push-up row
Desc: The dumbbell push-up row combines pressing, rowing, and core stabilization into a single sequence. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Rhomboids, Core
HowTo: 1. Start in a push-up position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a push-up by lowering your body towards the ground. 3. At the top of the push-up, row one dumbbell towards your hip while balancing on the other arm. 4. Alternate sides with each repetition. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: TBS Dumbbell Incline Press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with the dumbbells at shoulder level, palms facing forward. 3. Press the dumbbells up until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder level. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a 30-45 degree angle. 2. Lie back on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest, squeezing your pecs at the top. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell bench press-
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of lifters worldwide. It's a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest and triceps. It's often placed first in mass-building chest workouts, but can also be utilized as an accessory movement for the barbell bench press in strength training. It can be performed in lower strength-focused rep ranges, or for higher reps to build muscle.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows at about a 45-degree angle to your body. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Decline dumbbell fly and press
Desc: The decline dumbbell fly and press is a dumbbell complex that targets the chest muscles, particularly the lower pecs. By alternating the single-joint fly with the multijoint press, you get the benefits of both and put serious stress on the chest muscles even with relatively light weight. Because the fly will be the limiting factor in weight selection, this pairing is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with the dumbbells above your chest, arms extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, feeling the stretch in your chest. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest while pressing them up. 5. Alternate between the fly and press for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline dumbbell fly and press
Desc: The incline dumbbell fly and press is a dumbbell complex that targets the chest muscles, particularly the upper pecs. By alternating the single-joint fly with the multijoint press, you get the benefits of both and put serious stress on the chest muscles even with relatively light weight. Because the fly will be the limiting factor in weight selection, this pairing is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with the dumbbells above your chest, arms extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, feeling the stretch in your upper chest. 4. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest while pressing them up. 5. Alternate between the fly and press for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm decline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The single-arm decline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles, particularly the lower pecs. Because balance can be an issue, this press variation is usually performed with lighter weight for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a decline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Start with the dumbbell above your chest, arm extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell to your chest, keeping your elbow at about a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the dumbbell back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Single-arm incline dumbbell bench press
Desc: The single-arm incline dumbbell bench press is an upper-body exercise targeting the pectoral muscles. Because balance can be an issue, this press variation is usually performed with lighter weight for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Start with the dumbbell above your chest, arm extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell to your chest, keeping your elbow at about a 45-degree angle. 4. Press the dumbbell back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows at about a 45-degree angle to your body. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Chest Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. It’s a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, it’s often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells to your chest, keeping your elbows at about a 45-degree angle to your body. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, fully extending your arms. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Floor Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to build strength in the top portion of the lift and work on strengthening the shoulder stabilizers.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps Brachii, Anterior Deltoids
HowTo: Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells until your upper arms are resting on the floor, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The decline dumbbell bench press is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower chest. Utilizing dumbbells instead of a barbell increases the difficulty of stabilizing the weight.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows slightly bent. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The dumbbell chest fly is a popular exercise that targets the pectoral or chest muscles. It attempts to isolate the chest muscles, stretching and contracting them while limiting involvement of the shoulders. Unlike a press, where the elbows bend and flex, flyes should keep a relatively consistent elbow angle. The motion is sometimes compared to "hugging a tree." Dumbbell flyes are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a chest or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles.

Title: Machine rear delt fly
Desc: The machine rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear head of the shoulder muscle or deltoids, as well as the muscles of the upper back. It's sort of the reverse of the machine chest fly, and is sometimes performed on the same machine, but facing the opposite direction. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Sit on the machine with your chest against the pad and grasp the handles. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the handles back in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Return to the starting position.

Title: AM Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The dumbbell bench press is a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. It’s a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. As such, it’s often placed first in mass-building chest workouts.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Incline Dumbbell Press
Desc: The incline dumbbell bench press is an upper body exercise targeting the upper pectoral muscles.
Muscles: Upper Pectoralis Major, Anterior Deltoids, Triceps
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, keeping your elbows slightly bent. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position.

Title: UP Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell chest fly is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the upper chest and is typically used with aesthetic goals in mind. It will require less weight than an incline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your upper chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest, squeezing your pectoral muscles.

Title: Holman Push-Up to Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Push-Up to Belly Touch is a challenging upper body exercise that combines a traditional push-up with a belly touch at the bottom of the movement. Start in a push-up position, lower your body to the ground, and as you push back up, touch your belly with your hand before returning to the starting position. This exercise targets the chest, triceps, and core, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lower your body to the ground as in a standard push-up. At the bottom, touch your belly with one hand before pushing back up to the starting position. Alternate hands with each repetition.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell floor press
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell floor press is a multijoint pressing exercise performed lying on the floor, either with the knees bent or straight. It has less range of motion than a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. By performing it with one arm, you can strengthen weakness on certain sides or simply use it as a way to challenge the core more during this exercise.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Anterior Deltoids, Core
HowTo: Lie on the floor with one dumbbell in one hand. Keep your knees bent or straight. Lower the dumbbell to your chest, then press it back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Total Fitness Weighted Push-Up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Triceps, Anterior Deltoids, Core
HowTo: Get into a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Have a weight plate placed on your upper back. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position. Ensure you have a spotter if using multiple plates.

Title: King Maker Standing Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-builder (especially the front deltoids) that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows for more weight to be used.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position. Keep your core engaged and avoid arching your back.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Fly is an effective exercise targeting the upper chest muscles. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With your arms slightly bent, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest, then bring them back together above your chest.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With your arms slightly bent, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch in your chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest.

Title: 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Incline Dumbbell Bench Press is a powerful exercise for building upper chest strength. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Press focuses on building overall chest strength. Sit or lie down with a dumbbell in each hand, held together above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit or lie down with a dumbbell in each hand, held together above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Incline Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Dumbbells-Together Incline Bench Press targets the upper chest and shoulders. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, pressed together above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up, keeping them together.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, pressed together above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up, keeping them together.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest Dumbbell Fly is a classic exercise for isolating the chest muscles. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch, then bring them back together.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides until you feel a stretch, then bring them back together.

Title: 30 Chest Dumbbell Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Chest Dumbbell Bench Press is an effective exercise for targeting the pectoral muscles. Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.
HowTo: Lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells to the sides of your chest, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Fly
Desc: The 30 Chest 30-Degree Incline Dumbbell Fly is designed to isolate the chest muscles while minimizing shoulder strain. Set an incline bench to 30 degrees. Lie back with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, then bring them back together above your chest.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Anterior Deltoids
HowTo: Set an incline bench to 30 degrees. Lie back with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc, then bring them back together above your chest.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Push-Up
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates a single dumbbell for added resistance. Place one hand on a dumbbell while the other hand is on the floor. Perform a push-up, keeping your body straight and engaging your core. Alternate sides after a set number of repetitions.
HowTo: Place one hand on a dumbbell while the other hand is on the floor. Perform a push-up, keeping your body straight and engaging your core. Alternate sides after a set number of repetitions.

Title: Bodyweight Flyes
Desc: The Drop Push is a challenging bodyweight exercise that combines a push-up with a drop set. Start in a push-up position and perform a push-up. After completing the push-up, drop to your knees and perform a set of knee push-ups. This exercise helps build strength and endurance in the upper body.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position and perform a push-up. After completing the push-up, drop to your knees and perform a set of knee push-ups.

Title: Close-grip EZ-bar bench press
Desc: The Forward Drag with Press is a dynamic exercise that targets the shoulders and chest. Start in a standing position with a resistance band or cable attached to a low anchor point. Hold the handles and step back to create tension. Pull the handles towards your body while simultaneously pressing them overhead, engaging your core throughout the movement.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with a resistance band or cable attached to a low anchor point. Hold the handles and step back to create tension. Pull the handles towards your body while simultaneously pressing them overhead.

Title: Chest dip
Desc: The chest dip is a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders. Dips with a chest focus are usually performed with the torso leaning forward and the elbows angled out from the torso. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: Perform dips on parallel bars or a dip station. Lean your torso forward and angle your elbows out from your body as you lower yourself down, then push back up to the starting position.

Title: Drop Push
HowTo: Start in a push-up position and perform a push-up. After completing the push-up, drop to your knees and perform a set of knee push-ups.

Title: Forward Drag with Press
HowTo: Start in a standing position with a resistance band or cable attached to a low anchor point. Hold the handles and step back to create tension. Pull the handles towards your body while simultaneously pressing them overhead.

Title: Chain Press
Desc: The Chain Press is an upper body exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It involves pressing a weight upwards while lying on a bench, with chains added for variable resistance.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. Hold a weight in each hand at chest level, with chains attached. Press the weights upwards until your arms are fully extended. Lower the weights back to the starting position while maintaining control.

Title: Behind Head Chest Stretch
Desc: The Behind Head Chest Stretch is a flexibility exercise that stretches the chest and shoulders. It involves reaching behind the head with both arms and pulling gently to enhance the stretch.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Pectoralis Minor, Anterior Deltoids
HowTo: Stand or sit up straight. Reach both arms behind your head, grasping your elbows or wrists. Gently pull your arms down and back to stretch your chest and shoulders. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: Pass-through stretch with band
Desc: The pass-through stretch with band is a popular move to build and maintain mobility in the shoulder joint and to strengthen the muscles of the upper back and rotator cuff. It is common in CrossFit and Olympic lifting training and is usually performed as part of a warm-up or paired with movements in a workout. It can also be performed with a PVC pipe or dowel if a band isn't available.
Muscles: Pectoralis Major, Upper Back, Rotator Cuff
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a resistance band or PVC pipe with both hands in front of you. Raise the band or pipe overhead and then bring it behind your head, keeping your arms straight. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Weighted Push-Up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
HowTo: Get into a push-up position with your hands shoulder-width apart. Have a partner place a weight plate on your upper back. Lower your body until your chest nearly touches the ground, then push back up to the starting position. Ensure you have a spotter if using multiple plates.

Title: Heavy Bag Thrust
Desc: The Heavy Bag Thrust is a striking exercise that focuses on power and technique. It involves thrusting punches into a heavy bag to build strength and improve coordination.
HowTo: Stand in front of a heavy bag with your feet shoulder-width apart. Throw powerful punches into the bag, focusing on technique and speed. Rotate your hips and shoulders with each punch to maximize power.

Title: Decline Explosive Push-Up
Desc: The Decline Explosive Push-Up is a dynamic bodyweight exercise that targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps. It involves performing a push-up from a decline position and explosively pushing off the ground.
HowTo: Start in a decline push-up position with your feet elevated on a bench or platform. Lower your body towards the ground, then explosively push off the ground, lifting your hands off the floor. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Suspended Chest Fly
Desc: The Suspended Chest Fly is an exercise that targets the chest muscles using suspension training. It involves extending the arms out to the sides while maintaining tension in the suspension straps.
HowTo: Adjust the suspension straps to a suitable height. Stand facing away from the anchor point, holding the straps with your arms extended in front of you. Lean forward slightly and then extend your arms out to the sides, keeping tension in the straps. Return to the starting position.

Title: Svend press
Desc: The Svend press is an exercise where the chest is targeted by performing presses while squeezing two weight plates together. It is usually performed for relatively high reps with light weights as an accessory movement to the bench press or as a burnout movement on chest day.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding two weight plates together at chest level. Press the plates out in front of you while squeezing them together. Return to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Bar Push-Up Smith Machine
Desc: The hands-elevated push-up is a variation on the push-up, a body-weight standard. The hands are elevated, so that your body is aligned at an angle to the floor rather than parallel.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your hands on the elevated bar of the Smith machine. Lower your body towards the bar while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Push back up to the starting position, maintaining a straight line from head to heels.

Title: Plate-weighted push-up
Desc: The plate-weighted push-up is a simple way to make a classic bodyweight exercise more difficult. It targets all the same muscles as the push-up: chest, triceps, shoulders, upper back, and core. You can balance a plate on your upper back yourself, but it's easier and safer to have someone else put it there. If you stack a few plates up, be sure to have a spotter close at hand.
HowTo: Begin in a standard push-up position. Have a weight plate placed on your upper back. Lower your body into a push-up, keeping your core tight and back straight. Push back up to the starting position. Ensure you have a spotter to help place the plate safely.

Title: Double-bar roll-out chest fly
Desc: The double-bar roll-out chest fly is a chest exercise that utilizes two rotating barbells as "handles" for a chest fly. It targets the muscles of the chest, but is also an intense core workout. It's a tough movement that is usually performed in the chest-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Set up two rotating barbells at shoulder width. Start in a standing position, then lean forward and grasp the bars. Roll out while keeping your core engaged, then perform a fly motion by spreading your arms wide. Return to the starting position by rolling back in.

Title: Holman Plate Dynamo Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Plate Dynamo Push-Up is a dynamic upper body exercise that combines the push-up movement with the stabilization challenge of a plate. Start in a push-up position with your hands on a weight plate. As you lower your body, slide the plate to one side, then push back up and return the plate to the center. Alternate sides for a full set.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with your hands on a weight plate. Lower your body while sliding the plate to one side. Push back up to the starting position and return the plate to the center. Alternate sides with each repetition.

Title: Holman Towel Drag Two Steps to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Towel Drag Two Steps to Push-Up involves using a towel on a smooth surface to enhance the push-up. Begin in a push-up position with a towel under each hand. As you lower down, drag your hands back towards your feet while taking two steps back. Then push back up into the starting position. This exercise improves strength and coordination.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with a towel under each hand. As you lower down, drag your hands back towards your feet while taking two steps back. Push back up to the starting position, ensuring to keep your core engaged throughout.

Title: Taylor Val Slide Push-Up/Fly Combo
Desc: The Taylor Val Slide Push-Up/Fly Combo is a challenging exercise that combines push-ups with a fly movement. Start in a push-up position with your hands on sliders. As you lower into the push-up, slide your hands out to the sides to perform a fly, then return to the center and push back up. This targets the chest, shoulders, and core.
HowTo: Begin in a push-up position with your hands on sliders. Lower your body into a push-up while sliding your hands out to the sides to perform a fly. Return your hands to the center and push back up to the starting position.

Title: Exercise ball chest stretch
Desc: The exercise ball chest stretch is a simple stretch for the pectoral muscles that can be made more dynamic with help from a medicine ball. It can work in a dynamic warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy. If the stretch causes pain in the front of your shoulder, dial back the intensity or choose another chest stretch.
HowTo: Lie back on an exercise ball with your feet planted on the ground. Open your arms wide to stretch your chest, keeping your shoulders down. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, and if you feel any pain, reduce the intensity.

Title: Bosu Ball Push-Up
Desc: The Bosu Ball Push-Up is a variation of the traditional push-up that incorporates a Bosu ball for added instability. Place your hands on the flat side of the Bosu ball and perform a push-up. This exercise engages the core and stabilizing muscles more than a standard push-up.
HowTo: Position your hands on the flat side of a Bosu ball in a push-up stance. Lower your body towards the ground while maintaining balance. Push back up to the starting position, engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: Feet-elevated push-up on ball
Desc: The feet-elevated push-up on ball is a variation on the push-up, a bodyweight standard. The feet are elevated on a ball to align the body parallel to the floor and provide a greater stabilization challenge. This makes it more difficult than push-ups on the floor, but also puts more emphasis on the shoulder muscles. It can be a challenging non-gym substitute for incline presses, or as a burnout movement for a chest or shoulder workout.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your feet elevated on a stability ball. Lower your body towards the ground by bending your elbows, keeping your body straight. Push back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing alternating band speed row
Desc: The standing alternating band speed row is an explosive back exercise using exercise bands. It targets the muscles of the middle and upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and trapezius, as well as the biceps. It can be performed for time or reps either as part of a power or speed-focused portion of a workout or as a burnout at the end of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold an exercise band in both hands. Pull the band towards your chest in an alternating fashion, focusing on engaging your back muscles. Perform for a set time or number of reps.

Title: Band roundhouse elbow
Desc: The band roundhouse elbow is an explosive rotational power exercise using exercise bands. It targets the muscles of the obliques and deep core, but also engrains full-body coordination and striking ability. It can work in an ab workout, in martial arts training, or in general strength and muscle training.
HowTo: Attach an exercise band to a stable anchor. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with both hands. Rotate your torso and extend your arms as if throwing an elbow strike, engaging your core and obliques. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Palms-down wrist curl over bench
Desc: The palms-down wrist curl over bench is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on the edge, palms facing down. Hold a weight in each hand and curl your wrists up towards your body. Lower back down and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Palms-up wrist curl over bench
Desc: The palms-up wrist curl over bench is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on the edge, palms facing up. Hold a weight in each hand and curl your wrists up towards your body. Lower back down and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Standing behind-the-back wrist curl
Desc: The standing behind-the-back wrist curl is a popular exercise to target the muscles in the forearms, wrists, and fingers. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, and can work as isolated forearm training or as part of an arms-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with a weight in each hand, arms hanging behind your back. Curl your wrists up towards your body while keeping your elbows close to your sides. Lower back down and repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: Seated finger curl
Desc: The seated finger curl is an exercise targeting the muscles of the hands and forearms. It is popular with rock climbers and other athletes looking to build forearm size and strength. The range of motion is tiny, but done for moderate to high reps, these will definitely make the forearms burn.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs, holding a weight in each hand. Curl your fingers towards your palms, focusing on squeezing the forearm muscles. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated palms-up wrist curl
Desc: The seated palms-up wrist curl is an exercise targeting the forearms. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a grip or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on the edge, palms facing up. Hold a weight in each hand and curl your wrists up towards your body. Lower back down and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Bottoms-Up Clean From The Hang Position
Desc: The Bottoms-Up Clean from the Hang Position is a dynamic exercise that focuses on developing explosive strength and coordination. Start in a hang position with the barbell at knee level, then explosively pull the barbell up while flipping it to a 'bottoms-up' position, catching it in a front rack position.
HowTo: Start in a hang position with the barbell at knee level. Explosively pull the barbell up while flipping it to a 'bottoms-up' position. Catch the barbell in a front rack position.

Title: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl targets the forearm muscles, particularly the wrist flexors. Sit on a bench with your forearm resting on your thigh, holding a dumbbell with your palm facing up. Curl the dumbbell towards your body, focusing on squeezing the forearm at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearm resting on your thigh, holding a dumbbell with your palm facing up. Curl the dumbbell towards your body, squeezing the forearm at the top of the movement.

Title: Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
Desc: The Palms-Up Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench is an effective exercise for strengthening the wrist flexors. Lean forward over a bench with your forearms resting on it, palms facing up, and hold a dumbbell in each hand. Curl the weights up towards your body, then lower them back down in a controlled manner.
HowTo: Lean forward over a bench with your forearms resting on it, palms facing up. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl the weights up towards your body, then lower them back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Seated palms-down wrist curl
Desc: The Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench targets the wrist extensors. Similar to the palms-up variation, lean over a bench with your forearms resting on it, but this time with your palms facing down. Curl the dumbbells upwards, focusing on the contraction of the muscles in the back of the forearm.
HowTo: Lean over a bench with your forearms resting on it, palms facing down. Curl the dumbbells upwards, focusing on the contraction of the muscles in the back of the forearm.

Title: Palms-Down Dumbbell Wrist Curl Over A Bench
Desc: The Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl is designed to strengthen the wrist extensors. Sit on a bench, resting your forearm on your thigh with your palm facing down. Hold a dumbbell and curl it upwards, focusing on the movement of the wrist and the contraction of the forearm muscles.
HowTo: Sit on a bench, resting your forearm on your thigh with your palm facing down. Hold a dumbbell and curl it upwards, focusing on the movement of the wrist and the contraction of the forearm muscles.

Title: Seated One-Arm Dumbbell Palms-Down Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl is a straightforward exercise for building forearm strength. Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs, palms facing up. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl them towards your body, ensuring to fully extend and contract the wrist.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs, palms facing up. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl them towards your body, ensuring to fully extend and contract the wrist.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Palms-Up Wrist Curl
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your forearms resting on your thighs, palms facing up. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and curl them towards your body, ensuring to fully extend and contract the wrist.

Title: Partner farmer's walk
Desc: The partner farmer's walk is a protocol for performing farmer's carries with dumbbells or other weights. One partner walks for a predetermined distance or time, then passes the weight to the other partner who walks for the same distance or time.
HowTo: One partner walks for a predetermined distance or time while carrying weights. After completing the distance or time, they pass the weight to the other partner, who then walks for the same distance or time.

Title: Dumbbell suitcase carry
Desc: The dumbbell suitcase carry is similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, but only uses one dumbbell rather than two. This simple change provides a significant challenge to the abdominal muscles. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell suitcase carry, stand upright holding a dumbbell in one hand at your side. Keep your core engaged and shoulders back. Walk forward for a set distance or time while maintaining good posture.

Title: Suitcase Dumbbell Carry
Desc: The dumbbell suitcase carry is similar to a dumbbell farmer’s carry, but only uses one dumbbell rather than two. This simple change provides a significant challenge to the abdominal muscles. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: To perform the suitcase dumbbell carry, stand tall with a dumbbell in one hand. Engage your core and walk forward, keeping your body stable and avoiding leaning to one side.

Title: Side plank with dumbbell external rotation
Desc: The side plank with dumbbell external rotation is a movement that combines an isometric side plank hold with a dumbbell rotation to target both the core and the rotator cuff muscles. You probably won't be able to use much weight without disrupting your balance, but even at light weight, this is a movement that can help address multiple muscle groups in a dynamic warm-up or as accessory work at the end of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the side plank with dumbbell external rotation, start in a side plank position with your body in a straight line. Hold a dumbbell in the top hand and rotate it down towards your waist, then back up to the starting position while maintaining the plank.

Title: Rickshaw Carry
Desc: The Rickshaw Carry is a functional strength exercise that involves carrying a weighted rickshaw or similar implement over a set distance. It targets the legs, core, and grip strength, while also improving overall stability and endurance.
HowTo: To perform the rickshaw carry, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the handles of a weighted rickshaw. Keep your core tight and walk forward for a designated distance, focusing on maintaining stability and posture.

Title: Dumbbell farmer's walk
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell farmer's walk, pick up a dumbbell in each hand and stand tall. Engage your core and walk forward for a set distance while keeping your shoulders back and maintaining good posture.

Title: Wrist Roller
Desc: The Wrist Roller is an exercise that focuses on strengthening the forearm muscles and improving grip strength. It involves rolling a weight attached to a rope up and down using wrist movements.
HowTo: To perform the wrist roller, hold the wrist roller with both hands at shoulder height. Roll the weight up by twisting your wrists, then slowly lower it back down. Repeat for a set number of repetitions.

Title: Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze
Desc: The Standing Olympic Plate Hand Squeeze is an exercise that targets the forearms and grip strength. It involves holding an Olympic weight plate with both hands and squeezing it while standing, engaging the muscles of the hands and forearms.
HowTo: To perform the standing Olympic plate hand squeeze, hold an Olympic weight plate with both hands at chest level. Squeeze the plate tightly while standing, engaging your forearm muscles. Hold for a set duration.

Title: Plate Pinch
Desc: The Plate Pinch is an exercise designed to enhance grip strength. It involves pinching two weight plates together with your fingers and holding them for a set duration, engaging the muscles of the hands and forearms.
HowTo: To perform the plate pinch, take two weight plates and pinch them together with your fingers. Hold this position for a set duration, focusing on engaging your grip strength.

Title: Landmine Press and Catch
Desc: The single-arm linear jammer is an explosive pressing movement performed using an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The linear jammer involves pressing the weight into the air, then catching it with the other hand. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges, for lower reps with a focus on explosive pressing power, or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Set up a landmine device with a barbell anchored at floor level. 2. Stand facing the barbell, holding it with one hand. 3. Press the barbell explosively into the air. 4. Catch the barbell with the other hand as it comes down. 5. Repeat for desired reps, focusing on explosive power and shoulder engagement.

Title: Plate halo
Desc: The plate halo is an exercise targeting the shoulder complex. It's usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up prior to an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate at chest level. 2. Rotate the plate around your head in a circular motion, keeping your arms extended. 3. Perform the halo in both directions for desired reps.

Title: Bryant Wrist Curl
Desc: The Bryant Wrist Curl is an isolation exercise targeting the wrist flexors, performed by curling a weight towards the body while seated.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor. 2. Hold a weight in one hand with your palm facing up. 3. Curl the weight towards your body by flexing your wrist. 4. Lower the weight back down and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl
Desc: The Seated Two-Arm Palms-Up Low-Pulley Wrist Curl is a strength training exercise that targets the forearm muscles, performed by pulling a low pulley towards the body with both arms while seated.
HowTo: 1. Sit at a low pulley machine with your arms extended and palms facing up. 2. Grasp the handles with both hands. 3. Pull the handles towards your body by flexing your wrists. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Cable Wrist Curl
Desc: The Cable Wrist Curl is an exercise that focuses on strengthening the wrist flexors, performed by curling a cable attachment towards the body.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit at a cable machine with the cable attachment set low. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand, palm facing up. 3. Curl the cable towards your body by flexing your wrist. 4. Lower the handle back down and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Single-arm cable push-down
Desc: The single-arm cable push-down is a single-joint isolation movement that develops the triceps muscle one arm at a time. Because the action is purely at the elbow joint, it is difficult to use any substantial weight. Reps are usually high, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, with a focus on strict form and feeling the mind-muscle connection.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the cable set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Keeping your elbow close to your body, extend your arm downwards, pushing the cable down. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for desired reps.

Title: Wrist Circles
Desc: Wrist Circles are a mobility exercise that involves rotating the wrists in circular motions to improve flexibility and range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit comfortably. 2. Extend your arms in front of you with your palms facing down. 3. Rotate your wrists in circular motions, first clockwise and then counterclockwise. 4. Continue for desired duration.

Title: Kneeling Forearm Stretch
Desc: The Kneeling Forearm Stretch is a flexibility exercise that stretches the forearm muscles, performed by kneeling and extending the arms forward on the ground.
HowTo: 1. Kneel on the ground with your knees hip-width apart. 2. Extend your arms forward on the ground, palms facing down. 3. Lean forward gently to feel a stretch in your forearms. 4. Hold the stretch for desired duration.

Title: Hip Extension with Bands
Desc: The Hip Extension with Bands is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. To perform this exercise, secure a resistance band around your ankles or just above your knees. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, hinge at the hips, and extend one leg back while keeping your core engaged. Return to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: To perform the Hip Extension with Bands, secure a resistance band around your ankles or just above your knees. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, hinge at the hips, and extend one leg back while keeping your core engaged. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Hip Lift with Band
Desc: The Hip Lift with Band is designed to strengthen the glutes and lower back. Begin by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Press through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat.
HowTo: To perform the Hip Lift with Band, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Press through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: HM Monster Walk
Desc: The HM Monster Walk is a lateral movement exercise that targets the hip abductors and glutes. Start by placing a resistance band around your thighs or ankles. With your knees slightly bent, take a step to the side, keeping tension in the band. Continue stepping sideways for a set distance or number of steps, then return in the opposite direction.
HowTo: To perform the HM Monster Walk, place a resistance band around your thighs or ankles. With your knees slightly bent, take a step to the side, keeping tension in the band. Continue stepping sideways for a set distance or number of steps, then return in the opposite direction.

Title: UNS Banded Glute Bridge
Desc: The UNS Banded Glute Bridge is an effective exercise for activating the glutes. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Push through your heels to lift your hips off the ground, squeezing your glutes at the top. Hold for a moment before lowering back down.
HowTo: To perform the UNS Banded Glute Bridge, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Push through your heels to lift your hips off the ground, squeezing your glutes at the top. Hold for a moment before lowering back down.

Title: FYR2 Banded Glute Bridge
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Glute Bridge is similar to the traditional glute bridge but adds resistance for increased intensity. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Position a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Drive through your heels to lift your hips, engaging your glutes and core. Hold briefly at the top before lowering back down.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Banded Glute Bridge, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Position a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Drive through your heels to lift your hips, engaging your glutes and core. Hold briefly at the top before lowering back down.

Title: Piriformis SMR
Desc: Piriformis self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the piriformis muscles in the upper gluteal region, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle to relax or "release." Piriformis SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the iliotibial (IT) band or tensor fascia lata (TFL muscles), or by stretches that target the glutes and hips.
Muscles: Piriformis, Glutes, Iliotibial Band (IT Band), Tensor Fascia Lata (TFL)
HowTo: To perform Piriformis SMR, use a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other massage tool. Sit or lie down and place the tool under your gluteal region, targeting the piriformis muscle. Apply pressure and roll gently to release tension in the muscle.

Title: Barbell glute bridge
Desc: The barbell glute bridge is a popular exercise targeting the muscles of the glutes and hamstrings. It can be done as a strength movement on its own, as an activation drill or warm-up for lower-body training, or as a burnout at the end of a lower-body workout.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Glute Bridge, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Position a barbell across your hips. Push through your heels to lift your hips off the ground, squeezing your glutes at the top. Hold briefly before lowering back down.

Title: Barbell Hip Thrust
Desc: The barbell hip thrust is an exercise that engages the posterior chain, particular the glutes. It involves fully extending your hips while holding a weighted barbell across the midsection.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Hip Thrust, sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and a barbell positioned across your hips. Roll the barbell over your hips and plant your feet flat on the floor. Drive through your heels to lift your hips, fully extending at the top. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Kneeling Squat
Desc: The Kneeling Squat is an exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. Begin in a kneeling position with your knees on the ground. Lower your hips back towards your heels while keeping your chest up and core engaged. Return to the starting position.
HowTo: Begin in a kneeling position with your knees on the ground. Lower your hips back towards your heels while keeping your chest up and core engaged. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Kneeling Jump Squat
Desc: The Kneeling Jump Squat combines a kneeling position with an explosive jump. Start in a kneeling position, then push off the ground explosively, jumping into the air. Land softly and return to the kneeling position to repeat.
HowTo: Start in a kneeling position. Push off the ground explosively, jumping into the air. Land softly and return to the kneeling position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UN Rear Foot Elevated Split Squat
Desc: The UN Rear Foot Elevated Split Squat is an advanced lower body exercise. Place one foot on a bench behind you and lower your body into a lunge position. Keep your front knee aligned with your ankle and push through your front heel to return to the starting position.
HowTo: Place one foot on a bench behind you. Lower your body into a lunge position, keeping your front knee aligned with your ankle. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. Alternate legs as needed.

Title: Kettlebell thruster
Desc: The kettlebell thruster is a popular kettlebell movement that combines a kettlebell front squat with a kettlebell press, while holding the bell in a goblet or bottoms-up grip. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and you can perform a clean between each rep if you choose. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell in a goblet grip. Perform a squat, lowering your body while keeping the kettlebell close to your chest. As you rise from the squat, press the kettlebell overhead. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Taylor Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The Taylor Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic movement that targets the posterior chain. Hold a kettlebell with both hands and swing it between your legs, then thrust your hips forward to swing it up to shoulder height. Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell with both hands and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Swing the kettlebell between your legs, then thrust your hips forward to swing it up to shoulder height. Maintain a neutral spine throughout the movement.

Title: UN Goblet Squat
Desc: The UN Goblet Squat is a fundamental squat variation. Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. Return to standing.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell close to your chest with both hands. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up. Return to standing.

Title: Single-arm triceps kick-back
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is a popular movement to increase size and strength of the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand, hinge at your hips while keeping your back straight. Extend your arm back, squeezing your triceps at the top of the movement. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Lateral High Knees to Quad Touch Jump
Desc: The Holman Lateral High Knees to Quad Touch Jump is a high-intensity exercise that improves agility and coordination. Start by performing lateral high knees, bringing your knees up towards your chest. Then, jump and touch your opposite quad with your hand before landing and repeating.
HowTo: Start by performing lateral high knees, bringing your knees up towards your chest. Jump and touch your opposite quad with your hand before landing. Repeat the sequence for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Hip Thrust
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Hip Thrust is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It involves lying on your back with your shoulders on a bench, feet flat on the ground, and a dumbbell placed on your hips. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your shoulders on a bench and feet flat on the ground. 2. Place a dumbbell on your hips. 3. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling. 4. Squeeze your glutes at the top of the movement.

Title: FYR2 Glute Bridge Dumbbell Floor Press
Desc: The FYR2 Glute Bridge Dumbbell Floor Press combines a glute bridge with a dumbbell floor press. Begin by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, press them up while lifting your hips into a bridge position. This exercise works the glutes, chest, and triceps.
HowTo: 1. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell in each hand at chest level. 3. Press the dumbbells up while lifting your hips into a bridge position. 4. Lower the dumbbells back down while keeping your hips elevated.

Title: Suspended Hip Thrust
Desc: The Suspended Hip Thrust is performed using suspension straps. Start in a seated position with your upper back against a bench and your feet in the straps. Drive your hips upward while keeping your core tight, focusing on squeezing your glutes at the top of the movement.
HowTo: 1. Start in a seated position with your upper back against a bench and feet in the suspension straps. 2. Drive your hips upward while keeping your core tight. 3. Squeeze your glutes at the top of the movement. 4. Lower your hips back down to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg cable hip extension
Desc: The single-leg cable hip extension is an isolation exercise that targets the glutes, specifically the gluteus maximus. It is a common burnout movement on a lower-body focused day and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Attach a cable to the low pulley and adjust the weight. 2. Stand facing the cable machine and grab the handle with one hand. 3. Step back to create tension in the cable. 4. Extend your leg back while keeping your knee straight, focusing on squeezing your glutes. 5. Return to the starting position.

Title: Pull Through
Desc: The Pull Through is an exercise that primarily targets the posterior chain, including the glutes and hamstrings. Stand facing away from a cable machine with the cable set low. Grab the handle with both hands and step forward to create tension. Hinge at the hips to pull the cable through your legs, then return to standing.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from a cable machine with the cable set low. 2. Grab the handle with both hands and step forward to create tension. 3. Hinge at the hips to pull the cable through your legs. 4. Return to standing by extending your hips forward.

Title: Cable rope pull-through deadlift
Desc: The cable rope pull-through deadlift is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with the rope attachment at the low setting. 2. Grab the rope with both hands and step back to create tension. 3. Hinge at the hips and lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Pull the rope through your legs by extending your hips forward.

Title: UNS Cable Pull-Through
Desc: The UNS Cable Pull-Through is similar to the traditional pull-through but uses a cable machine. Stand facing away from the machine, grab the cable handle between your legs, and hinge at the hips to pull the cable through while keeping your back straight. This exercise effectively targets the glutes and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grab the cable handle between your legs. 3. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight. 4. Pull the cable through your legs by extending your hips forward.

Title: 30 Legs Glute-Ham Raise
Desc: The 30 Legs Glute-Ham Raise is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. It involves lying face down on a glute-ham raise machine, securing your feet, and lifting your torso by extending your hips and knees. This movement strengthens the posterior chain and improves overall leg strength.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a glute-ham raise machine, securing your feet. 2. Keep your body straight and engage your core. 3. Lift your torso by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower your torso back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Glute bridge
Desc: The glute bridge is a popular lower-body bodyweight exercise that primarily targets the glutes, but also activates the lower back and hamstrings. It can be performed with body weight alone, or with added resistance such as barbells, dumbbells, or bands. It can be performed for time or reps and works perfectly in a dynamic warm-up for lower-body training, but can also be performed for glute activation anytime.
HowTo: To perform the glute bridge, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Press through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Hold for a moment, then lower back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-leg glute bridge
Desc: The single-leg glute bridge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, lower back, and hamstrings. It is performed one side at a time.
HowTo: To perform the single-leg glute bridge, lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Extend one leg straight up towards the ceiling. Press through the heel of the foot that remains on the ground to lift your hips, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Step-up with knee raise
Desc: The step-up with knee raise is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It differs from a traditional step-up in that at the top, you lift the trailing leg up to full hip flexion. This gives the exercise a greater range of motion and more of a focus on powerful hip extension in the working leg. When performed with body weight, these are usually performed for high reps as part of a dynamic warm-up, as cardio acceleration, or as part of the lower-body portion of a workout or circuit.
HowTo: To perform the step-up with knee raise, stand in front of a sturdy step or bench. Step up with one foot, pressing through your heel to lift your body up. At the top of the movement, lift your trailing knee up towards your chest, engaging your core. Step back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching legs.

Title: Glute Kickback
Desc: The Glute Kickback is an effective exercise for targeting the gluteal muscles. To perform this exercise, start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Keeping your knee bent, lift one leg towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes. Lower the leg back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.
HowTo: To perform the glute kickback, start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Keeping your knee bent at 90 degrees, lift one leg towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes. Lower the leg back down without touching the floor and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Standing hip extension
Desc: The standing hip extension is a movement that activates the glutes and hamstrings. It is often performed either for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up.
HowTo: To perform the standing hip extension, stand upright and hold onto a wall or sturdy surface for balance. Keeping your leg straight, extend one leg straight back behind you, squeezing your glutes at the top of the movement. Lower your leg back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching legs.

Title: Lying glute stretch
Desc: The lying glute stretch is a stretch to help increase flexibility in the glutes and hips. It involves rotating a single leg over the body while lying flat on the back, and reaching around the leg to facilitate a stretch. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups or cool-downs, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: To perform the lying glute stretch, lie flat on your back with your legs extended. Bend one knee and cross it over your body towards the opposite side while keeping your shoulders flat on the ground. Reach around your bent leg to deepen the stretch. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Knee Across The Body
Desc: The Knee Across The Body exercise is designed to stretch and improve flexibility in the hips and lower back. To perform this stretch, lie on your back with your legs extended. Bend one knee and cross it over your body towards the opposite side, keeping your shoulders flat on the ground. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position and switch sides.
HowTo: To perform the Knee Across The Body stretch, lie on your back with your legs extended. Bend one knee and cross it over your body towards the opposite side, keeping your shoulders flat on the ground. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position and switch sides.

Title: Seated Glute
Desc: The Seated Glute exercise targets the glute muscles and can help improve hip mobility. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Bend one knee and place that foot on the opposite thigh. Gently press down on the bent knee while leaning forward slightly to deepen the stretch. Hold for a few seconds and then switch legs.
HowTo: To perform the Seated Glute stretch, sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Bend one knee and place that foot on the opposite thigh. Gently press down on the bent knee while leaning forward slightly to deepen the stretch. Hold for a few seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Lying Glute
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes. Hold for a few seconds and lower back down.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while squeezing your glutes. Hold for a few seconds, then lower back down.

Title: One Knee To Chest
Desc: Lie on your back and pull one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended on the floor. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.
HowTo: Lie on your back and pull one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg extended on the floor. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Seated Glute Stretch
Desc: Sit on the floor with one leg extended and the other leg bent, placing the foot against the inner thigh of the extended leg. Lean forward gently to stretch the glutes.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with one leg extended and the other leg bent, placing the foot against the inner thigh of the extended leg. Lean forward gently to stretch the glutes.

Title: Neck Bridge Supine
Desc: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips and shoulders off the ground, creating a bridge position while supporting your neck.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips and shoulders off the ground to create a bridge position while supporting your neck.

Title: Walking High Knee
Desc: Walk forward while lifting your knees high towards your chest, alternating legs and engaging your core.
HowTo: Walk forward while lifting your knees high towards your chest, alternating legs and engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: Walking Butt Kicks
Desc: Walk forward while kicking your heels up towards your glutes, alternating legs and maintaining an upright posture.
HowTo: Walk forward while kicking your heels up towards your glutes, alternating legs and maintaining an upright posture.

Title: Walking Glute Stretch
Desc: Stand and take a step forward, bending one knee while extending the other leg behind you. Hold the stretch to target the glutes.
HowTo: Stand and take a step forward, bending one knee while extending the other leg behind you. Hold the stretch to target the glutes.

Title: Lunge kick
Desc: The lunge kick is a lower-body, cardio-based exercise performed at a high intensity. It includes a kick of the front leg to make the movement more powerful. It can be performed either for time or reps and is a great inclusion in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: Perform a lunge by stepping forward with one leg and lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. As you return to standing, kick the front leg forward to add intensity. Repeat for time or reps.

Title: Curtsy lunge
Desc: The curtsy lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that targets the muscles of the hips and glutes. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per leg.
HowTo: Stand with feet hip-width apart. Step your right leg back and to the left, bending your knees into a lunge while keeping your torso upright. Ensure your left knee is aligned over your left ankle. Push through your left heel to return to the starting position. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each leg.

Title: Alternating standing glute stretch
Desc: The alternating standing glute stretch focuses on improving lower-body mobility and flexibility, particularly in the hips and glutes. It involves performing a partial squat in a "figure 4" position. It can be performed as part of a lower-body warm-up or done post-workout to help combat tightness and soreness.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and cross the opposite ankle over the standing knee, forming a 'figure 4' shape. Lower your hips into a partial squat while keeping your back straight. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to standing. Alternate legs and repeat as part of your warm-up or post-workout routine.

Title: Side-lying leg lift
Desc: The side-lying leg lift is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the hips and glutes. It can be a worthy addition to a dynamic warm-up on a lower-body or strength-focused training day, a component of a lower-body circuit or workout, or a glute activation drill to do anytime. Generally, leg lifts are done for high reps, such as 8-15 reps per leg or more.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs stacked and straight. Keeping your core engaged, lift your top leg up towards the ceiling while keeping it straight. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower it back down. Perform 8-15 reps on each leg.

Title: FYR Progressive High Knee
Desc: High knees is a full-body, cardio-based exercise with an emphasis on the lower body. It is often performed for reps or time as part of a dynamic warm-up.
HowTo: Stand tall and begin jogging in place, bringing your knees up towards your chest. Aim to lift your knees to hip height or higher. Use your arms to drive the movement. Continue for a set time or number of reps as part of your warm-up.

Title: Glute-Ham Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: Position yourself on a GHD machine with your feet secured. Lower your body towards the ground by bending at the hips and knees, then engage your glutes and hamstrings to lift your body back to the starting position. Perform for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lunge glute stretch
Desc: The lunge glute stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is influenced by the pigeon pose from yoga, but is performed with straight arms. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with your back knee on the ground. Keep your front foot flat and your back leg extended. Lean forward slightly to deepen the stretch in your glutes and hips. Hold for 20-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: Position yourself on a GHD machine with your feet secured. Lower your body towards the ground by bending at the hips and knees, then engage your glutes and hamstrings to lift your body back to the starting position. Perform for the desired number of reps.

Title: Groiner
Desc: The groiner is an explosive bodyweight exercise targeting the legs, shoulders, and core. It also includes a dynamic stretch of the hips. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Jump your feet forward towards your hands, landing in a squat position. Quickly jump back to the plank position. Repeat for time or reps as part of your workout.

Title: HM Alternating Donkey Kick
Desc: The HM Alternating Donkey Kick is an exercise that targets the glutes and hamstrings. Begin on all fours, then lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent, alternating legs.
HowTo: Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower the leg back to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: HM Alternating Slow Step-Down With Chair
Desc: The HM Alternating Slow Step-Down With Chair focuses on balance and lower body strength. Stand on one leg on a chair, slowly lower the other leg to the ground, then return to the starting position, alternating legs.
HowTo: Stand on one leg on a chair with the other leg hanging off. Slowly lower the hanging leg towards the ground while maintaining balance, then return to the starting position. Alternate legs after each repetition.

Title: HM Right Side Iron Cross
Desc: The HM Right Side Iron Cross is a core stability exercise. Lie on your back with arms extended, lift your legs to form a right angle, and cross one leg over the other while engaging your core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides. Lift your legs to a right angle, then cross one leg over the other while keeping your core engaged. Hold briefly and return to the starting position, alternating legs.

Title: HM Single-Leg Bridge
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Bridge strengthens the glutes and hamstrings. Lie on your back with one foot flat on the ground and the other leg extended, lift your hips off the ground using the grounded leg.
HowTo: Lie on your back with one foot flat on the ground and the other leg extended straight up. Press through the grounded foot to lift your hips off the ground, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat, then switch legs.

Title: HM Hi-Low
Desc: The HM Hi-Low is a dynamic exercise that combines high knees and low squats. Alternate between bringing your knees up towards your chest and dropping into a squat position.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Alternate between bringing your knees up towards your chest in a high-knee motion and dropping into a squat position. Keep your core engaged and maintain a steady rhythm.

Title: HM Kick-Back
Desc: The HM Kick-Back targets the glutes and triceps. Start in a bent-over position, extend one leg back while keeping your knee straight, and return to the starting position, alternating legs.
HowTo: Start in a bent-over position with your hands on your knees. Extend one leg back while keeping your knee straight, squeezing your glutes at the top. Return to the starting position and alternate legs.

Title: HM Left Side Iron Cross
Desc: The HM Left Side Iron Cross is similar to the right side version, focusing on core stability. Lie on your back, lift your legs to a right angle, and cross the left leg over the right while engaging your core.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides. Lift your legs to a right angle, then cross your left leg over your right while engaging your core. Hold briefly and return to the starting position, alternating legs.

Title: HM Left Side-Kick
Desc: The HM Left Side-Kick is an exercise that strengthens the hip abductors. Stand on one leg and kick the other leg out to the side, maintaining balance and control.
HowTo: Stand on one leg with your other leg lifted slightly off the ground. Kick the lifted leg out to the side, keeping your body upright and maintaining balance. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Leg Lifts
Desc: The HM Leg Lifts exercise targets the hamstrings and glutes. Lie on your back with your legs straight, lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the other leg flat on the ground. Alternate legs for a complete set.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs straight. Lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the other leg flat on the ground. Alternate legs for a complete set.

Title: Walking lunge
Desc: The walking lunge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and hamstrings while challenging stability and balance. It can be performed for reps, time, or distance in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: Stand upright with feet hip-width apart. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Push through the front heel to return to standing and alternate legs.

Title: High Plyometric Box Jump
Desc: The High Plyometric Box Jump is a high-intensity exercise that improves explosive power and leg strength. Stand in front of a sturdy box, jump onto the box with both feet, and land softly. Step back down and repeat.
