HowTo: Stand in front of a sturdy box with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back, then jump onto the box with both feet, landing softly. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Barbell hip thrust-
Desc: The barbell hip thrust is a popular exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. It involves fully extending your hips while holding a weighted barbell across the front of the hips. It is a great movement to activate the glutes prior to other lower-body training, but can also be performed in the main part of a workout, or for high reps as a glute burnout.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench or platform. Roll a barbell over your hips, then drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, fully extending your hips at the top. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: UN Glute Bridge
Desc: The UN Glute Bridge focuses on strengthening the glutes and hamstrings. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top, then lower back down.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Press through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Holman Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Donkey Kick is an effective exercise for targeting the glutes. Start on all fours, keeping your back flat. Lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent, then lower it back down. Alternate legs.
HowTo: Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Keeping your back flat, lift one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent. Lower it back down and alternate legs.

Title: Holman Hip Raise with Alternating Kick
Desc: The Holman Hip Raise with Alternating Kick combines glute activation with core stability. Lie on your back with knees bent. Lift your hips while extending one leg straight out, then alternate legs while maintaining the hip lift.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while extending one leg straight out. Alternate legs while maintaining the hip lift.

Title: Holman Left Leg Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Left Leg Donkey Kick is similar to the donkey kick but focuses on the left leg. Start on all fours, lift your left leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent, then lower it back down. Repeat for sets.
HowTo: Start on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your left leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent. Lower it back down and repeat for sets.

Title: Holman Diagonal Right Leg Step-Out to Right Knee-Up
Desc: Start in a standing position, step your right leg out diagonally to the side while lowering your body into a lunge. As you return to standing, bring your right knee up towards your chest.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, step your right leg out diagonally to the side into a lunge. As you return to standing, bring your right knee up towards your chest.

Title: Holman Right Leg Donkey Kick
Desc: Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your right leg towards the ceiling, keeping your knee bent, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your right leg towards the ceiling, keeping your knee bent, then lower it back down.

Title: Holman Butt Tap to Jump
Desc: Start in a standing position, lower into a squat and then tap your right hand to your left foot. Jump up explosively, reaching your arms overhead.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, lower into a squat and tap your right hand to your left foot. Jump up explosively, reaching your arms overhead.

Title: Holman Butt Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back
Desc: Begin in a squat position, perform a butt tap by touching your right hand to your right glute, then jump forward, land softly, and jump back to the starting position.
HowTo: Begin in a squat position, touch your right hand to your right glute for a butt tap, then jump forward, land softly, and jump back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Traveling High Knees to Squat Thrust
Desc: Start by jogging in place, bringing your knees up high towards your chest, then transition into a squat thrust by placing your hands on the ground and jumping your feet back.
HowTo: Start by jogging in place, bringing your knees up high towards your chest, then transition into a squat thrust by placing your hands on the ground and jumping your feet back.

Title: Holman Butt Kicker to High Knees
Desc: Begin by jogging in place while bringing your heels up towards your glutes, then transition into high knees by lifting your knees up towards your chest.
HowTo: Begin by jogging in place, bringing your heels up towards your glutes, then transition into high knees by lifting your knees up towards your chest.

Title: Holman Daisy Cutter
Desc: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips to lower your torso while extending your arms forward, then explosively return to standing.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips to lower your torso while extending your arms forward, then explosively return to standing.

Title: Holman Frogger
Desc: Start in a standing position, squat down and place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump forward to return to the squat.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, squat down and place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump forward to return to the squat.

Title: Holman Hip Raise with Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Hip Raise with Chest Press is a strength exercise that targets the glutes, hamstrings, and chest. Begin by lying on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a dumbbell or weight plate in both hands above your chest. As you lift your hips towards the ceiling, press the weight upwards, engaging your core and glutes. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Hold a dumbbell or weight plate in both hands above your chest. Lift your hips towards the ceiling while pressing the weight upwards. Engage your core and glutes throughout the movement. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Total Fitness Bear Crawl
Desc: The bear crawl is a popular bodyweight crawling exercise. While it looks simple, the bear crawl is an intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups, the shoulders, core, and legs in particular. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, in short bursts for power or circuit training, or for longer durations as cardiovascular conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a quadruped position on all fours. Lift your knees slightly off the ground and begin crawling forward using opposite hands and feet. Keep your back flat and core engaged. Move in a controlled manner, alternating limbs, and maintain a steady pace.

Title: Pigeon stretch
Desc: The pigeon stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the glutes, hips, and piriformis. It is similar to the pigeon pose from yoga, but is also popular as part of dynamic warm-ups or cool-downs in strength training. It can also be performed anytime to help combat training-related soreness.
HowTo: Begin in a seated position with one leg extended and the other bent. Bring the bent leg's foot to the opposite hip. Lean forward gently over the extended leg, keeping your back straight. Hold the stretch for 20-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Levitating side kick-through
Desc: The levitating side kick-through is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you kick into the air in a partial handstand. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Kick one leg out to the side while lifting your hips and torso into a partial handstand. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Legs Hip Thrust
Desc: The 30 Legs Hip Thrust is an effective exercise for building strength in the glutes and hamstrings. Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and your feet flat on the floor. Roll a barbell or place a weight plate over your hips. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top of the movement. Lower back down and repeat for 30 repetitions.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your upper back against a bench and your feet flat on the floor. Roll a barbell or place a weight plate over your hips. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat for 30 repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell single-leg hip thrust
Desc: The dumbbell single-leg hip thrust is a single-sided exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. It involves balancing on one foot and fully extending your hips while holding a dumbbell across the front of your hip. It is a great movement to activate the glutes prior to other lower-body training, but can also be performed in the main part of a workout, or for high reps as a glute burnout.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with one foot flat and the other leg extended. Hold a dumbbell across the front of your hip. Drive through the heel of the grounded foot to lift your hips, fully extending them at the top. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch legs.

Title: Medicine ball duck walk
Desc: The medicine ball duck walk is a dynamic medicine ball movement that challenges both the upper and lower body, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in medicine ball or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories while hammering the muscles of the legs.
HowTo: Hold a medicine ball at chest level and squat down into a low position. While maintaining this squat, walk forward by stepping with one foot and then the other. Keep your back straight and core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: Exercise ball hip thrust
Desc: The exercise ball hip thrust is a simple yet effective way to work the glutes and hamstrings. Proper form is essential to really feel the burn in the glutes, and the ball can help guide you into the right form better than a bench, which is the usual support for hip thrusts. Unlike the bench version, the ball hip thrust is best performed with body weight or bands as resistance for safety reasons. It can be an excellent component of a warm-up for lower-body training, or a glute activation drill performed anytime.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your upper back resting against an exercise ball. Roll the ball so that your shoulders are supported and your feet are flat on the floor. Drive through your heels to lift your hips towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Downward Facing Balance
Desc: The Downward Facing Balance is a yoga pose that promotes stability and strength while engaging the core and improving balance.
HowTo: 1. Start in a downward-facing position with your hands and feet on the ground. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips up and back, creating an inverted V shape. 3. Keep your arms straight and your heels pressing towards the ground. 4. Hold the position, focusing on your balance and breathing.

Title: Band Good Morning (Pull Through)
Desc: The Band Good Morning (Pull Through) is an exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and glutes, using a resistance band to enhance strength and flexibility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a resistance band under your feet. 2. Hold the ends of the band with both hands, keeping your arms straight. 3. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 4. Return to standing by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch
Desc: The Standing Hamstring and Calf Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the hamstrings and calves, helping to improve range of motion and reduce muscle tightness.
HowTo: 1. Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Bend at the hips and reach down towards your toes, keeping your knees slightly bent if necessary. 3. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch in your hamstrings and calves. 4. Slowly rise back to standing.

Title: Hamstring-SMR
Desc: Hamstring-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) involves using a foam roller or similar tool to relieve tension and improve flexibility in the hamstring muscles.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. 2. Place a foam roller under your hamstrings. 3. Use your hands for support and roll back and forth over the foam roller, applying pressure to tight areas. 4. Continue for 1-2 minutes, focusing on areas of tension.

Title: Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The Clean Deadlift is a strength training exercise that focuses on lifting a barbell from the ground to the standing position, emphasizing proper form and technique.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and a barbell on the ground in front of you. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the barbell with both hands. 3. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Stand tall and then lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Clean Deadlift
Desc: The Romanian Deadlift from Deficit is a variation of the Romanian Deadlift that increases the range of motion, targeting the hamstrings and glutes for greater strength development.
HowTo: 1. Stand on a raised platform with a barbell in front of you. 2. Hinge at your hips and grasp the barbell with both hands. 3. Lower the barbell down your legs while keeping your back straight and knees slightly bent. 4. Return to standing by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Sumo deadlift
Desc: The sumo deadlift is a compound movement in which the feet are set in a wide stance with toes pointed out and grip is placed inside of the legs. It is allowed to be performed instead of conventional deadlifts in most powerlifting competitions. The sumo deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, and upper back/traps, but also has a greater emphasis on stretching and strengthening the adductor and hip muscles due to the wide stance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed out. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to lower your body while keeping your chest up. 3. Grip the barbell placed between your legs. 4. Push through your heels to lift the barbell back to standing, focusing on engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Romanian Deadlift from Deficit
HowTo: 1. Stand on a raised platform with a barbell in front of you. 2. Hinge at your hips and grasp the barbell with both hands. 3. Lower the barbell down your legs while keeping your back straight and knees slightly bent. 4. Return to standing by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Power Snatch
Desc: The Power Snatch is a weightlifting exercise that involves lifting a barbell from the ground to an overhead position in one explosive movement. It emphasizes speed, technique, and full body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up, preparing for the lift. 4. In one explosive movement, pull the barbell off the ground and extend your hips and knees. 5. As the barbell reaches your hips, shrug your shoulders and pull yourself under the bar. 6. Catch the barbell overhead with your arms fully extended. 7. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Power Clean from Blocks
Desc: The Power Clean from Blocks is a variation of the clean where the barbell starts elevated on blocks. This exercise focuses on the initial pull and explosiveness, making it a great way to develop power and technique.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up. 4. In one explosive movement, pull the barbell from the blocks, extending your hips and knees. 5. As the barbell rises, shrug your shoulders and pull yourself under the bar. 6. Catch the barbell at shoulder level. 7. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Snatch Deadlift
Desc: The Snatch Deadlift is a deadlift variation that prepares lifters for the snatch. It focuses on the initial pull from the floor, emphasizing proper form and strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on the floor. 2. Grip the barbell with a snatch grip (wide grip). 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up. 4. Lift the barbell off the ground, focusing on engaging your posterior chain. 5. Keep the bar close to your body as you lift. 6. Stand up straight to complete the deadlift.

Title: Power clean
Desc: The Hang Snatch is a weightlifting movement where the barbell is lifted from a hanging position, typically just above the knees, to an overhead position. It emphasizes technique, speed, and explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell at a hanging position, just above your knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up. 4. In one explosive movement, pull the barbell from the hanging position to an overhead position. 5. Catch the barbell with your arms fully extended. 6. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Hang Snatch
Desc: The Wide Stance Stiff Legs is a deadlift variation performed with a wider stance and straight legs. It targets the hamstrings and lower back, promoting flexibility and strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your legs straight. 3. Hinge at your hips to lower the barbell towards the ground, maintaining a flat back. 4. Engage your hamstrings and glutes as you lower the barbell. 5. Return to the starting position by extending your hips and standing up straight.

Title: Wide Stance Stiff Legs
Desc: The Clean is a fundamental weightlifting movement where the barbell is lifted from the ground to the shoulders in one smooth motion. It builds strength, power, and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up. 4. In one smooth motion, lift the barbell from the ground to your shoulders. 5. Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift. 6. Stand up straight to complete the clean.

Title: Clean
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on the ground. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. 3. Lower your hips and keep your chest up. 4. In one smooth motion, lift the barbell from the ground to your shoulders. 5. Keep the bar close to your body throughout the lift. 6. Stand up straight to complete the clean.

Title: Good Morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and place a barbell across your upper back. 2. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at your hips. 3. Lower your torso forward while keeping your back straight. 4. Feel the stretch in your hamstrings and glutes. 5. Return to the starting position by extending your hips and standing up straight.

Title: Barbell stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. Keeping your legs straight, hinge at the hips and lower the barbell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower the barbell down your legs, keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position by extending your hips.

Title: Sumo Deadlift with Chains
Desc: The Sumo Deadlift with Chains is a variation of the traditional deadlift that incorporates chains to increase resistance as you lift. This exercise targets the posterior chain, including the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back, while also improving stability and strength in the sumo stance.
HowTo: Set up a barbell with chains attached on the floor. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. Lower your hips and pull the barbell up while keeping it close to your body, extending your hips and knees as you lift. Focus on maintaining a strong back and engaging your glutes.

Title: Sumo Deadlift with Bands
Desc: The Sumo Deadlift with Bands is a variation that uses resistance bands to provide accommodating resistance throughout the lift. This exercise helps to build explosive strength and improve lockout strength, targeting the same muscle groups as the traditional sumo deadlift.
HowTo: Set up a barbell with resistance bands attached to the ends. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. Hinge at your hips to lower the barbell while keeping your back straight. As you lift, focus on driving through your heels and engaging your glutes.

Title: Good Morning off Pins
Desc: The Good Morning off Pins is an exercise that focuses on the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. Performed by placing a barbell on your shoulders and hinging at the hips while keeping your back straight, this variation uses pins to limit the range of motion and emphasize the eccentric phase.
HowTo: Set a barbell on pins at shoulder height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and position the barbell on your shoulders. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight, lowering your torso until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to the starting position.

Title: Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. Keeping your legs straight, hinge at the hips and lower the barbell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Snatch Pull
Desc: The Snatch Pull is an Olympic weightlifting exercise that focuses on developing power and speed in the pull phase of the snatch. It involves pulling the barbell from the floor to the hips while keeping it close to the body, emphasizing the extension of the hips and knees.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the barbell on the floor. Pull the barbell up to your hips while keeping it close to your body, extending your hips and knees explosively. Focus on maintaining a strong back and driving through your heels.

Title: Hanging Bar Good Morning
Desc: The Hanging Bar Good Morning is an exercise that targets the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. It is performed by hanging from a pull-up bar and hinging at the hips to lower the torso while keeping the legs straight, providing a unique challenge to the posterior chain.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with your arms extended. Keeping your legs straight, hinge at your hips to lower your torso forward until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings and lower back. Return to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift
Desc: The Reverse Band Sumo Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that uses bands to reduce the load at the bottom of the lift. This exercise targets the posterior chain, particularly the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back, while allowing for a greater range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Set up the barbell with bands attached to the top of the squat rack. 2. Stand with your feet in a sumo stance, gripping the barbell with both hands. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up as you lower your hips to grab the bar. 4. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell while keeping your back straight. 5. As you lift, the bands will reduce the load at the bottom, allowing for a smoother transition. 6. Lock out your hips and knees at the top, then lower the bar back down with control.

Title: Muscle Snatch
Desc: The Muscle Snatch is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that involves lifting the barbell from the ground to overhead in one fluid motion. It emphasizes explosive power and technique, primarily targeting the shoulders, back, and legs.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the bar with both hands just outside your knees. 3. Begin the lift by extending your hips and knees simultaneously, pulling the barbell upward. 4. As the bar passes your knees, explosively extend your hips and shrug your shoulders. 5. Pull the barbell overhead in one fluid motion, dropping under it into a partial squat. 6. Stand up fully with the barbell overhead, ensuring your arms are locked out.

Title: Split Snatch
Desc: The Split Snatch is an Olympic weightlifting technique where the lifter snatches the barbell overhead while simultaneously splitting their legs into a lunge position. This movement requires coordination, balance, and strength, focusing on the legs, core, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Grip the bar with both hands just outside your knees. 3. Lift the barbell off the ground, extending your hips and knees. 4. As the bar passes your knees, explosively extend your hips and shrug your shoulders. 5. Pull the barbell overhead while simultaneously splitting your legs into a lunge position. 6. Stand up fully with the barbell overhead, ensuring your arms are locked out.

Title: Hang Snatch - Below Knees
Desc: The Hang Snatch - Below Knees is a variation of the snatch that starts with the barbell positioned just below the knees. This exercise emphasizes the second pull and requires explosive hip extension, targeting the legs, core, and upper body.
HowTo: 1. Begin with the barbell positioned just below your knees, feet hip-width apart. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your back straight and core engaged. 3. Drive through your heels and extend your hips explosively to lift the barbell. 4. Pull the barbell upward, keeping it close to your body. 5. As the bar reaches your hips, quickly drop under it and catch it overhead. 6. Stand up fully with the barbell locked out overhead.

Title: 30 Legs Sumo Deadlift
Desc: The 30 Legs Sumo Deadlift is a variation of the sumo deadlift that focuses on a wider stance, targeting the inner thighs, glutes, and lower back. This exercise is performed with a barbell and emphasizes proper form and technique to maximize strength and minimize injury.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower your hips down and back while maintaining a flat back. 4. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell, extending your hips and knees. 5. Keep the bar close to your body as you lift. 6. Lock out your hips and knees at the top, then lower the bar back down with control.

Title: Kettlebell pass-through lunge
Desc: The kettlebell pass-through lunge is a dynamic leg and core exercise in which a lifter passes a weight under their front leg during lunges. It is a unique coordination challenge, but also challenging to the musculature of the abdomen, lower body, shoulders, and upper back. It is most commonly performed for higher reps, such as 10-15 reps per side, or for time. It can work in circuit-style workouts, or in lower-body or full-body time-efficient training.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Shoulders, Upper Back
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position holding a kettlebell in one hand. 2. Step forward into a lunge with one leg, lowering your back knee toward the ground. 3. As you lunge, pass the kettlebell under your front leg to the opposite hand. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the standing position while bringing the kettlebell back to the starting hand. 5. Alternate legs and repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Kettlebell One-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell single-leg deadlift is a variation on the kettlebell deadlift where one foot stays planted on the ground while the other raises into the air at the bottom of the movement. It's popular in lower-body training for strength and muscle building, but also trains balance, grip, and the core muscles.
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with a kettlebell in the opposite hand. 2. Hinge at your hips while keeping your back straight, lowering the kettlebell toward the ground. 3. Keep your planted leg slightly bent and your other leg extended behind you. 4. Lower the kettlebell until your torso is parallel to the ground. 5. Engage your glutes and hamstrings to return to the standing position. 6. Switch legs and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell clean
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level in a single movement. While the kettlebell clean is often used as a transitional movement into the press or front squat, it is also a valuable strength and power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Hinge at your hips and lower your body to lift the kettlebell off the ground. 4. In one explosive motion, pull the kettlebell up to shoulder level, keeping it close to your body. 5. Rotate your wrist as you bring the kettlebell to the shoulder, preparing for the next movement. 6. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-leg kettlebell deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell single-leg deadlift is a variation on the kettlebell deadlift where one foot stays planted on the ground while the other raises into the air at the bottom of the movement. It's popular in lower-body training for strength and muscle building, but also trains balance, grip, and the core muscles.
HowTo: Stand on one leg with the other leg slightly bent behind you. Hold a kettlebell in one hand. Hinge at the hips, lowering the kettlebell towards the ground while keeping your back straight. As you lower the kettlebell, extend the other leg straight back. Return to the starting position by driving through the planted heel and engaging your core.

Title: Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell
Desc: The Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell is a strength exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. To perform this exercise, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in both hands. Hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight, and lower the kettlebell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in both hands. Hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight, and lower the kettlebell down along your legs until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. Pause briefly, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward and standing tall.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell swing
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell swing is a popular exercise emphasizing the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. Because you are only swinging with one arm at a time, it is also uniquely challenging to the grip and core muscles. It is often used to train explosive power, for aerobic or cardiovascular conditioning, or in circuit training.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand. Hinge at the hips and swing the kettlebell back between your legs. Drive your hips forward and swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. Allow the kettlebell to swing back down between your legs and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell Dead Clean
Desc: The Kettlebell Dead Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines a deadlift and a clean. Start with the kettlebell on the floor between your feet. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the kettlebell with one hand. In one fluid motion, lift the kettlebell by extending your hips and knees, and pull it up to your shoulder, rotating your wrist as you do so. This exercise builds strength and power in the posterior chain.
HowTo: Start with the kettlebell on the floor between your feet. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the kettlebell with one hand. In one fluid motion, lift the kettlebell by extending your hips and knees, pulling it up to your shoulder while rotating your wrist. Lower it back to the floor and repeat.

Title: Alternating Hang Clean
Desc: The Alternating Hang Clean is a kettlebell exercise that focuses on explosiveness and coordination. Start in a standing position with a kettlebell in each hand. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebells to just above the knees. In one motion, explosively pull one kettlebell up to your shoulder while allowing the other to drop back down. Alternate between sides for a full set, engaging your core and maintaining good form.
HowTo: Stand with a kettlebell in each hand. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebells to just above your knees. In one explosive motion, pull one kettlebell up to your shoulder while allowing the other to drop back down. Alternate sides for each repetition, maintaining good form and engaging your core.

Title: One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The One-Arm Open Palm Kettlebell Clean is a variation of the clean that emphasizes grip strength and control. Begin with a kettlebell on the floor. Using one hand, hinge at the hips to grasp the kettlebell. In one fluid motion, lift the kettlebell to your shoulder while keeping your palm facing outward. This exercise helps develop unilateral strength and stability.
HowTo: Begin with a kettlebell on the floor. Using one hand, hinge at the hips to grasp the kettlebell. In one fluid motion, lift the kettlebell to your shoulder while keeping your palm facing outward. Lower it back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Open Palm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The Open Palm Kettlebell Clean is a technique-focused exercise that helps improve your clean form. Start with a kettlebell on the ground. Grip the kettlebell with an open palm, hinge at the hips, and lift it explosively to your shoulder. The open palm allows for a more natural wrist position and helps develop grip strength. This exercise is beneficial for athletes looking to enhance their clean technique.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell on the ground. Grip the kettlebell with an open palm, hinge at the hips, and lift it explosively to your shoulder. Focus on keeping your wrist in a natural position as you pull the kettlebell up. Lower it back down and repeat to improve your clean technique.

Title: Kettlebell Hang Clean
Desc: The Kettlebell Hang Clean is an explosive movement that targets the entire body, particularly the legs, back, and shoulders. Start by holding a kettlebell with both hands at hip level. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell slightly, then explosively pull it up to your shoulder while keeping your elbows high. This exercise is great for building power and improving overall athletic performance.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell with both hands at hip level. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell slightly. In one explosive movement, pull the kettlebell up to your shoulder, keeping your elbows high. Lower it back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Alternating Hang Clean is a dynamic exercise that targets the entire body, focusing on the legs, core, and shoulders. It involves swinging two kettlebells from a hang position to the clean position in an alternating fashion, promoting coordination and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips to lower the kettlebells to a hang position, keeping your back straight. 3. Explosively extend your hips and knees to swing one kettlebell up while the other swings down. 4. As the kettlebell reaches shoulder height, pull it into the clean position. 5. Alternate arms with each repetition.

Title: Romanian Deadlift With Dumbbells
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Maintain a flat back and engage your core. 4. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 5. Drive through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your knees straight and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Keep your back flat and core engaged. 4. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 5. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels.

Title: Vertical Swing
Desc: The Vertical Swing is a kettlebell exercise that emphasizes explosive hip movement and full-body engagement. It involves swinging the kettlebell vertically, using the power of the hips and legs to drive the movement, which helps improve cardiovascular fitness and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell between your legs. 3. Explosively extend your hips and swing the kettlebell upward, keeping it close to your body. 4. As the kettlebell reaches its peak, allow it to drop back down and repeat the movement.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Swing
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Swing is a variation of the traditional kettlebell swing, using dumbbells instead. This exercise targets the posterior chain, including the glutes, hamstrings, and lower back, while also enhancing grip strength and overall stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the dumbbells between your legs. 3. Swing the dumbbells forward and upward, using your hips to generate momentum. 4. Control the swing back down and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell Lying Hamstring Curl
Desc: The Dumbbell Lying Hamstring Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the hamstrings. Performed lying on your stomach, it involves curling a dumbbell held between your feet towards your glutes, effectively strengthening the hamstring muscles.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with a dumbbell held between your feet. 2. Keep your legs straight and engage your core. 3. Curl the dumbbell towards your glutes by bending your knees. 4. Squeeze your hamstrings at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Dumbbell Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The 30 Legs Dumbbell Stiff-Legged Deadlift is a strength training exercise that focuses on the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It involves holding dumbbells while performing a deadlift with straight legs, promoting flexibility and strength in the posterior chain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your knees straight and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Maintain a flat back and engage your core. 4. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 5. Return to the starting position by driving through your heels.

Title: Box jump
Desc: The box jump is an explosive exercise that strengthens the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, calves, and hamstrings. They also develop power in the lower body while revving the heart rate. Box jumps can be performed for low reps to focus on strength and power, or for higher reps for metabolic conditioning. Most coaches recommend stepping down rather than jumping down between reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. 2. Bend your knees slightly and swing your arms back. 3. Jump explosively onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. 4. Stand up fully on the box. 5. Step back down carefully and repeat.

Title: Box Jump (Multiple Response)
Desc: The box jump is a plyometric exercise that strengthens the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, calves and hamstrings. They also develop power in the lower-body while revving the heart rate.
HowTo: Stand in front of a sturdy box or platform. Bend your knees and swing your arms back for momentum. Jump onto the box, landing softly with your knees slightly bent. Step back down and repeat.

Title: Sled push-
Desc: The sled push is a conditioning exercise that targets the cardiovascular system and the muscles of the lower body. It involves pushing a sled along turf or another flat surface either for time or distance. Depending on your type of equipment, you may be pushing handles or straps in front of the sled. It can be used as part of a dynamic warm-up or for power training, as a finisher, or as part of a conditioning workout or circuit.
HowTo: Stand behind the sled with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and grip the handles or straps. Push the sled forward using your legs and arms, maintaining a strong posture. Continue pushing for the desired distance or time.

Title: Lying Hamstring
Desc: The Lying Hamstring exercise involves lying on your back and lifting one leg while keeping the other leg flat on the ground. This stretch targets the hamstrings and helps improve flexibility.
HowTo: Lie on your back on a flat surface. Keep one leg flat on the ground while lifting the other leg towards the ceiling, keeping it straight. Hold the position to stretch the hamstring, then switch legs.

Title: Chair Leg Extended Stretch
Desc: The Chair Leg Extended Stretch is performed by sitting on a chair and extending one leg straight out in front of you while keeping the other foot on the ground. This stretch focuses on the hamstrings and lower back.
HowTo: Sit on a chair with your back straight. Extend one leg straight out in front of you, keeping the other foot flat on the ground. Lean forward slightly to deepen the stretch in your hamstring and lower back. Hold, then switch legs.

Title: Suspended Leg Curl
Desc: The Suspended Leg Curl is an exercise performed using suspension straps or a stability ball, where you curl your legs towards your glutes while maintaining balance. This targets the hamstrings and glutes.
HowTo: Attach suspension straps to an anchor point. Lie on your back and place your heels in the straps. Curl your legs towards your glutes while keeping your hips elevated. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: Box Skip
Desc: Box Skip is a dynamic exercise where you step up onto a box or platform and then back down, alternating legs. It improves cardiovascular fitness and leg strength.
HowTo: Stand in front of a box or platform. Step up with one foot, bringing the other foot up to the box. Step back down with the same foot, alternating legs with each repetition.

Title: Power Stairs
Desc: Power Stairs involves running or bounding up a flight of stairs to build explosive strength and cardiovascular endurance. It's an effective workout for the legs and core.
HowTo: Stand at the bottom of a flight of stairs. Run or bound up the stairs, using your legs to propel yourself upward. Focus on explosive movements and maintain a steady pace.

Title: Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch
Desc: The Seated Hamstring and Calf Stretch is performed by sitting on the floor with legs extended and reaching towards your toes, which stretches the hamstrings and calves.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Reach forward towards your toes, keeping your back straight. Hold the stretch to target your hamstrings and calves.

Title: Hamstring slide
Desc: The hamstring slide is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hamstrings. Lying supine on a smooth surface, bend your knees to pull both heels toward you. The sliding action requires a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under the heels. These are considered more difficult than exercise ball hamstring curls and are a great primer movement before heavy squats or deadlifts, or as an accessory movement later in a lower-body workout.
HowTo: Lie supine on a smooth surface with a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under your heels. Bend your knees to pull both heels toward you, sliding them along the surface.

Title: Seated Band Hamstring Curl
Desc: The Seated Band Hamstring Curl is an exercise that targets the hamstrings using a resistance band. Sit on a bench with your back straight and attach the band to your ankles. Curl your legs back towards your body while keeping your feet flexed, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight. Attach a resistance band to your ankles. Curl your legs back towards your body while keeping your feet flexed, then return to the starting position.

Title: Lying cable leg curl
Desc: The lying cable leg curl is a classic machine exercise for building greater muscle size and strength in the hamstrings. It's easy to learn, easy to master, and poses little in the way of injury risk. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: Lie face down on a cable leg curl machine. Adjust the machine to fit your legs and grasp the handles. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, then lower them back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Standing cable leg curl
Desc: The standing cable leg curl is an isolation exercise for the hamstrings. It is often used as a variation of leg curl machines and for working each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of lower-body training.
HowTo: Stand facing a cable machine with an ankle strap attached to the low pulley. Secure the strap to one ankle and lift your leg back, bending at the knee to curl your leg towards your glutes. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Lying Leg Curls
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: Lie face down on a leg curl machine, adjusting the pad to rest just above your heels. Curl your legs up towards your glutes, then lower them back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Glute Ham Raise
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: Position yourself on a GHD machine with your feet secured. Lower your body towards the ground by bending at the hips, then raise your body back up by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Reverse Hyperextension
Desc: The Reverse Hyperextension is an exercise designed to strengthen the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. Lie face down on a reverse hyperextension machine, with your legs hanging off the edge. Lift your legs up while keeping them straight, engaging your glutes and lower back, then lower them back down.
HowTo: Lie face down on a reverse hyperextension machine with your legs hanging off the edge. Lift your legs up while keeping them straight, engaging your glutes and lower back, then lower them back down.

Title: Seated Leg Curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: Sit on a seated leg curl machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the machine so the pad rests just above your ankles. Curl your legs down towards the floor, then return to the starting position.

Title: Standing Leg Curl
Desc: The Standing Leg Curl is an exercise that targets the hamstrings. It is performed while standing and involves curling the leg towards the glutes, engaging the muscles in the back of the thigh. This exercise can help improve leg strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the Standing Leg Curl, stand upright with your feet hip-width apart. Shift your weight onto one leg and bend the opposite knee, curling your heel towards your glutes. Squeeze your hamstring at the top of the movement, then lower your leg back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith machine stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The Smith machine stiff-legged deadlift is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and upper back. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed like a traditional stiff-legged or Romanian deadlift, in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: To perform the Smith machine stiff-legged deadlift, set the bar at mid-thigh height. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the bar with both hands. Keeping your legs straight but not locked, hinge at your hips and lower the bar down along your legs, maintaining a flat back. Once you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, return to the starting position by driving your hips forward. Perform for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lying Leg Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: To perform the Lying Leg Curl - Gethin Variation, lie face down on the leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower calves. Curl your legs towards your glutes while squeezing your hamstrings at the top of the movement. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Paul Carter Leg Extension
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: To perform the Paul Carter Leg Extension, sit on the leg extension machine and adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs, just above your feet. With your back against the pad, extend your legs straight out in front of you, squeezing your quadriceps at the top. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lying leg curl
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: To perform the Lying Leg Curl, lie face down on the leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower calves. Curl your legs towards your glutes while squeezing your hamstrings at the top of the movement. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated Hamstring Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: To perform the Seated Hamstring Curl - Gethin Variation, sit on the leg curl machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs, just above your ankles. Curl your legs down towards the seat, squeezing your hamstrings at the bottom. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-leg lying leg curl
Desc: The single-leg lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training. Performing it one leg a time allows you to focus on the mind-muscle connection of each leg and address muscle imbalances.
HowTo: To perform the Single-leg lying leg curl, lie face down on the leg curl machine with one leg off the edge. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower calf of the working leg. Curl your leg towards your glutes while focusing on the contraction of your hamstring. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner. Complete the desired repetitions before switching to the other leg.

Title: Leg curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: To perform the Leg Curl, sit on the leg curl machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs, just above your ankles. Curl your legs down towards the seat, squeezing your hamstrings at the bottom. Slowly return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Leg Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. Extend your legs upward until they are straight, then slowly lower them back to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg leg extension-
Desc: The single-leg leg extension is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training. Performing it one leg a time allows you to focus on the mind-muscle connection of each leg and address muscle imbalances.
HowTo: Sit on the single-leg leg extension machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower leg just above your ankle. Extend one leg upward until it is straight, then slowly lower it back to the starting position. Alternate legs after completing the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying Hamstring Curls - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: Lie face down on the lying leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge of the bench. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. Curl your legs up towards your glutes by bending your knees, then slowly lower them back to the starting position.

Title: AM Seated Hamstring Curl
Desc: The leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It comes in seated and lying varieties, but the seated leg curl machine is more common in commercial gyms. Leg curl variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: Sit on the seated leg curl machine with your back against the pad and your legs extended in front of you. Place your legs under the padded lever. Curl your legs down towards the floor by bending your knees, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: UP Hamstring Curl
Desc: The lying leg curl is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the hamstrings. It is similar to the seated leg curl, but the open hip angle in the lying leg curl may incorporate more glute and calf activation. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: Lie face down on the lying leg curl machine with your knees just off the edge of the bench. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. Curl your legs up towards your glutes by bending your knees, then slowly lower them back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Extension
Desc: The leg extension exercise primarily targets the quadriceps muscles. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad, and adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. Extend your legs upward until they are straight, then slowly lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the pad so it rests on your lower legs just above your ankles. Extend your legs upward until they are straight, then slowly lower them back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Seated Leg Curl
Desc: The seated leg curl exercise focuses on the hamstrings. Sit on the leg curl machine with your back against the pad and place your legs under the padded lever. Curl your legs down towards the floor by bending your knees, then slowly return to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit on the seated leg curl machine with your back against the pad and your legs extended in front of you. Place your legs under the padded lever. Curl your legs down towards the floor by bending your knees, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: Natural Glute Ham Raise
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD.
HowTo: Kneel on the GHD machine with your feet secured. Lower your body towards the ground by bending at the hips while keeping your back straight. Once you reach a comfortable range of motion, raise your body back to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Standing leg swing
Desc: The standing leg swing is a dynamic stretching exercise that involves moving one leg up in front of you, as if to punt an imaginary football. This is a classic move for warming up the body and stretching the hamstrings.
HowTo: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Swing one leg forward and upward as if you are kicking an imaginary football. Keep your upper body stable and engage your core. Alternate legs and repeat.

Title: Linear Acceleration Wall Drill
Desc: The Linear Acceleration Wall Drill is designed to improve acceleration and sprinting mechanics. Perform this drill by standing a few feet away from a wall, leaning forward with your hands on the wall, and driving your knees up towards your chest in a controlled manner.
HowTo: Stand a few feet away from a wall, lean forward with your hands on the wall. Drive your knees up towards your chest in a controlled manner, focusing on maintaining good posture and balance.

Title: Knee Tuck Jump
Desc: The tuck jump is a vertical jump, an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and jump explosively into the air, tucking your knees towards your chest at the peak of the jump. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Leg-Up Hamstring Stretch
Desc: The Leg-Up Hamstring Stretch is a flexibility exercise aimed at stretching the hamstrings. Lie on your back and raise one leg straight up while keeping the other leg flat on the ground. Hold the stretch to improve flexibility in the hamstrings.
HowTo: Lie on your back with one leg flat on the ground. Raise the other leg straight up towards the ceiling, keeping it as straight as possible. Hold the position for a stretch, then switch legs.

Title: Inchworm
Desc: The inchworm is a popular bodyweight exercise that involves “walking” the hands on the floor from a bent-over toe-touch position into a straight-arm plank. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up to help raise core body temperature and “limber up” the body from head to toe.
HowTo: Start in a standing position and bend forward to touch your toes. Walk your hands forward on the floor until you are in a plank position. Then, walk your hands back towards your feet and return to the standing position.

Title: Moving Claw Series
Desc: The Moving Claw Series is a dynamic mobility exercise that engages the core and improves hip flexibility. Start in a plank position and move your hands forward while keeping your hips low, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Move your hands forward while keeping your hips low to the ground. Return to the starting plank position and repeat.

Title: Lying groin stretch with band
Desc: The lying groin stretch with band is a simple way to stretch a chronically tight muscle group of the lower body. It is common in stretching and yoga classes but can also be performed individually as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy.
HowTo: Lie on your back and loop a resistance band around the foot of one leg. Keep the other leg flat on the ground. Gently pull the band to raise the leg towards you, feeling the stretch in your groin. Hold and switch legs.

Title: 90/90 Hamstring
Desc: The 90/90 Hamstring stretch targets the hamstrings and hip flexors. Sit on the floor with one leg bent at a 90-degree angle in front of you and the other leg bent at a 90-degree angle behind you. Lean forward to stretch the hamstring of the front leg.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with one leg bent in front of you at a 90-degree angle and the other leg bent behind you at a 90-degree angle. Lean forward over the front leg to stretch the hamstring. Hold the stretch and switch legs.

Title: World's greatest stretch
Desc: The world's greatest stretch is a popular movement that earned its name because it targets multiple parts of the body, including the hips, shoulders, and thoracic spine, in a single sequence. This makes it a great dynamic warm-up, post-workout stretch, or mobility work you can do anytime.
HowTo: Stand tall and take a deep breath. Step one foot forward into a lunge position, keeping the back leg straight. Reach your arms overhead and gently lean back to open up the hips and stretch the thoracic spine. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: The Straddle
Desc: The Straddle is an exercise that involves straddling the legs apart while maintaining balance, often used to improve flexibility and strength in the hip and groin areas.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with your legs straddled apart. Keep your back straight and lean forward, reaching towards your toes or the ground between your legs. Hold the position to stretch the hips and groin.

Title: Prone Manual Hamstring
Desc: The Prone Manual Hamstring exercise involves lying face down and having a partner assist in stretching the hamstrings by lifting the legs while keeping the hips grounded.
HowTo: Lie face down on a mat. Have a partner lift one leg at a time while keeping your hips grounded. Relax and breathe deeply as your partner assists in stretching your hamstrings.

Title: Knee To Chest
Desc: Knee To Chest is a stretching exercise where an individual lies on their back and pulls one knee towards their chest to stretch the lower back and glutes.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your legs extended. Pull one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg flat on the ground. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Hurdle Hops
Desc: Hurdle Hops are a plyometric exercise where an individual jumps over a series of hurdles or obstacles to improve agility, coordination, and leg strength.
HowTo: Set up a series of hurdles at a comfortable distance. Stand behind the first hurdle, jump over it with both feet, and land softly. Continue jumping over each hurdle in succession, focusing on maintaining good form and rhythm.

Title: Hip Stretch With Twist
Desc: The Hip Stretch With Twist involves sitting or lying down and twisting the torso while stretching one leg across the body to enhance hip flexibility and spinal mobility.
HowTo: Sit on the ground with one leg extended and the other bent, placing the foot outside the opposite knee. Twist your torso towards the bent knee, using your arm for leverage. Hold the stretch, then switch sides.

Title: Linear 3-Part Start Technique
Desc: The Linear 3-Part Start Technique is a sprinting drill that focuses on the three phases of a sprint start: the set position, the drive phase, and the acceleration phase.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and lower your body into a set position. Explode forward into the drive phase, driving your knees up and arms back. Transition into the acceleration phase, gradually increasing your speed.

Title: Alternating Leg Swing
Desc: Alternating Leg Swing is a dynamic stretching exercise where an individual swings one leg forward and backward while balancing on the other leg to improve hip mobility and flexibility.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and swing the opposite leg forward and backward, keeping your movements controlled. Focus on maintaining balance and engaging your core as you alternate legs.

Title: Single-leg balance and reach
Desc: The single-leg balance and reach is an exercise that focuses on lower-body strength and stability.
HowTo: Stand on one leg with the other leg lifted slightly off the ground. Maintain your balance and reach forward with your arms, extending the lifted leg behind you. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. Repeat for multiple sets.

Title: High Kick
Desc: The High Kick is a dynamic exercise that targets the hip flexors, quadriceps, and glutes. Stand tall, lift one leg straight up in front of you, and kick as high as you can while keeping your core engaged. Alternate legs for a complete set.
HowTo: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Lift one leg straight up in front of you, engaging your core. Kick as high as you can while keeping your standing leg slightly bent. Lower your leg back down and alternate legs for a complete set.

Title: Boss Everline 10-Yard Sprints
Desc: Boss Everline 10-Yard Sprints are high-intensity sprints designed to improve speed and agility. Start at one end of a 10-yard distance, sprint to the other end as fast as possible, and then return. Repeat for multiple sets.
HowTo: Start at one end of a 10-yard distance. Sprint to the other end as fast as possible, then quickly turn around and sprint back to the starting point. Rest briefly between sprints and repeat for multiple sets.

Title: Standing hamstring stretch
Desc: The standing hamstring stretch is an exercise that stretches the hamstrings, the muscles that cover the back of the thighs. It involves looping a band around one foot and then pulling it, which produces an intense stretch in the hamstrings. It can be performed prior to training the lower body or playing sports, or as a restorative stretch anytime.
HowTo: Stand tall and loop a band around one foot. Keep your knee straight and gently pull the band towards you while leaning forward slightly. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Reverse lunge
Desc: The reverse lunge is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The reverse lunge places more emphasis on the glutes than other lunge variations.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Step back with one leg into a lunge position, keeping your front knee over your ankle. Push through your front heel to return to standing. Alternate legs for a complete set.

Title: HM Alternating Cross Lunge
Desc: HM Alternating Cross Lunge is a strength and flexibility exercise that targets the legs and glutes. Step forward into a lunge, crossing one leg over the other, then return to standing and alternate legs.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Step forward into a lunge, crossing one leg over the other. Push back to the starting position and alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: HM Alternating Front Kick
Desc: HM Alternating Front Kick is a cardio and strength exercise that engages the core and legs. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, lift one leg and kick forward, then alternate with the other leg.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lift one leg and kick it forward while engaging your core. Lower your leg back down and alternate with the other leg. Repeat for a complete set.

Title: HM World's Greatest Stretch
Desc: HM World's Greatest Stretch is a comprehensive stretching exercise that improves flexibility and mobility. Start in a lunge position, place your hands on the ground, and rotate your torso towards the front leg, reaching your arm up. Alternate sides.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other back. Place your hands on the ground inside your front foot. Rotate your torso towards your front leg and reach your arm up towards the ceiling. Hold for a moment, then return to the lunge position and alternate sides.

Title: HM Alternating Sprawl Kick-Through
Desc: The HM Alternating Sprawl Kick-Through is a dynamic exercise that combines a sprawl with a kick-through movement, engaging the core, shoulders, and legs. Start in a plank position, perform a sprawl by lowering your hips and pushing back into a squat, then kick one leg through to the side while twisting your torso.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Perform a sprawl by lowering your hips and pushing back into a squat. From the squat position, kick one leg through to the side while twisting your torso towards that leg. Return to the plank position and repeat, alternating sides.

Title: HM Alternating Step-Back
Desc: The HM Alternating Step-Back is a lower body exercise that targets the glutes and quadriceps. Begin standing tall, step back with one leg into a lunge position, then return to standing and alternate legs.
HowTo: Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Step back with your right leg into a lunge position, keeping your left knee over your left ankle. Push through your left heel to return to standing. Repeat on the other side, alternating legs.

Title: HM Alternating Step-Up With Chair
Desc: The HM Alternating Step-Up With Chair involves stepping up onto a chair or platform with one foot, engaging the leg muscles, and alternating legs. This exercise improves balance and strength.
HowTo: Stand in front of a chair or platform. Step up onto the chair with your right foot, pressing through your heel. Bring your left foot up to meet your right on the chair, then step back down with your right foot followed by your left. Alternate legs with each repetition.

Title: HM Right Knee-Up
Desc: The HM Right Knee-Up is a core exercise that focuses on hip flexors and abdominal muscles. Stand tall and lift your right knee towards your chest while balancing on your left leg.
HowTo: Stand tall on your left leg. Lift your right knee towards your chest, engaging your core for balance. Hold for a moment, then lower your right leg back down. Repeat for several repetitions before switching to the left knee.

Title: HM Low Lunge With External Twist
Desc: The HM Low Lunge With External Twist is a flexibility and mobility exercise. Start in a low lunge position with one foot forward, then twist your torso towards the front leg, enhancing hip and spine mobility.
HowTo: Start in a low lunge position with your right foot forward and your left knee on the ground. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot. Twist your torso to the right, extending your right arm towards the ceiling. Hold the position to enhance hip and spine mobility, then switch sides.

Title: HM Ninja Crawl
Desc: The HM Ninja Crawl is a full-body movement that mimics a stealthy crawl. Start in a low squat position, then move forward by alternating your hands and feet, engaging your core and maintaining a low posture.
HowTo: Begin in a low squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Move forward by placing your right hand on the ground, followed by your left hand, while simultaneously extending your right leg back. Alternate your hands and feet as you crawl forward, keeping your core engaged and maintaining a low posture.

Title: HM Pigeon Stretch
Desc: The HM Pigeon Stretch is a flexibility exercise targeting the hips. Begin in a tabletop position, bring one knee forward and place it behind your wrist, extending the opposite leg back, and lean forward to deepen the stretch.
HowTo: Start in a tabletop position on your hands and knees. Bring your right knee forward and place it behind your right wrist, extending your left leg straight back. Lower your torso towards the ground, leaning forward to deepen the stretch in your hips. Hold the position, then switch sides.

Title: Single-Leg Deadlift Walk
Desc: The Single-Leg Deadlift Walk is a balance and strength exercise. Stand on one leg, hinge at the hips to lower your torso while extending the opposite leg back, then walk forward while maintaining balance.
HowTo: Stand on your right leg with your left leg slightly bent. Hinge at your hips to lower your torso towards the ground while extending your left leg straight back. Keep your back straight and your core engaged. Walk forward while maintaining your balance on the right leg, then switch to the left leg.

Title: Total Fitness Hamstring Slide
Desc: The hamstring slide is a bodyweight exercise targeting the hamstrings. Lying supine on a smooth surface, you bend your knees to pull both heels toward you. The sliding action requires a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under the heel. These are considered more difficult than exercise ball hamstring curls, and are a great primer movement before heavy squats or deadlifts, or as an accessory movement later in a lower-body workout.
HowTo: Lie supine on a smooth surface with a pad, cloth, or furniture sliders under your heels. Bend your knees to pull both heels toward you, sliding them along the surface.

Title: 30 Legs Walking Lunge
Desc: The 30 Legs Walking Lunge is a dynamic exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. To perform this exercise, take a step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Alternate legs as you walk forward, ensuring your front knee stays above your ankle.
HowTo: Step forward with one leg and lower your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Alternate legs as you walk forward, ensuring your front knee stays above your ankle.

Title: Glute ham raise-
Desc: The glute ham raise is an exercise targeting the glutes and hamstrings on a GHD, or glute ham developer bench. The unassisted version of the movement requires serious hamstring strength, so it is more common to see versions that use a band or PVC pipe for assistance. It is commonly performed as an accessory movement for heavy barbell lifts. While a single rep may be a struggle at first, with time, strong athletes can build up to doing them for 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Position yourself on a GHD bench. Start with your hips and knees flexed. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight, then pull yourself back up using your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Lying hamstring stretch with band
Desc: The lying hamstring stretch with band is a simple way to stretch a chronically tight muscle group of the lower body. It is common in stretching and yoga classes but can also be performed individually as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy.
HowTo: Lie on your back and loop a band around the ball of one foot. Keep your other leg flat on the ground. Gently pull the band towards you, keeping your leg straight, to stretch your hamstring.

Title: Upper Back-Leg Grab
Desc: The Upper Back-Leg Grab is a flexibility exercise that helps stretch the upper back and improve overall mobility. To perform this stretch, stand tall and reach your right arm across your body to grab your left leg behind your knee.
