Hold the position for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your upper back, then switch sides.
HowTo: Stand tall and reach your right arm across your body to grab your left leg behind your knee. Hold the position for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your upper back, then switch sides.

Title: Seated Hamstring
Desc: The Seated Hamstring stretch is designed to improve flexibility in the hamstrings. Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight out and the other leg bent with the foot against the inner thigh of the extended leg. Reach forward towards the toes of the extended leg, keeping your back straight, and hold the stretch.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with one leg extended straight out and the other leg bent with the foot against the inner thigh of the extended leg. Reach forward towards the toes of the extended leg, keeping your back straight, and hold the stretch.

Title: Alternating lunge jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward. Jump up explosively, switching your legs in mid-air, and land in a lunge position with the opposite leg forward.

Title: Runner's Stretch
Desc: The Runner's Stretch is a great way to loosen up the hip flexors and hamstrings. Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other leg extended back. Lower your hips towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Hold the position for a few breaths, then switch legs.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other leg extended back. Lower your hips towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Hold the position for a few breaths, then switch legs.

Title: Exercise ball leg curl
Desc: The exercise ball leg curl is an exercise targeting the hamstrings. In particular, it targets the knee flexion function of the hamstrings, as opposed to deadlift variations, which target the other hamstring function, hip flexion. Many lifters opt for this exercise when they don't have access to a lying leg curl machine, but it is worth considering even if you already do machine curls.
HowTo: 1. Start by lying on your back with your heels on top of an exercise ball. 2. Engage your core and lift your hips off the ground, creating a straight line from your shoulders to your knees. 3. Bend your knees and roll the ball towards you, keeping your hips elevated. 4. Extend your legs back out to the starting position while maintaining the hip lift. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Ball Hamstring Hat Trick
Desc: The exercise ball leg curl is an exercise targeting the hamstrings. In particular, it targets the knee flexion function of the hamstrings, as opposed to deadlift variations, which target the other hamstring function, hip flexion. Many lifters opt for this exercise when they don’t have access to a lying leg curl machine, but it is worth considering even if you already do machine curls.
HowTo: 1. Begin by lying on your back with your heels resting on an exercise ball. 2. Lift your hips off the ground to form a straight line from your shoulders to your feet. 3. Bend your knees to roll the ball towards your glutes, engaging your hamstrings. 4. Straighten your legs back out to the starting position while keeping your hips elevated. 5. Perform the exercise for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band-assisted pull-up
Desc: The band-assisted pull-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with an elastic band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, and is often used as a way to help people boost their pull-up numbers or perform their first rep.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy overhead point. 2. Loop the band around your feet or knees. 3. Grab the pull-up bar with an overhand grip, arms fully extended. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, using the band for assistance. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Assisted Chin-Up
Desc: The reverse-grip chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body, in an underhand position, with a band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand band-assisted pull-ups.
HowTo: 1. Set up a resistance band around a sturdy overhead point. 2. Loop the band around your feet or knees. 3. Grip the chin-up bar with an underhand grip, palms facing you. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, utilizing the band for support. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Pronated
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up with a pronated grip involves using a resistance band to assist in performing pull-ups. This variation targets the upper back, biceps, and shoulders while reducing the load on the muscles, making it easier to perform the exercise.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy overhead point. 2. Grip the pull-up bar with a pronated (overhand) grip. 3. Loop the band around your feet or knees for assistance. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, using the band to reduce the load. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 6. Perform the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Neutral
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up with a neutral grip uses a resistance band for assistance, allowing the performer to pull themselves up with palms facing each other. This grip variation engages the biceps and back muscles effectively while providing support.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy overhead point. 2. Grip the pull-up bar with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 3. Loop the band around your feet or knees for assistance. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, using the band for support. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UN Band Assisted Pull-up Supinated
Desc: The UN Band Assisted Pull-up with a supinated grip employs a resistance band to help perform the pull-up with palms facing towards the body. This variation emphasizes the biceps and the lower lat muscles, making it a great option for building strength.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy overhead point. 2. Grip the pull-up bar with a supinated grip (palms facing you). 3. Loop the band around your feet or knees for assistance. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, using the band to help. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position. 6. Perform the exercise for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Monster Band Face-Pull Hold
Desc: The FYR2 Monster Band Face-Pull Hold is an exercise that targets the rear deltoids and upper back. Using a resistance band, the performer pulls the band towards their face while holding the position to engage the muscles effectively.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band at chest height. 2. Stand facing the band and grab it with both hands. 3. Step back to create tension in the band. 4. Pull the band towards your face while keeping your elbows high. 5. Hold the position to engage your rear deltoids and upper back. 6. Slowly return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm band low row
Desc: The single-arm band low row is a single-arm row variation utilizing a band for resistance that is anchored low. It targets the muscles of the middle back, like the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids, but also the core. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-15 reps per set, in the later stages of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Anchor a resistance band low to the ground. 2. Stand facing the band with one foot forward and the opposite arm extended to grasp the band. 3. Pull the band towards your torso, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-15 reps before switching arms.

Title: Latissimus dorsi SMR
Desc: Latissimus dorsi self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the lat muscles of the mid back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Latissimus dorsi SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the pectorals or rhomboids, or by stretches that target the lats.
HowTo: 1. Sit or lie on the ground and place a foam roller or lacrosse ball under your lat muscles. 2. Apply pressure by leaning into the roller or ball, targeting tight areas. 3. Slowly roll back and forth or hold on tight spots for 20-30 seconds. 4. You can also stretch your lats after the release for added benefit.

Title: Bent-arm barbell pull-over
Desc: The bent-arm barbell pull-over was a staple exercise of the "Golden Era" of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise targets the pecs, lats, and serratus anterior muscles. Old-school bodybuilders would perform them with light weights for sets of 20 between sets of heavy 20-rep squats, but pull-overs are more popular today in moderate rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a barbell held above your chest with arms extended. 2. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, lower the barbell behind your head in a controlled manner. 3. Once you feel a stretch in your lats, pull the barbell back to the starting position over your chest. 4. Perform 8-12 reps for a set.

Title: Barbell pull-over to press
Desc: The barbell pull-over to press is a complex that combines two popular exercises into one sequence that works much of the upper body, particularly the chest, triceps, and serratus anterior muscles. It is commonly performed with an EZ-bar, but can also be performed with a straight bar or neutral-grip bar. Because the pull-over will determine the amount of weight you can use, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench holding a barbell above your chest with arms extended. 2. Lower the barbell behind your head in a pull-over motion. 3. Once you reach the bottom position, pull the barbell back over your chest. 4. Immediately press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm barbell bent-over row
Desc: The single-arm barbell bent-over row is a barbell exercise focused on the muscles of the middle back, such as the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It also targets the biceps and grip. If the loose end of the barbell moves around, it can be secured by placing it in the corner of a room.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in one hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, and lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Pull the barbell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Squeeze your back muscles at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for 8-12 reps before switching arms.

Title: Reverse Barbell Row
Desc: The Reverse Barbell Row is a strength training exercise that targets the upper back, biceps, and shoulders. It involves pulling a barbell towards your torso while maintaining a bent-over position, emphasizing proper form and control.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your torso, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back down with control. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Side kick-through to kettlebell high pull
Desc: The side kick-through to kettlebell high pull is a combination of a popular bodyweight exercise and an explosive kettlebell movement. Between them, the pairing targets the traps, shoulders, core, hips, hamstrings, and glutes. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss.
Muscles: Traps, Shoulders, Core, Hips, Hamstrings, Glutes
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with your hands on the ground. 2. Kick one leg through to the side while rotating your torso, placing the foot on the ground. 3. From this position, grab a kettlebell with the opposite hand. 4. Pull the kettlebell up towards your shoulder in a high pull motion. 5. Return to the plank position and repeat for time or reps.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Snatch
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Snatch is a dynamic exercise that combines strength and cardio. It involves lifting a kettlebell from the ground to overhead in a fluid motion, alternating arms to build power, coordination, and endurance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grab the kettlebell with one hand. 3. In one fluid motion, lift the kettlebell overhead while standing up, switching hands at the top. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat, alternating arms for each rep.

Title: FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The FYR2 Alternating Kettlebell Swing involves swinging a kettlebell from between your legs to shoulder height, alternating hands with each swing. Focus on maintaining a strong core and proper hip hinge.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands between your legs. 2. Hinge at your hips and bend your knees slightly. 3. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 4. Drive through your hips to swing the kettlebell forward to shoulder height, alternating hands at the top of the swing. 5. Keep your core engaged and maintain a strong posture throughout the movement.

Title: FYR2 American Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The FYR2 American Kettlebell Swing is a full-body exercise where you swing the kettlebell overhead, ensuring your arms are straight and your body is in a straight line from head to heels at the top of the swing.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. Drive through your hips and swing the kettlebell overhead, ensuring your arms are straight. 4. At the top of the swing, your body should form a straight line from head to heels. 5. Control the descent back to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Standing Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Standing Clean requires two kettlebells to be lifted from the ground to shoulder height in one fluid motion, emphasizing a powerful hip drive and proper elbow positioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding two kettlebells on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grasp the kettlebells. 3. Engage your core and drive through your hips to lift the kettlebells in one fluid motion to shoulder height. 4. Keep your elbows close to your body and ensure proper positioning as you lift. 5. Lower the kettlebells back to the ground with control.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing High Pull
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Swing High Pull combines a kettlebell swing with a high pull, bringing the kettlebell up to chest level while keeping your elbows high, engaging your back and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands between your legs. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell back. 3. As you swing forward, pull the kettlebell up to chest level, keeping your elbows high. 4. Engage your back and shoulders as you perform the high pull. 5. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press Combo
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press Combo is a sequence that starts with a kettlebell swing, transitions into a clean, and finishes with a press overhead, targeting multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell between your legs. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing, driving through your hips to swing it forward. 3. As the kettlebell reaches shoulder height, transition into a clean by bringing it to your shoulder. 4. From the clean position, press the kettlebell overhead. 5. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat the sequence.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press-Row Combo
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Swing-Clean-Press-Row Combo is a complex movement that includes a kettlebell swing, clean, press, and a row, providing a full-body workout and enhancing strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell between your legs. 2. Start with a kettlebell swing, driving through your hips. 3. Transition into a clean by bringing the kettlebell to your shoulder. 4. Press the kettlebell overhead. 5. After the press, perform a row by pulling the kettlebell towards your body. 6. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat the entire sequence.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Clean focuses on lifting a single kettlebell from the ground to shoulder height using one arm, emphasizing balance and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a single kettlebell on the ground beside you. 2. Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Engage your core and drive through your hips to lift the kettlebell to shoulder height. 4. Ensure your elbow is positioned correctly as you lift. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground with control.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Swing involves swinging a single kettlebell from between the legs to shoulder height with one arm, promoting unilateral strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a single kettlebell between your legs with one hand. 2. Hinge at your hips and swing the kettlebell back between your legs. 3. Drive through your hips to swing the kettlebell forward to shoulder height with one arm. 4. Focus on maintaining balance and engaging your core throughout the movement. 5. Control the descent back to the starting position.

Title: PJR pull-over-
Desc: The PJR pull-over is a triceps-focused version of the pull-over exercise, usually performed on either a flat or slightly inclined bench. The low position of the movement stretches the triceps—particularly the long head of the muscle—while the top position is a triceps press that contracts all three heads. It can be done in any type of strength or muscle-focused workout, in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps, or for higher reps.
HowTo: To perform the PJR pull-over, lie on a flat or slightly inclined bench with a dumbbell held above your chest. Lower the dumbbell behind your head while keeping your arms slightly bent, feeling the stretch in your triceps. Return to the starting position by pressing the dumbbell back up, engaging all three heads of the triceps. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell seal row
Desc: The dumbbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell seal row, lie face down on an elevated bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your arms extended towards the floor. Pull the dumbbells towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position with control. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell row is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the lower lats and upper back muscles.
HowTo: To perform the incline dumbbell row (Gethin Variation), set an incline bench at a 30-45 degree angle. Lie face down on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower rib cage, focusing on squeezing your lats and upper back. Lower the weights back down with control. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: FYR Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: To perform the FYR bent-over dumbbell row, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your upper back muscles at the top. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Straight-Arm Dumbbell Pull-Over - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm dumbbell pull-overpull-over was a staple exercise of the Golden Era of bodybuilding and a favorite of Arnold Schwarzenegger himself. Done properly, the exercise hits the bottom of the pecs, the lats, the abs, and the triceps.
HowTo: To perform the straight-arm dumbbell pull-over (Gethin Variation), lie on a flat bench with a dumbbell held above your chest with both hands. Keeping your arms straight, lower the dumbbell back behind your head until you feel a stretch in your lats and pecs. Return to the starting position by raising the dumbbell back up. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Bent-Over Dumbbell Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: To perform the bent-over dumbbell row (Gethin Variation), stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, focusing on squeezing your upper back muscles. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Bent-over dumbbell rear delt fly
Desc: The bent-over dumbbell rear delt fly is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the back of the shoulder joint, specifically the rear head of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: To perform the bent-over dumbbell rear delt fly, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing each other. Raise the dumbbells out to the side, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top. Lower the dumbbells back down with control. Aim for 10-15 reps.

Title: Band Resisted Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Band Resisted Dumbbell Row is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back, specifically the latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, and trapezius muscles. This exercise involves using a resistance band in conjunction with a dumbbell to increase the difficulty and engage stabilizing muscles. To perform the exercise, anchor the resistance band securely, hold a dumbbell in one hand, and bend forward slightly at the hips. Pull the dumbbell towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down with control. This movement helps improve strength, posture, and overall upper body stability.
HowTo: To perform the band resisted dumbbell row, anchor a resistance band securely at a low point. Hold a dumbbell in one hand and bend forward slightly at the hips. Pull the dumbbell towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, feeling the resistance from the band. Lower the dumbbell back down with control. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Holman Right Arm Weighted Half Jack
Desc: A dynamic exercise that combines a half jack movement with added resistance using a weight in the right arm, targeting the shoulders, arms, and core.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your right arm. Perform a half jack by jumping your feet out to the sides while raising your right arm overhead. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Arm Weighted Half Jack
Desc: A dynamic exercise that combines a half jack movement with added resistance using a weight in the left arm, targeting the shoulders, arms, and core.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in your left arm. Perform a half jack by jumping your feet out to the sides while raising your left arm overhead. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Renegade Row
Desc: A strength exercise that involves a rowing motion with weights while in a plank position, engaging the back, arms, and core.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with a weight in each hand. Row one weight towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm and legs. Alternate sides.

Title: Holman Renegade Row with Opposite Foot Step-Out
Desc: An advanced variation of the renegade row that includes stepping out with the opposite foot, enhancing core stability and coordination.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with weights in each hand. Perform a row with one arm, then step out with the opposite foot to enhance stability. Alternate sides.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Weighted Burpee
Desc: A combination exercise that transitions from a renegade row into a weighted burpee, providing a full-body workout that builds strength and endurance.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with weights. Perform a renegade row, then jump your feet forward and transition into a weighted burpee. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Weighted Double-Arm Cross Punch
Desc: An exercise that involves performing cross punches with weights while standing, targeting the shoulders, arms, and core stability.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in each hand. Perform cross punches by extending your right arm across your body while pivoting on your left foot, then switch sides.

Title: Holman Standing Flat Back Row
Desc: A rowing exercise performed while standing with a flat back, focusing on the upper back and shoulder muscles.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips to maintain a flat back. Hold weights in both hands and pull them towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Isometric Row Hold
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: Bend over at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a bent-over row by pulling the weights towards your lower ribcage, engaging your back muscles.

Title: Dumbbell renegade row
Desc: The dumbbell renegade row combines rowing and core training into a single difficult movement. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts, as well as in circuit-style training.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your body straight and engage your core. Row one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. Lower the dumbbell back to the ground and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Bent-Over Row to Rear-Delt Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn Bent-Over Row to Rear-Delt Raise is an exercise that targets the upper back and rear deltoids. It involves bending at the hips while holding weights, performing a row motion followed by a raise to engage the rear delts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in each hand. Bend at the hips while keeping your back straight. Perform a row by pulling the weights towards your torso, then extend your arms out to the sides to raise them to shoulder height, engaging your rear deltoids.

Title: FYR2 Bent-Over Reverse Fly
Desc: The FYR2 Bent-Over Reverse Fly is designed to strengthen the upper back and shoulders. This exercise is performed by bending forward at the hips and lifting weights out to the sides, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Bend forward at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, holding weights in each hand. With your arms hanging down, lift the weights out to the sides while squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower the weights back down and repeat.

Title: Weighted pull-up
Desc: The weighted pull-up is a more advanced variation of the pull-up exercise in which the lifter adds extra weight to their body. Options for adding weight include a dip belt, weighted vest, chains, a dumbbell placed between the feet or legs, or looping a kettlebell over the foot. Like other pull-up variations, the weighted pull-up builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core.
HowTo: Attach the weight to your body using a dip belt or vest. Grip the pull-up bar with your palms facing away. Hang with your arms fully extended, then pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down with control.

Title: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns
Desc: Rocky Pull-Ups/Pulldowns are variations of pull exercises that target the back and biceps. The pull-up involves lifting your body up to a bar, while the pulldown uses a cable machine to pull the bar down towards your chest.
HowTo: For pull-ups, grip the bar with palms facing away and pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. For pulldowns, sit at a cable machine, grip the bar with palms facing away, and pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Gironda Sternum Chins
Desc: Gironda Sternum Chins are a unique chin-up variation that emphasizes the upper back and biceps. This exercise requires you to pull your chest up towards the bar, keeping your elbows flared out to engage the lats effectively.
HowTo: Grip the bar with palms facing you and elbows flared out. Pull your chest towards the bar while keeping your body straight. Focus on engaging your upper back and biceps throughout the movement.

Title: Floor rope climb
Desc: The floor rope climb is an exercise that involves performing partial rope climbs in a prone position with the feet on the floor. It can help prepare someone for full rope climbs, but also trains the muscles of the back, biceps, and grip. It can be done for time or reps.
HowTo: Lie on your stomach with your feet on the floor. Grip the rope or a similar object. Pull your body up towards the rope as if climbing, using your arms and back muscles, while keeping your feet on the ground.

Title: Overhead Lat
Desc: The Overhead Lat exercise focuses on developing the latissimus dorsi muscles. It is performed by lifting weights overhead while engaging the core and maintaining proper posture to maximize lat activation.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights above your head. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Lower the weights behind your head while keeping your elbows close, then lift them back to the starting position.

Title: Around-the-world pull-up
Desc: The around-the-world pull-up is a more advanced version of the classic pull-up. It focuses stress more directly on the individual arms or sides of the back, while also boosting the time under tension at the top of each rep. It can be used as a progression toward a one-arm pull-up, or simply as a way to increase the challenge and variety of your pull-up training.
HowTo: 1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. 2. Pull your body up towards the bar while simultaneously moving your body to one side. 3. As you reach the top, shift your body to the other side and lower yourself back down. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps, alternating sides.

Title: L-sit chin-up
Desc: The L-sit chin-up is an exercise targeting the back, biceps, core, and overall upper-body strength. It is considered significantly more difficult than standard chin-ups, and as such, is often performed for relatively low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set or less, with a focus on strength and form.
HowTo: 1. Begin by hanging from a chin-up bar with your legs extended in front of you, forming an 'L' shape. 2. Pull your body up towards the bar while keeping your legs straight and elevated. 3. Focus on engaging your back and biceps throughout the movement. 4. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for 5-8 reps.

Title: Back Flyes - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the dumbbells out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Lower the weights back down with control. 4. Perform 10-15 reps, focusing on the contraction of the rear deltoids.

Title: Incline straight-arm pull-over
Desc: The incline straight-arm pull-over is an upper-body exercise targeting the chest and lats (latissimus dorsi). Performing it on an incline bench emphasizes the stretch on the chest in particular. If this movement causes pain in the front of the shoulders, perform it with a more limited range of motion or try pull-overs using a high cable stack instead. Pull-over variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of chest or back-focused upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in both hands, arms extended above your chest. 2. Keeping your arms straight, lower the dumbbell back behind your head, feeling the stretch in your chest and lats. 3. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position. 4. Perform for 8-12 reps, adjusting the range of motion if you experience shoulder pain.

Title: Machine high row
Desc: The machine high row is a machine-based exercise targeting the back muscles, including the lats, rhomboids, and middle and lower traps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight row, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine rows are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the machine high row with your feet flat on the ground and your chest against the pad. 2. Grasp the handles with your preferred grip. 3. Pull the handles towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: AM T-Bar Row
Desc: The AM T-Bar Row is a strength training exercise that targets the back muscles, particularly the latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, and trapezius. It involves pulling a T-bar towards your chest while maintaining a stable stance, which helps to build upper body strength and improve posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the T-bar with both hands. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the T-bar towards your chest, squeezing your back muscles. 4. Lower the bar back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Assisted Single-Arm Pull-Up
Desc: The Assisted Single-Arm Pull-Up is an exercise designed to help individuals build strength in their upper body, particularly the back and biceps. Using an assistance mechanism, this exercise allows you to perform a pull-up with one arm while reducing the amount of body weight you need to lift, making it easier to develop the necessary strength for unassisted pull-ups.
HowTo: 1. Set up an assistance mechanism (like a band or machine) to help with the pull-up. 2. Grip the pull-up bar with one hand while placing the other hand on the assistance device. 3. Pull yourself up using the assisted hand while focusing on engaging your back and biceps. 4. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Assisted Single-Arm Chin-Up
Desc: The Assisted Single-Arm Chin-Up is a variation of the chin-up that focuses on building strength in the biceps and back. This exercise utilizes assistance to allow you to perform a chin-up with one arm, helping to develop the strength and technique needed for full chin-ups.
HowTo: 1. Use an assistance mechanism to support your body weight. 2. Grip the chin-up bar with one hand while using the assistance device. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, focusing on using your biceps and back. 4. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Renegade Punch-Under
Desc: The Holman Renegade Punch-Under is a dynamic exercise that combines a renegade row with a punch under. Start in a plank position with weights in each hand. Perform a renegade row by pulling one weight towards your hip while stabilizing your body, then transition into a punch under by extending that arm forward while keeping your core engaged. Alternate sides for a full set.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with weights in each hand. Perform a renegade row by pulling one weight towards your hip while stabilizing your body. Transition into a punch under by extending that arm forward while keeping your core engaged. Alternate sides for a full set.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Split Jump
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row to Split Jump is an explosive full-body workout. Begin in a plank position with weights. Perform a renegade row by pulling one weight towards your hip, then jump your feet forward into a split stance while raising the weights overhead. Return to plank and repeat, alternating sides to engage your core and legs.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with weights. Perform a renegade row by pulling one weight towards your hip. Jump your feet forward into a split stance while raising the weights overhead. Return to plank and repeat, alternating sides to engage your core and legs.

Title: Holman Dirty Dog to Renegade Row
Desc: The Holman Dirty Dog to Renegade Row is a challenging exercise targeting the core and upper body. Start on all fours in a tabletop position. Lift one leg to the side (dirty dog) while simultaneously performing a renegade row with the opposite arm. Lower back to the starting position and repeat, alternating sides to enhance stability and strength.
HowTo: Start on all fours in a tabletop position. Lift one leg to the side (dirty dog) while simultaneously performing a renegade row with the opposite arm. Lower back to the starting position and repeat, alternating sides to enhance stability and strength.

Title: Holman Renegade Row to Side Punch to Forward Punch
Desc: The Holman Renegade Row to Side Punch to Forward Punch is a comprehensive exercise that builds strength and coordination. Begin in a plank position with weights. Perform a renegade row, then transition into a side punch with one arm, followed by a forward punch with the same arm. Alternate sides for a complete workout that engages the core and upper body.
HowTo: Begin in a plank position with weights. Perform a renegade row, then transition into a side punch with one arm, followed by a forward punch with the same arm. Alternate sides for a complete workout that engages the core and upper body.

Title: Standing dumbbell knee crunch
Desc: The standing dumbbell knee crunch is a great way to train the abs while standing up. Additionally, the deltoids are worked because the lifter holds a pair of dumbbells overhead throughout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand held overhead. Lift one knee towards your chest while engaging your core, then lower it back down. Alternate legs for a complete set.

Title: Close-grip pull-down
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that is performed with an overhand grip and the hands slightly closer than shoulder-width apart. This increases the range of motion beyond wider grips, and may increase the time under tension in each rep. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: Sit at a lat pull-down machine with a close grip. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly closer than shoulder-width apart. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for moderate to high reps.

Title: Shotgun row
Desc: The shotgun row is a single-arm row variation utilizing a cable stack in a staggered stance. It targets the muscles of the middle back, like the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids, but also the core. It is usually performed for moderate to high-reps, at least 8-15 reps per set, in the later stages of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: Stand in a staggered stance next to a cable stack. Grasp the handle with one hand and pull it towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body. Focus on squeezing your back muscles. Perform 8-15 reps before switching sides.

Title: Close-Grip Front Lat Pulldown
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: Sit at a close-grip lat pulldown machine. Grasp the bar with a close grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your sides. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for effective back training.

Title: Straight-arm rope pull-down
Desc: The straight-arm rope pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine and a rope grip. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: Stand upright or slightly bent over, grasp the rope grip attached to the cable stack. Pull the rope downwards with straight arms, engaging your lats and upper back. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. Perform for 8-15 reps.

Title: Lat pull-down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise that's ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective at building back size and strength. It's usually trained in moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set. If grip strength is a limitation, you can wear wrist straps.
HowTo: Sit at the lat pull-down machine with your knees secured under the pad. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest, keeping your back straight and elbows pointed down. Control the bar back to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Straight-Arm Pulldown
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
HowTo: Stand upright or slightly bent over, grasp the bar attached to the cable stack. With straight arms, pull the bar down towards your thighs, engaging your lats and upper back. Squeeze at the bottom and return to the starting position. Perform for 8-15 reps.

Title: Single-arm kneeling lat pull-down
Desc: The single-arm kneeling lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down exercise performed one arm at a time, with the knees on the ground, rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body.
HowTo: Kneel on the ground next to the cable machine. Grasp the handle with one hand. Pull the handle down towards your shoulder while keeping your core engaged. Focus on controlling the movement and squeezing your back muscles. Perform for 8-12 reps on each arm.

Title: Elevated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Lats, Traps, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: Sit at the cable row machine with your feet on the platform. Grasp the handle with both hands. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight and elbows close to your body. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. Perform for 8-12 reps.

Title: Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown
Desc: The Full Range-Of-Motion Lat Pulldown is an effective exercise for targeting the latissimus dorsi muscles in the back. This exercise involves pulling a bar down towards your chest while seated, ensuring a full range of motion to maximize muscle engagement. It helps improve upper body strength and can be performed using a cable machine.
HowTo: Sit at the lat pull-down machine with your knees secured. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest, ensuring a full range of motion by fully extending your arms at the top. Control the bar back to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Kneeling lat pull-down
Desc: The kneeling lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down exercise performed with the knees on the ground rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body.
HowTo: Kneel on the ground next to the cable machine. Grasp the handle with both hands. Pull the handle down towards your chest while keeping your core engaged. Focus on controlling the movement and squeezing your back muscles. Perform for 8-12 reps.

Title: Behind-the-neck pull-down
Desc: The behind-the-neck pull-down is a cable exercise intended to target the muscles of the upper and middle back. If you have the requisite shoulder mobility, it can help you target the upper back muscles, including the trapezius and rhomboids, as well as the lats (latissimus dorsi). It is popular among elite bodybuilders and physique athletes, but some coaches consider it unsafe to the shoulder joint, particularly for people with existing shoulder problems.
HowTo: Sit at the cable machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. Pull the bar down behind your neck towards your upper back, ensuring you maintain good shoulder mobility. Control the bar back to the starting position. Aim for 8-10 reps, but be cautious if you have shoulder issues.

Title: Straight-arm cable pull-over
Desc: The straight-arm cable pull-over is an exercise that focuses on the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and chest using a cable stack and a flat bench. It is most commonly used for higher reps, such as 10-15 or more, in muscle-building workouts. It is also an effective substitute for dumbbell pull-overs or a pull-over machine, if you don't have access to them or they aggravate your shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a high position and attach a straight bar. 2. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the bar with both hands, keeping your arms straight. 4. Pull the bar down in an arc until it reaches your thighs while keeping your arms straight. 5. Squeeze your lats at the bottom of the movement. 6. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Cable Straight-Arm Pulldown - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a high position and attach a straight bar. 2. Stand upright or slightly bent over, grasping the bar with both hands. 3. Keep your arms straight and pull the bar down towards your thighs, engaging your lats. 4. Hold for a moment at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: Rope Lat Pull-down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the rope attachment with both hands. 3. Pull the rope down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your sides. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Straight-Arm Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a high position and attach a straight bar. 2. Stand upright or slightly bent over, grasping the bar with both hands. 3. Keep your arms straight and pull the bar down towards your thighs, engaging your lats. 4. Hold for a moment at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: High-cable standing row
Desc: The high-cable standing row is an exercise targeting the lats. The high position allows for more engagement of the upper back, as well, specifically the rhomboids and teres major.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the cable to a high position and attach a handle. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbows high. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lat Pull-down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows pointed down. 4. Squeeze your lats at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Wide-Grip Lat Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows pointed down. 4. Squeeze your lats at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Behind-The-Neck Pull-Down - Gethin Variation
Desc: The behind-the-neck pull-down is a cable exercise intended to target the muscles of the upper and middle back. If you have the requisite shoulder mobility, it can help you targets the upper back muscles, including the trapezius and rhomboids, as well as the lats (latissimus dorsi). It is popular among elite bodybuilders and physique athletes, but some coaches consider it unsafe to the shoulder joint, in particular to people with existing shoulder problems.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable at a high position and attach a wide grip bar. 2. Sit at the lat pull-down machine and grasp the bar. 3. Pull the bar down behind your neck while keeping your elbows wide. 4. Squeeze your upper back muscles at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-Arm Cable Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable seated row is a version of the cable row movement that train the muscles of the upper back one side at a time. It targets a wide range of muscles including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, as well as the biceps. The single-arm row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Lats, Traps, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: Sit at a cable machine with a single handle attached. Grasp the handle with one hand, keeping your back straight and core engaged. Pull the handle towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blade towards your spine. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Scapular Rows
Desc: Scapular Rows are an exercise focused on strengthening the muscles around the scapula, promoting better shoulder stability and posture. This exercise is typically performed with resistance bands or cables, pulling the shoulder blades together while keeping the arms straight.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a resistance band or cable at shoulder height. Keep your arms straight and pull your shoulder blades together, bringing your arms back without bending your elbows. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing V-Grip Cable Rows
Desc: Standing V-Grip Cable Rows target the upper back, particularly the lats and rhomboids. This exercise is performed using a cable machine with a V-grip attachment, pulling the handle towards the torso while standing, which helps improve posture and upper body strength.
HowTo: Stand in front of a cable machine with a V-grip attachment. Grasp the handles and pull them towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Close-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The close-grip pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down, acable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: Sit at a lat pull-down machine with a close grip attachment. Grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing you. Pull the bar down towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Wide-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: Sit at a lat pull-down machine with a wide grip attachment. Grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing away from you. Pull the bar down towards your chest, focusing on engaging your back muscles. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UP Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: Sit at a lat pull-down machine. Grasp the bar with a shoulder-width grip, palms facing away from you. Pull the bar down towards your chest, keeping your back straight and core engaged. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse-grip lat pull-down
Desc: The reverse-grip lat pull-down is variation on the lat pull-down that targets the lower lats more than an overhand grip. Because the hands are relatively close together, it also increases the range of motion beyond wider-grip pull-down variations. It can be performed for low reps, such as 5-6 per set, for back strength, or for higher reps for size.
HowTo: Sit at a lat pull-down machine with a reverse grip (palms facing you). Grasp the bar with a close grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest, focusing on engaging your lower lats. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine seated row
Desc: The machine seated row is a popular exercise targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and middle and lower trapezius. There is a wide variety of seated row machines, but most of them approximate the motion of a free-weight row, but in an upright, forward-facing position. Machine row variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit at a seated row machine with your feet on the platform and your knees slightly bent. Grasp the handles with both hands. Pull the handles towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine-assisted pull-up
Desc: The machine-assisted pull-up takes a classic back-building exercise and adds assistance to make the movement easier than the bodyweight version. The amount of assistance can easily be changed by moving the pin in the stack. While some people use this variation as a substitute for pull-ups or as an assistance exercise for pull-ups, it is also effective as a way to perform the pull-up motion in traditional muscle-building ranges. This variation is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or back-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight stack to your desired level of assistance. 2. Sit down on the machine and grasp the handles with an overhand grip. 3. Keep your chest up and shoulders back. 4. Pull the handles down towards your chest, engaging your back muscles. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm pull-down
Desc: The single-arm pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that is performed one arm at a time, usually with a D-shaped handle and a cable stack. Many lifters find they can feel the lat (latissimus dorsi) muscles working better with single-arm variations.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight on the cable stack. 2. Stand or sit beside the machine and grasp the D-shaped handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle down towards your shoulder, keeping your elbow close to your body. 4. Squeeze your lat at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Chest-Supported Smith Machine Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Chest-Supported Smith Machine Row - Gethin Variation is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and rear deltoids. By using a chest support, you minimize lower back strain and focus on pulling the weight with your arms. This variation emphasizes proper form and muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Set the weight on the Smith machine. 2. Lie face down on the chest support pad with your feet flat on the ground. 3. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Pull the bar towards your chest, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm machine high row
Desc: The single-arm machine high row is a machine-based exercise targeting the back muscles, including the lats, rhomboids, and middle and lower traps. It approximates the motion of a free-weight row, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine-based rows are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight on the machine. 2. Sit down and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. Keep your back straight and pull the handle towards your torso, engaging your back muscles. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Machine Pull-Over - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Pull-Over - Gethin Variation is designed to target the lats and chest. This exercise involves pulling a weighted bar or handle from above your head down to your chest while seated, effectively engaging the upper body muscles. It is a great addition to any workout routine for building upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight on the machine. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles above your head. 3. Keep your elbows slightly bent and pull the handles down towards your chest. 4. Focus on engaging your lats and chest as you pull. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated Machine Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The machine seated row is an exercise targeting the back muscles, emphasizing the mid- to upper-back.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight on the machine. 2. Sit down with your feet flat on the ground and grasp the handles. 3. Keep your back straight and pull the handles towards your abdomen. 4. Squeeze your back muscles at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Wide-Grip Machine Row
Desc: The Wide-Grip Machine Row is a compound exercise that primarily targets the back muscles, particularly the lats and rhomboids. By using a wide grip, this variation helps to enhance the width of the back while also engaging the biceps and forearms. It's an excellent choice for building upper body strength and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Set the desired weight on the machine. 2. Sit down and grasp the handles with a wide grip. 3. Keep your chest up and pull the handles towards your torso, focusing on your back muscles. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: King Maker Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the weight on the lat pull-down machine. 2. Sit down and grasp the bar with a wide grip. 3. Keep your back straight and pull the bar down towards your chest. 4. Squeeze your lats at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return the bar to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Robertson Half-Kneeling Landmine Press
Desc: The Robertson Half-Kneeling Landmine Press is an upper body exercise that targets the shoulders, triceps, and core stability. It involves pressing a barbell anchored in a landmine setup while in a half-kneeling position, promoting unilateral strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the other foot flat on the floor in front of you. 2. Hold the barbell with both hands, positioned at shoulder height. 3. Engage your core and press the barbell upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position while maintaining control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Pullups
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of “relative strength” which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: 1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you, hands shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and pull your body upward until your chin is above the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down to the starting position with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Pull-up
Desc: The pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of "relative strength" which is strength in relation to body weight.
HowTo: 1. Begin by hanging from a pull-up bar with your palms facing away from you. 2. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, focusing on using your upper back and biceps. 3. Slowly lower yourself back down to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Muscle Up
Desc: The Muscle Up is an advanced exercise that combines a pull-up and a dip, allowing the athlete to transition from hanging below the bar to a position above it. It primarily targets the upper body, including the back, shoulders, and arms, and requires significant strength and technique.
HowTo: 1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar. 2. Perform a pull-up to bring your chest to the bar. 3. As you reach the top, transition your body forward and push down on the bar to move into a dip position. 4. Lower yourself into a dip, then press back up to the starting position above the bar. 5. Lower back down to the hanging position to complete one rep.

Title: Rope climb
Desc: The rope climb is an exercise that is used commonly in CrossFit workouts and as a test of upper-body strength. It was even contested at the Olympics in the early 20th century. It targets a wide range of upper-body musculature, including the hands and forearms, shoulders, biceps, lats (latissimus dorsi), and core.
HowTo: 1. Start by gripping the rope with both hands, standing under it. 2. Use your legs to jump and pull your body upward while simultaneously using your hands to grip the rope. 3. Alternate pulling with your arms and using your legs to push against the rope to climb higher. 4. Continue climbing until you reach the desired height, then lower yourself back down with control.

Title: Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up
Desc: The Wide-Grip Rear Pull-Up is a variation of the traditional pull-up that emphasizes the upper back and lats. By using a wider grip, this exercise increases the engagement of the teres major and the latissimus dorsi, promoting upper body strength and muscle development.
HowTo: 1. Begin by hanging from a pull-up bar with a wide grip. 2. Engage your core and pull your body upward, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Pull until your chin is above the bar, emphasizing the upper back and lats. 4. Lower yourself back down to the starting position with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Side To Side Chins
Desc: Side To Side Chins are a dynamic variation of the chin-up that involves pulling the body up towards one side of the bar and then the other. This exercise targets the biceps, back, and shoulders while also enhancing grip strength and core stability.
HowTo: 1. Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip. 2. Pull your body up towards one side of the bar, then lower back down. 3. Immediately pull up towards the opposite side of the bar. 4. Continue alternating sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Neutral-grip pull-up
Desc: The neutral-grip pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing one another. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It can be used as a more shoulder-friendly alternative to straight-bar pull-ups, or to help perform more reps than you can perform overhand.
HowTo: 1. Begin by hanging from a pull-up bar with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). 2. Engage your core and pull your body upward until your chin is above the bar. 3. Lower yourself back down to the starting position with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Kipping Muscle Up
Desc: The Kipping Muscle Up is an advanced gymnastic movement that combines a pull-up and a dip, using a kipping motion to generate momentum. It requires strength, technique, and timing.
HowTo: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Use your legs to generate momentum by swinging them slightly. As you swing up, pull your chest towards the bar while simultaneously pushing down with your arms. Once your chest is above the bar, transition your body over the bar and push down to finish in a dip position. Reverse the motion to return to the starting position.

Title: One Arm Against Wall
Desc: The One Arm Against Wall exercise focuses on improving shoulder stability and strength. It involves placing one arm against a wall while performing a controlled movement to engage the shoulder and core.
HowTo: Stand next to a wall and extend one arm out, placing your palm against the wall. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart and engage your core. Slowly lean away from the wall, allowing your shoulder to stretch while maintaining contact with the wall. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side.

Title: One Handed Hang
Desc: The single-arm hang is a static exercise that involves hanging from a bar by one hand. It is an advanced hanging exercise that demands above-average shoulder stability and grip strength, and may not be appropriate for some people. However, if someone is strong and stable enough to perform it, the movement can help build those same qualities.
HowTo: Find a sturdy pull-up bar and grip it with one hand. Engage your shoulder and core muscles to stabilize your body. Allow your body to hang freely, keeping your arm straight. Hold the position for as long as you can, focusing on maintaining control and stability. Switch arms and repeat.

Title: Standing side bend stretch
Desc: The standing side bend stretch is a stretching exercise targeting the obliques, the muscles that run along the side of the core. It is a common inclusion in dynamic warm-ups for the upper body, but can also be performed to help "limber up" for lifting or athletics anytime.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise one arm overhead and lean to the opposite side, feeling the stretch along your side. Hold the position for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. Repeat on the other side. Ensure to keep your core engaged throughout the movement.

Title: Burpee to pull-up
Desc: The burpee to pull-up is a variation of the bodyweight burpee in which the jump at the top of each rep leads into a jumping pull-up. It is popular in circuit-style and metcon workouts.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Kick your feet back into a plank position, perform a push-up if desired, then jump your feet back towards your hands. Explode upwards into a jump, reaching for the pull-up bar. Once at the top of the jump, pull yourself up into a pull-up. Lower yourself back down and repeat.

Title: Negative pull-up
Desc: The negative pull-up is a multijoint bodyweight exercise that focuses on just one half of the traditional pull-up: the lowering, eccentric, or "negative" portion. Because muscles are stronger eccentrically than they are concentrically, many people can perform negatives even if they can't perform full pull-ups. For this reason, it is a popular training tool to help people earn their first pull-up rep, or as a back-off exercise after doing full pull-ups.
HowTo: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Engage your core and pull yourself up slightly. Slowly lower yourself back down in a controlled manner, focusing on the eccentric phase of the movement. Aim to take 3-5 seconds to lower yourself down. Once you reach the bottom, drop down and repeat.

Title: Chin-Up
Desc: The a chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body, in an underhand position, with a grip that is narrower than shoulder-width. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand pull-ups. It can be used as a more shoulder-friendly alternative to straight-bar pull-ups, or to help perform more reps than you can perform overhand.
HowTo: Grip the pull-up bar with your palms facing you and your hands closer than shoulder-width apart. Hang with your arms fully extended. Engage your core and pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down in a controlled manner. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Superman Lat Pull
Desc: The HM Superman Lat Pull is an exercise that targets the latissimus dorsi muscles. It involves lying face down and simulating a lat pull-down motion while extending the arms and lifting the chest off the ground.
HowTo: Lie face down on the ground with your arms extended in front of you. Engage your core and lift your chest off the ground while simultaneously pulling your elbows down towards your sides, simulating a lat pull-down motion. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: AM Pull-Up
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of “relative strength” which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: To perform an AM Pull-Up, start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and pull your body up until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UP Chin-Up
Desc: The UP Chin-Up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the upper back, biceps, and shoulders. It involves pulling your body up towards a bar using an underhand grip, focusing on engaging the lats and maintaining proper form.
HowTo: To perform an UP Chin-Up, grasp the pull-up bar with an underhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. Hang with your arms fully extended, then pull your body up towards the bar, focusing on engaging your lats and biceps. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Alternating Forward and Side Punch
Desc: The Holman Alternating Forward and Side Punch is a dynamic exercise that combines upper body punches with lower body movement. It enhances coordination, agility, and cardiovascular fitness while targeting the shoulders, arms, and core.
HowTo: To perform the Holman Alternating Forward and Side Punch, start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Alternate punching forward and to the side while shifting your weight and moving your feet to enhance coordination. Maintain a strong core and keep your punches controlled and precise.

Title: Jump to pull-up
Desc: The jump to pull-up is a bodyweight exercise that targets the muscles of the back, biceps, and, to a lesser degree, legs. It involves jumping up to a pull-up bar between reps. Similar to a push-press, the legs help power through the most difficult portion of the pull-up, allowing you to perform more reps. Jumping pull-ups are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as an accessory to other pulling or pull-up training, or as a full-body movement in a circuit or metcon.
HowTo: To perform a Jump to Pull-Up, start by standing under a pull-up bar. Jump up to grab the bar with an overhand grip. Use your legs to assist in pulling your body up until your chin is above the bar. Lower yourself back down and repeat the jump and pull-up for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bent-over scapular slide
Desc: The bent-over scapular slide is an upper-body exercise that helps with scapular and shoulder mobility. It is commonly performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for the upper body.
HowTo: To perform a Bent-over Scapular Slide, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hinge at the hips to bend forward slightly. With your arms at your sides, slide your shoulder blades together and then apart while keeping your arms straight. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Iron cross stretch
Desc: The iron cross stretch is a bodyweight stretch that focuses on hip and thoracic spine mobility.
