HowTo: To perform the Iron Cross Stretch, lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides. Cross one leg over the other and allow it to fall towards the ground while keeping your shoulders flat on the floor. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Total Fitness Standing Lat Stretch
Desc: The Total Fitness Standing Lat Stretch is a flexibility exercise designed to stretch the latissimus dorsi muscles. It is performed standing, reaching overhead and to the sides to improve range of motion and relieve tension in the back.
HowTo: To perform the Total Fitness Standing Lat Stretch, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Reach both arms overhead and then lean to one side, feeling the stretch along the side of your body. Hold for a few seconds, then switch to the other side.

Title: King Maker Pull-Up
Desc: The pull-up is a multi-joint bodyweight exercise that builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core. It is often used as a measurement tool in military or tactical fitness tests, and is an excellent gauge of “relative strength” which is strength in relation to bodyweight.
HowTo: To perform a King Maker Pull-Up, start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, focusing on engaging your upper back and biceps. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Medicine ball slam
Desc: The medicine ball slam is an explosive exercise for developing power, strength, and speed. Muscles worked include the abdominals, legs, triceps, shoulders, and lats. The slams are usually done in rapid succession to complete one set. It can also be a component of a power or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball above your head. Engage your core and slam the ball down to the ground with force, bending your knees slightly as you do so. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat the movement in rapid succession.

Title: Catch and Overhead Throw
Desc: The Catch and Overhead Throw is a dynamic exercise that involves catching a ball and throwing it overhead, focusing on coordination, upper body strength, and explosive power.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a ball at chest level. As you catch the ball, lower your body slightly, then explosively throw the ball overhead, extending your arms fully. Catch the ball on the rebound and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Bent-Over Medicine Ball Slam
Desc: The FYR2 Bent-Over Medicine Ball Slam is an intense full-body exercise that combines a bent-over position with a powerful slam of a medicine ball to the ground, targeting the core, shoulders, and legs.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a medicine ball in both hands. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. From this bent-over position, slam the ball down to the ground with power, then catch it on the rebound and repeat.

Title: Dynamic Back Stretch
Desc: The Dynamic Back Stretch is a warm-up exercise designed to improve flexibility and mobility in the back through dynamic movements that gently stretch the spine.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Slowly bend forward at the waist, reaching your arms out in front of you. Then, gently twist your torso side to side while maintaining the stretch in your back. Repeat the movement to warm up your spine.

Title: Chair Lower Back Stretch
Desc: The Chair Lower Back Stretch is a seated exercise that helps relieve tension in the lower back by gently stretching the spine and surrounding muscles while seated in a chair.
HowTo: Sit on the edge of a chair with your feet flat on the ground. Slowly lean forward, reaching your hands towards your feet while keeping your back straight. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Side-Lying Floor Stretch
Desc: The Side-Lying Floor Stretch is a flexibility exercise performed on the floor that targets the hip and lower back muscles, promoting relaxation and increased range of motion.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs extended. Gently pull your top leg towards your chest while keeping your bottom leg straight. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch sides and repeat.

Title: Band good morning-
Desc: The band good morning is an exercise targeting the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed in powerlifting-style training for high reps, or in the place of barbell good mornings.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and place a resistance band around your shoulders. Keeping your back straight, hinge at your hips and bend forward slightly while maintaining tension in the band. Return to standing by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: FYR2 Monster Banded Good Morning
Desc: The FYR2 Monster Banded Good Morning is a resistance exercise that utilizes a band to enhance the Good Morning movement, focusing on strengthening the posterior chain, including the hamstrings and lower back.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and place a resistance band under your feet. Hold the ends of the band at shoulder height. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso while keeping your back straight. Return to standing by engaging your posterior chain.

Title: Band deadlift
Desc: The band deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings while also benefiting the glutes and lats using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: To perform the band deadlift, stand on a resistance band with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold the ends of the band with both hands, keeping your arms straight. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso while keeping your back flat. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to stand back up, pulling against the resistance of the band.

Title: Lower back SMR
Desc: Lower back self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the quadratus lumborum or spinal erector (erector spinae) muscles of the lower back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Lower back SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the glutes or piriformis muscles, or by stretches that target the piriformis or hips. However, some people find that SMR on the lower back can aggravate existing pain or injury, so be cautious when performing it.
Muscles: Quadratus Lumborum, Erector Spinae, Glutes, Piriformis
HowTo: To perform lower back SMR, sit on the floor and place a foam roller or lacrosse ball under your lower back. Gently roll back and forth, applying pressure to tight areas. Focus on the quadratus lumborum and spinal erector muscles. If you feel pain, adjust the pressure or stop the exercise.

Title: Barbell deficit deadlift
Desc: The barbell deficit deadlift is a compound exercise targeting the posterior chain. It is commonly utilized in powerlifting training to build pulling strength off the floor, but is also an effective muscle-building movement for the glutes and hamstrings. It is usually performed with lighter weight, and perhaps for higher reps, than traditional deadlifts. If these make your back sore, decrease the deficit and/or wear a weightlifting belt.
HowTo: To perform the barbell deficit deadlift, stand on a platform or weight plate to create a deficit. Position a barbell over your midfoot and grip it with both hands. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso while keeping your back flat. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell, engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Deadlift with Bands
Desc: The Deadlift with Bands is a variation of the traditional deadlift that incorporates resistance bands to increase tension throughout the lift. This exercise targets the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back, while also improving explosive strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the deadlift with bands, set up a barbell on the ground and attach resistance bands to the ends. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell, and hinge at your hips to lower your torso. Engage your posterior chain to lift the barbell while the bands provide additional resistance as you rise.

Title: Deadlift with Chains
Desc: The Deadlift with Chains adds variable resistance to the standard deadlift by using chains that lift off the ground as you rise. This method enhances strength at different points of the lift and is effective for building power and muscle in the posterior chain.
HowTo: To perform the deadlift with chains, set up a barbell on the ground with chains draped over the ends. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell, and hinge at your hips to lower your torso. As you lift, the chains will lift off the ground, increasing resistance as you rise.

Title: Rack Pull with Bands
Desc: Rack Pull with Bands is a partial deadlift variation performed from an elevated position, typically at knee height, using resistance bands for added tension. This exercise focuses on the upper portion of the deadlift, targeting the back, glutes, and hamstrings, while also improving lockout strength.
HowTo: To perform the rack pull with bands, set the barbell at knee height in a squat rack and attach resistance bands for added tension. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell, and lift it by extending your hips and knees. Focus on engaging your back, glutes, and hamstrings.

Title: Rack pull
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can be used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who can't deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: Glutes, Hamstrings, Erector Spinae, Lower Back
HowTo: To perform the rack pull, set the barbell at an elevated height using boxes or safety pins. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell, and lift it by extending your hips and knees. Keep your back straight and engage your glutes and hamstrings throughout the movement.

Title: Seated Good Mornings
Desc: Seated Good Mornings are performed while seated, targeting the lower back, hamstrings, and glutes. This exercise emphasizes hip hinge mechanics and is great for developing strength and flexibility in the posterior chain.
HowTo: To perform seated good mornings, sit on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. Hold a barbell across your upper back. Hinge at your hips to lean forward while keeping your back straight. Return to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning
Desc: The Stiff Leg Barbell Good Morning is an exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It involves bending at the hips while keeping the legs straight, allowing for a deep stretch in the hamstrings.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell across your upper back. Keeping your legs straight, hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward while maintaining a flat back. Go as low as your flexibility allows, feeling a stretch in your hamstrings. Return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Reverse Band Deadlift
Desc: The Reverse Band Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that uses bands to reduce the weight at the bottom of the lift. This allows for a greater range of motion and can help improve strength and technique.
HowTo: Set up a barbell on the ground with bands attached to the bar and anchored to the floor. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the bar with both hands. Begin the lift by pushing through your heels and extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Focus on maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.

Title: Paul Carter Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower the barbell along your legs, keeping it close to your body. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: TBS Good Morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: Position a barbell across your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Keeping a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward while maintaining a straight back. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: TBS Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back, Core
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. With your knees slightly bent, hinge at the hips and lower the barbell down your legs, keeping it close to your body. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: Barbell deadlift-
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart, with the barbell over the middle of your feet. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. Keep your back straight and chest up as you push through your heels to lift the barbell off the ground, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the barbell with hands outside your knees. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your body and grip the bar. Keep your back straight and chest up as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. Lower the barbell back to the ground with control.

Title: Barbell good morning
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: Position a barbell across your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower your torso forward while keeping a straight back. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: UP Conventional Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: To perform the UP Conventional Deadlift, stand with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell over the middle of your feet. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. Keep your back straight and chest up as you push through your heels to lift the barbell, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the barbell back to the ground by hinging at the hips and bending your knees.

Title: 30 Day Back Barbell Rack Pull
Desc: The 30 Day Back Barbell Rack Pull is a strength training exercise that targets the back muscles, particularly the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. It involves lifting a barbell from a rack at knee height, focusing on proper form and controlled movement to build strength and improve posture.
HowTo: To perform the 30 Day Back Barbell Rack Pull, set a barbell on a rack at knee height. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. Keep your back straight and engage your core. Drive through your heels to lift the barbell off the rack, extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. Lower the barbell back to the rack with control.

Title: FYR Sumo Deadlift High Pull
Desc: The kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull is a dynamic kettlebell exercise that focuses on the muscles of the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, traps, rear delts, and upper back. It can be done in lower reps for power or strength, or higher reps for conditioning and fat loss. It can also be a component of a circuit-style kettlebell workout, either for time or reps.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Traps, Rear Delts, Upper Back
HowTo: To perform the FYR Sumo Deadlift High Pull, start with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell on the ground between your legs. Squat down to grip the kettlebell with both hands. Engage your core and keep your back flat as you lift the kettlebell by extending your hips and knees. As the kettlebell rises, pull it up to your chest by bending your elbows and keeping them high. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell deadlift is a foundational movement in kettlebell training. It's often taught as a buildup or regression to the kettlebell swing, as well as to instruct the "hip hinge" motion in a more approachable manner than with a barbell.
HowTo: To perform the Kettlebell Deadlift, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell between your feet. Hinge at the hips and bend your knees to grip the kettlebell with both hands. Keep your back flat and chest up as you push through your heels to lift the kettlebell, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the kettlebell back down by hinging at the hips and bending your knees.

Title: HM Kettlebell Swing
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Swing is a dynamic full-body exercise that primarily targets the hips, glutes, and core. It involves swinging a kettlebell from between the legs to shoulder height using a powerful hip thrust, promoting explosive strength and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: To perform the HM Kettlebell Swing, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. Hinge at the hips to swing the kettlebell back between your legs, keeping your back flat. Drive your hips forward explosively to swing the kettlebell up to shoulder height, using the momentum from your hips. Let the kettlebell swing back down and repeat.

Title: KV Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell
Desc: The KV Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell is a lower body exercise that emphasizes the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It involves holding a kettlebell in one or both hands while hinging at the hips to lower the weight down the front of the legs, maintaining a flat back and a slight bend in the knees.
HowTo: To perform the KV Romanian Deadlift with Kettlebell, stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold a kettlebell in one or both hands. Keeping a slight bend in your knees, hinge at your hips to lower the kettlebell down the front of your legs while maintaining a flat back. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Good Morning
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Good Morning is an exercise that targets the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and lower back. It involves holding a kettlebell at chest level and bending forward at the hips while keeping the back straight, promoting flexibility and strength in the lower body.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Kettlebell Good Morning, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a kettlebell at chest level. Keeping your back straight, hinge at your hips to bend forward while maintaining a slight bend in your knees. Lower your torso until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Romanian Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that focuses on the hamstrings and glutes. It involves lowering a kettlebell along the front of the legs while maintaining a slight bend in the knees and a neutral spine, enhancing strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Kettlebell Romanian Deadlift, stand with your feet hip-width apart and hold a kettlebell in both hands. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at your hips to lower the kettlebell along the front of your legs while keeping a neutral spine. Lower until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Staggered-Stance Deadlift
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Staggered-Stance Deadlift is a strength exercise that targets the posterior chain, focusing on the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It involves holding a kettlebell in one hand while standing in a staggered stance, which helps improve balance and stability while performing the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand in a staggered stance with one foot forward and the other foot back. 2. Hold a kettlebell in one hand, allowing it to hang down in front of you. 3. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebell toward the ground while keeping your back straight. 4. Drive through your front heel to return to a standing position, engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that utilizes dumbbells. This exercise emphasizes proper form and technique, targeting the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. It is performed by bending at the hips and knees to lower the dumbbells to the ground, then driving through the heels to return to a standing position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and bend your knees slightly to lower the dumbbells toward the ground, keeping your back straight. 3. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Drive through your heels to return to a standing position, engaging your glutes and lower back.

Title: Dumbbell skier
Desc: As the name suggests, the dumbbell skier takes the motion of skiing and replaces the poles with dumbbells. The hip and torso motion are similar to a kettlebell swing, as are the muscles it targets, including the hamstrings, glutes, upper back, and grip. However, unlike the traditional kettlebell swing, the arms are outside of the knees. This movement can be performed for time or for reps, but is usually performed for relatively high reps, such as 8-12 sets per rep or more, as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, lowering the dumbbells while keeping your back straight. 3. As you lower the dumbbells, swing your arms back like skiing poles. 4. Drive through your heels to return to the starting position, focusing on your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: TBS Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your legs straight and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Maintain a straight back throughout the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to a standing position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Stiff-Legged Dumbbell Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, low and upper back, as well as the core. The purpose of the stiff-legged, as opposed to Romanian deadlift with slightly bent knees, is to engage the hamstrings and low back to an even greater degree.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Keep your legs straight and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells along your legs. 3. Focus on maintaining a straight back as you lower the weights. 4. Return to a standing position by engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: UNS Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The UNS Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift is a variation of the Romanian deadlift that uses dumbbells. This exercise primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes, focusing on hip hinge mechanics. It is performed by holding a dumbbell in each hand, lowering the weights along the legs while keeping the back straight, and then returning to an upright position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the dumbbells along your legs while keeping your back straight. 3. Lower the dumbbells until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Return to an upright position by driving through your heels and engaging your glutes.

Title: Holman Slow Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Slow Deadlift is a controlled variation of the traditional deadlift that emphasizes slow, deliberate movements. This exercise targets the entire posterior chain, including the back, glutes, and hamstrings. It is performed by slowly lowering the barbell or weights to the ground and then lifting it back up with a focus on maintaining proper form throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or weights in front of you. 2. Slowly lower the weights to the ground by bending at the hips and knees, maintaining a straight back. 3. Focus on controlling the movement and keeping your core engaged. 4. Lift the weights back up to the starting position, emphasizing slow and deliberate movements.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Overhead Press is a compound exercise that combines a deadlift with an overhead press. This movement targets multiple muscle groups, including the legs, back, shoulders, and arms. It is performed by lifting the barbell or dumbbells from the ground to a standing position, then pressing the weights overhead in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells on the ground. 2. Perform a deadlift by lifting the weights from the ground to a standing position, keeping your back straight. 3. Once standing, press the weights overhead in one fluid motion. 4. Lower the weights back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Staggered-Stance Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Staggered-Stance Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that emphasizes stability and balance. By placing one foot slightly forward and the other back, this exercise targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back while also engaging the core for improved posture.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, one foot slightly forward. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower your torso while keeping your back straight. 3. Grip the barbell or dumbbells with both hands. 4. Engage your core and push through your heels to lift the weight back to standing. 5. Squeeze your glutes at the top and repeat.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Front Raise
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Front Raise combines a deadlift with a front raise, targeting the posterior chain and shoulders. This exercise helps build strength in the lower body while also enhancing shoulder stability and upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with feet hip-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Perform a deadlift by hinging at the hips and lowering the weights towards the ground. 3. As you return to standing, raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Lower the weights back to your sides and repeat.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Chest Press
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Chest Press integrates a deadlift with a chest press, effectively working the entire body. This compound movement strengthens the legs, back, and chest, promoting functional strength and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position with a barbell or dumbbells at your sides. 2. Perform a deadlift by hinging at the hips and lowering the weights. 3. Once you reach the bottom of the deadlift, press the weights up to chest level. 4. Lower the weights back down and return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Squat Thrust is a dynamic exercise that combines a deadlift with a squat thrust, providing a full-body workout. This movement enhances cardiovascular endurance, strength, and agility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells. 2. Perform a deadlift by hinging at the hips and lowering the weights. 3. As you return to standing, drop into a squat thrust position. 4. Jump back to standing and repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Deadlift to Biceps Curl
Desc: The Holman Deadlift to Biceps Curl is a unique exercise that merges a deadlift with a biceps curl, targeting the lower body and arms. This combination helps improve overall strength and muscle definition in both the legs and arms.
HowTo: 1. Start with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells. 2. Perform a deadlift by hinging at the hips and lowering the weights. 3. As you stand up, curl the weights towards your shoulders. 4. Lower the weights back down and repeat the deadlift and curl.

Title: Dumbbell kickstand deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell kickstand deadlift is a movement targeting the muscles of the hamstrings, glutes, and back. The kickstand position can help focus the stretch and contraction on each individual leg, similar to a single-leg Romanian deadlift, while presenting less of a balance challenge. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, for strengthening the posterior chain, or for higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot slightly behind you, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips and lower the weights towards the ground, keeping your back straight. 3. Focus on the stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Return to standing by pushing through your front heel and repeat.

Title: Single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row
Desc: The single-leg stiff-legged deadlift to row takes two popular strength moves and combines them into one full-body blaster. Between the deadlift and the row, you'll target the glutes, hamstrings, quads, back, and biceps. Because balance can be a challenge, this movement is usually done with relatively light weights for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
Muscles: Glutes, Hamstrings, Quads, Lower Back, Biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at the hips to perform a stiff-legged deadlift, lowering the weights towards the ground. 3. As you return to standing, pull the weights towards your chest in a rowing motion. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift is a variation of the standard deadlift performed with dumbbells, focusing on the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. This exercise allows for a greater range of motion and helps improve grip strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet hip-width apart, holding dumbbells at your sides. 2. Perform a deadlift by hinging at the hips and lowering the weights. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core throughout the movement. 4. Return to standing and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift to Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Deadlift to Dumbbell Upright Row is a compound exercise that combines a deadlift with an upright row, targeting the posterior chain and shoulders. Begin by performing a dumbbell deadlift, then transition into an upright row, keeping the dumbbells close to your body.
HowTo: 1. Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Hinge at your hips and lower the dumbbells to the ground, keeping your back straight and core engaged to perform a dumbbell deadlift. 3. Once you reach the bottom of the deadlift, push through your heels to return to a standing position. 4. Transition into an upright row by pulling the dumbbells up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body and your elbows higher than your wrists. 5. Lower the dumbbells back down and repeat the sequence.

Title: Atlas Stones
Desc: Atlas Stones are a strongman event where competitors lift heavy spherical stones onto platforms of varying heights. The exercise develops overall strength, grip, and explosive power.
HowTo: 1. Approach the Atlas Stones and choose the appropriate weight. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the stone with both hands. 3. Lift the stone by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 4. Once the stone is at your waist, quickly transition to placing it on the platform. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Axle Deadlift
Desc: The Axle Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift using a thick barbell (axle) that challenges grip strength and overall pulling power. It is performed by lifting the axle from the ground to a standing position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the axle bar with both hands. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to lower your body and grasp the axle. 3. Engage your core and lift the axle by extending your hips and knees simultaneously until you are standing upright. 4. Lower the axle back to the ground with control and repeat.

Title: Atlas Stone Trainer
Desc: The Atlas Stone Trainer is a training tool designed to help athletes prepare for Atlas Stone events. It typically consists of a series of stones of different weights that can be lifted and placed onto platforms.
HowTo: 1. Select a stone from the Atlas Stone Trainer that is appropriate for your skill level. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, bending at your hips and knees to grip the stone. 3. Lift the stone by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 4. Place the stone onto the designated platform. 5. Repeat with different stones as needed.

Title: Partner Flat-Bench Back Extension
Desc: The partner bench back extensionis a clever way to perform this exercise, which works the spinal erectors in the lower back. There are machines and angled apparatus that allow this exercise to performed solo; but, lacking those, all you need is a bench and a workout partner.
HowTo: 1. Position a bench and have your workout partner hold your legs down. 2. Lie face down on the bench with your upper body hanging off the edge. 3. Engage your core and lower your upper body towards the ground in a controlled manner. 4. Raise your upper body back up until your body is in a straight line. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Keg Load
Desc: Keg Load is a strongman event where competitors lift and load heavy kegs onto platforms. This exercise emphasizes strength, stability, and technique in lifting awkward objects.
HowTo: 1. Approach the keg and squat down to grip it securely. 2. Lift the keg by extending your hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Once the keg is at waist height, quickly transition to placing it onto the platform. 4. Ensure you maintain a stable stance throughout the lift. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Partner bench back extension
Desc: The partner bench back extension is a clever way to target the glutes and spinal erector muscles. There are machines and angled benches that allow this exercise to be performed solo, but, lacking those, all you need is a bench and a workout partner. It is usually performed for high reps as a burnout or accessory movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Set up a bench and have your workout partner hold your legs down. 2. Lie face down on the bench with your upper body hanging off the edge. 3. Lower your upper body towards the ground in a controlled manner. 4. Raise your upper body back up until your body is in a straight line, engaging your glutes and lower back. 5. Perform for high repetitions as a burnout or accessory movement.

Title: Rack Pull - Gethin Variation
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can e used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who can’t deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: Glutes, Hamstrings, Upper Back, Lower Back
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on safety pins or boxes at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Engage your core and lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. 4. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Hex Bar Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The hex bar deadlift is a variety of deadlift performed in a hexagonal barbell also known as a trap bar. The bar is held with a parallel (palms in) grip outside of the legs. It is biomechanically different from a barbell deadlift in that it lines up with a lifter’s center of gravity, rather than placing it in front of their body. The trap bar deadlift can be trained in traditional strength and muscle-focused rep range, or for higher reps. It activates all of the same muscle groups as conventional or sumo deadlifts, including the glutes, quads, hamstring, lower back, lats, upper back, and grip.
Muscles: Glutes, Quads, Hamstrings, Lower Back, Lats, Upper Back, Grip
HowTo: To perform the Hex Bar Deadlift, stand inside the hexagonal bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the handles with a neutral grip (palms facing in). Keep your chest up and back straight. Engage your core and push through your heels to lift the bar, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the bar back to the ground by hinging at the hips and bending your knees.

Title: Holman Deadlift
Desc: The Holman Deadlift is a variation of the deadlift that emphasizes the posterior chain, particularly the hamstrings and glutes. It is performed by lifting a barbell from the ground while maintaining a neutral spine and engaging the core.
HowTo: To perform the Holman Deadlift, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell on the ground with both hands. Keep your back straight and engage your core. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees simultaneously, maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement. Lower the barbell back to the ground in a controlled manner.

Title: ACFT Low-handle trap bar deadlift
Desc: The low-handle trap bar deadlift is a variety of deadlift performed in a hexagonal barbell also known as a trap bar. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. The bar is held with a parallel (palms in) grip outside of the legs. It is biomechanically different from a barbell deadlift in that it lines up with a lifter's center of gravity, rather than placing the weight in front of their body. It activates all of the same muscle groups as conventional or sumo deadlifts, including the glutes, quads, hamstrings, lower back, lats, upper back, and grip.
Muscles: Glutes, Quads, Hamstrings, Lower Back, Lats, Upper Back, Grip
HowTo: To perform the ACFT Low-handle trap bar deadlift, step inside the trap bar and position your feet shoulder-width apart. Grip the handles with a neutral grip (palms facing in). Keep your chest up and back straight, engaging your core. Push through your heels to lift the bar, extending your hips and knees at the same time. Lower the bar back to the ground by hinging at the hips and bending your knees.

Title: Neutral-grip lat pull-down
Desc: The neutral-grip lat pull-down is a variation on the lat pull-down that uses a handle with a neutral (palms facing in) grip. This arrangement helps to build lat width and target the upper lats. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 per set or higher, as part of an upper-body or back-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the Neutral-grip lat pull-down, sit at the lat pull-down machine and grasp the neutral grip handle with both hands. Keep your chest up and pull the handle down towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Control the movement as you return the handle to the starting position, ensuring you maintain a slight lean back and engage your lats throughout.

Title: Seated cable deadlift
Desc: The seated cable deadlift is a version of the deadlift or hip hinge movement that is performed on a seated cable row machine. Similar to a stiff-legged deadlift or 45-degree back extension, it targets the muscles of the lower back, as well as the glutes and upper back to a lesser degree. It is usually utilized in higher rep ranges, at least 8-12 reps per set, on a back-focused muscle-building day, or as a deadlift accessory lift to strengthen the lower back.
HowTo: To perform the Seated cable deadlift, sit on the cable row machine with your feet on the platform. Grip the handle with both hands and sit up straight. Engage your core and hinge at the hips to pull the handle towards you, extending your hips and knees as you lift. Lower the handle back down in a controlled manner, maintaining good posture throughout.

Title: Cable stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The cable stiff-legged deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings, while also benefiting the glutes using a proper hip-hinging motion.
HowTo: To perform the cable stiff-legged deadlift, attach a handle to the low pulley of a cable machine. Stand facing the machine and grip the handle with both hands. Keep your legs straight but not locked, hinge at the hips to lower the handle towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-leg cable stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The single-leg cable stiff-legged deadlift is a lower-body exercise that mainly targets the hamstrings, while also benefiting the glutes using a proper hip-hinging motion. Training one leg at a time allows for working out imbalances.
HowTo: To perform the single-leg cable stiff-legged deadlift, attach a handle to the low pulley of a cable machine. Stand facing the machine and grip the handle with one hand. Lift one leg off the ground and hinge at the hips to lower the handle towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the starting position, then switch legs.

Title: UNS Banded Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift
Desc: The UNS Banded Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift incorporates resistance bands to increase tension throughout the movement. This exercise targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back, promoting strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the UNS Banded Dumbbell Romanian Deadlift, secure a resistance band under your feet and hold a dumbbell in each hand. Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Keeping your knees slightly bent, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells towards the ground while maintaining a straight back. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to return to the standing position, feeling the tension from the bands throughout the movement.

Title: Seated Back Extension
Desc: The Seated Back Extension is an exercise that targets the lower back muscles. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and your back straight. Lean back slightly while keeping your core engaged, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and your back straight. Lean back slightly while keeping your core engaged, then return to the starting position.

Title: Back extension
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Lie face down on a 45-degree bench with your feet anchored. Lower your upper body towards the ground, then lift it back up by engaging your lower back, hamstrings, and glutes. Perform for 15-20 reps or 8-12 reps with added weight.

Title: Hyperextensions With No Hyperextension Bench
Desc: Hyperextensions Without a Hyperextension Bench can be performed on the floor or a mat. Lie face down with your hips on the edge of a bench or mat, and lift your upper body by engaging your lower back muscles. Hold for a moment before lowering back down.
HowTo: Lie face down on the floor or a mat with your hips on the edge. Engage your lower back muscles to lift your upper body off the ground, hold for a moment, then lower back down.

Title: Superman
Desc: The Superman is a bodyweight exercise that consists of isometric holds in an extended spine position. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: Lie face down on the ground with your arms extended in front of you. Lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground simultaneously, holding the position for a few seconds before lowering back down.

Title: Hug A Ball
Desc: Hug A Ball is an exercise that focuses on core stability and flexibility. Lie on your back, hold a stability ball with both hands, and gently pull it towards your chest while engaging your core. This helps to stretch the back and strengthen the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: Lie on your back and hold a stability ball with both hands. Gently pull the ball towards your chest while engaging your core, feeling the stretch in your back and strengthening your abdominal muscles.

Title: Child's pose
Desc: Child’s pose is a traditional yoga pose that is also popular in fitness and strength training. It targets mobility of the thoracic spine and control of the vertebral column. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or as a mobility or restorative exercise anytime. It can also work as part of a yoga or bodyweight sequence with other poses.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor and sit back on your heels. Reach your arms forward on the ground, lowering your torso towards the floor. Hold this position for several breaths to stretch your back and improve thoracic mobility.

Title: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge
Desc: Pelvic Tilt Into Bridge is a great exercise for strengthening the glutes and lower back. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Perform a pelvic tilt by flattening your lower back against the floor, then lift your hips into a bridge position, squeezing your glutes at the top.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor. Flatten your lower back against the floor by performing a pelvic tilt, then lift your hips into a bridge position while squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: Hug Knees To Chest
Desc: Hug Knees To Chest is a simple stretch that helps relieve tension in the lower back. Lie on your back and pull your knees towards your chest, wrapping your arms around them. Hold this position for a few breaths, feeling the stretch in your lower back.
HowTo: Lie on your back and pull your knees towards your chest, wrapping your arms around them. Hold this position for a few breaths, feeling the stretch in your lower back.

Title: Pyramid
Desc: The Pyramid exercise involves standing with feet shoulder-width apart and raising your arms overhead, then bending forward at the hips to reach towards the ground, creating a pyramid shape with your body.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your arms overhead. Bend forward at the hips, reaching towards the ground, creating a pyramid shape with your body.

Title: Partner Superman with alternating high-five
Desc: The partner Superman with alternating high-five is an exercise in which both partners perform isometric holds for reps, high-fiving each other in between. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or as part of a core or back-focused workout or finisher.
Muscles: Lower Back, Glutes, Spinal Erectors, Upper Back
HowTo: Both partners perform isometric holds for reps while high-fiving each other in between. Focus on engaging the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back.

Title: Yoga plex
Desc: The yoga plex is a stretch that combines elements of the downward facing dog yoga pose with the “world’s greatest stretch.” It is most commonly performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, to limber up muscles from head to toe, raise the body’s core temperature, and mobilize the hips, upper back, and shoulders.
Muscles: Lower Back, Hips, Upper Back, Shoulders
HowTo: Start in a downward facing dog position. Transition into the 'world’s greatest stretch' by stepping one foot forward and lowering your hips, then switch sides.

Title: TBS Back Extension
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Lie face down on a 45-degree bench with your feet anchored. Lift your upper body by extending your back, then lower back down. Perform 15-20 reps for unweighted or 8-12 reps with added weight.

Title: Lower Back Stretch - Yates Variation
Desc: The lying cross-over lower back stretch is a simple bodyweight stretch targeting the lower back, hips, and torso. It involves rotating the legs while lying flat on the back. It is commonly included in dynamic warm-ups, but can also be performed as full-body mobility work anytime.
HowTo: Lie flat on your back and rotate your legs to one side while keeping your shoulders on the ground. Hold the stretch to target the lower back, hips, and torso.

Title: Hyperextension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Lie face down on a 45-degree bench with your feet anchored. Perform back extensions by lifting your upper body, then lowering it back down. Aim for 15-20 reps unweighted or 8-12 with added weight.

Title: Back Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The back extension is an exercise used to build lower back strength that also targets the hamstrings and glutes. It is often performed on a 45-degree bench with the feet anchored. Unweighted back extensions are often performed for high reps, such as 15-20 reps or more, but the movement can also be performed with added weight in lower rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: Lie face down on a 45-degree bench with your feet anchored. Lift your upper body by extending your back, then lower back down. Perform 15-20 reps for unweighted or 8-12 reps with added weight.

Title: HM Banana Stretch
Desc: The HM Banana Stretch is a flexibility exercise that involves lying on your back and stretching your arms and legs out to the sides, resembling a banana shape, to improve core stability and flexibility.
HowTo: Lie on your back and stretch your arms and legs out to the sides, forming a banana shape. Hold the position to improve core stability and flexibility.

Title: HM T-Spine Stretch on Wall
Desc: The HM T-Spine Stretch on Wall is designed to improve thoracic spine mobility. Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart. Place your arms in a 'W' position against the wall and gently slide them upward while keeping your back and arms in contact with the wall.
HowTo: Stand with your back against a wall, feet shoulder-width apart. Place your arms in a 'W' position against the wall. Gently slide your arms upward while keeping your back and arms in contact with the wall.

Title: HM Child's Pose
Desc: The HM Child's Pose is a restorative yoga pose that stretches the back and hips. Start on your hands and knees, then sit back on your heels, extending your arms forward on the floor and resting your forehead down. Breathe deeply and relax into the stretch.
Muscles: Erector Spinae, Gluteus Maximus, Quadratus Lumborum
HowTo: Start on your hands and knees. Sit back on your heels, extending your arms forward on the floor. Rest your forehead down and breathe deeply, relaxing into the stretch.

Title: HM Cobra
Desc: The HM Cobra is a backbend that stretches the chest and spine. Lie face down, place your hands under your shoulders, and press into your palms to lift your chest off the ground while keeping your hips down. Look slightly upward and hold the position.
Muscles: Erector Spinae, Latissimus Dorsi, Pectoralis Major
HowTo: Lie face down and place your hands under your shoulders. Press into your palms to lift your chest off the ground while keeping your hips down. Look slightly upward and hold the position.

Title: HM Cobra With Arm Retraction
Desc: The HM Cobra With Arm Retraction enhances the traditional Cobra pose by adding an arm movement. From the Cobra position, retract your shoulder blades and draw your elbows back towards your body, then return to the starting position. This engages the upper back muscles.
HowTo: From the Cobra position, retract your shoulder blades and draw your elbows back towards your body. Return to the starting position to engage the upper back muscles.

Title: HM Dive-Bomber
Desc: The HM Dive-Bomber is a dynamic movement that combines a downward dog and upward dog position. Start in downward dog, then lower your chest towards the ground while bending your elbows, and swoop your chest forward and up into upward dog. Reverse the motion to return.
HowTo: Start in downward dog. Lower your chest towards the ground while bending your elbows. Swoop your chest forward and up into upward dog. Reverse the motion to return to downward dog.

Title: HM Downward-Facing Dog Pose
Desc: The HM Downward-Facing Dog Pose is a foundational yoga pose that stretches the entire body. Start on your hands and knees, tuck your toes, and lift your hips up and back, straightening your legs and arms. Keep your head between your arms and breathe deeply.
HowTo: Start on your hands and knees. Tuck your toes and lift your hips up and back, straightening your legs and arms. Keep your head between your arms and breathe deeply.

Title: HM Downward Dog To Left Leg Extension To Warrior Pose
Desc: The HM Downward Dog To Left Leg Extension To Warrior Pose transitions from downward dog to a warrior pose. From downward dog, lift your left leg high, then step it forward between your hands, rising into a warrior pose with your arms extended.
HowTo: From downward dog, lift your left leg high. Step it forward between your hands and rise into a warrior pose with your arms extended.

Title: HM Downward Dog To Right Leg Extension To Warrior Pose
Desc: The HM Downward Dog To Right Leg Extension To Warrior Pose is similar to the left leg extension. Begin in downward dog, lift your right leg high, step it forward between your hands, and rise into a warrior pose, extending your arms and grounding your feet.
HowTo: Begin in downward dog. Lift your right leg high, step it forward between your hands, and rise into a warrior pose, extending your arms and grounding your feet.

Title: HM Spine Twist
Desc: The HM Spine Twist is a gentle exercise that promotes spinal mobility and flexibility. It involves twisting the spine while seated or lying down, helping to relieve tension in the back and improve overall posture.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you or lie down on your back. Keep your spine straight. Slowly twist your torso to one side, using your hands to support the movement. Hold the position for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your spine. Return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: HM Good Morning
Desc: The HM Good Morning is a strength exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. It involves bending at the hips while keeping the back straight, mimicking the motion of bowing forward.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hinge at your hips, keeping your back straight, and bend forward as if bowing. Engage your hamstrings and glutes as you lower your torso. Return to the starting position by engaging your glutes and hamstrings to stand back up.

Title: HM Rag Doll
Desc: The HM Rag Doll is a relaxing stretch that focuses on the hamstrings and lower back. It involves bending forward with knees slightly bent, allowing the arms to hang down and the head to relax.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to fold forward, letting your arms hang down towards the floor. Relax your head and neck, and feel the stretch in your hamstrings and lower back. Hold for several breaths.

Title: HM Upward-Facing Dog Pose
Desc: The HM Upward-Facing Dog Pose is a yoga posture that stretches the chest, shoulders, and abdomen. It involves lying face down and lifting the chest and thighs off the ground while keeping the arms straight.
HowTo: Start lying face down on the mat. Place your hands under your shoulders. Press into your hands to lift your chest and thighs off the ground, keeping your arms straight. Engage your core and lift your chest high, opening your shoulders and stretching your abdomen. Hold the position for a few breaths.

Title: Superman-
Desc: The Superman is a bodyweight exercise that consists of isometric holds in an extended spine position. It targets the muscles of the posterior chain, including the muscles of the glutes, spinal erectors, and upper back. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or for muscle activation or mobility anytime.
HowTo: Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended in front of you and legs straight. Simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the ground, engaging your back and glute muscles. Hold this position for a few seconds, then lower back down. Repeat for several repetitions.

Title: Weighted back extension
Desc: The weighted back extension is an exercise targeting the spinal erectors, as well as the glutes and hamstrings. Back extensions are often done for high reps without weight, but when done with weight, they can be an excellent accessory movement for deadlift strength as well as an overall posterior-chain strength builder. Because your back is the limiting factor, it's still an exercise that is usually done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher. You can weight it with a plate or by holding a dumbbell or other weight in your hands.
HowTo: Position yourself on a back extension bench or mat. Secure your feet and hips, then hinge at your hips to lower your upper body towards the ground. With a weight plate or dumbbell held against your chest, lift your upper body back to a straight position, engaging your spinal erectors, glutes, and hamstrings. Perform 8-12 repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Superman
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Superman is a core strengthening exercise that targets the lower back, glutes, and shoulders. It involves lying face down and lifting opposite arms and legs alternately.
HowTo: Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended in front of you and legs straight. Lift your right arm and left leg simultaneously, keeping your core engaged. Lower them back down and then lift your left arm and right leg. Continue alternating sides for several repetitions.

Title: MetaBurn Swimmer
Desc: The MetaBurn Swimmer is a dynamic exercise that engages the back, shoulders, and core. It mimics the motion of swimming by alternating arm and leg movements while lying face down.
HowTo: Lie face down on the floor with your arms extended in front of you and legs straight. Simulate a swimming motion by lifting your right arm and left leg off the ground, then switch to lift your left arm and right leg. Continue alternating in a controlled manner while engaging your core.

Title: Dancer's Stretch
Desc: The Dancer's Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the hip flexors, quadriceps, and hamstrings. It involves extending one leg behind while reaching forward with the opposite arm, promoting balance and stretching the body.
HowTo: Stand on one leg while extending the other leg behind you. Reach forward with the opposite arm to maintain balance. Hold the stretch to target the hip flexors, quadriceps, and hamstrings.

Title: Cat Stretch
Desc: The Cat Stretch is a gentle yoga pose that helps to improve spinal flexibility and relieve tension in the back. It involves arching the back upwards while on hands and knees, then lowering the belly and lifting the head to create a gentle wave motion.
HowTo: Start on your hands and knees. Arch your back upwards, tucking your chin to your chest, then lower your belly while lifting your head to create a wave motion. Repeat to improve spinal flexibility.

Title: Crossover Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Crossover Reverse Lunge is a dynamic lower body exercise that targets the glutes, hamstrings, and quadriceps. It involves stepping back into a lunge while crossing the back leg behind the front leg, enhancing balance and coordination.
HowTo: Stand upright and step back with one leg into a lunge, crossing it behind the front leg. Push through the front heel to return to standing. Repeat on the other side to target glutes, hamstrings, and quadriceps.

Title: Standing Pelvic Tilt
Desc: The Standing Pelvic Tilt is an exercise that focuses on strengthening the core and improving posture. It involves standing upright and tilting the pelvis forward and backward, engaging the abdominal muscles.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Tilt your pelvis forward by engaging your abdominal muscles, then tilt it backward. Repeat to strengthen the core and improve posture.

Title: Exercise ball weighted hyperextension
Desc: The exercise ball weighted hyperextension is an exercise that strengthens the lower back. If balance is an issue, have someone hold your feet.
HowTo: Lie face down on an exercise ball with your feet anchored. Hold weights in both hands and lift your upper body by extending your back. Lower back down and repeat to strengthen the lower back.

Title: Exercise ball rear delt fly
Desc: The exercise ball rear delt fly is a dumbbell exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, as well as the muscles of the upper-middle back. Lying prone on an exercise ball offers support to perform the movement. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps as a part of upper body or shoulder training.
HowTo: Lie prone on an exercise ball with your feet firmly planted. Hold dumbbells in each hand and lift your arms out to the side, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower back down and repeat for shoulder and upper back strength.

Title: Lying rear delt Y
Desc: The lying rear delt Y works the shoulders, specifically the rear heads, as well as the lower trapezius muscles. At the top of the motion, the arms and torso form a Y—hence the name. Shoulder Y variations are usually performed with light weights as a warm-up or prehab movement for upper-body training, or as a burnout on shoulder day.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench or the floor with your arms extended in a Y shape. Lift your arms and torso off the ground while squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower back down and repeat to target the rear delts and lower trapezius.

Title: Partner Facing Feet-Elevated Side Plank With Band Row
Desc: The Partner Facing Feet-Elevated Side Plank With Band Row is a challenging exercise that targets the obliques, shoulders, and back. It requires two partners to face each other in a side plank position with feet elevated, while one partner performs a band row, engaging the core and upper body.
HowTo: With a partner, get into a side plank position with your feet elevated. One partner holds a resistance band and performs a row while maintaining the plank position. Engage your core and keep your body straight throughout the movement.

Title: Partner side plank band row
Desc: The partner side plank band row is an abdominal exercise where two partners perform side planks while pulling on the opposite ends of an exercise band. This technique can be done for time or reps in any ab-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a side plank position with your partner. 2. Each partner holds one end of the exercise band. 3. While maintaining the side plank, pull the band towards your body, engaging your back and core. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired time or number of reps.

Title: Band-assisted chin-up
Desc: The band-assisted chin-up is a variation of the pull-up exercise in which the reps are performed with the palms facing toward the body in an underhand position, with a band looped around the feet or knees. This reduces weight and resistance at the bottom of the rep, while increasing it toward the top. Like other pull-up variations, it builds strength and muscle in the upper back, biceps, and core, but it utilizes the biceps slightly more than overhand band-assisted pull-ups.
HowTo: 1. Loop a resistance band around your feet or knees. 2. Grab the pull-up bar with an underhand grip, palms facing you. 3. Hang from the bar with your arms fully extended. 4. Engage your core and pull yourself up towards the bar, using the band for assistance. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Back Band-Assisted Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Band-Assisted Pull-Up is an exercise designed to help individuals build upper body strength by using a resistance band for support. This variation allows for a controlled movement while targeting the back muscles, particularly the latissimus dorsi, biceps, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to the pull-up bar and loop it around your knees or feet. 2. Grip the bar with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Hang with your arms fully extended. 4. Engage your back and pull your chin above the bar, using the band for support. 5. Lower yourself back down and repeat for 30 reps.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Band-Assisted Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Reverse-Grip Band-Assisted Pull-Up is a variation of the traditional pull-up that focuses on the back and biceps. By using a reverse grip and a resistance band for assistance, this exercise helps improve strength and technique while reducing the load on the upper body.
HowTo: 1. Secure a resistance band around your knees or feet and grip the pull-up bar with a reverse grip (palms facing you). 2. Hang from the bar with arms fully extended. 3. Pull yourself up towards the bar, focusing on engaging your back and biceps. 4. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band bent-over row
Desc: The band bent-over row is an exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. Bands provide dynamic resistance and can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Lower Trapezius, Rear Deltoids
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the band with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight, until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. 3. Pull the band towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the band back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Heavy band bent-over row
Desc: The heavy band bent-over row is a variation of the popular barbell exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lats), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Lower Trapezius, Rear Deltoids
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a heavy resistance band with both hands. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the band towards your torso, engaging your upper back muscles. 4. Lower the band back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse-grip bent-over row
Desc: The reverse-grip bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is thought to target the biceps and lats a bit more directly than overhand barbell rows. Because it can be loaded heavily, it is a popular movement in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Lower Back, Biceps
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with a reverse grip. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: One-Arm Long Bar Row
Desc: The single-arm landmine bent-over row is a barbell exercise focused on the muscles of the middle back, such as the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It also targets the biceps and grip. It utilizes a landmine device which anchors one end of the barbell near the ground, but could also be approximated by placing the barbell in the corner of a room.
HowTo: 1. Set up a landmine device or place one end of a barbell in the corner of a room. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, facing the landmine. 3. Bend at the hips and knees, holding the free end of the barbell with one hand. 4. Pull the barbell towards your torso, engaging your back and biceps. 5. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bent Over Barbell Row
Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower it back down.

Title: Yates Row Reverse Grip
Desc: The Yates Row with a reverse grip targets the upper back and biceps. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an underhand grip. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower it back down.

Title: Pendlay Row
Desc: The Pendlay row, named after the well-known strength coach Glenn Pendlay, is a bent-over row variation where each rep starts with the barbell resting on the ground. This eliminates the stretch reflex and forces the lifter to pull with power and a bent-over spine. The Pendlay row can be performed heavy for low reps, but is usually performed for moderate reps, such as 5-8 per set.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a barbell on the ground in front of you. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the barbell with an overhand grip. Keep your back flat and pull the barbell towards your torso, ensuring each rep starts from the ground.

Title: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows
Desc: Straight Bar Bench Mid Rows are performed on a bench with a straight barbell. Lie face down on the bench, grip the barbell with both hands, and pull it towards your torso. This exercise primarily targets the middle back and helps improve posture.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench, gripping a straight barbell with both hands. Pull the barbell towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: Barbell seal row
Desc: The barbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: Lie face down on an elevated bench with a barbell. Grip the barbell with both hands, then pull it towards your torso while keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

Title: Yates Row
Desc: The Yates Row is a variation of the bent-over row that emphasizes the upper back and biceps. With a barbell in hand and a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips and pull the barbell towards your lower chest, maintaining a neutral spine throughout the movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. Bend at the hips and knees, maintaining a neutral spine. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower it back down.

Title: Plate Row
Desc: Plate Row involves using a weight plate to perform a rowing motion. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, hold a weight plate with both hands, and hinge at the hips. Pull the plate towards your torso, engaging your back muscles, then lower it back down.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight, then pull the plate towards your torso, engaging your back muscles, and lower it back down.

Title: Barbell Deadlift Bent Row Complex
Desc: The barbell deadlift bent-over row complex combines two movements to target the posterior chain. It requires using a lighter weight than you could handle for heavy deadlifts alone, but doubles down on activation in the upper back, lower back, and glutes.
HowTo: Start with a barbell on the ground. Perform a deadlift to lift the barbell to hip level, then hinge at the hips and pull the barbell towards your torso in a bent-over row motion. Alternate between the deadlift and the row for the complex.

Title: Single-Arm Landmine Row
Desc: The Single-Arm Landmine Row is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats and rhomboids. To perform this exercise, position a barbell in a landmine attachment or securely in a corner. Stand with one side of your body facing the barbell, grasp the handle with one hand, and hinge at the hips. Pull the barbell towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down. This exercise helps improve unilateral strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the Single-Arm Landmine Row, position a barbell in a landmine attachment or securely in a corner. Stand with one side of your body facing the barbell, grasp the handle with one hand, and hinge at the hips. Pull the barbell towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: TBS T-Bar Row
Desc: The TBS T-Bar Row is a compound exercise that primarily targets the back muscles, including the lats, traps, and rhomboids. To execute this exercise, stand over a T-Bar row machine or a barbell set in a landmine position. Bend at the hips and knees, grasp the handles or bar with both hands, and pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner. This exercise is excellent for building thickness in the back.
HowTo: To execute the TBS T-Bar Row, stand over a T-Bar row machine or a barbell set in a landmine position. Bend at the hips and knees, grasp the handles or bar with both hands, and pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner.

Title: TBS Deficit Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deficit deadlift is a compound exercise targeting the posterior chain.
HowTo: To perform the TBS Deficit Deadlift, stand on a platform to increase the range of motion. Grip the barbell with both hands, hinge at the hips, and lower your body to grasp the bar. Keep your back straight and lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright.

Title: Bent-Over Barbell Row - Gethin Variation
