Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: To perform the Bent-Over Barbell Row - Gethin Variation, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips, and grasp the barbell with both hands. Pull the barbell towards your lower chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down in a controlled manner.

Title: Barbell bent-over row
Desc: The barbell bent-over row is a compound exercise used to build strength and size in both the lower and upper back. It targets nearly all of the muscles in the back, but particularly the lats, rhomboids, and lower back. It is commonly utilized as an accessory movement for the deadlift in powerlifting, but is also popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body workouts.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Bent-Over Row, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips, and grasp the barbell with both hands. Pull the barbell towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower it back down.

Title: UN Barbell Rack Pull
Desc: The UN Barbell Rack Pull is a strength training exercise that focuses on the posterior chain, particularly the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. To perform this exercise, set a barbell on a squat rack at knee height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and lift it by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position. This exercise is great for improving deadlift strength and overall back development.
HowTo: To perform the UN Barbell Rack Pull, set a barbell on a squat rack at knee height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and lift it by extending your hips and knees until you are standing upright. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position.

Title: UN Barbell Scrape The Rack
Desc: The UN Barbell Scrape The Rack is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. To perform this movement, set a barbell on a squat rack at about waist height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and pull it towards your body while keeping it close to your torso, as if scraping the rack. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement before lowering the barbell back down. This exercise helps to strengthen the upper back and improve posture.
HowTo: To perform the UN Barbell Scrape The Rack, set a barbell on a squat rack at about waist height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and pull it towards your body while keeping it close to your torso, as if scraping the rack. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement before lowering the barbell back down.

Title: Barbell deadlift bent-over row complex
Desc: The barbell deadlift bent-over row complex combines two movements to target the posterior chain. It requires using a lighter weight than you could handle for heavy deadlifts alone, but doubles down on activation in the upper back, lower back, and glutes.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Deadlift Bent-Over Row Complex, start with a deadlift by gripping the barbell and lifting it from the ground. Once standing, hinge at the hips and pull the barbell towards your torso in a bent-over row. Alternate between the deadlift and the row for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Back Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The Back Barbell Deadlift is a compound exercise that primarily targets the muscles of the back, glutes, and hamstrings. To perform this exercise, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and lift it from the ground while keeping your back straight and engaging your core.
Muscles: Erector Spinae, Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and lift it from the ground while keeping your back straight and engaging your core.

Title: 30 Back Bent-Over Barbell Row
Desc: The Bent-Over Barbell Row is an effective exercise for building strength in the upper back, lats, and biceps. To execute this movement, bend at the hips and knees while keeping your back straight, then pull the barbell towards your abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.
HowTo: Bend at the hips and knees while keeping your back straight, then pull the barbell towards your abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.

Title: 30 Back T-Bar Row
Desc: The T-Bar Row is a great exercise for targeting the middle back and lats. To perform this exercise, stand over the T-Bar machine, grip the handles, and pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight and your elbows close to your body.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Erector Spinae
HowTo: Stand over the T-Bar machine, grip the handles, and pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight and your elbows close to your body.

Title: 30 Back Underhand Bent-Over Barbell Row
Desc: The Underhand Bent-Over Barbell Row emphasizes the lower lats and biceps. To perform this exercise, bend at the hips with your knees slightly bent, grip the barbell with an underhand grip, and pull the barbell towards your waist while keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Bend at the hips with your knees slightly bent, grip the barbell with an underhand grip, and pull the barbell towards your waist while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Kettlebell alternating renegade row
Desc: The kettlebell alternating renegade row combines rowing and core training into a single difficult movement. It's popular in time-efficient strength and muscle-building workouts, as well as in circuit-style training.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with a kettlebell in each hand. Row one kettlebell towards your side while stabilizing your body, then alternate to the other side.

Title: Alternating Kettlebell Row
Desc: The Alternating Kettlebell Row is a unilateral exercise that targets the upper back and core. To perform this exercise, hinge at the hips, hold a kettlebell in one hand, and row it towards your side while stabilizing your body with the opposite arm.
HowTo: Hinge at the hips, hold a kettlebell in one hand, and row it towards your side while stabilizing your body with the opposite arm.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Row
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Row is an effective exercise for strengthening the back and improving posture. To execute this movement, hinge at the hips with a kettlebell in each hand, and pull both kettlebells towards your torso while keeping your back flat and core engaged.
HowTo: Hinge at the hips with a kettlebell in each hand, and pull both kettlebells towards your torso while keeping your back flat and core engaged.

Title: Kettlebell bent-over row to clean
Desc: The kettlebell bent-over row to clean is a combination kettlebell exercise that targets many of the muscles of the upper body including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, shoulders, and core. It also strengthens and trains power output of the lower body. It can be done for reps or for time as a strength or muscle-focused complex, or in circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Biceps, Core
HowTo: Hinge at the hips with a kettlebell in each hand, perform a bent-over row, then transition into a clean by pulling the kettlebells up to your shoulders.

Title: UP Deficit Kettlebell Stiff-Legged Deadlift
Desc: The kettlebell deficit deadlift is a more advanced version of the kettlebell deadlift movement that is performed standing on steps or boxes. It can be done to build strength or hip mobility for squats or deadlifts, in high reps or in more traditional strength and muscle-focused rep ranges.
HowTo: To perform the kettlebell deficit deadlift, stand on a step or box with a kettlebell in each hand. Hinge at the hips and lower the kettlebells towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Drive through your heels to return to a standing position, engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: FYR2 Dagger-Grip Double-Kettlebell Gorilla Row
Desc: The FYR2 Dagger-Grip Double-Kettlebell Gorilla Row is a strength exercise that targets the back, shoulders, and arms. To perform this exercise, hold a kettlebell in each hand with a dagger grip (palms facing each other) and hinge at the hips. Pull the kettlebells towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down. This movement helps improve upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Dagger-Grip Double-Kettlebell Gorilla Row, start by holding a kettlebell in each hand with your palms facing each other. Hinge at the hips and lower your torso until it's nearly parallel to the ground. Pull the kettlebells towards your torso, keeping your elbows close to your body, then lower them back down to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Swing Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Swing Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines the kettlebell swing and clean. Start with two kettlebells on the ground in front of you. Perform a swing by driving your hips back and then explosively thrusting them forward to swing the kettlebells up. As they reach shoulder height, pull them into a clean position, catching them at your shoulders. This exercise enhances power, coordination, and grip strength.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Swing Clean, start with two kettlebells on the ground in front of you. Hinge at the hips and swing the kettlebells back between your legs. Thrust your hips forward to swing the kettlebells up explosively. As they reach shoulder height, pull them into your body and catch them at your shoulders in a clean position.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell row-
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell row is a popular muscle- and strength-building exercise that works the muscles of the back and core simultaneously. It has all the same benefits as a single-arm dumbbell row, but some people find a kettlebell more comfortable to hold during the movement.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm kettlebell row, place one knee and hand on a bench for support. Hold a kettlebell in the opposite hand, letting it hang straight down. Pull the kettlebell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Ascending-Rep Swing-Squat Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Ascending-Rep Swing-Squat Complex is a compound exercise that combines kettlebell swings and squats. Begin with a kettlebell in front of you, perform a swing, and then transition into a squat by lowering your hips back and down. As you rise from the squat, perform another swing. This complex movement builds strength, endurance, and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: To perform the FYR2 Ascending-Rep Swing-Squat Complex, start with a kettlebell in front of you. Perform a kettlebell swing by driving your hips back and then thrusting them forward. After the swing, lower your hips into a squat position. As you rise from the squat, perform another swing. Repeat this complex for the desired number of reps.

Title: One-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: To perform the One-Arm Dumbbell Row, place one knee and hand on a bench for support. With the other hand, hold a dumbbell and let it hang straight down. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat.

Title: Incline dumbbell row
Desc: The incline dumbbell row is an upper-body exercise targeting the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper-back muscles, as well as the biceps. Performing it on an incline bench helps target the lower lats in particular. Dumbbell row variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the incline dumbbell row, lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Let the dumbbells hang straight down. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.

Title: Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In
Desc: The Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In is a back-strengthening exercise. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing inwards. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down. This exercise targets the upper back and improves posture.
HowTo: To perform the Bent Over Two-Dumbbell Row With Palms In, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing inwards. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso while keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbells towards your waist, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.

Title: Man-maker
Desc: The man-maker is a sequence of exercises combining a dumbbell front squat, military press, renegade row, and sprawl. Between these movements it challenges muscles across the body, along with the cardiovascular system. It can be performed for rounds or for time as a single full-body exercise or as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the man-maker, start in a standing position holding a dumbbell in each hand. Begin with a dumbbell front squat, lowering your body as if sitting back into a chair. As you rise, press the dumbbells overhead into a military press. Next, transition into a renegade row by getting into a plank position and rowing one dumbbell towards your hip while stabilizing your body with the other arm. After completing the row, perform a sprawl by jumping your feet back towards your hands and then jumping back to the starting position. Repeat for rounds or for time.

Title: Dumbbell bent-over row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell bent-over row, start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and a dumbbell in each hand. Bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground, keeping your back straight. With your arms extended down, pull the dumbbells towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Middle Back Shrug
Desc: The Middle Back Shrug is an exercise that targets the upper and middle trapezius muscles. To perform this exercise, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your arms straight and shrug your shoulders up towards your ears, then lower them back down. This movement helps improve posture and upper back strength.
HowTo: To perform the Middle Back Shrug, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your arms straight and shrug your shoulders up towards your ears. Hold the contraction for a moment, then lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell pull-over to skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell pull-over to skullcrusher is a complex that combines two popular exercises into one sequence that works much of the upper body, particularly the chest, triceps, and serratus anterior muscles. Because the pull-over will determine the amount of weight you can use, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell pull-over to skullcrusher, start by lying on a bench with a dumbbell held in both hands above your chest. For the pull-over, lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping your arms slightly bent, feeling the stretch in your chest. Return to the starting position. Then, transition to the skullcrusher by lowering the dumbbell towards your forehead by bending your elbows, and then extending your arms back to the starting position. Repeat the sequence for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Single-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Single-Arm Dumbbell Row is an effective exercise for targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats. To perform this exercise, place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the floor. Hold a dumbbell in the free hand, and pull it towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat.
HowTo: To perform the Dumbbell Fix Single-Arm Dumbbell Row, place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the opposite foot on the floor. Hold a dumbbell in the free hand, keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body. Squeeze your back muscles at the top of the movement, then lower the dumbbell back down. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching sides.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The Dumbbell Fix Bent-Over Dumbbell Row is a compound exercise that works the back, biceps, and shoulders. To perform this exercise, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms extended down. Pull the dumbbells towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.
HowTo: To perform the Dumbbell Fix Bent-Over Dumbbell Row, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and bend at the hips until your torso is nearly parallel to the ground. Hold a dumbbell in each hand with your arms extended down. Pull the dumbbells towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Seal Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The dumbbell seal row is a weighted exercise targeting the muscles of the middle back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi) and rhomboids. It can be performed on a special elevated bench, on a bench placed on top of boxes or benches, or on a bench with a slight incline. The higher the bench, the greater the range of motion and stretch at the bottom of the movement. It is usually performed as an assistance movement for back strength and muscle growth, in rep ranges of 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: To perform the Dumbbell Seal Row - Gethin Variation, lie face down on an elevated bench with your arms hanging straight down, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your feet on the ground for stability. Pull the dumbbells up towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower the dumbbells back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Decline dumbbell chest fly
Desc: The decline dumbbell chest fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the chest, particularly the lower chest. It will require less weight than a decline press, which makes it a great hypertrophy exercise with high reps. Fly variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: To perform the decline dumbbell chest fly, lie on a decline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. With a slight bend in your elbows, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a wide arc until you feel a stretch in your chest. Bring the dumbbells back together above your chest, squeezing your chest muscles at the top. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The dumbbell bent-over row is a popular exercise to develop and strengthen the muscles of the upper and middle back, like the latissimus (lat), lower trapezius, and rear deltoids. It can work equally well in strength, muscle-building, or circuit-style fat-loss workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Lower Trapezius, Rear Deltoids
HowTo: To perform the bent-over dumbbell row, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight, and let the dumbbells hang at arm's length. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower rib cage, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower them back down.

Title: HM Alternating Bent-Over Quick Row
Desc: The HM Alternating Bent-Over Quick Row is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and biceps. To perform this exercise, hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight, and alternate rowing the dumbbells towards your torso.
HowTo: To perform the alternating bent-over quick row, hinge at the hips with a straight back, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Alternate rowing the dumbbells towards your torso, keeping your elbows close to your body and your core engaged.

Title: HM Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The HM Bent-Over Dumbbell Row is designed to strengthen the back muscles, particularly the lats and rhomboids. Bend at the hips with a slight bend in the knees, and pull the dumbbells towards your waist while keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: To perform the bent-over dumbbell row, bend at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, keeping your back flat. Hold the dumbbells with your palms facing each other and pull them towards your waist, keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: AM Single Arm Row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm row, place one knee and hand on a bench for support, keeping your back flat. With the other hand, hold a dumbbell and pull it towards your waist, squeezing your back muscles at the top of the movement.

Title: Dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift
Desc: The dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift is a dumbbell exercise that targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, and core. The difference between a stiff-legged deadlift and a Romanian deadlift is primarily the amount of knee bend. The knees are only slightly bent in a stiff-legged deadlift, while they bend more in a Romanian deadlift. Stiff-legged deadlifts are generally performed for low to moderate reps, such as 8-10 reps per set, with a focus on maximizing the hamstring stretch rather than moving heavy weight. Feel free to wear a weight belt to protect your lower back.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell stiff-legged deadlift, stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs. With a slight bend in your knees, hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells down your legs while keeping your back straight. Focus on stretching your hamstrings as you lower the weights, then return to standing.

Title: Single-arm bench dumbbell row
Desc: The single-arm bench dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. The bench is used for support during the rowing motion.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm bench dumbbell row, place one knee and hand on a bench for support. With the other hand, hold a dumbbell and pull it towards your waist, keeping your elbow close to your body and your back flat.

Title: UN Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The UN Bent-Over Dumbbell Row focuses on building back strength and improving posture. Bend forward at the hips, maintaining a flat back, and pull the dumbbells towards your lower rib cage.
HowTo: To perform the bent-over dumbbell row, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, bend forward at the hips while maintaining a flat back. Pull the dumbbells towards your lower rib cage, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.

Title: UN Dumbbell RDL
Desc: The UN Dumbbell RDL (Romanian Deadlift) is a great exercise for developing hamstring and glute strength. Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold the dumbbells in front of your thighs, and hinge at the hips to lower the weights while keeping your back straight.
HowTo: To perform the dumbbell Romanian deadlift, stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding the dumbbells in front of your thighs. Hinge at the hips to lower the weights while keeping your back straight and your knees slightly bent. Return to standing by driving your hips forward.

Title: UN Chest Supported Row
Desc: The UN Chest Supported Row is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. It is performed by lying face down on a bench with your chest supported and pulling weights towards your body, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench with your chest supported. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended towards the floor. Pull the weights towards your body, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: MetaBurn Bent-Over Renegade Row
Desc: The MetaBurn Bent-Over Renegade Row is a compound exercise that combines a plank position with a bent-over row. It engages the back, arms, and core, promoting strength and stability. Perform this exercise by holding a dumbbell in each hand, bending at the hips, and rowing one dumbbell at a time while maintaining a stable plank.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. Bend at the hips while keeping your back straight. Row one dumbbell at a time towards your waist, maintaining a stable plank position.

Title: 30 Back Bent-Over Dumbbell Row
Desc: The 30 Back Bent-Over Dumbbell Row is an effective exercise for targeting the upper back and lats. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips, and row the dumbbells towards your waist, keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Hinge at the hips while keeping your back straight. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and row the dumbbells towards your waist, keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: 30 Back Dumbbell Pull-Over
Desc: The 30 Back Dumbbell Pull-Over is a great exercise for targeting the lats and chest. Lie on a bench, hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest, and lower it back over your head while keeping your arms slightly bent, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a dumbbell held with both hands above your chest. Lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping your arms slightly bent. Return to the starting position by bringing the dumbbell back above your chest.

Title: 30 Back Incline Dumbbell Row
Desc: The 30 Back Incline Dumbbell Row is performed on an incline bench to target the upper back muscles. Lie face down on the bench with dumbbells in hand, and pull the weights towards your sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Pull the dumbbells towards your sides while squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower them back down.

Title: 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Row
Desc: The 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Row focuses on one side of the back at a time. Place one knee and hand on a bench for support while rowing a dumbbell with the opposite hand, pulling it towards your hip.
HowTo: Place one knee and hand on a bench for support. Hold a dumbbell in the opposite hand and row it towards your hip, keeping your elbow close to your body.

Title: 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Swing Row
Desc: The 30 Back Single-Arm Dumbbell Swing Row combines a swinging motion with a rowing action to engage the back and core. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hinge at the hips, and swing the dumbbell back before rowing it towards your waist.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Hinge at the hips and swing the dumbbell back. As you swing it forward, row the dumbbell towards your waist, engaging your back and core.

Title: T-Bar Row with Handle
Desc: The T-Bar Row with Handle is a compound exercise that targets the back muscles. Stand over the T-Bar row machine, grip the handle, and pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight and core engaged.
HowTo: Stand over the T-Bar row machine and grip the handle. Pull the weight towards your chest while keeping your back straight and your core engaged.

Title: T-Bar Row
Desc: The T-Bar Row is a strength training exercise that targets the upper back, lats, and biceps. It is performed by placing one end of a barbell in a corner or T-Bar row machine, loading the other end with weights, and pulling the bar towards your torso while keeping your back straight.
HowTo: 1. Set up a T-Bar row machine or place one end of a barbell in a corner. 2. Load weights on the free end of the barbell. 3. Stand over the bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 5. Grasp the handles or the bar with both hands. 6. Pull the bar towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 7. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Alternating sit-through with crunch
Desc: The alternating sit-through with crunch is a full-body movement that starts in a bear crawl position and ends with a leg kicked out to the side. In between reps, you perform a crunch. It is commonly performed for reps or time in bodyweight circuits and animal-style flows, but can also work on its own or as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility sequence.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. 2. Lift your right hand and left foot off the ground, extending your left leg out to the side. 3. As you do this, perform a crunch by bringing your right knee towards your chest. 4. Return to the starting position and switch sides, lifting your left hand and right foot while crunching your left knee towards your chest. 5. Continue alternating for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at a cable machine with your feet on the platform and knees slightly bent. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your arms extended. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position, extending your arms fully. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Upside-down pull-up
Desc: The upside-down pull-up is an advanced bodyweight exercise that is normally performed on a pair of gymnastic rings. It involves pulling the body toward the ceiling in an inverted position. It targets the same muscles as traditional pull-ups, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), biceps, and core. However, the pulling angle is more akin to a bent-over row or upright row, depending on the angle of your hips.
HowTo: 1. Set up gymnastic rings at a height that allows you to hang with your body straight. 2. Grip the rings with your palms facing each other. 3. Engage your core and pull your body upward towards the rings, keeping your elbows close to your sides. 4. Maintain an inverted position, with your body straight and hips elevated. 5. Lower your body back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Smith machine inverted row
Desc: The Smith machine inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Upper Back, Biceps
HowTo: 1. Set the bar of the Smith machine to a height that allows you to hang underneath it. 2. Lie underneath the bar and grasp it with an overhand grip, hands shoulder-width apart. 3. Keep your body straight and your heels on the ground. 4. Pull your chest towards the bar by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying T-Bar Row
Desc: The Lying T-Bar Row is an effective exercise for building back strength and muscle. It involves lying face down on a bench with a T-Bar row setup, pulling the bar towards your chest while maintaining a neutral spine. This variation emphasizes the lats and upper back.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on a bench with a T-Bar row setup. 2. Grasp the handles or bar with both hands, keeping your arms extended. 3. Pull the bar towards your chest while maintaining a neutral spine. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Suspended row
Desc: The suspended row is a bodyweight pulling exercise that focuses on the muscles of the middle and upper back, as well as the biceps. It can be trained in traditional muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps. It can also work as part of a dynamic warm-up for a pressing or pulling-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set up a suspension trainer or find a sturdy bar at waist height. 2. Grab the handles or bar with an overhand grip, leaning back with your body straight. 3. Pull your chest towards the handles or bar by bending your elbows and squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Keep your body straight throughout the movement. 5. Lower yourself back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Inverted Row with Straps
Desc: The Inverted Row with Straps is a bodyweight exercise that targets the back, biceps, and core. It is performed by hanging from suspension straps or a bar, with your body in a straight line, and pulling your chest towards the straps or bar while keeping your heels on the ground.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the straps of the suspension trainer to a suitable height. 2. Hang from the straps with your body in a straight line, heels on the ground. 3. Pull your chest towards the straps by bending your elbows and engaging your back muscles. 4. Keep your body straight and core engaged throughout the movement. 5. Lower yourself back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: One Arm Chin-Up
Desc: The One Arm Chin-Up is an advanced bodyweight exercise that targets the upper body, particularly the back, biceps, and shoulders. It requires significant strength and control, as the individual pulls their body up using one arm while the other arm is kept at their side.
HowTo: To perform the One Arm Chin-Up, start by hanging from a pull-up bar with one hand while the other arm remains at your side. Engage your core and pull your body upward using the strength of the arm that is gripping the bar. Aim to bring your chin above the bar, then lower yourself back down in a controlled manner. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Sled Row
Desc: The Sled Row is a strength training exercise that involves pulling a weighted sled towards the body using a rowing motion. It primarily targets the back muscles, including the lats and rhomboids, while also engaging the arms and core for stability.
HowTo: To execute the Sled Row, stand facing the sled with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to grab the handles of the sled. Keeping your back straight, pull the sled towards your body using a rowing motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter T-Bar Row
Desc: The Paul Carter T-Bar Row is a variation of the T-Bar Row exercise, designed to build thickness in the back. It involves using a T-Bar row machine or a barbell with a landmine attachment, focusing on pulling the weight towards the torso while maintaining a strong back posture.
HowTo: To perform the Paul Carter T-Bar Row, position yourself at a T-Bar row machine or set up a barbell with a landmine attachment. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and bend your knees slightly. Grip the handles or bar with both hands, keeping your back straight. Pull the weight towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner and repeat.

Title: Single-Arm Bent-Over Rear Delt Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The 30 Back Plate Hyperextension is an exercise that targets the lower back, glutes, and hamstrings. It involves lying face down on a hyperextension bench and lifting the upper body while holding a weight plate, promoting strength and endurance in the posterior chain.
HowTo: To do the Single-Arm Bent-Over Rear Delt Raise - Gethin Variation, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a dumbbell in one hand. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back flat. With your free hand resting on your knee for support, raise the dumbbell out to the side, focusing on contracting your rear deltoid. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: 30 Back Plate Hyperextension
HowTo: To perform the 30 Back Plate Hyperextension, lie face down on a hyperextension bench with your hips at the edge. Hold a weight plate against your chest or with both hands extended in front of you. Lower your upper body towards the ground while keeping your back straight, then lift your torso back up until your body is in a straight line. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: To execute Seated Cable Rows, sit at a cable row machine with your feet placed against the footrest. Grab the handle with both hands and sit up straight. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable seated row
Desc: The single-arm cable seated row is a version of the cable row movement that trains the muscles of the upper back one side at a time. It targets a wide range of muscles including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The single-arm row can work well in a variety of rep ranges but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: To perform the Single-arm cable seated row, sit at a cable row machine and adjust the pulley to a low position. Grab the handle with one hand and sit up straight. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your elbow close to your body, focusing on engaging your upper back muscles. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: Paul Carter Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The lat pull-down is a cable-based exercise machine that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. This back builder is easy to learn and highly effective, allowing for variable resistance depending on where you place the pin in the stack.
HowTo: To execute the Paul Carter Lat Pull-Down, sit at a lat pull-down machine and adjust the knee pad to secure your legs. Grasp the bar with a wide grip, palms facing away from you. Pull the bar down towards your chest while leaning back slightly, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat.

Title: TBS Lat Pull-Down
Desc: The TBS Lat Pull-Down is an exercise targeting the latissimus dorsi muscles in the back. It involves pulling a bar down towards your chest while seated, using a cable machine. This exercise helps improve upper body strength and is essential for developing a V-shaped torso.
HowTo: 1. Sit down at the cable machine and adjust the seat height if necessary. 2. Grasp the bar with a wide grip, palms facing away from you. 3. Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows pointed down and back. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return the bar to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: One-Arm Cable Read Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear deltoids. It is a great way to isolate this area of the shoulder and attack each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. 2. Grasp the handle with one hand and bend forward at the hips. 3. With your back straight, pull the cable out and up, focusing on squeezing your rear deltoid. 4. Return to the starting position with control. 5. Complete the desired number of reps before switching sides.

Title: UP Seated Cable Row
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: 1. Sit at the cable row machine with your feet placed on the footrest. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the handle towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Hold for a moment at the peak contraction, then slowly extend your arms back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UP Cable Straight-Arm Pull-Down
Desc: The straight-arm rope pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine and a rope grip. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent-over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, like 8-15 reps or above.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Trapezius, Core, Triceps
HowTo: 1. Stand facing the cable machine with the rope attachment set at a high position. 2. Grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. With a slight bend in your knees, lean slightly forward. 4. Pull the rope down and apart, keeping your arms straight, until your hands are at hip level. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UN Cable Pull-Through
Desc: The UN Cable Pull-Through is an exercise that primarily targets the glutes and hamstrings. It involves standing facing away from a cable machine, bending at the hips, and pulling the cable through your legs while keeping your back straight. This movement helps enhance hip hinge mechanics and posterior chain strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand facing away from the cable machine and attach the cable to the lowest setting. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands between your legs. 3. Hinge at your hips, keeping your back straight, and pull the cable through your legs. 4. Squeeze your glutes as you stand back up, pulling the cable through. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Back Close-Grip Seated Cable Row
Desc: The 30 Back Close-Grip Seated Cable Row is an exercise that focuses on the middle back, biceps, and forearms. While seated, you pull a cable handle towards your torso with a close grip, squeezing your shoulder blades together. This exercise is great for building back thickness and improving posture.
HowTo: 1. Sit at the cable row machine with your feet on the footrest and grasp the close-grip handle. 2. Keep your back straight and pull the handle towards your torso, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Hold briefly at the peak of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Back Incline Face-Up Cable Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Incline Face-Up Cable Pull-Down is an exercise that targets the upper back and rear deltoids. Lying face-up on an incline bench, you pull a cable bar down towards your face, engaging the upper back muscles. This variation helps improve shoulder stability and upper back strength.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a low angle and lie face-up on it. 2. Grasp the cable bar with both hands, positioned above your head. 3. Pull the cable bar down towards your face while engaging your upper back muscles. 4. Squeeze at the bottom of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Back Kneeling High Cable Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Kneeling High Cable Pull-Down is an exercise that works the upper back and lats. Kneeling in front of a cable machine, you pull the cable down from a high position towards your chest. This movement emphasizes the lats and helps improve overall back strength.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of the cable machine with the pulley set at a high position. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands. 3. Pull the cable down towards your chest while keeping your elbows pointed down. 4. Squeeze your lats at the bottom of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Back Leaning V-Bar Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Leaning V-Bar Pull-Down targets the upper back and biceps. Perform this exercise by leaning back slightly while pulling the V-bar down towards your chest, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Sit at the pull-down machine and grasp the V-bar with both hands. Lean back slightly and pull the V-bar down towards your chest while focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Down is effective for targeting the lower lats and biceps. Use an underhand grip on the bar and pull it down towards your upper chest while keeping your elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Sit at the pull-down machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip. Pull the bar down towards your upper chest while keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: 30 Back Standing Low Cable Bar Row
Desc: The 30 Back Standing Low Cable Bar Row engages the middle back and rear deltoids. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, pull the bar towards your torso while keeping your back straight and squeezing your shoulder blades.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the cable bar. Pull the bar towards your torso while keeping your back straight and squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: 30 Back Standing Low Cable Rope Row
Desc: The 30 Back Standing Low Cable Rope Row focuses on the upper and middle back. Use a rope attachment, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, and pull the rope towards your chest while keeping your elbows high.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and use a rope attachment. Pull the rope towards your chest while keeping your elbows high and engaging your upper and middle back.

Title: 30 Back Straight-Arm Bar Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Straight-Arm Bar Pull-Down primarily targets the lats. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grasp the bar with both hands, and pull it down in front of you with straight arms, engaging your back muscles.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the bar with both hands. Pull the bar down in front of you with straight arms, focusing on engaging your lats throughout the movement.

Title: 30 Back Straight-Arm Rope Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Straight-Arm Rope Pull-Down is great for isolating the lats. Use a rope attachment, pull the rope down while keeping your arms straight, and focus on engaging your back throughout the movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and use a rope attachment. Pull the rope down while keeping your arms straight, focusing on engaging your lats throughout the movement.

Title: 30 Back Wide-Grip Behind-The-Head Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Wide-Grip Behind-The-Head Pull-Down targets the upper lats and shoulders. Grasp the bar with a wide grip and pull it down behind your head, ensuring to keep your back straight and core engaged.
HowTo: Sit at the pull-down machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. Pull the bar down behind your head while keeping your back straight and core engaged.

Title: 30 Back Wide-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Wide-Grip Pull-Down is effective for building width in the back. With a wide grip on the bar, pull it down towards your chest, focusing on using your back muscles rather than your arms.
HowTo: Sit at the pull-down machine and grasp the bar with a wide grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest, focusing on using your back muscles rather than your arms.

Title: 30 back Wide-Grip Seated Cable Row
Desc: The 30 back wide-grip seated cable row is an exercise that targets the upper back, specifically the latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, and trapezius muscles. It involves sitting at a cable machine with a wide grip handle, pulling the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight and elbows close to your body.
HowTo: Sit at the cable machine with your feet planted firmly on the platform. Grasp the wide grip handle with both hands, keeping your arms extended. Pull the handle towards your torso while squeezing your shoulder blades together, keeping your back straight and elbows close to your body. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rower
Desc: The rower is a popular gym machine that is serious cardiovascular work, but also targets the legs, back, and arm muscles. It's a great way build overall aerobic and muscular fitness. It is popular in CrossFit-style workouts, but is also a staple in all types of gyms. It can be equally effective for HIIT-style interval workouts or for longer-duration endurance work.
HowTo: Sit on the rower with your feet secured in the foot straps. Grasp the handle with both hands and begin by pushing with your legs while leaning back slightly. Pull the handle towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. Extend your arms and lean forward to return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated Cable Rows
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep-ranges, but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Trapezius, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: Sit at the cable machine with your feet planted on the footrest. Grasp the handle with both hands, keeping your arms extended. Pull the handle towards your torso while keeping your back straight and squeezing your shoulder blades together. Control the return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith machine bent-over row
Desc: The Smith machine bent-over row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the back, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi). This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand in front of the Smith machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grasp the bar with an overhand grip, hinge at your hips, and bend your knees slightly. Pull the bar towards your torso while keeping your elbows close to your body. Lower the bar back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Leverage High Row
Desc: The machine high row is an exercise targeting the lats and works the back overall.
HowTo: Sit at the leverage high row machine with your feet on the footrests. Grasp the handles with both hands and pull them towards your torso while keeping your back straight. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Machine Low Row
Desc: The machine low row is an exercise targeting the back muscles.
HowTo: Sit at the machine low row with your feet on the footrests. Grasp the handles with both hands and pull them towards your abdomen while keeping your back straight. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Standing lat pull-down
Desc: The standing lat pull-down is a variation of the lat pull-down performed standing next to a cable stack rather than sitting on a bench or machine. It has all of the same benefits of a lat pull-down performed on a bench or machine, in addition to providing further activation to the core and lower body. If you are too tall to perform this movement, a kneeling lat pull-down provides all of the same benefits.
HowTo: Stand next to the cable stack with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grasp the lat pull-down bar with an overhand grip. Pull the bar down towards your chest while engaging your core and keeping your back straight. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Back Machine Seated Row
Desc: The 30 back machine seated row is an exercise designed to strengthen the back muscles, particularly the lats and rhomboids. It is performed on a seated row machine where you pull the handles towards your body while keeping your back straight and engaging your core.
HowTo: Sit on the seated row machine with your feet on the footrests. Grasp the handles with both hands and pull them towards your torso while keeping your back straight and engaging your core. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Back Smith Machine Push-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Smith Machine Push-Up is a variation of the push-up that utilizes the Smith machine for added stability and support. This exercise targets the chest, shoulders, and triceps while also engaging the core.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. Position yourself under the bar, gripping it with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower your body into a push-up by bending your elbows, keeping your body straight. Push back up to the starting position, engaging your chest, shoulders, and triceps.

Title: Mixed Grip Chin
Desc: The Mixed Grip Chin is a pull-up variation where one hand is in an underhand grip and the other in an overhand grip. This exercise primarily targets the biceps and back muscles, promoting strength and muscle balance.
HowTo: Grab the pull-up bar with one hand in an underhand grip and the other in an overhand grip. Hang with your arms fully extended. Pull yourself up until your chin is above the bar, engaging your biceps and back muscles. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rhomboids SMR
Desc: Rhomboids self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the upper body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the rhomboid muscles of the mid back, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight area to relax or "release." Rhomboids SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the lats, or by stretches that target the rhomboids or lats.
HowTo: Sit or lie on the floor with a foam roller or lacrosse ball positioned under your mid-back, targeting the rhomboids. Slowly roll back and forth, applying pressure to the tight areas. Hold on particularly tender spots for 20-30 seconds to help release tension.

Title: Spinal Stretch
Desc: The Spinal Stretch is a gentle exercise aimed at increasing flexibility in the spine. It involves twisting movements that help to relieve tension in the back and improve overall spinal health.
HowTo: Sit or stand with your back straight. Gently twist your torso to one side, keeping your hips facing forward. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the center and repeat on the other side. Focus on breathing deeply to enhance the stretch.

Title: Upper Back Stretch
Desc: The Upper Back Stretch is designed to release tension in the upper back and shoulders. This stretch can be performed by reaching the arms overhead and leaning to one side, promoting flexibility and relaxation.
HowTo: Stand or sit comfortably. Reach your arms overhead and lean to one side, feeling the stretch along the upper back and shoulders. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the center and repeat on the other side.

Title: Middle Back Stretch
Desc: The Middle Back Stretch focuses on elongating the muscles in the mid-back region. This stretch can be performed by reaching forward while seated or standing, helping to alleviate tightness and improve posture.
HowTo: Sit or stand with your back straight. Extend your arms forward at shoulder height and round your upper back, reaching forward as far as comfortable. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then relax and repeat.

Title: TBS Pull-Up
Desc: The TBS Pull-Up is a variation of the traditional pull-up that emphasizes the upper back and biceps. It can be performed with a wide grip to target the lats more effectively.
HowTo: Grab the pull-up bar with a wide grip. Hang with your arms fully extended. Pull yourself up, focusing on engaging your upper back and biceps. Lower yourself back down to the starting position and repeat.

Title: HM Angel Stretch
Desc: The HM Angel Stretch is a shoulder and chest opener that involves lying on your back with arms extended out to the sides. This stretch helps to improve shoulder mobility and relieve tightness.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides at shoulder height. Keep your palms facing up. Relax and breathe deeply, allowing your shoulders to sink into the ground, feeling the stretch across your chest and shoulders.

Title: UNS Foam Roll Upper Back
Desc: The UNS Foam Roll Upper Back exercise involves using a foam roller to release tension in the upper back muscles. Lie on your back with the foam roller positioned under your upper back. Gently roll back and forth to massage the muscles, focusing on tight areas.
HowTo: Lie on your back with the foam roller positioned under your upper back. Gently roll back and forth to massage the muscles, focusing on tight areas.

Title: 30 Back Neutral-Grip Pull-Down
Desc: The 30 Back Neutral-Grip Pull-Down exercise targets the upper back and biceps. Sit at a pull-down machine with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then slowly return to the starting position.
HowTo: Sit at a pull-down machine with a neutral grip (palms facing each other). Pull the bar down towards your chest while keeping your elbows close to your body, then slowly return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Back Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Pull-Up exercise is a bodyweight movement that strengthens the upper back and arms. Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip, pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down with control.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down with control.

Title: 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Up
Desc: The 30 Back Reverse-Grip Pull-Up exercise focuses on the upper back and biceps using an underhand grip. Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip, pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down with control.
HowTo: Hang from a pull-up bar with an underhand grip. Pull your body up until your chin is above the bar, then lower yourself back down with control.

Title: ACFT Medicine ball overhead power throw
Desc: The medicine ball overhead power throw is an explosive exercise targeting the abdominals and hips. This specific exercise is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. It can be performed for lower reps with a focus on power or for higher reps with a focus on fat loss and conditioning. It begins in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball, which then gets "scooped" up and thrown overhead in one continuous movement.
HowTo: Begin in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball. Scoop the ball up and throw it overhead in one continuous explosive movement.

Title: Upright Row - With Bands
Desc: The Upright Row - With Bands exercise targets the shoulders and upper back. Stand on a resistance band with both feet, holding the band with both hands. Pull the band upwards towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists, then lower back down.
HowTo: Stand on a resistance band with both feet, holding the band with both hands. Pull the band upwards towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists, then lower back down.

Title: Band seated row
Desc: The band seated row is a band alternative to the popular cable exercise and trains the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The band row can work well in a variety of rep ranges, requiring a heavier band for muscle-building and strength workouts and a lighter band for weight-loss work and as an accessory movement.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Trapezius, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended. Secure a resistance band around your feet and hold the ends with both hands. Pull the band towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together, then return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell shrug
Desc: The barbell shrug is an exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body training, and is often trained on a shoulder day. With the assistance of straps, it can be loaded heavily, but it is still usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. Lift the barbell by shrugging your shoulders upwards, keeping your arms straight, then lower back down.

Title: Barbell behind-the-back shrug
Desc: The barbell behind-the-back shrug is an exercise targeting the traps. Having the bar behind you helps keep your shoulders pulled up and back, rather than rounded forward. It is popular in strength and muscle-focused upper-body training, and is often trained on a shoulder day. With the assistance of straps, it can be loaded heavily, but it is still usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-10 reps per set.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell behind your back. Keep your arms straight and your shoulders back. Lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing your traps at the top of the movement. Lower back down and repeat for 8-10 reps.

Title: Clean Shrug
Desc: The Clean Shrug is an exercise that targets the upper trapezius and helps improve shoulder stability. It involves lifting the shoulders towards the ears while maintaining a strong core and proper posture.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells at your sides. Keep your core engaged and your back straight. Lift your shoulders towards your ears while maintaining proper posture. Lower back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Snatch Shrug
Desc: The Snatch Shrug is a variation of the shrug that focuses on the upper trapezius and is often performed as part of Olympic weightlifting training. It involves shrugging the shoulders while holding a barbell in a snatch grip, emphasizing explosive upward movement.
HowTo: Set up with a barbell in a snatch grip. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Shrug your shoulders explosively towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. Focus on generating upward movement through your traps. Lower back down and repeat for 6-10 reps.

Title: Single-arm inverted row
Desc: The single-arm inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row.
HowTo: Set the bar of the Smith machine at a height that allows you to hang underneath it. Grab the bar with one hand, keeping your body straight. Pull your chest towards the bar while squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull
Desc: The kettlebell sumo deadlift high pull is a dynamic kettlebell exercise that focuses on the muscles of the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, traps, rear delts, and upper back. It can be done in lower reps for power or strength, or higher reps for conditioning and fat loss. It can also be a component of a circuit-style kettlebell workout, either for time or reps.
Muscles: Hamstrings, Glutes, Trapezius, Rear Deltoids, Upper Back
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. Squat down and grab the kettlebell with both hands. Stand up while pulling the kettlebell up towards your chin, keeping your elbows high. Lower back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing dumbbell shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It's often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Keep your arms straight and your shoulders back. Lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing your traps at the top. Lower back down and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Standing dumbbell upright row
Desc: The standing dumbbell upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding dumbbells in each hand at your thighs. Pull the dumbbells up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body and your elbows higher than your wrists. Lower back down and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell pull-over
Desc: The dumbbell pull-over is a popular muscle and strength-building exercise that targets the muscles of the chest, upper back, lats, and the serratus anterior. It was a favorite of old-school bodybuilders, who believed high-rep pull-overs helped build a V-taper shape in the torso.
Muscles: Chest, Upper Back, Latissimus Dorsi, Serratus Anterior
HowTo: Lie on a bench with your upper back supported and hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. Lower the dumbbell back over your head in a controlled manner, feeling the stretch in your lats. Pull the dumbbell back to the starting position above your chest. Repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Shrug - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It’s a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell row is a popular exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. It is most often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per arm or more, as part of a muscle-building upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Place one knee and hand on a bench for support, with the other foot on the ground. Hold a dumbbell in the free hand, arm extended towards the floor. Pull the dumbbell towards your hip while keeping your elbow close to your body. Squeeze your back muscles at the top of the movement, then lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: Lying Face Down Plate Neck Resistance
Desc: This exercise involves lying face down while holding a plate against the back of your head. It targets the neck muscles by providing resistance as you lift your head upwards.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench or mat with a weight plate held against the back of your head. Keep your body flat and your neck in a neutral position. Slowly lift your head upwards against the resistance of the plate, engaging your neck muscles. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your head back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying Face Up Plate Neck Resistance
Desc: In this exercise, you lie face up with a plate held against your forehead. This movement works the neck muscles by resisting the downward force as you lift your head.
HowTo: Lie face up on a bench or mat with a weight plate held against your forehead. Keep your body flat and your neck in a neutral position. Slowly lift your head upwards against the resistance of the plate, engaging your neck muscles. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your head back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated Head Harness Neck Resistance
Desc: The seated head harness neck resistance exercise involves wearing a head harness attached to weights. While seated, you perform neck flexion and extension movements to strengthen the neck muscles.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a head harness attached to weights. Keep your back straight and your feet flat on the ground. Perform neck flexion by lowering your head forward against the resistance, then return to the starting position. Next, perform neck extension by lifting your head back against the resistance. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cable straight-bar upright row
Desc: The cable straight-bar upright row is an isolation exercise for the traps and the medial deltoids. It may not be appropriate for all lifters depending on their shoulder health and injury history. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand upright holding a straight bar attached to a cable at waist height. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart. Pull the bar straight up towards your chin, keeping your elbows high and close to your body. Squeeze your traps at the top of the movement, then lower the bar back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cable shrug
Desc: The cable shrug is an exercise targeting the traps, as well as hitting the shoulders and upper back. Cables allow for lighter loading which is beneficial for higher-rep sets.
HowTo: Stand upright facing the cable machine with the cable set at the lowest position. Hold the cable handle in each hand with your arms at your sides. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine shrug
Desc: The Smith machine shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: Stand with your back against the Smith machine bar, which should be resting on your shoulders. Grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Raise your shoulders towards your ears while keeping your arms straight. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Leverage Shrug
Desc: The Leverage Shrug is an exercise targeting the upper trapezius muscles, performed using a leverage machine to enhance shoulder elevation and strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the leverage machine so that your shoulders are aligned with the machine's pads. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the handles. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Elevate your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing the traps at the top of the movement. 5. Slowly lower your shoulders back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug
Desc: The Calf-Machine Shoulder Shrug is an exercise that utilizes a calf machine to perform shoulder shrugs, focusing on the upper traps and improving shoulder stability.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the calf machine to a comfortable height and load the desired weight. 2. Stand facing the machine with your feet shoulder-width apart and place your shoulders under the pads. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Lift your shoulders towards your ears, focusing on contracting the upper traps. 5. Lower your shoulders back down in a controlled manner. 6. Perform for the recommended reps.

Title: Smith machine behind-the-back shrug
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-back shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height and load the desired weight. 2. Stand with your back to the bar and grasp it with both hands, positioning it behind your back. 3. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart and your core engaged. 4. Raise your shoulders towards your ears, focusing on the contraction of the traps. 5. Lower your shoulders back down slowly. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Smith machine upright row
Desc: The Smith machine upright row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the traps and shoulders. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height and load the desired weight. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the bar with an overhand grip. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Pull the bar upwards towards your chin, keeping your elbows high and squeezing your traps. 5. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. 6. Perform for 8-12 reps.

Title: Machine low row-
Desc: The machine low row is a popular exercise targeting the back muscles, particularly the lats (latissimus dorsi), rhomboids, and middle and lower trapezius. Machine row variations are often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or back-focused portion of a workout.
Muscles: Latissimus Dorsi, Rhomboids, Middle and Lower Trapezius
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height and load the desired weight. 2. Sit down with your feet flat on the ground and grasp the handles. 3. Keep your back straight and engage your core. 4. Pull the handles towards your torso, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Machine Shrug - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Shrug - Gethin Variation is a specific variation of the shrug exercise performed on a machine, emphasizing the upper traps and designed to build muscle mass in the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height and load the desired weight. 2. Sit down with your back against the pad and grasp the handles. 3. Keep your feet flat on the ground and your back straight. 4. Elevate your shoulders towards your ears, focusing on the contraction of the upper traps. 5. Lower your shoulders back down slowly. 6. Perform for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine single-arm shrug
Desc: The Smith machine single-arm shrug is an upper-body exercise targeting the traps (trapezius muscles). It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of shoulder or trap-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height and load the desired weight. 2. Stand next to the bar and grasp it with one hand. 3. Keep your feet shoulder-width apart and your core engaged. 4. Raise your shoulder towards your ear, focusing on the contraction of the traps. 5. Lower your shoulder back down slowly. 6. Perform for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Isometric Neck Exercise - Sides
Desc: The Isometric Neck Exercise - Sides involves holding a position to strengthen the neck muscles laterally, enhancing stability and support for the cervical spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand in a comfortable position with your back straight. 2. Place your hand on the side of your head to provide resistance. 3. Tilt your head towards your shoulder, holding the position for a few seconds. 4. Return to the starting position and repeat on the other side. 5. Perform for the desired number of reps on each side.

Title: Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back
Desc: The Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back involves holding a position to strengthen the neck muscles by pushing the head against resistance in both forward and backward directions.
