HowTo: To perform the Isometric Neck Exercise - Front And Back, sit or stand upright. Push your forehead against your hands or a wall for 10-15 seconds, engaging your neck muscles. Then, place your hands behind your head and push backward against resistance for another 10-15 seconds. Repeat for 3-5 sets.

Title: Neck Bridge Prone
Desc: The Neck Bridge Prone is an exercise performed lying face down that strengthens the neck and upper back by lifting the head and shoulders off the ground while maintaining a bridge position.
HowTo: To perform the Neck Bridge Prone, lie face down on a mat. Lift your head and shoulders off the ground while keeping your feet and hips in contact with the floor. Hold this position for a few seconds, then lower back down. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Side Neck Stretch
Desc: The Side Neck Stretch is a gentle stretch that targets the muscles on the sides of the neck, helping to improve flexibility and relieve tension.
HowTo: To perform the Side Neck Stretch, sit or stand upright. Gently tilt your head to one side, bringing your ear towards your shoulder. Hold for 15-30 seconds, feeling the stretch on the opposite side of your neck. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Neck-SMR
Desc: Neck-SMR (Self-Myofascial Release) involves using a foam roller or similar tool to apply pressure to the neck muscles, promoting relaxation and reducing tightness.
HowTo: To perform Neck-SMR, lie on your back with a foam roller under your neck. Slowly roll your head side to side and up and down, applying pressure to tight areas. Spend 1-2 minutes on each side to promote relaxation.

Title: Scapular Pull-Up
Desc: The Scapular Pull-Up is an exercise that focuses on engaging the scapular muscles by performing a pull-up while emphasizing the downward movement of the shoulder blades.
HowTo: To perform the Scapular Pull-Up, hang from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Without bending your elbows, pull your shoulder blades down and together, engaging your scapular muscles. Hold for a moment, then relax. Repeat for 8-10 reps.

Title: Single-leg depth squat
Desc: The single-leg depth squat is an exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is sometimes used as a substitute for the pistol squat, since it doesn't demand the same level of flexibility to perform. It is usually performed for low to moderate reps with a focus on proper form and control.
HowTo: To perform the single-leg depth squat, stand on one leg with the other leg extended in front of you. Lower your body into a squat position while keeping your extended leg off the ground. Go as low as you can while maintaining balance, then return to standing. Repeat for 6-10 reps on each leg.

Title: Squats - With Bands
Desc: Squats - With Bands involve performing squats while using resistance bands to increase the difficulty and engage the lower body muscles more effectively.
HowTo: To perform Squats - With Bands, place a resistance band around your thighs, just above your knees. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and squat down, keeping your knees aligned with your toes against the band's resistance. Stand back up and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Hip Flexion with Band
Desc: Hip Flexion with Band is an exercise that uses a resistance band to strengthen the hip flexors by lifting the knee towards the chest against the band's resistance.
HowTo: To perform Hip Flexion with Band, attach a resistance band to a sturdy object and loop it around your ankle. Stand tall and lift your knee towards your chest against the band's resistance. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower back down. Repeat for 10-15 reps on each leg.

Title: Forward Band Walk
Desc: The Forward Band Walk is an exercise that targets the glutes and hip muscles. It involves walking sideways while keeping a resistance band around the legs, promoting lateral movement and strength.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above the knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Step sideways, maintaining tension in the band, and keep your knees aligned with your toes. 4. Continue walking sideways for a set distance or number of steps, then return to the starting position.

Title: Boss Everline Resistance-Band Pull Sprint
Desc: The Boss Everline Resistance-Band Pull Sprint is a high-intensity exercise that combines sprinting with resistance band pulls. It enhances speed, power, and overall athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a sturdy anchor point behind you. 2. Stand facing away from the anchor, holding the band handles. 3. Assume a sprinting stance with one foot forward. 4. Sprint forward while pulling the band with you, driving your knees up and pumping your arms. 5. Repeat for a set distance or time.

Title: Banded jump squat
Desc: The banded jump squat is an explosive bodyweight squat variation performed with a band around the thighs just above the knees. This increases muscle activation in the hips and glutes, while the squat targets the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. The banded jump squat can be performed for low reps as a power-focused exercise, or for higher reps to build muscle in the lower body, challenge conditioning, and burn fat.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above the knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and lower into a squat position. 3. Explode upward into a jump, using the band for added resistance. 4. Land softly and immediately lower back into the squat position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Speed Box Squat
Desc: The banded barbell box squat is a strength and power exercise targeting the lower body. It is popular in powerlifting training, either performed with light weights as a power and speed exercise, or heavier for strength. It is usually performed to a box of a height that demands the squatter to decent to around parallel.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box at a height that allows you to squat to parallel. 2. Load a barbell on your shoulders and stand in front of the box. 3. Lower yourself into a squat, sitting back onto the box while keeping your chest up. 4. Pause briefly on the box, then drive through your heels to stand back up. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: HM Banded Squat Toe Tap
Desc: The HM Banded Squat Toe Tap is a dynamic lower body exercise that combines squats with toe taps. It engages the quads, hamstrings, and glutes while improving balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a resistance band around your thighs. 2. Lower into a squat position. 3. While in the squat, lift one foot to tap your toes on the ground in front of you, alternating sides. 4. Maintain tension in the band and keep your chest up. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UP Band Abducted Squat
Desc: The UP Band Abducted Squat is a lower body exercise that focuses on the glutes and outer thighs. It involves performing a squat while keeping a resistance band around the legs to add resistance and enhance muscle activation.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above the knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower into a squat while pushing your knees outward against the band. 4. Hold the squat position, then pulse up and down slightly. 5. After a set number of pulses, explode upward into a jump. 6. Land softly and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Lateral Band Walk
Desc: The FYR2 Lateral Band Walk is an exercise that targets the hip abductors and glutes. It involves walking sideways with a resistance band around the legs, promoting strength and stability in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your legs, just above the knees. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Step sideways, keeping tension in the band and your knees aligned with your toes. 4. Continue walking sideways for a set distance or number of steps, then return to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Banded Squat Hold-Pulse-Jump Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Banded Squat Hold-Pulse-Jump Complex is a comprehensive lower body workout that combines a squat hold, pulsing squats, and explosive jumps, all while using a resistance band to increase intensity and muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Place a resistance band around your thighs, just above the knees. 2. Lower into a squat position and hold. 3. Perform small pulsing movements while holding the squat. 4. After a set number of pulses, explode upward into a jump. 5. Land softly and immediately lower back into the squat position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Band split squat
Desc: The band split squat is a band movement targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed either for time or reps, and is often included as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout. Leaning back places more emphasis on the glutes and hamstrings, while standing straight up targets the quads.
HowTo: To perform the band split squat, start by placing a resistance band under your front foot and holding the other end with both hands. Step back with your other foot into a lunge position, keeping your front knee aligned over your ankle. Lower your hips until your back knee nearly touches the ground, then push through your front heel to return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band front squat
Desc: The band front squat is a popular exercise for targeting the muscles of the lower body, including the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. Holding band in the racked position also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Because the tension of the band changes as it stretches, the resistance more closely matches the natural strength curve of the squat. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing it with a wider stance.
HowTo: To perform the band front squat, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band in a racked position at shoulder height. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your chest up and core engaged. Go as low as you can while maintaining good form, then push through your heels to return to standing. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Squat hold with band pull-apart
Desc: The squat hold with band pull-apart is a combination of the squat hold and band pull-apart. It involves holding the squat position with the thighs at or below parallel to the ground while performing a band pull-apart. The band pull-apart is an exercise targeting the upper back muscles, including the trapezius, rear delts, and rhomboids. The squat hold band pull-apart can be performed for mobility purposes or to increase time under tension on lower-body muscles including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: To perform the squat hold with band pull-apart, start in a squat position with your thighs parallel to the ground. Hold a resistance band with both hands in front of you at shoulder height. While maintaining the squat position, pull the band apart by moving your hands outward, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Hold the squat and the pull-apart for the desired duration.

Title: Banded squat toe tap
Desc: The banded squat toe tap is a banded variation on the classic bodyweight squat, but with a lateral toe tap to add extra focus to the stabilizer muscles around the hips. It can be performed for time or for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for the lower body, or in any lower-body portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the banded squat toe tap, begin in a squat position with a resistance band around your thighs. From the squat, lift one foot to tap your toes to the side, then return to the squat. Alternate sides for the desired number of reps or time, focusing on maintaining stability and control.

Title: Band overhead squat
Desc: The band overhead squat is a full-body, functional movement that works to build full-body strength and stability. It is a variation of the classic barbell exercise and can be used to train core strength and stability for Olympic weightlifting or CrossFit.
HowTo: To perform the band overhead squat, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a resistance band overhead with both arms extended. Lower your body into a squat while keeping the band overhead and your core engaged. Ensure your knees track over your toes and your back remains straight. Rise back to standing while maintaining the band overhead.

Title: Quadriceps SMR
Desc: Quadriceps self-myofascial release (SMR) is a self-administered soft-tissue treatment for the lower body, usually using a foam roller, lacrosse ball, or other "trigger point" massage tool. By applying pressure strategically to the quad muscles of the upper leg, some people find they can cause this often painful and tight muscle group to relax or "release." Quadriceps SMR is often accompanied by SMR on the calf, glute, or hip muscles, or by stretches that target the calves or quads.
HowTo: To perform quadriceps SMR, sit on the floor and place a foam roller under your thighs. Use your arms to lift your body off the ground and roll back and forth over the roller, applying pressure to the quads. Focus on areas that feel tight or painful, spending extra time on those spots.

Title: Clean from Blocks
Desc: This exercise focuses on cleaning the body from a stationary position, using blocks for support and stability. It emphasizes proper alignment and controlled movements to enhance strength and flexibility.
HowTo: To perform the clean from blocks, start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell positioned on blocks at knee height. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your back straight and core engaged. In one fluid motion, pull the barbell up by extending your hips and knees, then drop under the bar to catch it in a front rack position. Stand up to finish the movement.

Title: Barbell Full Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: To perform the barbell full squat, set a barbell on your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. Go as low as you can while maintaining form, ideally until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell back squat to box
Desc: The barbell back squat to box is a popular version of a classic lower-body exercise that utilizes a box at the bottom position of the movement. This allows the lifter to customize the depth of the squat, as well as limit the stretch reflex at the bottom of the squat. The movement targets the quadriceps, glutes, and hamstrings. The squat to box can be performed for low reps to build strength or power, or for higher reps to build muscle.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box behind you at the desired height. 2. Position the barbell on your upper back, ensuring a secure grip. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Initiate the squat by bending at the hips and knees, lowering your body towards the box. 5. Keep your chest up and back straight throughout the movement. 6. Lightly touch the box with your glutes without resting. 7. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Push-press
Desc: The push-press is an overhead press variation in which the barbell is pushed upward with assistance from the lower body. This "push" helps the weight travel through the sticking point of a strict press. The push-press is commonly performed as part of barbell complexes, power training for all types of athletics, or as a powerful shoulder exercise.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the barbell at shoulder level. 2. Bend your knees slightly and dip down, using your legs to generate power. 3. As you drive up, push the barbell overhead using your arms. 4. Lock out your elbows at the top position. 5. Lower the barbell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Power snatch-
Desc: The power snatch is a full-body lift in which the bar is pulled from the floor with a wide grip to the overhead position in one movement. The bar is received in the "power" position, with the hips higher than a full-depth squat position. The power snatch can be used as a learning tool for the full snatch, or to train muscular power and strength on its own. It is usually performed for low reps, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, barbell on the floor in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the bar with a wide grip. 3. Pull the bar explosively off the ground, extending your hips and knees. 4. As the bar rises, pull yourself under it, receiving it overhead in a power position. 5. Stand up straight to complete the lift.

Title: Hang Clean
Desc: The Hang Clean is a weightlifting exercise that involves lifting a barbell from a hanging position to shoulder level in one fluid motion. It focuses on developing explosive power, strength, and technique, primarily targeting the legs, back, and shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell at thigh level. 2. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at your hips to lower the barbell to just above your knees. 3. Explode upward, extending your hips and knees while pulling the barbell to your shoulders. 4. Catch the barbell on your shoulders and stand up straight.

Title: Barbell walking lunge
Desc: The barbell walking lunge tests your ability to maintain balance while challenging the quads, glutes, and hamstrings as well as the core muscles. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise. It can be performed for moderate reps, such as 8-15 per set or across the gym, or for higher reps as a conditioning and mental toughness challenge.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell across your upper back, standing tall with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about 90 degrees. 3. Ensure your front knee stays above your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs as you walk forward.

Title: Olympic Squat
Desc: The Olympic Squat is a variation of the squat that emphasizes depth and proper form, often performed with a barbell on the shoulders. It is crucial for building leg strength, improving mobility, and enhancing overall athletic performance.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on your upper back, standing with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. 3. Lower your body as deep as possible while keeping your chest up and back straight. 4. Pause briefly at the bottom, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Narrow-stance squat
Desc: The narrow-stance squat is an exercise that targets the lower body with an emphasis on the quads. Many people will find they can't go as deep in a narrow-stance squat as with a wider squat, which is normal. The narrow-stance squat can be performed for time or reps in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet close together, barbell on your upper back. 2. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and hips, keeping your torso upright. 3. Lower your body as far as comfortable, ideally until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Box Squat with Bands
Desc: The Box Squat with Bands is a squat variation that incorporates a box and resistance bands to enhance strength and explosiveness. It helps in developing proper squat mechanics, building leg strength, and improving power output.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box behind you and attach resistance bands to the barbell. 2. Position the barbell on your upper back, standing with feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Initiate the squat by bending at the hips and knees, lowering your body towards the box. 4. Lightly touch the box with your glutes, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Weighted Jump Squat
Desc: The Weighted Jump Squat is a plyometric exercise that combines a squat with an explosive jump, using added weight to increase resistance and enhance power and strength in the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weighted barbell across your upper back. 2. Lower your body into a squat position by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 3. Once your thighs are parallel to the ground, explode upward into a jump, extending your legs fully. 4. Land softly and immediately lower back into the squat position to repeat.

Title: Squat with Chains
Desc: The Squat with Chains is a strength training exercise that involves performing a squat while using chains attached to the barbell, providing variable resistance that increases as you rise from the squat position.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your shoulders and attach chains to each side. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 4. As you rise from the squat, the chains will lift off the ground, increasing resistance. 5. Fully extend your legs at the top before descending into the next squat.

Title: Barbell Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell on your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 3. Lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. 4. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell front squat
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
HowTo: 1. Place a barbell across your front shoulders, resting on your anterior deltoids. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Keep your chest up and core engaged. 4. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your elbows high and back straight. 5. Squat down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Barbell forward lunge
Desc: The barbell forward lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The forward lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell across your upper back and stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. 2. Step forward with one leg, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Keep your back straight and your front knee over your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Smith machine box squat
Desc: The Smith machine box squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or power or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height and sit on a box or bench. 2. Position the bar across your shoulders and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and sitting back onto the box. 4. Pause briefly before pushing through your heels to return to standing. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Barbell step-up
Desc: The barbell step-up is a great exercise for building lower-body strength and power. It targets all the same muscles as bodyweight step-ups, such as the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, but allows for greater muscular overload.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a sturdy bench or platform with a barbell across your upper back. 2. Step up onto the bench with one foot, driving through your heel. 3. Bring your other foot up to meet the first on the bench. 4. Step back down one foot at a time to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Barbell Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The barbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is easier to overload with the barbell than when using dumbbells. If balance is an issue, consider using a Smith machine or holding dumbbells at your side instead.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench with a barbell across your back. 2. Place one foot on the bench behind you, resting the top of your foot on it. 3. Lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Complete the desired repetitions on one leg before switching to the other.

Title: Hang Clean - Below the Knees
Desc: The Hang Clean - Below the Knees is a weightlifting exercise that focuses on developing explosive strength and power. It involves lifting a barbell from a hanging position just below the knees to the shoulders, emphasizing proper technique and positioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell hanging just below your knees. 2. Grip the barbell with an overhand grip, keeping your arms straight. 3. Engage your core and pull the barbell up explosively, extending your hips and knees. 4. As the bar reaches your thighs, shrug your shoulders and pull yourself under the bar. 5. Catch the barbell on your shoulders in a front rack position, standing tall.

Title: Barbell hack squat
Desc: The barbell hack squat is a variety of deadlift performed with the barbell behind the legs. This forces the lifter into a body position similar to a squat and targets the quads and glutes. It is named after famed strongman George Hackenschmidt, who performed it as an overall leg-building exercise. The barbell hack squat can be used as a substitute for the machine hack squat, or as a lower-body strength and size movement on its own.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, barbell positioned behind your legs. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell with both hands. 3. Keep your chest up and back straight as you lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees. 4. Lower the barbell back down to the ground while maintaining control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Adjust the machine to ensure your knees track over your toes. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell thruster
Desc: The barbell thruster is a full-body exercise that incorporates both squatting and pressing in one functional movement. It's especially common in contemporary CrossFit workouts, but also in general strength training. The barbell is usually cleaned into place first, but it could be performed taken from a squat rack in a front-rack position. The thruster can be performed in traditional strength-focused rep ranges to build strength in the press, or in higher reps for full-body conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in a front rack position at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat, lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. As you rise from the squat, push the barbell overhead by extending your arms and legs simultaneously. 4. Lock out your arms overhead and stabilize the weight. 5. Lower the barbell back to the front rack position and repeat.

Title: Split Jerk
Desc: The Split Jerk is an Olympic weightlifting movement that involves lifting a barbell from the shoulders to overhead in a split stance. It requires coordination, balance, and strength, as the lifter pushes the barbell upward and splits their legs to stabilize the weight.
HowTo: 1. Begin with the barbell resting on your shoulders, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Dip down slightly by bending your knees and hips. 3. Explosively push the barbell overhead while simultaneously splitting your legs into a front and back stance. 4. Stabilize the weight overhead and hold the position. 5. Return to the starting position by bringing your feet back together and lowering the barbell.

Title: Push-jerk
Desc: The push-jerk is a movement in which the barbell is pushed from the front rack position to overhead with help from the legs. It differs from the push-press in that the lifter dips under the bar rather than simply pushing it up. It is popular in CrossFit workouts and Olympic weightlifting, as well as power training for athletics. It is usually performed for low reps, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in a front rack position at shoulder height. 2. Dip down slightly by bending your knees and hips. 3. Push the barbell overhead while simultaneously dipping under the bar. 4. Lock your arms out overhead and stabilize the weight. 5. Lower the barbell back to the front rack position and repeat.

Title: Barbell back squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your upper back, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Zercher squat
Desc: The Zercher squat is a barbell exercise in which the bar is placed in the crease of your elbows as you perform a normal squat. This movement can be awkward at first but is extremely effective in building both size and strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the barbell in the crease of your elbows. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your back straight and chest up. 3. Go as low as comfortable while maintaining form. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Jefferson Squats
Desc: The Jefferson Squat is a lower body exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves a unique stance where one foot is positioned forward and the other back, allowing for a deep squat while maintaining balance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot forward and the other foot back, maintaining a shoulder-width stance. 2. Hold a barbell or weight in front of you. 3. Lower your body into a squat by bending both knees, keeping your chest up and back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Jerk Dip Squat
Desc: The Jerk Dip Squat is a dynamic movement that combines a dip and a squat, primarily used in Olympic weightlifting. It helps develop explosive strength and stability in the legs and core, essential for performing the jerk lift.
HowTo: 1. Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Dip down by bending your knees and hips while keeping your chest up. 3. As you reach the bottom of the dip, transition into a squat position by lowering your hips down. 4. Drive through your heels to return to standing, engaging your core throughout.

Title: Barbell side split squat
Desc: The barbell side split squat is a variation of the split squat that targets the lower body, specifically the quads, and requires good hip mobility.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell across your back. 2. Step one foot out to the side, keeping your other foot in place. 3. Lower your body into a squat on the side with the extended leg, keeping your torso upright. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Frankenstein Squat
Desc: The Frankenstein Squat is a variation of the squat where the barbell is held in front of the shoulders with arms extended, resembling the posture of Frankenstein. This exercise emphasizes core stability and upper body strength while targeting the lower body.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your shoulders with arms extended. 2. Lower your body into a squat while keeping the barbell in place. 3. Ensure your chest stays up and your back remains straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell speed squat
Desc: The barbell speed squat targets the lower-body muscle groups using lighter weights to perform fast-paced back squats. Speed squats are popular in certain powerlifting training methodologies as a way to engrain form and lifting speed that can carry over to max-effort lifts. In this approach, they are usually performed in numerous sets of 3-5 reps with adequate rest in between. Speed squats are also sometimes performed with bands or chains adding extra resistance to the top half of the lift.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your back with lighter weights. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat quickly, ensuring proper form. 4. Explode back up to standing, focusing on speed and control. 5. Repeat for 3-5 reps, resting adequately between sets.

Title: Single-arm side deadlift
Desc: The single-arm side deadlift is a compound exercise that strengthens the glutes, quads, hamstrings, back, and core. It has more of a core stability and anti-rotational component than other deadlift variations. The side deadlift is usually done for low to moderate reps, such as 5-8 reps per side, with a focus on posture and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight in one hand. 2. Shift your weight to one side and hinge at the hips, lowering the weight towards the ground while keeping your back straight. 3. Engage your core to maintain stability. 4. Return to standing by pushing through your heel and engaging your glutes.

Title: Barbell Squat To A Bench
Desc: The barbell back squat to box takes a classic compound exercise for developing the lower body and adds the box element. Muscles worked include the quads, hips, glutes, and upper hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Set a bench or box behind you and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell on your back. 2. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Sit back onto the bench or box lightly without losing tension. 4. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Clean Pull
Desc: The Clean Pull is a weightlifting exercise that focuses on the initial phase of the clean lift. It involves pulling the barbell from the ground to the hips while maintaining a strong back and engaged core, helping to develop power and technique for the clean.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, with a barbell on the ground in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the barbell. 3. Engage your core and pull the barbell up to your hips, keeping your back straight and elbows extended. 4. Focus on driving through your heels and maintaining a strong posture throughout the movement.

Title: Front Barbell Squat To A Bench
Desc: The Front Barbell Squat To A Bench is a strength exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves squatting down to a bench while holding a barbell across the front of your shoulders, ensuring proper form and depth to maximize muscle engagement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and a barbell resting on your front shoulders, elbows high. 2. Engage your core and maintain a straight back. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight, until your thighs are parallel to the ground or you touch the bench. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell reverse lunge
Desc: The barbell reverse lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The reverse lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, holding a barbell across your upper back. 2. Step back with one leg, lowering your body until your front thigh is parallel to the ground. 3. Keep your chest up and your core engaged. 4. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Alternate legs for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Split Clean
Desc: The Split Clean is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that involves lifting a barbell from the ground to the shoulders in a split stance. It emphasizes explosive power, coordination, and technique, making it a great exercise for developing strength and athleticism.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the ground in front of you. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your feet in a split stance. 3. Explosively lift the barbell from the ground to your shoulders while simultaneously dropping into a squat. 4. Stand up from the squat, maintaining control of the barbell. 5. Return the barbell to the ground and repeat.

Title: Close-stance dumbbell front squat
Desc: The close-stance dumbbell front squat is a popular exercise for targeting the muscles of the lower body, the quadriceps in particular. Holding dumbbells in the racked position also works the core and upper-back muscles to maintain posture while the lower body moves. Because the amount of weight you can use will be limited by what you can clean to the rack position, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set or more. If this movement hurts your knees, try performing it with a wider stance.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet close together, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and maintain a straight back. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up, until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Front Squat (Clean Grip)
Desc: The Front Squat (Clean Grip) is a variation of the squat that focuses on the quadriceps and core stability. In this exercise, the barbell is held in a clean grip position across the front of the shoulders, requiring good posture and depth in the squat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the barbell in a clean grip across your front shoulders. 2. Engage your core and maintain a straight back. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, ensuring your elbows stay high. 4. Squat down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell front squat to back squat
Desc: The barbell front squat to back squat is a complex that combines two fundamental barbell squat movements with a press in between to build overall strength, coordination, and endurance. This combo hits every muscle in the lower body, but also seriously challenges the upper-body musculature to control and transition the weight.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Upper Body
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the front squat position. 2. Perform a front squat, lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Stand up and transition the barbell to the back squat position. 4. Perform a back squat, lowering your body again until your thighs are parallel. 5. Stand up to complete the complex.

Title: Squat Jerk
Desc: The Squat Jerk is an Olympic weightlifting movement that combines a squat with an overhead press. The lifter squats down while receiving the barbell overhead, emphasizing strength, balance, and coordination. It is crucial for developing explosive power and proper lifting technique.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders, standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Dip slightly by bending your knees. 3. Explosively extend your legs and press the barbell overhead as you squat down. 4. Catch the barbell overhead in a squat position. 5. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Barbell Front-To-Back Squat
Desc: The barbell front squat to back squat is a complex that combines two fundamental barbell squat movements with a press in between to build overall strength, coordination, and endurance. This combo hits every muscle in the lower body, but also seriously challenges the upper-body musculature to control and transition the weight.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes, Core, Upper Body
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the front squat position. 2. Perform a front squat, lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Stand up and transition the barbell to the back squat position. 4. Perform a back squat, lowering your body again until your thighs are parallel. 5. Stand up to complete the complex.

Title: Box Squat with Chains
Desc: The Box Squat with Chains is a variation of the squat that incorporates chains to increase resistance at the top of the movement. This exercise helps to build explosive strength and improve squat mechanics.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box behind you at an appropriate height. 2. Attach chains to the barbell to increase resistance. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. 4. Initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. 5. Lower yourself until you sit on the box, ensuring your back remains straight. 6. Pause briefly on the box, then drive through your heels to stand back up, engaging your core and glutes.

Title: Snatch from Blocks
Desc: The Snatch from Blocks is a weightlifting exercise where the barbell is lifted from a set of blocks, focusing on the initial pull and the transition to the catch position. This variation helps to improve technique and power.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, gripping the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Engage your core and pull the barbell off the blocks, focusing on a strong initial pull. 4. As the barbell passes your knees, transition into a powerful extension, driving through your legs and hips. 5. Quickly drop under the bar into the catch position, stabilizing it overhead.

Title: Power Snatch from Blocks
Desc: The Power Snatch from Blocks is a dynamic weightlifting movement that emphasizes speed and power. The barbell is lifted from blocks to a full extension overhead without going into a full squat.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on blocks at knee height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell. 3. Engage your core and pull the barbell off the blocks explosively. 4. Extend your hips and knees quickly, driving the bar overhead without going into a full squat. 5. Lock out your arms overhead and stabilize the bar.

Title: Front Squat (Bodybuilder)
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your anterior deltoids, crossing your arms or using a clean grip. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your elbows high. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell step-down reverse lunge
Desc: The barbell step-down reverse lunge is an exercise targeting the lower body, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. The front foot is slightly elevated during this movement, making the subsequent step-down more pronounced and difficult. These are usually performed for time or for relatively high reps, such as 10 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a barbell racked on your shoulders. 2. Position your front foot on an elevated surface. 3. Step back with your rear leg, lowering your body into a reverse lunge. 4. Ensure your front knee stays aligned with your ankle. 5. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Squat with Bands
Desc: The Squat with Bands involves using resistance bands to add tension during the squat. This variation helps to improve strength, stability, and explosiveness throughout the movement.
HowTo: 1. Attach resistance bands to a sturdy anchor point and place them under your feet. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the bands providing tension. 3. Hold the barbell on your upper back. 4. Initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. 5. Lower yourself while maintaining tension in the bands. 6. Drive through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Heaving Snatch Balance
Desc: The Heaving Snatch Balance is a weightlifting drill that focuses on the receiving position of the snatch. It involves a dip and drive to help lifters practice stabilizing the bar overhead.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell on your shoulders. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Perform a slight dip by bending your knees and hips. 4. Drive upward explosively, extending your legs and pushing the barbell overhead. 5. As the bar reaches its peak, drop under it into a stable receiving position, catching it overhead.

Title: Snatch Balance
Desc: The Snatch Balance is a technique exercise in weightlifting where the lifter performs a dip and drive to quickly drop under the barbell into a squat position, enhancing the catch phase of the snatch.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Perform a dip by bending your knees slightly. 4. Drive up explosively while simultaneously dropping under the bar. 5. Catch the bar in a squat position, stabilizing it overhead. 6. Stand up to complete the lift.

Title: Reverse Band Power Squat
Desc: The Reverse Band Power Squat is a variation of the squat that utilizes bands to assist in the lift, allowing for greater focus on strength and power development. The bands help reduce the weight at the bottom of the squat, making it easier to lift heavier loads while still training the full range of motion.
HowTo: 1. Set up a barbell with bands attached to the squat rack. 2. Position the barbell on your upper back, ensuring the bands are taut. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, lowering your body while keeping your chest up. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower, depending on your flexibility. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, focusing on engaging your glutes and quads.

Title: Paul Carter Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on your upper back, resting it on your traps. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and hips, lowering your body while keeping your back straight. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, fully extending your hips and knees.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Split Squat
Desc: The barbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg, full-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is easier to overload with the barbell as opposed to using dumbbells.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell on your upper back and stand in a split stance with one foot forward and the other back. 2. Keep your torso upright and engage your core. 3. Lower your body by bending your front knee, ensuring your back knee approaches the ground. 4. Keep your front knee aligned with your toes. 5. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: TBS High-Bar Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on your upper back, resting it on your traps. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and hips, lowering your body while keeping your back straight. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, fully extending your hips and knees.

Title: TBS Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The barbell front squat is a compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups. With the barbell racked in front of the body on the anterior delts, the front squat emphasizes the quads and glutes, but also upper back and core strength to remain upright. Front squats can be trained as an alternative to back squats, as an accessory movement for either squats or deadlifts, or for strength and muscle on their own. Many lifters and athletes prefer them to back squats, although they can be uncomfortable and difficult to learn at first.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your anterior deltoids, crossing your arms to secure it. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and hips, lowering your body while keeping your torso upright. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on your upper back, resting it on your traps. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and hips, lowering your body while keeping your back straight. 5. Descend until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, fully extending your hips and knees.

Title: Front-To-Back Barbell Squat
Desc: The Front-To-Back Barbell Squat is a dynamic exercise that combines the traditional squat with a forward and backward movement pattern. This variation targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes while also improving balance and coordination. It involves squatting down with the barbell positioned on the front of the shoulders, then transitioning to a back squat position.
HowTo: 1. Position the barbell on your front shoulders. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and keep your chest up. 4. Squat down by bending your knees and lowering your hips, keeping your back straight. 5. Once at the bottom of the squat, transition to a back squat position by shifting the barbell to your upper back. 6. Stand back up, pushing through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Lunge - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell forward lunge is a popular lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using a barbell allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength or muscle-focused rep ranges. The forward lunge can be performed as part of a barbell complex, in a circuit, or on its own in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: 1. Position a barbell across your upper back or shoulders. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Step forward with one leg, lowering your body until your back knee nearly touches the ground. 4. Keep your front knee aligned with your toes. 5. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 6. Alternate legs for the desired number of reps.

Title: Rack Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The rack pull is a variation of the deadlift performed from an elevated height, either using boxes, safety pins, or the safeties in a squat rack. It targets all the same muscles as the deadlift, including the glutes, hamstrings, upper back, lower back, and grip. It can e used to strengthen deadlift lockout, but also as a deadlift alternative for people who can’t deadlift from the floor without pain.
Muscles: Glutes, Hamstrings, Lower Back, Upper Back
HowTo: To perform the Rack Deadlift, set the barbell on a rack or boxes at knee height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands just outside your knees. Keep your back straight and engage your core. Push through your heels to lift the barbell, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the barbell back to the starting position with control.

Title: Barbell Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Squat, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. Engage your core and keep your chest up. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your back straight and your weight on your heels. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Good Morning - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell good morning is an exercise that targets glute, hamstring, and lower back development. It is often trained as an accessory movement to the deadlift, but also has value on its own. It is sometimes performed for reps in traditional strength-focused rep ranges such as 5-8 reps per set, but due to the risk posed to the lower back, is rarely treated as a max-effort single-rep lift.
HowTo: To perform the Barbell Good Morning, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at the hips, lowering your torso towards the ground while keeping your back straight. Go down until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings, then return to the starting position by driving your hips forward.

Title: AM Barbell Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: To perform the AM Barbell Squat, position the barbell on your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and maintain a straight back. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, keeping your weight on your heels. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to rise back up.

Title: Plyometric Power Clean
Desc: The Plyometric Power Clean is a dynamic exercise that combines the explosive movement of a clean with a plyometric jump. It focuses on developing power, speed, and strength, making it ideal for athletes looking to enhance their performance in sports that require quick, powerful movements.
HowTo: To perform the Plyometric Power Clean, start with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell on the ground. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the barbell. In one explosive motion, lift the barbell off the ground, extending your hips and knees, and then jump off the ground while pulling the barbell up to your shoulders. Land softly and absorb the impact before resetting for the next rep.

Title: Banded Split Jerk
Desc: The Banded Split Jerk is a variation of the split jerk that incorporates resistance bands to increase the difficulty of the lift. This exercise helps improve stability, strength, and technique in the overhead position, making it beneficial for weightlifters and athletes.
HowTo: To perform the Banded Split Jerk, set up with a barbell on your shoulders and resistance bands attached to the bar. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive the barbell overhead while splitting your legs into a lunge position. Stabilize the bar overhead, then return to the starting position.

Title: UP Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: To perform the UP Squat, position the barbell on your upper back and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and keep your chest up. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back, ensuring your back remains straight. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: UN Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Back Squat is a foundational strength exercise that targets the lower body, particularly the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves squatting with a barbell placed on the upper back, promoting overall strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the UN Barbell Back Squat, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on your upper back. Engage your core and maintain a straight back. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your weight on your heels. Go down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to rise back up.

Title: UN Barbell Box Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Box Squat is a variation of the squat that involves sitting back onto a box or bench to help improve squat depth and form. It emphasizes the posterior chain and helps develop strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Set up a box or bench behind you. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell racked on your upper back. 3. Initiate the squat by pushing your hips back and bending your knees. 4. Lower your body until you sit back onto the box or bench. 5. Pause briefly, ensuring your weight is distributed evenly. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: UN Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The UN Barbell Front Squat is a squat variation where the barbell is positioned on the front of the shoulders. This exercise targets the quadriceps, core, and upper back, promoting an upright torso during the squat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on the front of your shoulders. 2. Keep your elbows high and your chest up. 3. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and lowering your body. 4. Keep your torso upright and your weight on your heels. 5. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: KV Bulgarian Split Squat
Desc: The KV Bulgarian Split Squat is a single-leg squat variation performed with the rear foot elevated on a bench or platform. It focuses on building strength in the legs and improving balance and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand a few feet in front of a bench or platform with a dumbbell or barbell in one hand. 2. Place your rear foot on the bench behind you. 3. Keep your front foot flat on the ground and your torso upright. 4. Lower your body by bending your front knee until your thigh is parallel to the ground. 5. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The barbell back squat is a popular compound movement that emphasizes building the lower-body muscle groups and overall strength. It's the classic way to start a leg day, and is a worthy centerpiece to a lower-body training program. The squat is a competitive lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also a classic measurement of lower-body strength. With the barbell racked on the traps or upper back, the emphasis is placed on the posterior chain but the entire body gets worked. The back squat can be trained in everything from heavy singles to sets of 20 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on a squat rack at about chest height. 2. Step under the bar and position it on your upper back, gripping it with both hands. 3. Stand up to lift the bar off the rack and step back. 4. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 5. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up. 6. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 7. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Barbell Deadlift
Desc: The barbell deadlift is a compound exercise used to develop overall strength and size in the posterior chain. It is a competition lift in the sport of powerlifting, but is also considered a classic benchmark of overall strength. When performed with the hands outside the knees, it is often called a "conventional" deadlift. When the feet are wide and the hands are inside the knees, it is a sumo deadlift.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Hamstrings, Glutes, Erector Spinae, Core
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet hip-width apart and the barbell on the floor in front of you. 2. Bend at your hips and knees to grip the barbell with both hands, keeping your back flat. 3. Engage your core and lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees simultaneously. 4. Stand up straight with the barbell at thigh level. 5. Lower the barbell back to the ground by bending at the hips and knees.

Title: 30 Legs Barbell Back Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Barbell Back Squat is a compound exercise that involves squatting with a barbell resting on the upper back. It primarily targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes, making it a fundamental movement for leg development.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on a squat rack at shoulder height. 2. Step under the bar and position it on your upper back. 3. Stand up to lift the bar off the rack and step back. 4. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 5. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up. 6. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 7. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Barbell Front Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Barbell Front Squat is a variation of the squat where the barbell is held in front of the shoulders. This exercise emphasizes the quadriceps and requires significant core stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell resting on the front of your shoulders. 2. Keep your elbows high and your chest up. 3. Initiate the squat by bending your knees and lowering your body. 4. Keep your torso upright and your weight on your heels. 5. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Barbell Back Squats
Desc: Barbell Back Squats are a foundational strength training exercise that involves squatting with a barbell placed across the upper back. This exercise is effective for building overall leg strength and muscle mass.
HowTo: 1. Set the barbell on a squat rack at about chest height. 2. Step under the bar and position it on your upper back, gripping it with both hands. 3. Stand up to lift the bar off the rack and step back. 4. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 5. Lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up. 6. Squat down until your thighs are at least parallel to the ground. 7. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Front Squats With Two Kettlebells
Desc: The Front Squats With Two Kettlebells is a lower body exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. To perform this exercise, hold a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height, with your elbows pointing down. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, then lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height with elbows pointing down. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Kettlebell Pistol Squat
Desc: The Kettlebell Pistol Squat is an advanced single-leg exercise that challenges balance, strength, and flexibility. Begin by holding a kettlebell in front of you with both hands. Stand on one leg and extend the other leg forward. Lower your body into a squat on the standing leg while keeping the extended leg off the ground. Aim to go as low as possible while maintaining control, then push back up to the starting position.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in front of you with both hands. Stand on one leg and extend the other leg forward. Lower into a squat on the standing leg while keeping the extended leg off the ground. Push back up to the starting position.

Title: Goblet Squat
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise where you hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest as if you are supporting a heavy cup or goblet. It can help lifters of all levels improve their squat technique and hip mobility, but can also work as a muscle-building or strength accessory movement for experienced athletes. It also works well in combinations, complexes, and flows with other kettlebell movements like swings, presses, and cleans.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body into a squat, keeping the weight close to your chest and your back straight. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Kettlebell Curtsy Lunge
Desc: The Kettlebell Curtsy Lunge is a dynamic lower body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and inner thighs. Start by holding a kettlebell in one hand at your side. Step back and to the side with the opposite leg, crossing it behind your standing leg into a curtsy position. Lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee aligned with your ankle. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in one hand at your side. Step back and to the side with the opposite leg, crossing it behind your standing leg into a curtsy. Lower into a lunge, keeping your front knee aligned with your ankle. Push through your front heel to return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell overhead squat
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell overhead squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding a single kettlebell in a locked-out overhead position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, while also challenging and building shoulder stability and upper-back mobility. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in a locked-out overhead position with one arm. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body into a squat while keeping the kettlebell overhead. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Kettlebell side squat
Desc: The kettlebell side squat is a popular movement to build mobility and lateral strength in the hips. It can be performed for time or for reps, either on its own or as part of a kettlebell circuit, complex, or flow.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in front of you with both hands. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart. Shift your weight to one side and lower into a squat, keeping the kettlebell close to your body. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: Kettlebell sumo squat
Desc: The kettlebell sumo squat is a lower-body movement emphasizing the muscles of the hips, glutes, and quads. It shares attributes with both the kettlebell deadlift and the goblet squat, but is usually performed with a wider stance and the feet pointed more outward, similar to a sumo deadlift. Its unique stance helps the lifter keep an upright torso, as well as emphasize stretching the hips and adductor muscles.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width apart and toes pointed outward. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your chest up and back straight. Push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Kettlebell thruster progression
Desc: The kettlebell thruster progression is a kettlebell combination movement that includes a squat, curl, press, and overhead extension in a single sequence. It can work well with a light or moderate weight either for time or reps, in circuit-style training, or as a single kettlebell "flow."
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell at shoulder height. Perform a squat, then curl the kettlebell to your chest. Press the kettlebell overhead, then lower it back to shoulder height and repeat the sequence.

Title: Kettlebell power clean
Desc: The kettlebell power clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level with a slight swing between the legs. It is often used as a drill to teach kettlebell clean technique, but is also a valuable power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: Start with the kettlebell on the floor between your feet. Hinge at your hips and bend your knees to grab the kettlebell with both hands. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then explosively pull it up to your shoulder level while keeping your elbows high. Lower the kettlebell back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Kettlebell fire feet
Desc: Kettlebell fire feet is a dynamic movement that works most of the major muscle groups in the body simultaneously, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in kettlebell or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a kettlebell in each hand at your sides. Quickly lift your feet off the ground, alternating between them as if you are running in place, while keeping your arms engaged. Continue for a set time or number of repetitions.

Title: Single Arm Overhead Kettlebell Squat
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell overhead squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding a single kettlebell in a locked-out overhead position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, while also challenging and building shoulder stability and upper-back mobility. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand overhead. Lower your body into a squat, keeping the kettlebell locked out overhead. Ensure your chest stays up and your core is engaged. Push through your heels to return to standing. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Pulsing goblet squat
Desc: The pulsing goblet squat is a simple way to make a popular squat variation more taxing for the lower body and cardiovascular system. They can be done for time or reps, allowing you to get a significant training effect from a light weight in circuit-style training.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. Lower into a squat, then rise slightly before lowering back down again without fully standing up. Continue pulsing in this manner for the desired time or number of repetitions.

Title: Double-kettlebell alternating lunge to clean
Desc: The double-kettlebell alternating lunge to clean is a combination of kettlebell moves in a single sequence. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss, or in a kettlebell complex or flow.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with a kettlebell in each hand. Step back into a lunge with one leg while bringing the kettlebell to the opposite shoulder in a clean motion. Return to standing and switch legs, alternating between lunges and cleans for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR Goblet Squat
Desc: The goblet squat is a popular lower-body exercise where you hold a kettlebell or dumbbell in front of your chest as if you are supporting a heavy cup or goblet. It can help lifters of all levels improve their squat technique and hip mobility, but can also work as a muscle-building or strength accessory movement for experienced athletes. It also works well in combinations, complexes, and flows with other kettlebell movements like swings, presses, and cleans.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell close to your chest with both hands. Lower your body into a squat, keeping your elbows inside your knees. Push through your heels to return to standing. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR Kettlebell Sumo Squat
Desc: The kettlebell sumo squat is a lower-body movement emphasizing the muscles of the hips, glutes, and quads. It shares attributes with both the kettlebell deadlift and the goblet squat, but is usually performed with a wider stance and the feet pointed more outward, similar to a sumo deadlift. Its unique stance helps the lifter keep an upright torso, as well as emphasize stretching the hips and adductor muscles.
HowTo: Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands in front of you. Lower into a squat, keeping your back straight and chest up, while pushing your knees outward. Return to standing and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Double-kettlebell front squat
Desc: The double-kettlebell front squat is a popular kettlebell movement performed while holding two kettlebells in the front-racked position. It targets the muscles of the lower body dynamically, and the muscles of the upper back and core isometrically. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Glutes, Hamstrings, Core, Upper Back
