HowTo: To perform the Single-Leg Hop Progression, start by standing on one leg. Begin with small hops forward, then progress to larger hops and lateral hops. Focus on landing softly and maintaining balance. As you advance, incorporate more complex movements like hopping over obstacles.

Title: Rickshaw Deadlift
Desc: The Rickshaw Deadlift is a variation of the traditional deadlift that uses a rickshaw or trap bar. This exercise targets the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back. By lifting from a neutral grip, it reduces strain on the lower back and allows for a more upright torso position, making it a great option for building strength.
HowTo: To perform the Rickshaw Deadlift, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grasp the handles of the rickshaw or trap bar. Keep your back straight and engage your core. Push through your heels to lift the weight, extending your hips and knees simultaneously. Lower the weight back to the ground with control. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-cone sprint drill
Desc: The single-cone sprint drill is an agility drill that involves moving quickly around a single cone. It demands that an athlete start, stop, and change directions all in a short period of time and a small space. It can be beneficial for football players and other athletes where quick changes of direction are important.
HowTo: To perform the single-cone sprint drill, start by standing a few feet away from a cone. Sprint towards the cone, touch it, then quickly change direction and sprint back to the starting point. Repeat this drill, focusing on quick starts and stops, for a set amount of time or repetitions.

Title: Single-Leg Stride Jump
Desc: The Single-Leg Stride Jump is a dynamic exercise that combines a jump and a lunge movement. It focuses on improving explosive power, balance, and coordination. To perform this exercise, jump forward off one leg and land in a lunge position on the same leg, then return to the starting position. This exercise is excellent for athletes looking to enhance their performance.
HowTo: To perform the Single-Leg Stride Jump, start by standing on one leg. Jump forward explosively off that leg, landing in a lunge position on the same leg. Ensure your front knee is aligned over your ankle. Push off the front foot to return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Trap Bar Jump
Desc: The Trap Bar Jump is a plyometric exercise that utilizes a trap bar to enhance lower body power and explosiveness. It involves jumping while holding the trap bar, which allows for a more natural jumping motion. This exercise primarily targets the legs and core, making it effective for athletes looking to improve their vertical jump and overall athletic performance.
HowTo: To perform the Trap Bar Jump, stand inside the trap bar with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grip the handles and squat down slightly. Explode upwards, jumping off the ground while holding the trap bar. Land softly and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-Leg Lateral Hop
Desc: Stand on one leg and hop laterally to the side, landing on the same leg. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching legs.
HowTo: Stand on one leg, engage your core, and hop laterally to the side. Land softly on the same leg and maintain balance. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching to the other leg.

Title: Burpee Box-Jumps
Desc: Start in a standing position, drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a plank position, perform a push-up, jump your feet back to your hands, and explosively jump onto a box.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Kick your feet back into a plank position and perform a push-up. Jump your feet back to your hands and explosively jump onto a box.

Title: Sandbag Load
Desc: Lift a sandbag from the ground to your shoulders or chest, focusing on proper form and engaging your core throughout the movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at the hips and knees to lift the sandbag from the ground. Engage your core and lift the sandbag to your shoulders or chest, keeping your back straight throughout the movement.

Title: Single-leg knee-tap squat
Desc: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, grip the barbell with both hands, and lift it from the ground to a standing position, keeping your back straight and engaging your legs.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Grip the barbell with both hands, lift it from the ground to a standing position, and lower it back down while keeping your back straight and engaging your legs.

Title: Car Deadlift
Desc: Stand in front of a box or platform, squat down, and sit back onto the box, then stand back up, ensuring to maintain control and proper form.
HowTo: Stand in front of a box or platform. Squat down and sit back onto the box, ensuring your knees do not go past your toes. Stand back up, maintaining control and proper form throughout the movement.

Title: Barbell Squat To A Box
Desc: Jump rope while performing two rotations of the rope for each jump, focusing on timing and rhythm to maintain a continuous flow.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Jump rope while performing two rotations of the rope for each jump. Focus on timing and rhythm to maintain a continuous flow.

Title: Double Under
HowTo: Stand with your feet together and hold the jump rope handles. Swing the rope over your head and jump as it comes down, aiming to clear the rope twice for each jump.

Title: Plate push
Desc: The plate push is a conditioning exercise that targets the cardiovascular system and the muscles of the lower body. It involves pushing a plate along turf or another flat surface either for time or distance. It can be used as part of a dynamic warm-up or for power training, as a finisher, or as part of a conditioning workout or circuit.
HowTo: Position yourself behind the plate. Bend your knees and grip the plate. Push the plate forward along the turf or flat surface, using your legs and core to drive the movement. Continue pushing for the desired distance or time.

Title: Hybrid deadlift
Desc: The hybrid deadlift is a version of the barbell deadlift in which the lifter's stance is wider than a conventional position, but narrower than a wide sumo deadlift. The feet are just outside the shoulders and grip placement is just inside of the legs. Many non-competitive lifters find this position to be more spine friendly and strong than either of the other traditional stances. This variation of the deadlift has all the same benefits as the others, and is capable of building serious full-body and posterior chain strength.
HowTo: Stand with your feet just outside shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell just inside your legs. Lower your hips and grasp the barbell, keeping your back straight. Lift the barbell by extending your hips and knees simultaneously, standing tall at the top.

Title: Boss Everline Suspension Side Run
Desc: The Boss Everline Suspension Side Run is an exercise that targets the lower body, particularly the glutes, hamstrings, and quadriceps. It involves using suspension straps to perform a lateral running motion, enhancing stability and strength while engaging the core.
HowTo: Attach the suspension straps to a secure anchor point. Stand facing away from the anchor, holding the straps with both hands. Step to the side and lower your body into a lunge while driving your opposite knee up, then return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Boss Everline Lunge Sled Push
Desc: The Boss Everline Lunge Sled Push is a dynamic exercise that combines lunging with pushing a sled. This movement targets the legs, glutes, and core while improving overall strength and power.
HowTo: Stand behind the sled with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lunge forward with one leg while pushing the sled with your hands. Alternate legs with each lunge, maintaining a strong core and proper form throughout the movement.

Title: Squat Bottom Position Hold
Desc: The Squat Bottom Position Hold is an isometric exercise where you hold the squat position at the lowest point. This exercise builds strength and endurance in the legs and improves flexibility in the hips and ankles.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and lower your body into a squat until your thighs are parallel to the ground. Hold this position, keeping your chest up and core engaged, for a designated amount of time.

Title: TRX Squat Jump
Desc: The TRX Squat Jump is a plyometric exercise that combines a squat with a jump while using TRX straps for support. This exercise enhances lower body power, coordination, and stability.
HowTo: Adjust the TRX straps to mid-length. Stand facing the anchor point and lower into a squat. Explode upward into a jump while using the TRX straps for support, landing softly back into the squat position.

Title: Landmine squat
Desc: The landmine squat is a lower-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The landmine squat is similar in many ways to a goblet squat, but with slight differences due to the angle of the barbell. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: Position the barbell in the landmine device or corner. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the end of the barbell with both hands. Lower your body into a squat while keeping your chest up and the bar close to your body, then push through your heels to return to standing.

Title: Dumbbell Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The dumbbell Bulgarian split squat is a single-leg exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Overloading the movement with dumbbells usually presents less of a balance challenge than putting a barbell on the back. Dumbbell split squats are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per leg, but they are also effective done with heavier weights in lower rep ranges.
HowTo: Stand a few feet in front of a bench or elevated surface. Place one foot on the bench behind you and hold a dumbbell in each hand. Lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee aligned with your ankle, then push back up to the starting position. Alternate legs.

Title: Holman Towel Alternating Prisoner Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Towel Alternating Prisoner Reverse Lunge is a functional exercise that involves using a towel for resistance while performing alternating reverse lunges. This movement targets the legs, glutes, and core, promoting balance and strength.
HowTo: Hold a towel with both hands, extending it overhead. Step back into a reverse lunge with one leg while pulling the towel down and engaging your core. Return to standing and switch legs, alternating lunges.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch
Desc: A dynamic exercise combining a weighted burpee with a belly touch, focusing on explosive movement and core engagement.
HowTo: Start in a standing position holding weights. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a plank position. Perform a belly touch by lowering your body to the ground, then push back up to plank. Jump your feet back towards your hands and explode upwards, reaching overhead.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Front Punch
Desc: A high-intensity exercise that integrates a weighted burpee with a front punch, enhancing strength and coordination.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with weights. Perform a weighted burpee by squatting down, placing your hands on the ground, and jumping back into a plank. Jump your feet back towards your hands, then explode upwards while simultaneously delivering a front punch.

Title: Holman Weighted Low Squat Punch
Desc: A strength-building exercise that involves a low squat while delivering punches, targeting the legs and upper body.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat position while keeping your back straight. As you squat, throw punches alternately with each arm, focusing on engaging your core and maintaining balance.

Title: Holman Weighted Hook Punch to Squat Thrust
Desc: A combination of a hook punch and a squat thrust, this exercise builds power and agility in the lower and upper body.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Perform a hook punch with your right arm while stepping into a squat. Push off from the squat position and jump back into a squat thrust, landing softly and preparing for the next punch.

Title: Holman Towel Alternating Side Lunge Squat
Desc: An alternating side lunge squat with a towel, designed to improve flexibility and strength in the legs and core.
HowTo: Stand with feet together holding a towel. Step to the side into a lunge while pulling the towel taut. Alternate sides, ensuring to keep your core engaged and your back straight throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Renegade Side Punch
Desc: A challenging exercise that merges a weighted burpee with a renegade side punch, focusing on core stability and upper body strength.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with weights. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a plank position. Perform a renegade side punch by rotating your torso and punching to the side with one arm while stabilizing with the other. Return to the squat and jump back up.

Title: Holman Weighted Reverse Lunge to Knee-Up Overhead Press
Desc: A compound movement that combines a reverse lunge with a knee-up and an overhead press, targeting multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: Stand with feet hip-width apart holding weights. Step back into a reverse lunge while lowering the weights. As you return to standing, bring one knee up and press the weights overhead, engaging your core throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Lunge Jump with Overhead Press
Desc: An explosive lunge jump paired with an overhead press, designed to enhance power, coordination, and overall fitness.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward into a lunge and jump explosively while switching legs. As you jump, press weights overhead, focusing on coordination and maintaining a strong core.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Belly Touch to Standing T
Desc: Perform a weighted burpee by adding a weight to your chest. After the push-up, touch your belly to the ground and jump back to your feet. Finish with a standing T raise, lifting the weights overhead.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding a weight against your chest. 2. Perform a burpee: drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a push-up position, and lower your chest to the ground. 3. Push back up and jump your feet towards your hands. 4. Touch your belly to the ground. 5. Jump back to your feet and finish with a standing T raise, lifting the weights overhead.

Title: Holman Weighted Squat Jump
Desc: Start in a squat position with weights in hand. Jump explosively into the air, extending your body fully while lifting the weights overhead. Land softly and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a squat position with weights in hand. 2. Jump explosively into the air, extending your body fully while lifting the weights overhead. 3. Land softly, absorbing the impact with your legs. 4. Repeat the movement for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Plie Squat
Desc: Stand with feet wider than shoulder-width and hold weights. Lower into a squat, keeping your heels flat and chest up. Push through your heels to return to standing.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet wider than shoulder-width apart, holding weights at your sides. 2. Lower into a squat, keeping your heels flat and your chest up. 3. Push through your heels to return to a standing position, squeezing your glutes at the top.

Title: Holman Heels-Elevated Sissy Squat
Desc: Stand with your heels elevated on a platform. Lower into a squat while keeping your knees forward and your torso upright. Return to standing, focusing on your quads.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your heels elevated on a platform, feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower into a squat while keeping your knees forward and your torso upright. 3. Focus on engaging your quads as you return to standing.

Title: Holman Squat Jump to Overhead Press
Desc: Start in a squat position with weights at shoulder height. Jump up explosively, pressing the weights overhead as you rise. Land softly and return to the squat.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with weights at shoulder height. 2. Jump up explosively, pressing the weights overhead as you rise. 3. Land softly, bending your knees to absorb the impact. 4. Return to the squat position and repeat.

Title: Holman 180 Jump to Overhead Press
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Jump 180 degrees while holding weights, landing softly. Immediately press the weights overhead as you stabilize your landing.
HowTo: 1. Begin in a standing position with weights in hand. 2. Jump 180 degrees while holding the weights, landing softly. 3. Immediately press the weights overhead as you stabilize your landing. 4. Prepare for the next repetition.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to Row
Desc: Perform a weighted burpee by adding weights to your chest. After the push-up, row the weights towards your chest before jumping back to your feet.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding weights against your chest. 2. Perform a weighted burpee: drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a push-up position, and lower your chest to the ground. 3. After the push-up, row the weights towards your chest. 4. Jump your feet back to your hands and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Burpee to 180 Jump
Desc: Execute a weighted burpee, and after the push-up, jump 180 degrees while holding the weights. Land softly and prepare for the next repetition.
HowTo: 1. Begin by holding weights against your chest. 2. Execute a weighted burpee: drop into a squat, kick your feet back into a push-up position, and lower your chest to the ground. 3. After the push-up, jump 180 degrees while holding the weights. 4. Land softly and prepare for the next repetition.

Title: Holman Weighted 180 Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted 180 Jump is a dynamic exercise that involves jumping 180 degrees while holding weights. It targets the legs, core, and improves agility and coordination.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands. Bend your knees slightly and jump explosively while rotating your body 180 degrees. Land softly on your feet and repeat.

Title: Holman Weighted Narrow-Mid-Wide Hop
Desc: The Holman Weighted Narrow-Mid-Wide Hop is a plyometric exercise that combines three different jump widths while holding weights. It enhances lower body strength, stability, and cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with weights in hand. Jump to the narrow position, then mid, and finally wide, alternating between the three widths. Ensure to land softly and maintain control.

Title: Holman Alternating Weighted Diagonal Burpee
Desc: The Holman Alternating Weighted Diagonal Burpee is a full-body exercise that combines a burpee with a diagonal weight lift. It improves strength, coordination, and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with weights. Drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, kick your feet back into a push-up position, perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to your hands and lift one weight diagonally overhead. Alternate sides.

Title: Holman Towel Burpee to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Towel Burpee to Push-Up is a variation of the burpee that incorporates a towel for added resistance during the push-up phase. It targets the chest, arms, and core.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with a towel in hand. Perform a burpee by squatting down, placing your hands on the ground, jumping back into a push-up position, perform a push-up while pulling on the towel, then jump back to your hands and stand up.

Title: Holman Towel Right Side Squat
Desc: The Holman Towel Right Side Squat is a strength exercise that involves squatting to the right while holding a towel for resistance. It focuses on the legs, glutes, and core stability.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together, holding a towel in both hands. Step your right foot out to the side and lower into a squat while pulling the towel for resistance. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: ACFT Sprint-drag-carry
Desc: The sprint-drag-carry is a strength and endurance relay that is part of the new Army Combat Fitness Test or ACFT. It combines sprinting, reverse sled drag, side shuffle, and a farmer's carry to test overall strength and athletic conditioning. Practicing this relay as a drill is great for developing strenght, speed, endurance, and power, and can also be great conditioning work for lifters and athletes of all ability levels.
HowTo: Start by sprinting forward, then drag a sled backward, followed by a side shuffle to one side. Finish with a farmer's carry by holding weights in each hand and walking a set distance.

Title: Cable Hip Adduction
Desc: Cable Hip Adduction is an exercise performed using a cable machine to target the hip adductor muscles. It strengthens the inner thighs and improves hip stability.
HowTo: Stand next to a cable machine with the cable set at the lowest position. Attach the ankle strap and stand with your side to the machine. Lift your leg away from the machine against the resistance of the cable, focusing on the inner thigh.

Title: Cable Deadlifts
Desc: Cable Deadlifts are performed using a cable machine to mimic the deadlift movement. This exercise targets the posterior chain, including the hamstrings, glutes, and lower back.
HowTo: Stand facing the cable machine with feet hip-width apart. Grab the cable handle with both hands, hinge at your hips, and pull the cable upward while keeping your back straight, mimicking the deadlift movement.

Title: KV Cable Squat
Desc: The KV Cable Squat is an exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves using a cable machine to provide resistance while performing a squat, which helps improve leg strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable machine to the appropriate weight. 2. Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Grasp the cable handle with both hands, keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower your body into a squat position, ensuring your knees do not extend past your toes. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Single-Leg Press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that it’s safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and adjust the seat so your knees are at a 90-degree angle. 2. Place one foot on the platform, ensuring it is centered. 3. Push through your heel to extend your leg, keeping the other leg off the platform. 4. Slowly lower the platform back to the starting position, maintaining control.

Title: Stair climber
Desc: The stair climber is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stair climber also helps build strength in the lower body, especially the glutes. It can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the stair climber and adjust the settings for resistance and speed. 2. Stand upright with your feet on the pedals. 3. Begin stepping as if you are climbing stairs, maintaining a steady pace. 4. Use your arms to assist with balance and rhythm, if necessary.

Title: Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine and adjust the seat for comfort. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs while keeping your back against the seat. 4. Slowly lower the platform back to the starting position, ensuring your knees track over your toes.

Title: Elliptical trainer
Desc: The elliptical trainer is a popular machine for cardiovascular training without the significant impact on your joints of running. On many machines, you can adjust the resistance level to make the movement more difficult for all four limbs. The elliptical is a mainstay in most commercial gyms, and can be equally effective for HIIT-style interval workouts or for longer-duration endurance work.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the elliptical trainer and adjust the resistance and incline settings. 2. Place your feet on the pedals and grasp the handles. 3. Begin moving your legs in a circular motion while simultaneously pushing and pulling the handles. 4. Maintain a steady pace, adjusting resistance as needed for your workout.

Title: Narrow-stance leg press
Desc: The narrow-stance leg press is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs. It emphasizes the quads, particularly the muscles of the outer quads and hips. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training when it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the narrow-stance leg press machine and adjust the seat. 2. Position your feet close together on the platform. 3. Push through your heels to extend your legs while keeping your back against the seat. 4. Slowly lower the platform back to the starting position, focusing on engaging your quads.

Title: Narrow Stance Hack Squats
Desc: Narrow Stance Hack Squats focus on the quadriceps by positioning the feet closer together on the hack squat machine. This variation emphasizes the front of the thighs and helps build strength and muscle definition in the legs.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet close together on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back straight. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, focusing on the contraction in your quads.

Title: Stairmaster
Desc: The stair climber is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stair climber also helps build strength in the lower body, especially the glutes. It can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: 1. Step onto the Stairmaster and select your desired workout settings. 2. Stand upright with your feet on the pedals. 3. Begin stepping in a climbing motion, maintaining a steady rhythm. 4. Adjust the speed and resistance as needed to match your fitness level.

Title: Machine Squat
Desc: The machine squat is a strength training exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves using a machine to perform squats with added weight, providing stability and support for the user.
HowTo: To perform the machine squat, adjust the seat height so that your knees are aligned with the pivot point of the machine. Sit down and place your back against the padded support. Position your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Engage your core and push through your heels to squat down, lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. Then, press back up to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine back squat
Desc: The Smith machine back squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: To perform the Smith machine back squat, set the bar at shoulder height and load it with an appropriate weight. Stand under the bar, positioning it across your upper back, and grasp the bar with both hands. Unrack the bar by rotating the safety hooks. With your feet shoulder-width apart, lower your body into a squat by bending your knees and pushing your hips back. Keep your chest up and back straight. Squat down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Leg Extensions
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: To perform leg extensions, sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the machine so that the pad rests on your lower legs, just above your ankles. Select an appropriate weight. Extend your legs by straightening your knees, lifting the pad until your legs are fully extended. Hold for a moment, then slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.

Title: Treadmill running
Desc: Treadmill running is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your running and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: To run on a treadmill, start by stepping onto the machine and adjusting the speed to a comfortable level. Hold onto the handrails if needed. Begin walking or jogging, maintaining a steady pace. You can adjust the incline to increase the intensity of your workout. Monitor your heart rate and time using the built-in features of the treadmill.

Title: Stationary bike
Desc: The stationary bike is a popular cardio machine found in most commercial gyms. Along with burning a ton of calories, the stationary bike also helps develop the lower body. Stationary bikes come in multiple variations, ranging from ones that resemble riding a bike, to recumbent bikes, to fan bikes that work both the arms and the legs. No matter the variation, a stationary bike can work well at higher speeds for interval-style conditioning training, but also works well at slower paces for steady-state cardio.
HowTo: To use a stationary bike, adjust the seat height and position so that your legs have a slight bend at the bottom of the pedal stroke. Start pedaling at a comfortable pace. You can adjust the resistance to increase or decrease the intensity of your workout. For interval training, alternate between high-speed pedaling and slower recovery periods.

Title: Treadmill jogging
Desc: Treadmill jogging is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your jogging and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: To jog on a treadmill, step onto the machine and set the speed to a comfortable jogging pace. You can adjust the incline to simulate outdoor running conditions. Maintain a steady rhythm and use the handrails for balance if necessary. Keep track of your time and distance using the treadmill's display.

Title: Recumbent Bike
Desc: The recumbent bike is a stationary exercise bike that allows the user to sit in a reclined position while pedaling. It provides a low-impact cardiovascular workout, focusing on the legs and lower body, and is suitable for all fitness levels.
HowTo: To use a recumbent bike, adjust the seat so that your feet can comfortably reach the pedals. Sit back in the reclined position and start pedaling at a comfortable pace. You can adjust the resistance to increase the difficulty of your workout. Focus on maintaining a steady pace for cardiovascular benefits.

Title: Smith machine leg press
Desc: The Smith machine leg press is a machine-based movement that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can serve as a substitute for the leg press or be programmed similarly to the leg press. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of lower-body training. If your Smith machine has safety bars, set them at a height that allows you a full range of motion while giving adequate protection from the weight potentially falling.
HowTo: To perform the Smith machine leg press, adjust the seat and foot platform so that your knees are aligned with the pivot point. Sit down and place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Grip the handles for support. Lower the weight by bending your knees until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push back up to the starting position, ensuring to keep your back against the pad throughout the movement.

Title: Lying Machine Squat
Desc: The Lying Machine Squat is an exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves lying on a machine and pushing a weighted platform away using your legs, providing a controlled movement that isolates the lower body muscles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat of the lying machine so that your back is flat against the pad. 2. Position your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Grasp the handles or sides of the machine for stability. 4. Push the platform away by extending your legs, ensuring to keep your back against the pad. 5. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your knees.

Title: Seated Leg Press
Desc: The seated leg press is a lower body exercise that targets the quads, adductors, glutes, and hamstrings.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the seat if necessary to ensure comfort. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your feet flat. 4. Slowly lower the platform back towards you by bending your knees, ensuring they do not extend past your toes.

Title: Smith machine pistol squat
Desc: The Smith machine pistol squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is similar in form to a pistol squat but is performed with a bar on the shoulders. This adds extra resistance, but also eliminates some of the balance challenge of single-leg squats. This squat variation can be performed in low reps for strength or for higher reps for muscle gain.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar on your shoulders and adjust the Smith machine to the appropriate height. 2. Stand on one leg with the other leg extended forward. 3. Lower your body into a squat by bending the knee of the standing leg while keeping the other leg extended. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position.

Title: Leverage Deadlift
Desc: The Leverage Deadlift is a strength training exercise that focuses on the posterior chain, including the back, glutes, and hamstrings. It is performed using a leverage machine that allows for a safer and more controlled lifting motion, making it ideal for building strength and muscle mass.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the leverage machine with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 2. Adjust the seat so that your knees are aligned with the pivot point of the machine. 3. Grip the handles and engage your core. 4. Push through your heels to lift the weight, extending your hips and knees. 5. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.

Title: Leg press-
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the leg muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It's a favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine. The leg press is often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the seat if necessary for comfort. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your back flat. 4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your knees.

Title: TBS Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the machine to ensure proper alignment. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back against the pad. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Leg Extensions - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the leg extension machine with your back against the pad and feet under the padded lever. 2. Adjust the seat so that your knees align with the pivot point. 3. Extend your legs to lift the weight, squeezing your quads at the top. 4. Slowly lower the weight back to the starting position.

Title: Seated leg press-
Desc: The seated leg press is a machine-based exercise that targets the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It is similar in many ways to larger leg press machines, but often utilizes a selectorized weight stack rather than plate loading. Leg press variations are often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the seated leg press machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. 2. Adjust the seat if necessary for comfort. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your feet flat. 4. Slowly lower the platform back towards you by bending your knees.

Title: Smith machine front squat
Desc: The Smith machine front squat is a machine-based exercise targeting the muscles of the lower body. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a full-body or lower-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar to a comfortable height. 2. Position yourself under the bar, resting it on your upper back. 3. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and your toes slightly pointed out. 4. Unrack the bar and lower your body by bending your knees and hips, keeping your chest up and back straight. 5. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Machine Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Machine Deadlift - Gethin Variation focuses on building strength in the posterior chain, particularly the glutes and hamstrings. This exercise is performed on a machine, allowing for a controlled movement that emphasizes proper form and reduces the risk of injury. Ensure to adjust the machine settings to your height for optimal performance.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine settings to your height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Grip the handles or the bar securely. 4. Hinge at your hips and lower your body, keeping your back straight. 5. Drive through your heels to lift the weight back to the starting position, focusing on engaging your glutes and hamstrings.

Title: Single-leg hack squat
Desc: The single-leg hack squat is a lower-body exercise mainly targeting the quads, performed one side at a time per set. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training, and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand with one foot on the platform and the other foot off the edge. 2. Lower your body by bending the knee of the standing leg, keeping your chest up and back straight. 3. Go down until your thigh is parallel to the ground or lower. 4. Push through your heel to return to the starting position. 5. Complete the desired reps and switch legs.

Title: Narrow-stance hack squat
Desc: The narrow-stance hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, or as a muscle-building movement during lower-body training, and is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back against the pad. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Alternating Single-Leg Curl - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Alternating Single-Leg Curl - Gethin Variation is designed to isolate and strengthen the hamstrings while improving balance and stability. This exercise involves curling one leg at a time, allowing for a greater range of motion and muscle engagement. Focus on maintaining a slow and controlled movement to maximize effectiveness.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the machine to your height. 2. Lie face down on the machine with one leg extended and the other leg positioned to curl. 3. Curl the leg towards your glutes in a controlled manner. 4. Focus on squeezing the hamstring at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the leg back to the starting position and repeat for the desired reps before switching legs.

Title: Stiff-Legged Deadlift - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell stiff-legged deadlift targets the hamstrings, glutes, lower and upper back, as well as the core. It is a popular accessory movement for the deadlift, but also a muscle-building hamstring movement.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keep your knees slightly bent and hinge at your hips to lower the barbell down your legs, maintaining a straight back. 3. Lower the barbell until you feel a stretch in your hamstrings. 4. Engage your hamstrings and glutes to lift the barbell back to the starting position.

Title: Single-Leg Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that it’s safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit on the machine with one foot on the platform and the other leg hanging off. 3. Push the platform away by extending the knee of the standing leg. 4. Lower the weight back down in a controlled manner, ensuring your knee does not extend past your toes. 5. Complete the desired reps and switch legs.

Title: Hack squat-
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Position yourself on the hack squat machine with your back against the pad. 2. Place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back against the pad. 4. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 5. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Smith machine lunge squat
Desc: The Smith machine lunge squat is an exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. Using added weight allows you to overload the exercise beyond body weight and perform the movement in strength ranges. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability.
HowTo: 1. Set the Smith machine bar at an appropriate height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, positioning them slightly forward on the platform. 3. Step under the bar and rest it on your upper back. 4. Unrack the bar by straightening your legs. 5. Step back and stabilize your stance. 6. Lower your body into a lunge by bending one knee while keeping the other leg straight behind you. 7. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. 8. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch legs.

Title: Hack Squat - Gethin Variation
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the hack squat machine to your height. 2. Position your back against the pad and place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Unrack the weight by straightening your legs. 4. Lower your body by bending your knees, keeping your back against the pad. 5. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground or lower. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Leg Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Unrack the weight by straightening your legs. 4. Lower the platform by bending your knees, keeping your back against the seat. 5. Go down until your knees are at about a 90-degree angle. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: AM Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Unrack the weight by straightening your legs. 4. Lower the platform by bending your knees, keeping your back against the seat. 5. Go down until your knees are at about a 90-degree angle. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Leg extension
Desc: The leg extension is a popular machine-based exercise for the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a leg pre-exhaust or as a muscle-building movement for lower-body training.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg extension machine to fit your height. 2. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and your feet under the padded lever. 3. Select an appropriate weight. 4. Extend your legs by straightening your knees until your legs are fully extended. 5. Hold for a moment at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UP Quad Extension
Desc: The leg extension is an isolation exercise for the quads.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg extension machine to fit your height. 2. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and your feet under the padded lever. 3. Select an appropriate weight. 4. Extend your legs by straightening your knees until your legs are fully extended. 5. Hold for a moment at the top, then slowly lower back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: UP Single-Leg Press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is an exercise targeting the quadriceps one leg at a time. Many lifters prefer the leg press to squatting for several reasons, including the perception that it’s safer for the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the single-leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place one foot on the platform while the other foot is off. 3. Unrack the weight by straightening your leg. 4. Lower the platform by bending your knee, keeping your back against the seat. 5. Go down until your knee is at about a 90-degree angle. 6. Push through your heel to return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch legs.

Title: UP Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your height. 2. Sit down and place your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Unrack the weight by straightening your legs. 4. Lower the platform by bending your knees, keeping your back against the seat. 5. Go down until your knees are at about a 90-degree angle. 6. Push through your heels to return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Pop Squat On Leg Press
Desc: The Pop Squat on Leg Press is a dynamic exercise that combines a squat movement with the leg press machine. It targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes while also engaging the core for stability.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit on the machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. 3. Lower your body into a squat position by bending your knees while keeping your feet flat. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, engaging your core for stability.

Title: King Maker Leg Press
Desc: The leg press is a machine exercise targeting the quadriceps. It’s favorite among lifters who prefer the seated position to standing with a load on the spine.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit down and place your feet on the platform, shoulder-width apart. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your back against the pad. 4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your knees.

Title: Single-leg leg press
Desc: The single-leg leg press is a machine exercise targeting the leg muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The leg press is often used as an accessory for squats or deadlifts, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit on the machine and place one foot on the platform, keeping the other leg off. 3. Push through the heel of the foot on the platform to extend your leg. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position, maintaining control.

Title: King Maker Hack Squat
Desc: The hack squat is a machine-based exercise that targets the muscles of the legs, particularly the quadriceps. It is often used as an accessory for squats, but can also be the main lower-body movement in a workout. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the hack squat machine to your desired weight. 2. Stand on the platform with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back pressed against the pad. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Feet-High Leg Press
Desc: The 30 Legs Feet-High Leg Press is an exercise performed on a leg press machine with the feet positioned high on the platform. This variation emphasizes the hamstrings and glutes, providing a different angle of resistance.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit on the machine and place your feet high on the platform. 3. Lower your body by bending your knees, ensuring your back remains against the pad. 4. Push through your heels to return to the starting position, focusing on engaging your hamstrings and glutes.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Press
Desc: The 30 Legs Leg Press is a foundational strength exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. It involves pushing a weighted platform away from the body using the legs.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit on the machine and place your feet on the platform, shoulder-width apart. 3. Push the platform away by extending your legs, keeping your back against the pad. 4. Slowly return to the starting position by bending your knees.

Title: 30 Legs Leg Press Calf Raise
Desc: The 30 Legs Leg Press Calf Raise is a variation of the leg press that focuses on the calves. After performing the leg press, the exercise is completed by raising the heels to engage the calf muscles.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the leg press machine to your desired weight. 2. Sit on the machine and place your feet on the platform. 3. Perform a leg press by pushing the platform away. 4. At the end of the leg press, raise your heels to engage your calf muscles, then lower back down.

Title: 30 Legs Lying Leg Curl
Desc: The 30 Legs Lying Leg Curl is an isolation exercise that targets the hamstrings. Performed on a lying leg curl machine, it involves curling the legs towards the glutes to strengthen the back of the thighs.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the lying leg curl machine to your desired weight. 2. Lie face down on the machine and position your legs under the padded lever. 3. Curl your legs towards your glutes, squeezing your hamstrings. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Machine Hack Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Machine Hack Squat targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. Position yourself on the machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back straight, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.
HowTo: Position yourself on the machine with your back against the pad and feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body by bending your knees while keeping your back straight, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Extension
Desc: The 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Extension isolates the quadriceps on one leg at a time. Sit on the leg extension machine, adjust the pad to rest on your lower leg, and extend your leg upward while keeping your back against the seat. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.
HowTo: Sit on the leg extension machine, adjust the pad to rest on your lower leg, and extend your leg upward while keeping your back against the seat. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching legs.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Press
Desc: The 30 Legs Single-Leg Leg Press focuses on the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. Push the platform away by extending your leg, then slowly return to the starting position. This exercise helps to improve balance and strength in each leg individually.
HowTo: Sit on the leg press machine and place one foot on the platform. Push the platform away by extending your leg, then slowly return to the starting position. This exercise helps to improve balance and strength in each leg individually.

Title: 30 Legs Single-Leg Lying Leg Curl
Desc: The 30 Legs Single-Leg Lying Leg Curl targets the hamstrings. Lie face down on the leg curl machine and place one ankle under the pad. Curl your leg up towards your glutes, squeezing the hamstring at the top, then lower back down. Perform the desired reps before switching to the other leg.
HowTo: Lie face down on the leg curl machine and place one ankle under the pad. Curl your leg up towards your glutes, squeezing the hamstring at the top, then lower back down. Perform the desired reps before switching to the other leg.

Title: 30 Legs Smith Machine Split Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Smith Machine Split Squat is a great exercise for the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. Position the barbell on your upper back and stand in a split stance. Lower your body by bending your front knee while keeping your back leg straight, then push through your front heel to return to the starting position.
HowTo: Position the barbell on your upper back and stand in a split stance. Lower your body by bending your front knee while keeping your back leg straight, then push through your front heel to return to the starting position.

Title: 30 Legs Smith Machine Squat
Desc: The 30 Legs Smith Machine Squat is a compound exercise that targets the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. Set the barbell on your upper back, stand with feet shoulder-width apart, and squat down by bending your knees while keeping your chest up. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.
HowTo: Set the barbell on your upper back, stand with feet shoulder-width apart, and squat down by bending your knees while keeping your chest up. Push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Jumping rope
Desc: Jumping rope is a classic conditioning exercise that is popular with everyone from children to boxers to CrossFit athletes. It targets many different muscles, including the calves, glutes, shoulders, and upper back, and is great for everything from fat loss to improving overall athletic performance.
Muscles: Quadriceps, Calves, Glutes, Shoulders, Upper Back
HowTo: Hold the rope handles and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Swing the rope over your head and jump as it comes down towards your feet. Continue to jump in a rhythmic motion, keeping your core engaged and landing softly on your feet.

Title: Forward lunge
Desc: The forward lunge is a lower-body bodyweight exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. The forward lunge places more emphasis on the quads than other lunge variations. It can be performed for time or reps in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Step forward with one leg, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Ensure your front knee is directly above your ankle. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: Side-to-side box skip
Desc: The side-to-side box skip is an explosive lower-body exercise that involves jumping laterally over a bench or box, landing with one foot on top of the surface, and then switching positions. It primarily targets the muscles of the lower body, but is also a serious cardiovascular challenge. It is often performed for high reps or for time as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout or circuit.
HowTo: Stand next to a box or bench. Jump laterally to the side, landing with one foot on top of the box while the other foot remains on the ground. Push off the box and jump to the opposite side, landing with the other foot on the box. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Bodyweight squat
Desc: The bodyweight squat is a fundamental exercise that strengthens the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, for time or reps during a workout, or for hip and spine mobility any time.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body by bending your knees and pushing your hips back as if sitting in a chair. Keep your chest up and back straight. Go down until your thighs are parallel to the ground, then push through your heels to return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Broad jump
Desc: The broad jump is an explosive lower-body exercise. It is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the farther you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. Explode forward, jumping as far as you can while swinging your arms forward. Land softly with your knees slightly bent. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Burpee
Desc: The burpee is a high-intensity exercise that recruits the entire body to build strength and aerobic capacity. It is common in CrossFit workouts and group fitness classes, but can also be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Drop into a squat position with your hands on the ground. Kick your feet back into a plank position. Perform a push-up (optional). Jump your feet back to your hands, then explosively jump up, reaching your arms overhead. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Trail Running/Walking
Desc: Trail running/walking is an outdoor activity that combines running or walking on trails, often through natural landscapes. It provides a great cardiovascular workout while allowing participants to enjoy nature and improve their endurance. Suitable for various skill levels, it can be done on different terrains, making it a versatile exercise option.
HowTo: Choose a trail or path. Start walking or running at a comfortable pace. Focus on your breathing and enjoy the scenery. Adjust your speed and intensity based on your fitness level and the terrain. Continue for your desired distance or time.

Title: Scissors Jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward and the other back. Jump explosively, switching your legs in mid-air so that you land in a lunge with the opposite leg forward. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Jumping jack-
Desc: The jumping jack is a classic calisthenics exercise to improve overall conditioning. It’s one the most recognizable exercises on the planet, and it’s almost synonymous with training for military recruits. It can be done for time or reps, often in dynamic warm-ups or to mobilize the hips and shoulders.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Jump up while spreading your legs shoulder-width apart and raising your arms overhead. Land softly with your feet back together and arms at your sides. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Arms-crossed jump squat
Desc: The arms-crossed jump squat is an explosive version of the jump squat. Crossing your arms eliminates any extra power that could come from swinging your arms, making the movement extra strict and challenging for the lower body. It can be performed for time or reps and is especially effective in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and arms crossed over your chest. Lower into a squat, then jump explosively into the air while keeping your arms crossed. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Bodyweight Reverse Lunge
Desc: The reverse lunge is a lower-body exercise targeting the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. The reverse lunge places more emphasis on the glutes than other lunge variations.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step back with one leg into a lunge position, keeping your front knee over your ankle. Lower your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. Alternate legs.

Title: Alien Squat
Desc: The Alien Squat is a dynamic exercise that combines squatting with an alien-like arm movement to engage your core and lower body. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, squat down while extending your arms forward, and then return to standing.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down while extending your arms forward, mimicking an alien-like movement. Keep your back straight and core engaged. Return to standing by pushing through your heels and bringing your arms back to your sides.

Title: Treadmill walking
Desc: Treadmill walking is a popular cardiovascular exercise performed on a machine that is available in most gyms. Performing this exercise on a treadmill allows you to adjust the speed of your walking and, depending on the machine, perform it on an adjustable incline. Many machines also have built-in heart rate monitors and timers to help you track your progress.
HowTo: Step onto the treadmill and adjust the speed to your desired walking pace. Hold onto the handrails if needed for balance. Walk at a steady pace, adjusting the incline if desired to increase intensity. Monitor your heart rate and time as you walk.

Title: Rocket Jump
Desc: The Rocket Jump is an explosive plyometric exercise that targets your legs and improves your vertical leap. Start in a squat position, then jump as high as you can while reaching your arms overhead, landing softly back into the squat.
HowTo: Start in a squat position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Explode upwards, jumping as high as you can while reaching your arms overhead. Land softly back into the squat position to absorb the impact.

Title: Depth jump box jump
Desc: The depth jump box jump is a plyometric exercise that entails jumping off one box, dropping into a squat, and then jumping up onto another box. These are all performed fluidly to complete one rep. Depth jumps have been a staple of high-level athletic programming for decades. They are usually performed for low reps with a focus on power and technique. If they hurt your knees or back, consider performing box jumps or squat jumps instead.
HowTo: Stand on one box and step off, dropping into a squat as you land. Immediately jump up onto another box, using your arms to help propel you. Ensure a fluid motion throughout the movement, focusing on power and technique.

Title: Bodyweight Walking Lunge
Desc: The walking lunge is a lower-body exercise that targets the glutes, quads, and hamstrings while challenging stability and balance. It can be performed for reps, time, or distance in the lower-body portion of any workout.
HowTo: Stand upright with your feet together. Step forward with one leg into a lunge, lowering your hips until both knees are bent at about a 90-degree angle. Push through your front heel to return to standing and repeat with the opposite leg.

Title: Walking High Knees
Desc: Walking High Knees is a cardio exercise that involves marching in place while lifting your knees high towards your chest. This exercise helps improve coordination and warms up your lower body.
HowTo: Stand tall and march in place, lifting your knees high towards your chest with each step. Swing your arms in coordination with your legs to enhance the movement and maintain balance.

Title: Lateral lunge
Desc: The lateral lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that works the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It is often performed for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility routine but can also work in a circuit or other workouts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step out to the side with one leg, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. Push through your bent leg to return to the starting position. Alternate sides.

Title: Jump Squat
Desc: The jump squat is an explosive bodyweight exercise targeting the quads, hamstrings, and glutes. It is also a serious cardiovascular challenge when done for reps. It can be performed as a power exercise to build jumping power, or in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat position, keeping your chest up and knees behind your toes. Explode upwards, jumping as high as you can while extending your arms overhead. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Over bench jump
Desc: The over bench jump is a plyometric exercise requiring only a weight bench to perform. It improves jumping ability and athleticism while burning a lot of calories.
HowTo: Stand facing a weight bench. Bend your knees and jump over the bench, landing softly on the other side. Immediately jump back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Split Jump
Desc: The alternating lunge jump is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the lower-body muscles, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can be performed for time or reps in power training, and is also effective in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with one foot forward. Jump explosively, switching your legs mid-air so that you land in a lunge with the opposite leg forward. Continue alternating legs for the desired time or reps.

Title: 90-degree jump squat
Desc: The 90-degree jump squat is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets the muscles of the lower body, including the quads, glutes, and hamstrings, as well as the cardiovascular system. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower into a squat, then jump explosively while turning 90 degrees in the air. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Skip
Desc: The skip is an exercise that builds power and explosiveness in the legs. It's commonly performed by children and in gym classes, but is also great for working the legs and hip flexors, making it a favorite warm-up for athletes who need to explode vertically.
HowTo: Stand tall and begin to skip by lifting your knees high and swinging your arms in coordination. Focus on driving your knees up and landing softly on the balls of your feet.

Title: Kneeling hip flexor stretch
Desc: The kneeling hip flexor stretch is a stretch targeting greater flexibility in the front side of the hips. It targets a chronically tight muscle group and is often performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, a cool-down, or as recovery work after training.
HowTo: Start in a kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the other foot in front, bent at 90 degrees. Push your hips forward gently to feel a stretch in the hip flexor of the back leg. Hold for the desired duration, then switch sides.

Title: Iron Crosses (stretch)
Desc: The Iron Cross stretch is a dynamic flexibility exercise that targets the shoulders, chest, and back. It involves lying on your back and extending your arms and legs in a cross position, then alternating movements to stretch the upper and lower body.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms extended out to the sides and legs straight. Lift one leg and cross it over your body towards the opposite side while keeping your shoulders on the ground. Hold the stretch, then switch sides.

Title: All Fours Quad Stretch
Desc: The All Fours Quad Stretch is a flexibility exercise that targets the quadriceps and hip flexors. Begin on all fours, then bring one foot towards your glutes while keeping your knee bent, holding the stretch to enhance flexibility in the front of the thigh.
HowTo: Begin on all fours with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Bring one foot towards your glutes while keeping your knee bent, feeling the stretch in the quadriceps. Hold the position, then switch legs.

Title: Lying quad stretch with band
Desc: The lying quad stretch with band is a simple way to stretch a chronically tight muscle group of the lower body. It is common in stretching and yoga classes but can also be performed individually as part of a warm-up, paired with movements in a workout, or as part of a cool-down or recovery strategy.
HowTo: Lie on your back with a resistance band around your ankle. Pull the band towards you while keeping your knee straight to stretch the quadriceps. Hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: One Half Locust
Desc: The One Half Locust is an exercise that targets the back muscles and improves flexibility. To perform this exercise, lie face down on the floor, lift one leg off the ground while keeping the other leg and arms extended. Hold for a few seconds and switch legs.
HowTo: Lie face down on the floor. Lift one leg off the ground while keeping your arms extended. Hold the position for a few seconds, then lower your leg and switch to the other leg.

Title: Standing Hip Flexors
Desc: The Standing Hip Flexors exercise stretches the hip flexor muscles. Stand tall and take a step back with one leg while bending the front knee. Keep your back leg straight and push your hips forward to feel the stretch in the hip flexor of the back leg.
HowTo: Stand tall and take a step back with one leg. Bend your front knee while keeping your back leg straight. Push your hips forward to feel the stretch in the hip flexor of the back leg. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Looking At Ceiling
Desc: Looking At Ceiling is an exercise that helps improve neck mobility. Lie on your back and gently turn your head to look at the ceiling, keeping your shoulders relaxed. Hold for a few seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: Lie on your back. Gently turn your head to look at the ceiling while keeping your shoulders relaxed. Hold for a few seconds, then switch to the other side.

Title: Rear Leg Raises
Desc: Rear Leg Raises target the glutes and hamstrings. Stand with your feet hip-width apart, hinge at the hips, and lift one leg straight back while keeping your knee straight. Hold for a moment, then lower and switch legs.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Hinge at the hips and lift one leg straight back while keeping your knee straight. Hold for a moment, then lower your leg and switch to the other leg.

Title: On Your Side Quad Stretch
Desc: The On Your Side Quad Stretch is a great way to stretch the quadriceps. Lie on your side, bend your top knee, and grab your ankle to pull your heel towards your glutes. Keep your hips aligned and hold the stretch.
HowTo: Lie on your side with your legs stacked. Bend your top knee and grab your ankle, pulling your heel towards your glutes. Keep your hips aligned and hold the stretch for 15-30 seconds.

Title: On-Your-Back Quad Stretch
Desc: The On-Your-Back Quad Stretch is performed by lying on your back and pulling one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg straight. This helps stretch the quadriceps and hip flexors.
HowTo: Lie on your back. Pull one knee towards your chest while keeping the other leg straight on the ground. Hold the position for 15-30 seconds, then switch legs.

Title: Standing Elevated Quad Stretch
Desc: The Standing Elevated Quad Stretch involves standing on one leg and placing the other foot on an elevated surface. Pull your elevated foot towards your glutes to stretch the quadriceps of the standing leg.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and place the other foot on an elevated surface. Pull your elevated foot towards your glutes to stretch the quadriceps of the standing leg. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch legs.

Title: Thigh killa
Desc: The thigh killa is a challenging lower-body bodyweight exercise that builds muscular endurance with a series of hops and bodyweight squats. It can be performed for time or reps, usually in a circuit workout or as a lower-body finisher.
HowTo: Perform a series of hops followed by bodyweight squats. Focus on maintaining good form and control throughout the exercise. You can do this for a set time or a specific number of repetitions, typically as part of a circuit workout.

Title: Southpaw sprawl
Desc: The southpaw sprawl is a full-body movement that combines elements of a single-arm plank and a sprawl. It also has a rotational component, with a jumping leg-cross and torso twist in a single-arm plank position. It is a challenging move that trains balance, core strength, and many muscle groups, making it work well in a time-efficient bodyweight circuit workout.
HowTo: Start in a single-arm plank position. From there, perform a sprawl by dropping your hips and legs while simultaneously twisting your torso. As you return to the plank, jump your legs across and twist your torso, then repeat the movement to build balance and core strength.

Title: Stride Jump Crossover
Desc: The Stride Jump Crossover is an explosive exercise that combines a stride jump with a crossover step, enhancing agility and power. It involves jumping forward while crossing one leg over the other, focusing on landing softly and maintaining balance.
HowTo: Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Jump forward while crossing one leg over the other, landing softly on the balls of your feet. Focus on maintaining balance and control as you prepare for the next jump.

Title: Side Standing Long Jump
Desc: The Side Standing Long Jump is a lateral movement exercise that improves leg strength and coordination. Stand on one leg and jump sideways as far as possible, landing on the same leg. Repeat on the other side for balanced development.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and jump sideways as far as possible, landing on the same leg. Maintain balance upon landing, then repeat the jump on the opposite leg for balanced strength and coordination.

Title: Wall squat
Desc: The wall squat is a bodyweight exercise targeting the quadriceps, as well as other muscles in the lower body and core. The lifter's back is flat against a wall, and the back slides down and up the wall during each rep. If you don't have a smooth wall to slide on, the exercise can also be performed with an exercise ball between the back and the wall.
HowTo: Stand with your back against a wall and slide down into a squat position, keeping your back flat against the wall. Hold the squat for a moment, then slide back up to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Slide Jump Shot
Desc: The Slide Jump Shot is a dynamic basketball drill that combines jumping and shooting. Start in a low stance, slide to one side, jump to shoot the ball at the peak of your jump, and focus on form and accuracy.
HowTo: Start in a low athletic stance. Slide to one side, then jump and shoot the basketball at the peak of your jump. Focus on your shooting form and accuracy as you execute the drill.

Title: Sprawl frog kick
Desc: The sprawl frog kick is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets multiple muscle groups across the upper and lower body. It is similar to a traditional sprawl, but with an extra hop in the middle of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position, then drop into a sprawl by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back. Perform a frog kick by bringing your knees towards your chest and then jumping back up explosively. Repeat for time or reps.

Title: Lateral Speed Step
Desc: The Lateral Speed Step is a quick footwork drill that enhances lateral agility and speed. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and step side to side quickly, focusing on maintaining a low center of gravity and quick foot movement.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Quickly step side to side, maintaining a low center of gravity. Focus on fast foot movement and agility as you perform the drill.

Title: Side Hop-Sprint
Desc: The Side Hop-Sprint is a dynamic exercise that combines lateral hops with a sprint to improve agility, speed, and cardiovascular endurance. Start by hopping side to side for a set distance, then immediately sprint forward for a short distance.
HowTo: Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and engage your core. Begin hopping side to side for a set distance, landing softly on your feet.
