Desc: Start in a squat position with hands on the ground. Jump back into a plank, perform a renegade row by pulling one arm up towards your side, then jump forward back into a squat and punch forward.
HowTo: Start in a squat position with hands on the ground. Jump back into a plank, perform a renegade row by pulling one arm up towards your side, then jump forward back into a squat and punch forward.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl
Desc: Start in a bear crawl position with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Move forward by crawling on hands and feet, keeping your back flat and core engaged.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Move forward by crawling on your hands and feet, keeping your back flat and core engaged.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Donkey Kick
Desc: Begin in a bear crawl position. Transition to a donkey kick by lifting one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the other leg stable, then return to the bear crawl position.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position. Lift one leg towards the ceiling to perform a donkey kick while keeping the other leg stable, then return to the bear crawl position.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Froggy Push-Up
Desc: Start in a bear crawl position. Lower your body to perform a push-up, then push back up and transition into a froggy position by bringing your feet forward and squatting.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position. Lower your body to perform a push-up, then push back up and transition into a froggy position by bringing your feet forward and squatting.

Title: Holman Bear Crawl to Shoulder Tap
Desc: Begin in a bear crawl position. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder while maintaining a stable core, then alternate sides.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position. Lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder while maintaining a stable core, then alternate sides.

Title: Holman Burpee to Tuck Jump
Desc: Start in a standing position. Perform a burpee by dropping into a squat, kicking your feet back into a plank, returning to squat, and jumping up with knees tucked.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Drop into a squat to perform a burpee, kick your feet back into a plank, return to squat, and jump up with your knees tucked.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust to Tuck Jump
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Perform a burpee, then after the jump, transition into a flying squat thrust by landing into a squat and thrusting back into a plank.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Perform a burpee, then after the jump, land into a squat and transition into a flying squat thrust by thrusting back into a plank.

Title: Holman Forward Lunge to Reverse Lunge
Desc: Start in a standing position. Step forward into a lunge, then push back to standing and step back into a reverse lunge, alternating legs.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward into a lunge, then push back to standing and step back into a reverse lunge, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Renegade Lunge Jump
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Step into a lunge, then jump explosively to switch legs in mid-air, landing in a lunge on the opposite side.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Step into a lunge, then jump explosively to switch legs in mid-air, landing in a lunge on the opposite side.

Title: Holman Squat Jump to Lunge Jump
Desc: The Holman Squat Jump to Lunge Jump combines a squat jump with a lunge jump, targeting the legs and improving explosive power. Start in a squat position, jump up explosively, and land softly into a lunge position.
HowTo: Start in a squat position with feet shoulder-width apart. Jump up explosively, extending your legs and arms upward. As you land, transition into a lunge by stepping one foot forward and bending both knees. Alternate legs with each jump.

Title: Holman Prisoner Reverse Lunge
Desc: The Holman Prisoner Reverse Lunge involves stepping back into a lunge while keeping your hands behind your head. This exercise strengthens the legs and engages the core for stability.
HowTo: Stand with feet hip-width apart and hands behind your head. Step back with one leg into a lunge, keeping your torso upright. Push through the front heel to return to the starting position. Alternate legs.

Title: Holman Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump focuses on transitioning from a wide squat to a narrow squat jump, enhancing leg strength and agility. Begin in a wide squat, jump up, and land in a narrow squat.
HowTo: Begin in a wide squat position with feet wider than shoulder-width. Jump up explosively, bringing your legs together in the air. Land softly into a narrow squat position. Repeat the jump back to wide squat.

Title: Holman Donkey Run
Desc: The Holman Donkey Run is a dynamic exercise that mimics a running motion while on all fours. It engages the core, shoulders, and legs, improving overall coordination and strength.
HowTo: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Engage your core and mimic a running motion by lifting one knee towards your chest while extending the opposite arm forward. Alternate sides quickly.

Title: Holman Weighted Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Weighted Wide-to-Narrow Squat Jump adds resistance to the wide-to-narrow squat jump, increasing the intensity of the workout. Use a weight plate or dumbbells while performing the exercise.
HowTo: Hold a weight plate or dumbbells at chest level. Start in a wide squat position. Jump up explosively, bringing your legs together in the air, and land softly into a narrow squat position. Ensure to maintain control of the weights throughout.

Title: Holman Wide-to-Narrow Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Wide-to-Narrow Donkey Kick involves transitioning from a wide position to a narrow position while performing donkey kicks. This targets the glutes and core effectively.
HowTo: Begin in a wide position on all fours. Perform a donkey kick by lifting one leg towards the ceiling while keeping the knee bent. Transition to a narrow position by bringing the knee in closer to the body before kicking back again. Alternate legs.

Title: Holman Mule Kick
Desc: The Holman Mule Kick is a variation of the donkey kick, focusing on kicking the leg back while maintaining core stability. It helps strengthen the glutes and lower back.
HowTo: Start on all fours with hands under shoulders and knees under hips. Keeping your core engaged, lift one leg straight back while squeezing the glutes. Lower the leg back down and repeat on the other side.

Title: Holman Goal Post to Squat
Desc: The Holman Goal Post to Squat combines an arm movement resembling a goal post with a squat, engaging both the upper and lower body. It enhances coordination and strength.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and arms bent at 90 degrees like a goal post. Lower into a squat while keeping your arms in position. Push through your heels to return to standing, maintaining the arm position throughout.

Title: Holman Frogger Squat to Heel Click
Desc: The Holman Frogger Squat to Heel Click is a dynamic exercise that combines a frogger movement with a squat and a heel click. Start in a squat position, jump forward into a frogger position, then return to squat and perform a heel click before repeating.
HowTo: Start in a squat position with feet shoulder-width apart. Jump forward into a frogger position by placing your hands on the ground and landing in a squat. Return to the squat position and perform a heel click by jumping and bringing your heels together. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Stair Sprint
Desc: The Holman Stair Sprint is a high-intensity exercise that involves sprinting up a flight of stairs as quickly as possible. This exercise improves cardiovascular fitness and leg strength.
HowTo: Stand at the bottom of a flight of stairs. Sprint up the stairs as quickly as possible, using your arms to drive your legs. Focus on maintaining a fast pace and good form. Repeat for the desired number of sets.

Title: Holman Stair Bear Crawl
Desc: The Holman Stair Bear Crawl is a full-body workout that involves crawling up a flight of stairs on all fours. This exercise engages the core, shoulders, and legs while enhancing coordination.
HowTo: Start at the bottom of a flight of stairs. Get on all fours and begin crawling up the stairs, alternating your hands and feet. Keep your core engaged and maintain a steady pace. Continue until you reach the top.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust
Desc: The Holman Burpee to Flying Squat Thrust is a challenging exercise that combines a burpee with a flying squat thrust. Start with a burpee, then jump into a flying squat thrust position, engaging your core and legs.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground to perform a burpee. Jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump forward into a squat. From the squat, jump into a flying squat thrust position, engaging your core and legs. Repeat the sequence.

Title: Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Push-Up
Desc: The Holman Flying Squat Thrust to Push-Up is a compound exercise that transitions from a flying squat thrust into a push-up. This movement targets the chest, shoulders, and legs while improving overall strength.
HowTo: Start in a flying squat thrust position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body into a squat and then place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a push-up position. Perform a push-up, then jump your feet back to the flying squat thrust position. Repeat.

Title: Holman Foot-Elevated Step-To-Lunge
Desc: The Holman Foot-Elevated Step-To-Lunge is an exercise that involves stepping onto an elevated surface with one foot and then lunging forward with the other leg. This targets the quads, hamstrings, and glutes.
HowTo: Stand in front of an elevated surface. Place one foot on the elevated surface and step up, bringing the other foot to meet it. From this position, lunge forward with the leg that is not on the elevated surface. Push back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Holman Split Lunge
Desc: The Holman Split Lunge is a lower-body exercise that involves stepping one leg forward into a lunge position while keeping the back leg straight. This exercise enhances balance and strengthens the legs.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Step one leg forward into a lunge position, keeping your back leg straight and your front knee over your ankle. Push back to the starting position and switch legs. Repeat the movement, alternating legs.

Title: Holman Stair Climb
Desc: The Holman Stair Climb is a cardiovascular exercise that involves repeatedly climbing a flight of stairs. This workout targets the legs and improves cardiovascular endurance.
HowTo: Begin at the bottom of a flight of stairs. Step up onto the first step with one foot, then bring the other foot up to meet it. Continue stepping up one step at a time until you reach the top. Focus on a steady pace and good posture.

Title: Holman Burpee to Flying Jack
Desc: Start in a standing position, perform a Holman Burpee by dropping into a squat, kicking your feet back into a plank position, returning to the squat, and then jumping into a Flying Jack.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Drop into a squat, then kick your feet back into a plank position. Return to the squat position and jump into a Flying Jack.

Title: Holman Right Reverse Lunge
Desc: Stand upright, step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle, then return to standing.
HowTo: Stand upright. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle. Return to standing.

Title: Holman Left Reverse Lunge
Desc: Stand upright, step back with your left leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle, then return to standing.
HowTo: Stand upright. Step back with your left leg into a reverse lunge, keeping your front knee over your ankle. Return to standing.

Title: Holman Squat Tap to Hop
Desc: Begin in a squat position, tap one foot out to the side, then jump up explosively, landing softly back into the squat.
HowTo: Begin in a squat position. Tap one foot out to the side, then jump up explosively. Land softly back into the squat position.

Title: Holman Squat Tap to Jump-Forward-Jump-Back
Desc: Start in a squat position, tap one foot forward, then jump forward and back while maintaining the squat position.
HowTo: Start in a squat position. Tap one foot forward, then jump forward and back while maintaining the squat position.

Title: Holman Squat Hip Drive
Desc: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, squat down, then drive through your heels to stand up while thrusting your hips forward.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Squat down, then drive through your heels to stand up while thrusting your hips forward.

Title: Holman Alternating Double Lunge Hop
Desc: Start in a standing position, lunge forward with one leg, then hop and switch legs, alternating between lunges and hops.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Lunge forward with one leg, then hop and switch legs, alternating between lunges and hops.

Title: Holman Right Reverse Lunge to Front Kick
Desc: Stand upright, step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, then drive your knee forward into a front kick as you return to standing.
HowTo: Stand upright. Step back with your right leg into a reverse lunge, then drive your knee forward into a front kick as you return to standing.

Title: Holman Right Leg Forward Lunge Hop
Desc: Start in a standing position. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge, then explosively hop up, switching legs in the air, landing in a lunge with your left leg forward.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward with your right leg into a lunge, then explosively hop up, switching legs in the air, landing in a lunge with your left leg forward.

Title: Holman Right Squat Thrust
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump your feet back to your hands and return to standing.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump your feet back to your hands and return to standing.

Title: Holman Left Reverse Lunge to Front Kick
Desc: Start in a standing position. Step back with your left leg into a reverse lunge, then kick your right leg forward as you return to standing.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step back with your left leg into a reverse lunge, then kick your right leg forward as you return to standing.

Title: Holman Left Leg Forward Lunge Hop
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge, then explosively hop up, switching legs in the air, landing in a lunge with your right leg forward.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Step forward with your left leg into a lunge, then explosively hop up, switching legs in the air, landing in a lunge with your right leg forward.

Title: Holman Left Side Diagonal Burpee
Desc: Start in a standing position. Jump down into a squat, place your hands on the ground, kick your legs back into a plank, then jump your feet back towards your hands and jump up, reaching your arms overhead.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Jump down into a squat, place your hands on the ground, kick your legs back into a plank, then jump your feet back towards your hands and jump up, reaching your arms overhead.

Title: Holman Left Squat Thrust
Desc: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump your feet back to your hands and return to standing.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, jump your feet back into a plank position, then jump your feet back to your hands and return to standing.

Title: Holman Wide Squat Thrust
Desc: Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. Drop into a squat and then thrust your legs back into a plank position, followed by jumping back to the squat position.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. Drop into a squat and then thrust your legs back into a plank position, followed by jumping back to the squat position.

Title: Holman Alternating Single-Leg Hop to Squat to 180 Jump
Desc: Begin in a standing position on one leg. Hop forward, land softly, then transition into a squat. From the squat, jump 180 degrees, landing facing the opposite direction.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position on one leg. Hop forward, land softly, then transition into a squat. From the squat, jump 180 degrees, landing facing the opposite direction.

Title: Holman Right Lunge Hop to Chest Press
Desc: Begin in a lunge position with your right leg forward. Perform a hop while bringing your chest press weights forward. Land softly and repeat.
HowTo: Begin in a lunge position with your right leg forward. Perform a hop while bringing your chest press weights forward. Land softly and repeat.

Title: Holman Left Lunge Hop to Overhead Press
Desc: Start in a lunge position with your left leg forward. Jump up and press the weights overhead as you land back into the lunge.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with your left leg forward. Jump up and press the weights overhead as you land back into the lunge.

Title: Holman 180 Jump Hop Forward Hop Back
Desc: Start in a standing position, jump forward 180 degrees, land softly, and then hop back to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, jump forward 180 degrees, land softly, and then hop back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Right Split Squat
Desc: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, step back with your right leg into a split squat, keeping your front knee over your ankle.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, step back with your right leg into a split squat, keeping your front knee over your ankle.

Title: Holman Left Split Squat
Desc: Stand tall, step back with your left leg into a split squat, ensuring your front knee does not extend past your toes.
HowTo: Stand tall, step back with your left leg into a split squat, ensuring your front knee does not extend past your toes.

Title: Holman Double Squat Pulse to 180 Jump
Desc: Begin in a squat position, pulse twice at the bottom, then explode into a 180-degree jump, landing softly.
HowTo: Begin in a squat position, pulse twice at the bottom, then explode into a 180-degree jump, landing softly.

Title: Holman Towel Left Side Squat
Desc: Stand with a towel under your left foot, squat down while keeping tension on the towel, then return to standing.
HowTo: Stand with a towel under your left foot, squat down while keeping tension on the towel, then return to standing.

Title: Holman Alternating Lunge Jump
Desc: Start in a standing position, alternate jumping forward into a lunge, landing softly and switching legs with each jump.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, alternate jumping forward into a lunge, landing softly and switching legs with each jump.

Title: Holman Lunge Jump to Squat Jump
Desc: The Holman Lunge Jump to Squat Jump is a dynamic exercise that combines a lunge jump followed by a squat jump, targeting the legs, glutes, and core while improving explosive strength and coordination.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward into a lunge position, jumping off the ground explosively. As you land, transition into a squat jump by lowering your body into a squat and then jumping up again. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Burpee with Belly Touch
Desc: The Holman Burpee with Belly Touch is a full-body exercise that involves performing a burpee followed by a belly touch on the ground, enhancing cardiovascular endurance, strength, and agility.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Drop into a squat and place your hands on the ground. Kick your feet back into a plank position. Perform a push-up if desired. Jump your feet back toward your hands, then jump up and touch your belly with your hands before landing back on the ground. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Bootstrapper squat
Desc: The bootstrapper squat is a movement that improves mobility, muscular strength, and flexibility in the hips and hamstrings. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the lower body to mobilize the hips and improve squat form.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your body into a squat. Place your hands on the ground in front of you, then walk your hands out to a plank position. From there, walk your feet toward your hands and return to the squat position. Stand up and repeat.

Title: Total Fitness Broad Jump
Desc: The broad jump is an explosive lower-body exercise. It is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the farther you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. Explode forward, jumping as far as you can while swinging your arms forward for momentum. Land softly on your feet and reset for the next jump.

Title: Total Fitness Lateral Lunge
Desc: The lateral lunge is a lower-body bodyweight movement that works the quads, glutes, and hamstrings. It can also be performed holding dumbbells or other weights. It is often performed for reps as part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility routine but can also work in a circuit or other workouts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet together. Step out to the side with one leg, bending that knee while keeping the other leg straight. Push through the bent leg to return to the starting position. Alternate sides for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Lateral shuffle
Desc: The lateral shuffle is a common exercise in sports training and gym classes. It involves taking steps to one side and then steps to the other side. It can be performed as part of a circuit for athletes of any level, but is also a great movement for beginners.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Take a step to the right, bending your knees slightly and keeping your feet low to the ground. Quickly step back to the left, maintaining a low position. Continue alternating sides for the desired duration.

Title: Total Fitness Skip
Desc: The skip is an exercise that builds power and explosiveness in the legs. It's commonly performed by children and in gym classes, but is also great for working the legs and hip flexors, making it a favorite warm-up for athletes who need to explode vertically.
HowTo: Stand tall with your feet together. Begin by lifting one knee up towards your chest while simultaneously driving the opposite arm forward. Step forward with the opposite leg, landing softly and repeating the motion in a rhythmic manner.

Title: Total Fitness Spider Lunge
Desc: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step forward with one leg into a lunge position, keeping your back leg straight. Place both hands on the ground inside your front foot. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then switch legs and repeat.

Title: Spider lunge stretch
Desc: The spider lunge stretch is a lower-body stretch targeting the hips, groin, and quads. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up or mobility work performed anytime.
HowTo: Start in a lunge position with your right foot forward and your left leg extended back. Lower your hips toward the ground while keeping your right foot flat and your left knee off the ground. Hold for a moment, then switch sides.

Title: Spider lunge with T-rotation
Desc: The spider lunge with T-rotation is an exercise that produces a deep stretch in the glutes and hamstrings while also rotating and mobilizing the thoracic spine region. It is a great movement to include in a dynamic warm-up, or as mobility work anytime.
HowTo: Begin in a lunge position with your right foot forward. Place your left hand on the ground inside your right foot. Rotate your torso to the right and extend your right arm upward. Hold the position, then return to the starting lunge and switch sides.

Title: Standing quad stretch
Desc: The standing quad stretch is a simple exercise designed to stretch the quadriceps, the big muscles that cover most of the thighs. This is a static stretch, meaning it’s usually performed by holding the stretched position for a certain length of time.
HowTo: Stand on one leg and pull your other foot towards your glutes, holding it with your hand. Keep your knees close together and push your hips forward to deepen the stretch. Hold for a specified duration, then switch legs.

Title: Vertical jump
Desc: The vertical jump is an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. Explode upward, jumping as high as you can while swinging your arms forward. Land softly and repeat.

Title: King Maker Burpee
Desc: The burpee is a high-intensity exercise that recruits the entire body to build strength and aerobic capacity. It is common in CrossFit workouts and group fitness classes, but can also be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Drop into a squat, placing your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a plank position. Perform a push-up (optional), then jump your feet back to your hands and explode upward into a jump. Repeat.

Title: King Maker Explosive High Jump
Desc: The tuck jump is a vertical jump, an explosive lower-body exercise that is a common way to measure explosive hip and lower-body strength in athletes. The more explosive you are, the higher you'll be able to jump.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and jump upward, tucking your knees towards your chest. Land softly and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Muscle Beach Skip
Desc: A dynamic exercise that combines skipping with a focus on agility and cardiovascular endurance, often performed on the beach for added resistance and enjoyment.
HowTo: Begin by skipping forward, focusing on light and quick footwork. Use your arms to drive the movement and maintain a steady rhythm. Incorporate changes in direction or speed for added agility.

Title: Muscle Beach Broad Jump
Desc: A powerful plyometric exercise that involves jumping as far as possible from a standing position, targeting leg strength and explosiveness, commonly practiced on sandy surfaces for added challenge.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees and swing your arms back. Jump forward as far as you can, landing softly on your feet. Measure the distance and repeat for multiple attempts.

Title: Muscle Beach Sprint
Desc: A high-intensity sprinting exercise performed on the beach, focusing on speed and agility.
HowTo: Start by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Sprint forward on the beach, focusing on quick, explosive movements. Keep your arms bent at 90 degrees and pump them as you run. Aim for maximum speed and agility, and maintain a steady pace for the duration of the sprint.

Title: Muscle Beach Front Kick
Desc: A dynamic kick that targets the front of the body, enhancing leg strength and flexibility.
HowTo: Stand with your feet hip-width apart. Lift one knee and extend the opposite leg forward in a kicking motion, keeping your core engaged. Alternate legs, ensuring to maintain balance and control throughout the movement. Focus on the strength and flexibility of your legs.

Title: Muscle Beach Side Kick
Desc: A lateral kick that improves hip mobility and strengthens the outer thigh muscles.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position with feet together. Step to the side with one leg and perform a lateral kick, keeping your body upright. Engage your core and focus on the outer thigh as you kick. Alternate sides to improve hip mobility and strength.

Title: Muscle Beach Spin Kick
Desc: A spinning kick that combines balance and power, targeting opponents from different angles.
HowTo: Start in a fighting stance. Pivot on your supporting foot and spin your body to execute a kick with your other leg. Aim to strike with the heel or the side of your foot, using your core for balance and power. Practice the movement to improve your technique and accuracy.

Title: Muscle Beach Freestyle Kick
Desc: A versatile kick that incorporates various movements, promoting overall leg strength and coordination.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Perform a series of kicks by alternating legs, incorporating different angles and heights. Focus on maintaining balance and control, while engaging your core for stability. This exercise promotes overall leg strength and coordination.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge To Squat
Desc: A compound exercise that combines a curtsy lunge with a squat, targeting the glutes and quads.
HowTo: Begin by standing with your feet together. Step back into a curtsy lunge with one leg while keeping the other leg bent in front. Push back to the starting position and immediately lower into a squat. Repeat the sequence, alternating legs to target the glutes and quads effectively.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Curtsy Lunge With High Knee
Desc: A dynamic exercise that alternates between a curtsy lunge and a high knee, enhancing lower body strength and cardio.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step back into a curtsy lunge with one leg, then drive that knee up towards your chest as you return to standing. Alternate legs, ensuring to keep your movements fluid and controlled to enhance lower body strength and cardio.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Diagonal Sprawl
Desc: A full-body movement that involves a diagonal sprawl, engaging core muscles and improving agility.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Step one leg back and to the side into a sprawl position, while reaching your arms forward. Engage your core as you return to standing and repeat the movement diagonally. This full-body exercise improves agility and core strength.

Title: MetaBurn Alternating Lateral Sprawl
Desc: The MetaBurn Alternating Lateral Sprawl is a dynamic exercise that targets the core and lower body. Start in a standing position, then squat down and place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet out to the sides, alternating between left and right, while keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Squat down and place your hands on the ground. Jump your feet out to the sides, alternating between left and right, while keeping your core engaged.

Title: MetaBurn Curtsy Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Curtsy Lunge is a lower body exercise that strengthens the glutes, quads, and hamstrings. Begin in a standing position, step one leg back and to the side into a curtsy position, bending both knees. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position. Step one leg back and to the side into a curtsy position, bending both knees. Return to standing and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Frogger
Desc: The MetaBurn Frogger is a full-body movement that enhances agility and coordination. Start in a squat position with your hands on the ground. Jump your feet forward towards your hands, then jump back to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a squat position with your hands on the ground. Jump your feet forward towards your hands, then jump back to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn High Knee Rotation
Desc: The MetaBurn High Knee Rotation is a cardio exercise that increases heart rate while engaging the core. Stand tall and alternate bringing your knees up towards your chest while rotating your torso to the side, engaging your obliques.
HowTo: Stand tall and alternate bringing your knees up towards your chest while rotating your torso to the side, engaging your obliques.

Title: MetaBurn Side-To-Side Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Side-To-Side Lunge is a lateral movement that targets the inner and outer thighs. Step to the side into a lunge position, keeping your opposite leg straight, then push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Step to the side into a lunge position, keeping your opposite leg straight. Push back to the starting position and repeat on the other side.

Title: MetaBurn Star Jump
Desc: The MetaBurn Star Jump is an explosive plyometric exercise that works the entire body. Start in a squat position, then jump up while spreading your arms and legs out like a star, landing softly back into the squat.
HowTo: Start in a squat position. Jump up while spreading your arms and legs out like a star, landing softly back into the squat.

Title: MetaBurn Tuck Jump With Knee Slap
Desc: The MetaBurn Tuck Jump With Knee Slap is a high-intensity exercise that builds power and coordination. Jump straight up, bringing your knees towards your chest, and slap your knees with your hands before landing softly.
HowTo: Jump straight up, bringing your knees towards your chest, and slap your knees with your hands before landing softly.

Title: MetaBurn Lateral Bounding Hop
Desc: The MetaBurn Lateral Bounding Hop is a plyometric exercise that improves lateral strength and stability. Jump sideways from one leg to the other, landing softly and maintaining balance before repeating.
HowTo: Jump sideways from one leg to the other, landing softly and maintaining balance before repeating.

Title: MetaBurn Double Lunge
Desc: The MetaBurn Double Lunge is a dynamic lower body exercise that targets the glutes, quadriceps, and hamstrings. Start in a standing position, step back into a lunge with one leg while keeping the front knee aligned over the ankle, then return to standing and switch legs.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Step back into a lunge with one leg, keeping the front knee aligned over the ankle. Return to standing and switch legs.

Title: Robertson Sprinter Step-Up
Desc: The Robertson Sprinter Step-Up is a powerful exercise that combines a step-up with a knee drive, targeting the legs and core. Begin by stepping onto a bench with one foot, driving the opposite knee up towards your chest, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Begin by stepping onto a bench with one foot. Drive the opposite knee up towards your chest. Return to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Front Kick-Through
Desc: The FYR2 Front Kick-Through is an agile movement that enhances hip mobility and core strength. Start in a plank position, kick one leg through to the opposite side while rotating your torso, then return to plank and repeat on the other side.
HowTo: Start in a plank position. Kick one leg through to the opposite side while rotating your torso. Return to plank and repeat on the other side.

Title: Lunge high-knee clap
Desc: The FYR2 Plyo Split Squat is an explosive lower body exercise that builds strength and power. Start in a split squat position, then jump and switch your legs mid-air, landing softly in a split squat on the opposite side.
HowTo: Start in a split squat position. Jump and switch your legs mid-air, landing softly in a split squat on the opposite side.

Title: FYR2 Plyo Split Squat
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee is a full-body exercise that combines a squat and a roll to build strength and coordination. Start in a standing position, squat down, roll back onto your shoulders, then roll forward and return to standing.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Squat down, roll back onto your shoulders, then roll forward and return to standing.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee to Regular Burpee is a compound movement that transitions from a reverse burpee into a standard burpee. Begin with a reverse burpee, then immediately move into a plank position and perform a regular burpee.
HowTo: Begin with a reverse burpee. Immediately move into a plank position and perform a regular burpee.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee to Regular Burpee
Desc: The FYR2 Reverse Burpee Tuck Jump is an advanced variation that combines a reverse burpee with a tuck jump. Start in a standing position, perform a reverse burpee, then explode upwards into a tuck jump before landing and repeating.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Perform a reverse burpee, then explode upwards into a tuck jump before landing and repeating.

Title: FYR2 Reverse Burpee Tuck Jump
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Perform a reverse burpee, then explode upwards into a tuck jump before landing and repeating.

Title: FYR2 Sprawlee
Desc: The FYR2 Sprawlee is a dynamic exercise that combines a sprawl with a jump, engaging the core, legs, and arms for a full-body workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, then drop into a sprawl by placing your hands on the ground and kicking your legs back into a plank position. Quickly return to your feet and jump explosively into the air, reaching your arms overhead.

Title: FYR2 Squat Hold
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Hold is an isometric exercise where you hold a squat position to build strength and endurance in the legs and glutes.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, lower your body into a squat position, and hold that position while keeping your back straight and your knees behind your toes. Engage your core and maintain the squat for the desired duration.

Title: FYR2 Squat Jump
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Jump is a plyometric exercise that involves performing a squat and then jumping explosively to increase power and agility.
HowTo: Begin in a standing position, lower into a squat, then explode upward into a jump. Land softly and immediately go back into the squat position for the next rep.

Title: FYR2 Squat Pulse
Desc: The FYR2 Squat Pulse is a variation of the squat where you pulse up and down in the squat position to target the quads and glutes.
HowTo: Lower into a squat position, then pulse up and down slightly without fully standing up. Keep your weight in your heels and your chest up, focusing on engaging your quads and glutes.

Title: Sprinter burpee
Desc: The sprinter burpee is an explosive version of the burpee exercise that adds a sprinter jump to the top of each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, drop into a squat, place your hands on the ground, kick your feet back into a plank position, perform a push-up if desired, then jump your feet back to your hands and explode upwards into a sprinter jump.

Title: Shuttle run training
Desc: Shuttle run training is an athletic conditioning drill that’s great for developing speed and power, as well as changing direction. It’s a favorite of football and basketball players, but it can also be great conditioning work for lifters and athletes of all ability levels.
HowTo: Set up two markers about 10-20 yards apart. Sprint from one marker to the other, touch the ground, and quickly return to the starting point. Repeat for the desired number of sets.

Title: Medicine ball ninja
Desc: The medicine ball ninja is a dynamic medicine ball movement that challenges both the upper and lower body, while also elevating the heart rate. It's a great movement to include in medicine ball or bodyweight circuit training to increase fatigue and burn serious calories while hammering the muscles of the legs.
HowTo: Hold a medicine ball at chest level, squat down, and then explosively throw the ball forward while jumping. Catch the ball on the way back down and repeat the movement.

Title: FYR Air Ball Plus Medicine Ball Jumping Sprawl
Desc: The medicine ball air ball to jumping sprawl is a series of bodyweight and medicine ball movement strung together into a single sequence. They collectively target virtually every muscle in the body, as well as seriously challenging the cardiovascular system. It can be a single-movement workout if done for high reps, or part of a larger circuit workout.
HowTo: Start with a medicine ball at your feet, squat down to pick it up, then jump back into a plank position. From the plank, perform a sprawl by bringing your feet back towards your hands, then jump up with the medicine ball overhead.

Title: Medicine ball cowboy squat
Desc: The medicine ball cowboy squat is an explosive exercise targeting the lower body, although several upper-body muscles play important supporting roles. The move involves performing jumping squats while holding a medicine ball overhead. It's commonly performed as part of a bodyweight and medicine ball circuit focused on fat loss or athleticism.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding a medicine ball overhead. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Lower your body into a squat position while keeping the medicine ball raised. 4. Explode upward into a jump, extending your legs and arms. 5. Land softly and immediately go into the next squat.

Title: Medicine ball jumping jill
Desc: The medicine ball jumping jill is an explosive medicine ball exercise that is similar to a jumping jack but performed holding a medicine ball between the hands. It can be performed for time or reps in a dynamic warm-up or fat-loss or conditioning circuit, usually paired with other bodyweight or medicine ball movements.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet together, holding a medicine ball between your hands. 2. Jump out to the side, spreading your legs while raising the medicine ball overhead. 3. Jump back to the starting position, bringing your legs together and lowering the ball. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps or time.

Title: Alternate Leg Diagonal Bound
Desc: A dynamic exercise that involves jumping from one leg to the opposite arm, promoting balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Start on one leg with the opposite arm extended forward. 2. Jump forward, landing on the opposite leg while reaching the opposite arm forward. 3. Balance on the landing leg before repeating the jump back to the starting position. 4. Alternate legs with each jump.

Title: Sit Squats
Desc: A lower body exercise where you squat down and hold the position, engaging the thighs and glutes.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a squat position, keeping your weight on your heels. 3. Hold the squat position, engaging your thighs and glutes. 4. Hold for a set amount of time before standing back up.

Title: Frog Hops
Desc: A plyometric exercise that involves jumping forward in a frog-like position, enhancing leg strength and explosiveness.
HowTo: 1. Start in a squat position with your hands on the ground. 2. Jump forward, landing in a squat position again. 3. Repeat the jump forward in a continuous motion, maintaining the frog-like position.

Title: Dumbbell lateral hop to sprint
Desc: The dumbbell lateral hop to sprint is a multi-part explosive exercise combining weighted hops with weighted sprinting. Adding dumbbells adds a challenge to the core and shoulders. Because balance can be a challenge, it is usually performed with relatively light weights, often as a component of fat-loss or athletic training.
HowTo: 1. Hold a dumbbell in each hand and stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Perform a lateral hop to the side, landing softly on one foot. 3. Immediately push off and sprint forward for a few steps. 4. Repeat the lateral hop and sprint for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine lunge sprint
Desc: The Smith machine lunge sprint is a lower-body power exercise performed with the bar of a Smith machine on the back. It is similar to an alternating jump lunge or "scissor lunge," but with added weight. The contained bar of the Smith machine makes it safer and less of a balance challenge than using a free weight.
HowTo: 1. Position the bar of the Smith machine on your back. 2. Step forward into a lunge position with one leg. 3. Push off the front leg and switch to the other leg, alternating lunges. 4. Maintain a steady rhythm and focus on your balance.

Title: Sissy squat
Desc: The sissy squat is a bodyweight squat variation that involves letting the knees travel far over the toes, placing an extreme stretch on the quads. This movement targets the quad muscles directly and can be performed in partial or full ranges of motion based on knee health and pain.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a squat, allowing your knees to travel over your toes. 3. Keep your torso upright and engage your core. 4. Hold the squat position for a set amount of time or rise back up to standing.

Title: Wall ball toss
Desc: The wall ball toss is an explosive full-body exercise utilizing a medicine ball. It involves squatting down, then explosively pressing a weighted ball into the air and catching it on a bounce off of a vertical surface. It is common in CrossFit workouts and can be performed for time or reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball at chest level. 2. Squat down until your thighs are parallel to the ground. 3. Explosively push through your heels to stand up while simultaneously pressing the medicine ball overhead. 4. Catch the ball as it bounces off the wall and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bosu Ball Squat
Desc: The Bosu Ball Squat is an exercise that targets the lower body, particularly the quadriceps, hamstrings, and glutes. Stand on the flat side of the Bosu ball with your feet shoulder-width apart. Lower your body into a squat position while maintaining balance on the ball. Ensure your knees do not extend past your toes. Hold the squat for a moment before returning to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the flat side of the Bosu ball with your feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Lower your body into a squat position while keeping your balance on the ball. 3. Ensure your knees do not extend past your toes. 4. Hold the squat for a moment, then push through your heels to return to the starting position.

Title: Exercise ball Bulgarian split squat
Desc: The exercise ball Bulgarian split squat is an exercise that builds the quads, hamstrings, and glutes one leg at a time. The exercise ball is used to support the trailing shin and foot. Due to the balance challenge, this version of the split squat is usually performed for moderate to high reps with body weight only or light weights in the hands. If balance is a problem, you can stick the ball in the corner of a room while performing the exercise.
HowTo: 1. Place an exercise ball behind you and rest your trailing shin and foot on it. 2. Stand in a split stance with your front foot flat on the ground. 3. Lower your body into a lunge, keeping your front knee aligned over your ankle. 4. Push through your front heel to return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch legs.

Title: Internal Rotation with Band
Desc: The Internal Rotation with Band is an exercise that focuses on strengthening the rotator cuff muscles. Attach a resistance band to a stable object at waist height. Stand with your side to the band, holding it with the hand closest to the attachment point. Keep your elbow bent at 90 degrees and pull the band towards your body, rotating your arm inward. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Attach a resistance band to a stable object at waist height. 2. Stand with your side to the band, holding it with the hand closest to the attachment point. 3. Keep your elbow bent at 90 degrees and pull the band towards your body, rotating your arm inward. 4. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Band Pull Apart
Desc: The band pull-apart is an exercise targeting the upper back muscles, including the trapezius, rear delts, and rhomboids. The band creates dynamic tension, allowing you to really focus on contracting these muscles, making it a great activation drill prior to upper-body lifting.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band with both hands in front of you at shoulder height. 2. Pull the band apart by extending your arms out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Back Flyes - With Bands
Desc: Back Flyes with Bands is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band in both hands. Bend slightly at the hips and keep your back straight. With your arms extended in front of you, pull the band apart while keeping your elbows slightly bent, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Return to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a resistance band in both hands. 2. Bend slightly at the hips while keeping your back straight. 3. With your arms extended in front of you, pull the band apart while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the end of the movement. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lateral Raise - With Bands
Desc: Lateral Raise with Bands is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. Stand on the center of a resistance band, holding the ends in each hand. With your arms at your sides, raise your arms out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower back down to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the center of a resistance band, holding the ends in each hand. 2. With your arms at your sides, raise your arms out to the side until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 3. Lower back down to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Shoulder Press - With Bands
Desc: Shoulder Press with Bands is an exercise that strengthens the shoulders and triceps. Stand on the center of a resistance band and hold the ends at shoulder height with your palms facing forward. Press the bands overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower back down to shoulder height and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Stand on the center of a resistance band and hold the ends at shoulder height with your palms facing forward. 2. Press the bands overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower back down to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: External Rotation with Band
Desc: Perform external rotation by holding a resistance band with both hands, keeping elbows at your sides, and rotating your forearms outward.
HowTo: Hold a resistance band with both hands, keeping your elbows at your sides. Rotate your forearms outward to perform the external rotation.

Title: FYR Band Pull-Apart
Desc: Stand with a resistance band held in both hands at shoulder height, pull the band apart by moving your arms outward while keeping your elbows slightly bent.
HowTo: Stand with a resistance band held in both hands at shoulder height. Pull the band apart by moving your arms outward while keeping your elbows slightly bent.

Title: HM Lateral Raise
Desc: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand, raise your arms to the side until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand. Raise your arms to the side until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.

Title: Rusin Banded Over-And-Back
Desc: Hold a resistance band with both hands, stretch it overhead and then bring it back behind your head, keeping your arms straight.
HowTo: Hold a resistance band with both hands. Stretch it overhead and then bring it back behind your head, keeping your arms straight.

Title: Rusin Banded Face Pull
Desc: Anchor a resistance band at chest height, hold the ends with both hands, and pull the band towards your face while squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Anchor a resistance band at chest height. Hold the ends with both hands and pull the band towards your face while squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: UP Band Pull-Apart
Desc: Stand with a resistance band held in front of you at shoulder height, pull the band apart while keeping your arms straight and engaging your back muscles.
HowTo: Stand with a resistance band held in front of you at shoulder height. Pull the band apart while keeping your arms straight and engaging your back muscles.

Title: Jordan Shallow Band-Resisted Thread the Needle
Desc: Kneel on the floor with a resistance band anchored in front of you, thread your arm through the band while maintaining a stable core and a straight back.
HowTo: Kneel on the floor with a resistance band anchored in front of you. Thread your arm through the band while maintaining a stable core and a straight back.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Banded Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: Sit on a bench with a barbell and a resistance band, press the barbell overhead while the band provides additional resistance.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a barbell and a resistance band. Press the barbell overhead while the band provides additional resistance.

Title: Band shoulder press
Desc: The band shoulder press is a deltoid exercise and an alternative to the classic dumbbell shoulder press. The dynamic tension of the band forces the core to stabilize the body and more closely matches the strength curve of the shoulder press. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, to build shoulder strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and for conditioning. It can work as the main focus of a shoulder day but is also popular as an accessory movement to the bench press or barbell military press.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band at shoulder height with both hands. Press the band overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position. Perform 5-8 reps for strength or 8-12 reps for muscle building.

Title: Band lateral raise
Desc: The band lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a variation of the dumbbell lateral raise, a staple strength-training move. The band lateral raise is a great option for warm-up or accessory work on upper-body training days. The dynamic tension of the band provides constant tension and matches the strength curve of the movement. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding the band at your sides. Raise your arms out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower back to the starting position. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Band upright row
Desc: The band upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders and similar to the dumbbell upright row. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. Using the band provides dynamic resistance and is easier on the shoulder than using a barbell. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the band with both hands in front of your thighs. Pull the band upwards towards your chin, keeping your elbows high and close to your body. Lower back to the starting position. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Staggered-stance band shoulder press
Desc: The staggered-stance band shoulder press is a deltoid exercise and a variation of the band shoulder press. The dynamic tension of the band forces the core to stabilize the body, and the staggered-stance provides more stability and relieves tension on the back. It can be performed in low reps, such as 5-8 reps per set, to build shoulder strength, or for higher reps to build muscle and for conditioning. It can work as the main focus of a shoulder day but is also popular as an accessory movement to the bench press or barbell military press.
HowTo: Stand in a staggered stance with one foot forward. Hold the band at shoulder height with both hands. Press the band overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position. Perform 5-8 reps for strength or 8-12 reps for muscle building.

Title: Single-arm banded landmine press
Desc: The single-arm banded landmine press is an upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The band adds constant tension and dynamic resistance to the exercise. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids and can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: Stand next to the landmine setup, holding the band attached to the barbell. Press the barbell overhead with one arm, keeping your core engaged. Lower it back to shoulder height. Perform 8-12 reps for strength or muscle building.

Title: Band front raise rear fly row combo
Desc: The band front raise rear fly row combo is a combination of three different shoulder exercises to build and strengthen the anterior, middle deltoids, and posterior portions of the shoulders. It requires a continuous loop band to provide constant, dynamic tension throughout the movement. In addition to the front and rear delts, this exercise works the arms, chest, back, and core, making it a great time-efficient shoulder burnout or accessory movement on an upper-body day.
Muscles: Anterior Deltoids, Medial Deltoids, Posterior Deltoids, Biceps, Triceps
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Hold the band with both hands and perform a front raise, then transition into a rear fly, and finish with a row. Ensure to maintain control throughout the movements. Perform 8-12 reps for each part.

Title: Jordan Shallow Foam Roller Thoracic Extension
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Foam Roller Thoracic Extension is an exercise designed to improve thoracic spine mobility and posture. It involves lying on a foam roller placed horizontally under the upper back and gently extending the thoracic spine over the roller while keeping the hips down. This movement helps to open up the chest and shoulders, relieving tension and promoting better alignment.
HowTo: Lie on a foam roller placed horizontally under your upper back. Keep your hips down and gently extend your thoracic spine over the roller. Hold for a few seconds, then return to the starting position. Repeat for 8-10 reps.

Title: Jordan Shallow Thread the Needle (with Foam Roller)
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Thread the Needle (with Foam Roller) is a mobility exercise that targets the thoracic spine and shoulders. In this exercise, you start in a tabletop position with a foam roller placed under one arm. You then reach the opposite arm under your body, threading it through while rotating your torso. This movement enhances flexibility and helps release tension in the upper back and shoulders.
HowTo: Start in a tabletop position with a foam roller under one arm. Reach the opposite arm under your body, rotating your torso as you thread it through. Hold for a moment, then return to the starting position. Perform 8-10 reps on each side.

Title: Clean and press
Desc: The clean and press is a full-body lift comprised of two movements: the clean, where the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases, followed by the overhead press. Decades ago, it was contested in the Olympics. Today, it remains a worthy centerpiece of a power and strength training program, and has full-body benefits when done for low reps as well as moderate to high reps.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the floor. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Initiate the clean by pulling the barbell off the floor, extending your hips and knees. 4. As the barbell reaches your knees, pull it up explosively, shrugging your shoulders and pulling yourself under the bar. 5. Catch the barbell in the front rack position with your elbows high. 6. From the front rack, press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 7. Lower the barbell back to the front rack and repeat.

Title: Clean and jerk
Desc: The clean and jerk is a full-body lift that is one of two contested lifts in Olympic weightlifting competitions. It is comprised of two movements: the clean, where the bar is pulled from the floor and caught in the front rack position in three pulls or phases, followed by the jerk overhead. The clean and jerk hits every muscle from head to toe and can be the centerpiece of a lifting program. It is also popular in CrossFit and athletic training programs. It is usually performed in low rep ranges, focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on the floor. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width. 3. Pull the barbell off the floor, extending your hips and knees to bring it to the front rack position. 4. From the front rack, dip slightly by bending your knees, then drive through your legs to push the barbell overhead in one explosive movement. 5. Lock out your arms overhead, ensuring your head is through the arms. 6. Lower the barbell back to the front rack and repeat.

Title: Military press
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell at shoulder height. 2. Keep your core tight and your back straight. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated barbell shoulder press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder press is a classic exercise for building muscle and strength in the shoulders. The triceps also play a significant role in pressing the barbell overhead. Performing the movement seated reduces help from the lower body and decreases the risk of overextending the lumbar spine during the movement. This press variation can be the primary pressing movement on an upper-body or shoulder day, or an effective accessory movement later in a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and grip the barbell at shoulder height. 2. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Snatch-Grip Behind-The-Neck Overhead Press
Desc: The Snatch-Grip Behind-The-Neck Overhead Press is a strength training exercise that targets the shoulders, upper back, and core. It involves gripping the barbell with a wide grip, lifting it from behind the neck to an overhead position, which enhances shoulder stability and strength. This exercise is beneficial for developing explosive power and improving overall upper body strength.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with a wide grip behind your neck. 2. Engage your core and keep your back straight. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back behind your neck in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing Bradford press
Desc: The standing Bradford press is an obscure yet effective shoulder exercise that alternates front presses with behind-the-neck presses. It can be used as a warm-up for other press variations on a shoulder day, or as a muscle-building movement on its own in a shoulder or upper-body focused workout. It is usually performed for relatively high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set or higher, or just to the point of fatigue.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the barbell overhead, then lower it back to shoulder height. 3. Immediately transition to a behind-the-neck press by lowering the barbell behind your neck and pressing it overhead again. 4. Alternate between front and behind-the-neck presses for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder pressis a classic exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also play a significant roles in pressing the barbell overhead.
HowTo: 1. Sit with your back against a bench and grip the barbell at shoulder height. 2. Keep your core tight and your back straight. 3. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell rear delt bent-over row
Desc: The barbell rear delt bent-over row is a movement used to target the shoulders as well as the upper-back muscles. It is performed with lighter weights than a traditional barbell bent-over row, and is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of a back or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands, palms facing you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to lower your torso, keeping your back straight. 3. Pull the barbell towards your chest, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell upright row
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. Pull the barbell straight up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Bradford/Rocky Presses
Desc: The Bradford/Rocky Presses are a compound exercise targeting the shoulders and triceps, performed by pressing weights overhead while seated or standing. This exercise helps to build upper body strength and stability.
HowTo: Sit or stand with a barbell at shoulder height. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Lying rear delt fly
Desc: The lying rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the rear deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement lying face down on a bench, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the weights out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the floor. Lower the weights back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine Shoulder (Military) Press
Desc: The machine shoulder press is an upper body exercise targeting the deltoids.
HowTo: Sit at the machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. Grasp the handles and press them upward until your arms are fully extended. Lower the handles back to shoulder level. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing Barbell Press Behind Neck
Desc: The standing behind-the-head press is a classic shoulder exercise that was used widely during bodybuilding's professed Golden Era. In addition to the deltoids, it also works the trapezius and triceps muscles. It may not be a good choice for some people's shoulders, depending on their injury history. It can be trained in strength-focused rep ranges, but is more commonly trained in moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set.
HowTo: Stand with a barbell behind your neck at shoulder height. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Barbell front raise
Desc: The barbell front raise is an upper-body isolation exercise that targets the shoulders. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the shoulder-focused part of any workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs with an overhand grip. Raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. Lower the barbell back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Overhead bar front raise
Desc: The overhead bar front raise is an exercise targeting the muscles of the traps (trapezius), especially the upper traps, as well as the front or anterior shoulders. It can also be performed with a weight plate or dumbbell, providing a neutral grip that may be more shoulder-friendly for some lifters. Overhead raises are most common for high reps (at least 8-12 reps per set or higher) on a shoulder, trap, or other upper-body-focused muscle-building day.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or weight plate overhead with both hands. Lower the weight in front of you to shoulder height, then raise it back overhead. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline barbell shoulder protraction
Desc: The incline barbell shoulder protraction is an upper-body movement that targets strength and mobility in the scapula or shoulder blades. This can help increase pressing strength and prevent injury. It also helps develop the serratus anterior, an often-neglected muscle around the ribcage that can aid in shoulder health and upper-body muscle definition. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie on an incline bench with a barbell in your hands. Keep your arms straight and push the barbell forward, protracting your shoulder blades. Return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Behind-the-head push-press
Desc: The behind-the-head push-press is an overhead press variation in which the barbell starts in the back rack position and is pushed overhead with assistance from the lower body. It is most often seen in training for Olympic weightlifting. It can be part of a barbell complex or performed for low reps focusing on power and movement quality.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell in the back rack position. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Engage your core and grip the barbell firmly. 4. Bend your knees slightly and use your legs to help drive the barbell overhead. 5. Push the barbell upward until your arms are fully extended. 6. Lower the barbell back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Title: Rack Delivery
Desc: The Rack Delivery is an exercise that focuses on the explosive delivery of the barbell from the rack position to the starting position for various lifts. It emphasizes proper positioning and technique.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of the barbell in the rack position. 2. Grip the barbell with both hands at shoulder width. 3. Engage your core and maintain a strong posture. 4. Explosively lift the barbell from the rack to the starting position, typically at shoulder height. 5. Ensure proper technique and positioning throughout the movement.

Title: Smith Incline Shoulder Raise
Desc: The Smith Incline Shoulder Raise is an exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, performed on a Smith machine. It involves raising the weights from shoulder height to above the head while maintaining proper form.
HowTo: 1. Sit on the bench of the Smith machine with your back against the pad. 2. Position the barbell at shoulder height. 3. Grip the barbell with both hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Press the barbell upward until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height with control, maintaining proper form.

Title: Tall Muscle Snatch
Desc: The Tall Muscle Snatch is a dynamic Olympic weightlifting movement that focuses on the snatch technique. It involves lifting the barbell from a standing position to overhead in one fluid motion.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the barbell at mid-thigh level. 2. Grip the barbell with a wide grip. 3. Initiate the lift by extending your hips and knees while pulling the barbell upward. 4. As the barbell reaches your hips, explosively pull it overhead in one fluid motion. 5. Lock out your arms overhead and stabilize the position.

Title: Axle Clean And Press
Desc: The Axle Clean And Press is a strength training exercise that involves lifting a thick barbell (axle) from the ground to the shoulders and then pressing it overhead. It builds overall strength and power.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and the axle barbell on the ground in front of you. 2. Bend at the hips and knees to grip the axle. 3. Lift the axle to your shoulders, keeping your back straight and core engaged. 4. From the shoulders, press the axle overhead until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the axle back to your shoulders and then to the ground.

Title: Jerk Balance
Desc: The Jerk Balance is an exercise that helps improve the jerk portion of the Olympic lift. It focuses on balance and stability while transitioning the barbell from the shoulders to an overhead position.
HowTo: 1. Start with the barbell on your shoulders in a standing position. 2. Take a step back into a stable stance. 3. Lower your body into a slight dip while keeping your torso upright. 4. As you rise from the dip, push the barbell overhead. 5. Focus on balance and stability throughout the movement.

Title: Seated EZ-bar shrug
Desc: The seated EZ-bar shrug is an exercise targeting the trapezius muscle, that V-shaped muscle that forms a triangle where the shoulders meet the neck. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps during an upper-body or shoulders and traps-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold the EZ-bar with both hands at shoulder width. 3. Raise your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing the trapezius muscles. 4. Lower the barbell back down in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Paul Carter Barbell Seated Military Press
Desc: The seated barbell shoulder pressis a classic exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also play a significant roles in pressing the barbell overhead.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your back straight and feet flat on the ground. 2. Position the barbell at shoulder height. 3. Grip the barbell with both hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. 4. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 5. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height with control, ensuring proper form.

Title: TBS Barbell Military Press
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell with both hands. Start with the barbell at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat for 3-5 sets of 6-12 reps.

Title: Incline Front Barbell Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline face-down bar front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: Set an adjustable bench to a 30-45 degree incline and lie face down on it. Hold a barbell with both hands, arms extended towards the floor. Raise the barbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your elbows slightly bent. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps.

Title: Barbell Front Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell front raise is an upper-body isolation exercise that targets the shoulders. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or higher, as part of the shoulder-focused part of any workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with both hands in front of your thighs. Keeping your arms straight, raise the barbell to shoulder height in front of you. Lower the barbell back to the starting position and repeat for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm barbell lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm barbell lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders. It is more challenging than using a dumbbell and has an instability component that may make the deltoid muscles work harder. It is generally performed one side at a time for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps per set, as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell in one hand at your side. Raise the barbell out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbow. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for 3-4 sets of 8-15 reps on each side.

Title: AM Upright Row
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a barbell with both hands in front of your thighs. Pull the barbell up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body and leading with your elbows. Lower the barbell back down and repeat for 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps.

Title: AM Barbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing barbell shoulder press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. The shoulder press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell at shoulder height. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat for 3-5 sets of 6-12 reps.
