Title: Standing barbell shoulder press
Desc: The standing barbell shoulder press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. The shoulder press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the barbell at shoulder height. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat for 3-5 sets of 6-12 reps.

Title: King Maker Barbell Thruster
Desc: The barbell thruster is a full-body exercise that incorporates both squatting and pressing in one functional movement. It's especially common in contemporary CrossFit workouts, but also in general strength training. The barbell is usually cleaned into place first, but it could be performed taken from a squat rack in a front-rack position. The thruster can be performed in traditional strength-focused rep ranges to build strength in the press, or in higher reps for full-body conditioning.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with the barbell at shoulder height. Squat down while keeping the barbell in the front rack position. As you rise from the squat, press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height and repeat for 3-5 sets of 8-15 reps.

Title: Single-arm incline cable cross-over
Desc: The single-arm incline cable cross-over is an isolation movement that uses a cable stack and a bench to target the upper part of the pectoral muscles. Working the chest one side at a time allows you to focus on balance between the sides of your chest and really feel the chest muscles contracting. It is common in upper-body and chest-focused muscle-building workouts, often in combination with other presses or flyes to target the chest from different angles.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a 30-45 degree angle. 2. Attach a cable to a low pulley on one side. 3. Stand to the side of the bench, holding the cable handle with one hand. 4. Position yourself so that your arm is extended out to the side, parallel to the ground. 5. Pull the cable across your body in a wide arc, focusing on contracting your chest. 6. Squeeze at the top of the movement, then slowly return to the starting position. 7. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching sides.

Title: Barbell bear complex
Desc: The barbell bear complex is a series of barbell lifts that run together in a single sequence: a barbell power clean, front squat, push-press, back squat, and another push-press from behind the neck. It trains the entire body for both building strength and improving conditioning. It is often performed for rounds, either with or without rest between rounds.
HowTo: 1. Start with a barbell on the ground. 2. Perform a power clean to lift the barbell to shoulder height. 3. Lower into a front squat, keeping the barbell on your shoulders. 4. Stand up from the squat and perform a push-press by driving the barbell overhead. 5. Lower the barbell back to your shoulders, then perform a back squat. 6. Stand up from the back squat and perform another push-press from behind the neck. 7. Repeat the sequence for the desired number of rounds.

Title: 30 Shoulders Barbell Shrug
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Barbell Shrug is an exercise that targets the upper trapezius muscles. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands in front of your thighs. Shrug your shoulders upward towards your ears, hold for a moment, and then lower back to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell in front of your thighs. 2. Keep your arms straight and lift your shoulders towards your ears. 3. Hold the shrug position for a moment. 4. Lower your shoulders back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Up Straight-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Up Straight-Bar Front Raise is an exercise that focuses on the anterior deltoids. Lie on an incline bench face up, holding a straight bar with both hands. Raise the bar straight up in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it back down with control.
HowTo: 1. Lie face up on an incline bench, holding a straight bar with both hands. 2. Start with the bar at shoulder height. 3. Raise the bar straight up in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. 4. Lower the bar back down to the starting position with control. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press is a compound exercise that targets the shoulder muscles. Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells upward until your arms are fully extended overhead. 3. Lower the dumbbells back down to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Behind-The-Head Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Standing Behind-The-Head Shoulder Press is an effective shoulder exercise. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell behind your neck. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back down behind your head.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell behind your neck. 2. Keep your elbows pointing down and press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the barbell back down behind your head to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Barbell Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Standing Barbell Press is a powerful shoulder exercise. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at shoulder height. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back to shoulder height.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: FYR2 Wide Overhead Press
Desc: The FYR2 Wide Overhead Press is an exercise that targets the shoulders and upper chest. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height with a wide grip. Press the weights overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height with a wide grip. 2. Press the weights overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the weights back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell push-press
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the floor. 2. Clean the kettlebell to shoulder height. 3. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 4. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then press the kettlebell overhead using your legs for assistance. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Military Press is a strength exercise that targets the shoulders, triceps, and upper chest. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, hold a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height, and press the weights overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the kettlebells back to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. 2. Hold a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. 3. Press both kettlebells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Alternating Kettlebell Press
Desc: The Alternating Kettlebell Press is a dynamic shoulder exercise that engages the deltoids and triceps. Begin by standing with a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the kettlebell overhead while simultaneously lowering the other kettlebell to shoulder height. Alternate between arms for a set number of repetitions.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the kettlebell overhead while lowering the other kettlebell to shoulder height. 3. Alternate arms, pressing one kettlebell while lowering the other for a set number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell snatch
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell snatch is a kettlebell exercise that involves lifting a kettlebell overhead in a single motion. It is popular as a full-body strength and conditioning movement, but it's also competed for reps in Russian-style girevoy sport. A "snatch test" of max reps in 5 or 10 minutes is also a common measurement of conditioning in kettlebell training. It can be performed from the ground or with a swing
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grasp the kettlebell. 3. In one explosive motion, lift the kettlebell overhead in a single motion. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell clean and jerk
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell clean and jerk is a popular kettlebell movement that is performed both in an exercise setting and competitively as a part of Russian-style girevoy sport. It differs from a clean and push-press in that the lifter "dips" under the weight rather than simply using the legs to help push the weight up. Each rep of a clean and jerk is preceded by a clean at the start of each set. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the ground. 2. Clean the kettlebell to shoulder height. 3. Dip under the weight by bending your knees, then jerk the kettlebell overhead. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell pirate ship
Desc: The kettlebell pirate ship is a rotational shoulder and core-focused kettlebell movement. It demands the lifter raise the kettlebell to the side in both directions, emphasizing core strength in the transverse abdominis and obliques in particular. It is best learned with a light weight, using controlled movements in both directions.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell in one hand at your side. 2. Raise the kettlebell to the side, engaging your core. 3. Rotate your torso and lower the kettlebell back to the starting position. 4. Repeat on the other side.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Clean is a powerful movement that works the entire body, focusing on the legs, back, and shoulders. Start with a kettlebell on the floor between your feet. Bend your knees and hinge at the hips to grasp the kettlebell with both hands. In one explosive motion, lift the kettlebell to your shoulders while keeping your elbows high and your back straight. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: 1. Start with a kettlebell on the floor between your feet. 2. Bend your knees and hinge at the hips to grasp the kettlebell with both hands. 3. In one explosive motion, lift the kettlebell to your shoulders while keeping your elbows high. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Double Kettlebell Push Press
Desc: The double-kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a double clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: 1. Start with two kettlebells on the floor. 2. Clean both kettlebells to shoulder height. 3. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then press both kettlebells overhead using your legs for assistance. 4. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Kettlebell Seated Press
Desc: The Kettlebell Seated Press is a strength exercise that targets the shoulders, triceps, and upper chest. It involves pressing a kettlebell overhead while seated, which helps to stabilize the core and improve shoulder mobility.
HowTo: Sit on a bench or sturdy surface with a kettlebell in one hand. Start with the kettlebell at shoulder height, palm facing you. Press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position while maintaining a stable core.

Title: Double Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Jerk is a dynamic exercise that involves using two kettlebells to perform a powerful overhead press. It focuses on building explosive strength and coordination, engaging the legs, core, and shoulders.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive through your legs while pressing the kettlebells overhead. Lock out your arms at the top and return to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell Arnold Press
Desc: The Kettlebell Arnold Press is a variation of the traditional shoulder press that incorporates a rotational movement. It targets the deltoids and engages the upper chest while improving shoulder stability and mobility.
HowTo: Start seated or standing with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. Rotate your palms outward as you press the kettlebells overhead. Lower them back down while rotating your palms back to the starting position.

Title: Double-kettlebell windmill
Desc: The double-kettlebell windmill is an advanced kettlebell exercise emphasizing core strength and shoulder and hip mobility and stability. Because it involves holding one weight overhead while holding another under the torso, it builds strength across the core and stability in the shoulders. It doesn't work well in a metcon or conditioning setting, and shouldn't be performed under intense fatigue.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding one kettlebell overhead and the other kettlebell under your torso. Hinge at your hips and lower your torso towards the ground while keeping the kettlebell overhead stable. Return to standing while maintaining control of both kettlebells.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Split Snatch is an explosive movement that combines a snatch with a split stance. It develops power, coordination, and strength in the shoulders, back, and legs.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell on the ground between your feet. Swing the kettlebell back between your legs, then explosively extend your hips and pull the kettlebell up, catching it overhead in a split stance. Return to the starting position.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Para Press is a shoulder exercise that involves pressing a kettlebell overhead with one arm while maintaining a stable core. It enhances shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the kettlebell overhead while keeping your core tight and your body stable. Lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Split Jerk is a powerful overhead pressing movement that requires a split stance. It emphasizes explosive strength and coordination, engaging the legs and core.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then explosively drive through your legs while pressing the kettlebell overhead into a split stance. Return to the starting position.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Military Press To The Side is a shoulder exercise that targets the deltoids and triceps. It involves pressing a kettlebell overhead to the side, enhancing shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the kettlebell overhead to the side, keeping your core engaged and your body stable. Lower it back to shoulder height.

Title: One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The One-Arm Kettlebell Jerk is a dynamic exercise that involves lifting a kettlebell overhead using one arm. It focuses on developing shoulder strength, stability, and overall power. Start by holding a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height, then dip slightly and drive through your legs to propel the kettlebell overhead, locking out your arm at the top.
HowTo: Hold a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then drive through your legs to propel the kettlebell overhead. Lock out your arm at the top.

Title: Double Kettlebell Snatch
Desc: The Double Kettlebell Snatch is an explosive full-body exercise that involves lifting two kettlebells from the ground to an overhead position in one fluid motion. This exercise enhances strength, power, and coordination. Begin with a kettlebell in each hand, hinge at the hips, and perform a powerful hip extension to snatch the kettlebells overhead, ensuring a strong lockout at the top.
HowTo: Begin with a kettlebell in each hand. Hinge at the hips and perform a powerful hip extension to lift the kettlebells from the ground to an overhead position in one fluid motion, ensuring a strong lockout at the top.

Title: Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk
Desc: The Two-Arm Kettlebell Jerk is a powerful overhead lifting movement that utilizes both arms to drive kettlebells overhead. This exercise builds shoulder strength, coordination, and explosive power. Start with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height, dip slightly by bending your knees, and then drive upward with your legs while pushing the kettlebells overhead, locking your arms out at the top.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. Dip slightly by bending your knees, then drive upward with your legs while pushing the kettlebells overhead. Lock your arms out at the top.

Title: FYR Kettlebell Power Clean
Desc: The kettlebell power clean is an explosive kettlebell exercise where the lifter pulls the weight to shoulder level with a slight swing between the legs. It is often used as a drill to teach kettlebell clean technique, but is also a valuable power exercise in its own right. It can be performed in low rep ranges for strength or higher rep ranges for technique practice or muscle growth.
HowTo: Stand with a kettlebell between your legs. Hinge at the hips and swing the kettlebell back slightly. Explosively pull the kettlebell to shoulder level, keeping it close to your body, and then lower it back down with control.

Title: Kettlebell upright row
Desc: The kettlebell upright row is an exercise targeting the muscles of the traps (trapezius), as well as the posterior muscles of the shoulders or deltoid muscles. It is common as a light- or moderate-weight accessory movement in upper-body or shoulder training, usually in rep ranges of 8-12 or more. It may not be appropriate for some people, depending on their shoulder health.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell with both hands. Pull the kettlebell up towards your chin, keeping your elbows higher than your wrists, and then lower it back down to the starting position.

Title: Kettlebell upright row and press
Desc: The kettlebell upright row and press is a combination of two popular kettlebell movements in a single sequence. This combination can be performed for time or for reps, often as circuit-style training for conditioning or fat loss, or in a kettlebell complex or flow.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell in each hand at the sides. Perform an upright row by pulling the kettlebells up towards your chin, then transition directly into a press by pushing the kettlebells overhead. Lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Single-arm kettlebell thruster
Desc: The single-arm kettlebell thruster is a popular kettlebell movement that combines a kettlebell front squat with a kettlebell press. It is preceded by a clean at the start of each set, and you can perform a clean between each rep if you choose. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: Start with a kettlebell on the floor. Clean the kettlebell to the rack position, then perform a front squat. As you rise from the squat, press the kettlebell overhead. Lower it back to the rack position and repeat.

Title: Double-kettlebell shoulder press
Desc: The double-kettlebell shoulder press is a popular movement in strength and muscle-focused kettlebell workouts. Each set is started by cleaning the weights up to the rack position. The weights can optionally be re-cleaned between each rep, which is known as a clean and press. The double press can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-growth rep ranges (e.g., 5x5 or 8-12 reps per set), or in circuit-style fat-loss training or kettlebell complexes.
HowTo: Clean the kettlebells to the rack position. From there, press both kettlebells overhead simultaneously. Lower them back to the rack position and repeat. Optionally, you can re-clean the weights between each rep.

Title: Double-kettlebell push-press
Desc: The double-kettlebell push-press is a popular kettlebell movement that involves performing a press with help from the muscles of the lower body. It is preceded by a double clean at the start of each set, and optionally you can perform a clean between each rep. It can be trained in traditional strength or muscle-building rep ranges, in circuit or fat-loss training, or as part of a larger kettlebell combination or complex.
HowTo: Start by performing a double clean to bring the kettlebells to the rack position. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, engage your core, and press the kettlebells overhead, using your legs to assist in the movement. Lower the kettlebells back to the rack position and repeat.

Title: HM Kettlebell Windmill
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Windmill is a dynamic exercise that targets the core, shoulders, and hips. It involves holding a kettlebell overhead while performing a windmill motion, bending at the waist to touch the ground with the opposite hand, and returning to the starting position.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a kettlebell overhead with one arm. Bend at the waist, keeping your legs straight, and reach down with your opposite hand to touch the ground. Return to the starting position by engaging your core and standing upright.

Title: HM Kettlebell Z-Press
Desc: The HM Kettlebell Z-Press is a seated overhead press that emphasizes shoulder strength and stability. While sitting on the floor with legs extended, you press the kettlebell overhead, engaging the core to maintain an upright posture.
HowTo: Sit on the floor with your legs extended in front of you. Hold a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder level. Engage your core and press the kettlebell overhead while maintaining an upright posture. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder level and repeat.

Title: Taylor Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Halo
Desc: The Taylor Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Halo is an exercise that improves shoulder mobility and core stability. From a half-kneeling position, you hold a kettlebell at chest level and move it around your head in a halo motion, keeping your core engaged.
HowTo: Begin in a half-kneeling position with a kettlebell held at chest level. Keep your core engaged and move the kettlebell around your head in a halo motion, ensuring to maintain control and stability throughout the movement. Return to the starting position.

Title: Taylor Towel Kettlebell Farmer's Walk
Desc: The Taylor Towel Kettlebell Farmer's Walk is a functional strength exercise that involves carrying a kettlebell in one hand while holding a towel in the other. This exercise enhances grip strength, core stability, and overall body coordination.
HowTo: Stand tall with a kettlebell in one hand and a towel in the other. Walk forward while maintaining a strong grip on the kettlebell and towel, engaging your core for stability. Switch hands as needed to maintain balance and coordination.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Alternating Press
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Alternating Press is a powerful upper body exercise that targets the shoulders and triceps. Using two kettlebells, you alternate pressing them overhead while maintaining a strong core and stable stance.
HowTo: Stand with a kettlebell in each hand at shoulder height. Engage your core and press one kettlebell overhead while lowering the other back to shoulder level. Alternate pressing each kettlebell overhead in a controlled manner.

Title: FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Thruster
Desc: The FYR2 Double-Kettlebell Thruster is a full-body movement that combines a squat and an overhead press. Holding two kettlebells at shoulder height, you squat down and then explosively press the kettlebells overhead as you stand up.
HowTo: Start with two kettlebells at shoulder height. Perform a squat by lowering your hips back and down, keeping your chest up. As you stand up, explosively press both kettlebells overhead, fully extending your arms. Lower the kettlebells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Clean
Desc: The FYR2 Half-Kneeling Kettlebell Clean is a dynamic exercise that focuses on explosiveness and coordination. From a half-kneeling position, you perform a clean by lifting the kettlebell from the ground to the rack position in one fluid motion.
HowTo: Begin in a half-kneeling position with a kettlebell on the ground beside you. Reach down and lift the kettlebell in one smooth motion to the rack position at your shoulder, keeping your core engaged. Return the kettlebell to the ground and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Clean and Press
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Clean and Press is a full-body exercise that combines a kettlebell clean with an overhead press. It targets the shoulders, arms, and core while also engaging the legs and back during the clean phase.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell on the ground between your feet. 2. Hinge at the hips and grasp the kettlebell with one hand. 3. Perform a kettlebell clean by driving through your legs and pulling the kettlebell up to your shoulder. 4. Once the kettlebell is at shoulder height, press it overhead by extending your arm fully. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell High Pull to Overhead Press
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell High Pull to Overhead Press is a dynamic movement that starts with a high pull of the kettlebell followed by an overhead press. This exercise enhances shoulder strength, explosiveness, and overall upper body coordination.
HowTo: 1. Begin with the kettlebell on the ground. 2. Perform a high pull by explosively pulling the kettlebell up towards your chin. 3. As the kettlebell reaches chest height, transition into an overhead press by pushing the kettlebell straight up. 4. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Kettlebell Swing Clean and Press
Desc: The FYR2 Kettlebell Swing Clean and Press combines the kettlebell swing with a clean and an overhead press. This compound movement improves power, strength, and endurance, engaging multiple muscle groups throughout the body.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell between your feet. 2. Perform a kettlebell swing to generate momentum. 3. As the kettlebell swings up, transition into a clean by pulling it to your shoulder. 4. From the clean position, press the kettlebell overhead. 5. Lower the kettlebell back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Press
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Arm Kettlebell Press focuses on unilateral strength development. It targets the shoulders, triceps, and core stability, allowing for improved balance and coordination.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a kettlebell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and press the kettlebell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the kettlebell back to shoulder height with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: FYR2 Ascending-Rep High-Pull-Press Complex
Desc: The FYR2 Ascending-Rep High-Pull-Press Complex is a challenging sequence that increases the number of repetitions with each set. It combines high pulls and presses, enhancing muscular endurance and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: 1. Start with the kettlebell at your side. 2. Perform a high pull, bringing the kettlebell to chest height. 3. Immediately transition into an overhead press. 4. Increase the number of repetitions in each subsequent set, starting with one rep and adding one more each time.

Title: Dumbbell front raise to lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise is a dumbbell complex that combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you perform it, it targets both the anterior and medial deltoids, making it a great time-efficient shoulder burnout or accessory movement on an upper-body day.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height (front raise). 3. Lower it back down and immediately raise the other dumbbell out to the side to shoulder height (lateral raise). 4. Alternate between front raises and lateral raises for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm palm-in dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm palm-in dumbbell shoulder press builds the shoulder muscles but with two major differences from the standard dumbbell shoulder press. It's done one arm at a time and the wrist stays neutral throughout the movement. It can be performed standing or seated. A single dumbbell press can be pursued as a strength goal, or trained in traditional muscle-building rep ranges such as 8-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, palm facing in. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead while keeping your wrist neutral. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height with control. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: Standing palms-in shoulder press
Desc: The standing palms-in shoulder press is a dumbbell exercise targeting the shoulders. It can be performed in strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing in. 2. Press both dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated Dumbbell Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height with palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position at shoulder height. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-building exercise that is common in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows more weight to be used and taxes the core more than seated presses. The standing press is worthy of being the main movement in a muscle-building shoulder workout, but is also a great strength movement and accessory for the bench press.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a staple strength-training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper-body training days. Hold on to a post for balance, or do it free-standing to challenge core strength and stability. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per side, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, arm at your side. Raise the dumbbell out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbow. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: Power Partials
Desc: Power Partials are a strength training exercise that focuses on developing explosive power and strength in a specific range of motion. This exercise typically involves performing a partial lift of a weight, such as a squat or deadlift, to build strength in the muscles used during the full range of the lift.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height. Perform a partial squat or deadlift by lowering the weight only partway down, focusing on explosive power as you lift back up. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline dumbbell reverse fly
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench, holding a dumbbell in each hand with arms hanging down. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Overhead dumbbell front raise
Desc: The overhead dumbbell front raise takes the dumbbell front raise one step further, extending the motion all the way above the head. In addition to the shoulders, it activates and strengthens the muscles of the traps and upper back. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-15 reps or more. It can be part of a dynamic upper-body warm-up, performed as a muscle-building upper-body movement, or as a burnout movement on shoulder day.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at thigh level. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then continue raising them overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated dumbbell shoulder press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder press is a popular exercise for building muscle and strength in the shoulders. The triceps also work hard in this lift. Many lifters find using dumbbells to be more comfortable and shoulder-friendly for this press variation than a barbell. This can be the primary pressing movement on an upper-body or shoulder day, or an effective accessory movement later in a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height with palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Alternating standing shoulder press
Desc: The alternating standing shoulder press is a popular dumbbell exercise targeting the shoulders. It can be performed in strength-focused rep ranges, such as 5-8 reps per set, or for higher reps to build muscle or for conditioning.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press one dumbbell overhead while keeping the other at shoulder height. Alternate arms with each rep. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm incline rear delt raise
Desc: The single-arm incline rear delt raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior deltoids or shoulder muscles, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Training each side independently can help correct imbalances in size, strength, and shoulder stability. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a comfortable angle. 2. Lie face down on the bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 3. Keep your arm straight and let the dumbbell hang down. 4. Raise the dumbbell out to the side, keeping a slight bend in your elbow. 5. Squeeze your shoulder blade at the top of the movement. 6. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 7. Perform 10-15 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Alternating dumbbell front raise
Desc: The alternating dumbbell front raise is a single-joint exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the front or anterior deltoids. Performing the movement one shoulder at a time gives a momentary rest to each side while the other is working, potentially allowing you to do more reps during each set. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to your side. 4. Repeat with the other arm. 5. Continue alternating arms for 8-12 reps per arm.

Title: Alternating Deltoid Raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height. 3. Without lowering the first dumbbell, raise the second dumbbell to the side to shoulder height. 4. Lower the first dumbbell back to your side, then lower the second dumbbell. 5. Alternate between front and lateral raises for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-dumbbell front raise
Desc: The single-dumbbell front raise is an isolation movement that targets the shoulders. In particular, it focuses on the anterior or front head of the deltoid muscles. By performing it with one dumbbell at a time, you can focus on each shoulder muscle independently and try to address muscular imbalances between shoulders. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your thigh. 2. Raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to your thigh. 4. Switch to the other arm and repeat. 5. Perform 8-12 reps per arm.

Title: Arnold press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder and movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press. It allows the hands to rotate naturally, while also hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
Muscles: Anterior Deltoids, Lateral Deltoids, Posterior Deltoids
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. 2. Rotate your palms outward as you press the dumbbells overhead. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height while rotating your palms back to face you. 4. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm standing shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press is a popular exercise to build size and strength the shoulders and triceps. Most lifters find they can go heavier (per arm) on this movement than if they are pressing two dumbbells simultaneously, making it an effective strength movement as well as a muscle-building movement in higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height. 4. Perform 8-12 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Dumbbell front raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise is a single-joint exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the front or anterior deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise both dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to your sides. 4. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Bent-over dumbbell rear delt row
Desc: The bent-over dumbbell rear delt row is a popular upper-body exercise that targets the muscles on the backside of the shoulder joint, specifically the medial and rear heads of the deltoid. Since pressing movements build the front and (to a lesser degree) side deltoid heads, this move is often done to promote balanced shoulder development. It is usually performed for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand bent over with a dumbbell in each hand, palms facing each other. 2. Pull the dumbbells towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 4. Perform 10-15 reps.

Title: Incline dumbbell front raise
Desc: The incline dumbbell front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to a 30-45 degree angle. 2. Lie face down on the bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging straight down. 3. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Side Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, squeezing your shoulder muscles. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell external shoulder rotation
Desc: The dumbbell external shoulder rotation is a lightweight dumbbell exercise intended to maintain the health of the shoulder joints, including the rotator cuffs. It is often used as a warm-up or prehab for a shoulder or chest-focused workout with lots of pressing.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, elbow bent at 90 degrees. 2. Keeping your elbow close to your body, rotate your forearm outward, away from your body. 3. Hold for a moment at the top of the movement. 4. Return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 10-15 reps on each arm.

Title: Single-arm incline lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm incline lateral raise is an exercise targeting the lateral or medial head of the shoulder muscles. It is performed lying sideways on an incline bench set to around 45 degrees, which helps to increase the range of motion in the lift and enforce strict form. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to about 45 degrees and lie sideways on it with a dumbbell in the upper hand. 2. Allow the dumbbell to hang straight down. 3. Keeping a slight bend in your elbow, raise the dumbbell to shoulder height. 4. Squeeze your shoulder at the top of the movement. 5. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Seated rear delt fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the floor and a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lean forward slightly and let the dumbbells hang down at arm's length. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulders and upper arms. It involves lifting a dumbbell with one or both arms to shoulder height or above, focusing on controlled movement and proper form to build strength and stability.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise the dumbbells to shoulder height or above, keeping your elbows slightly bent. 3. Focus on controlled movement and proper form throughout the lift. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Seated Side Lateral Raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raiseis an iconic exercise for developing the shoulders. If you’ve ever worked out with weights, chances are you’ve done this move at some point. Proper execution is paramount to avoid injury.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keeping your back straight, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, ensuring proper form. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell Lying Rear Lateral Raise
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench to about 30-45 degrees and lie face down on it with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Allow the dumbbells to hang straight down. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top. 5. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Head-on-bench dumbbell rear delt raise
Desc: The head-on-bench dumbbell rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the posterior shoulder muscles, or rear deltoids. This variation of the bent-over rear delt raise often helps to better isolate this area of the shoulder. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your arms hanging straight down. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower the weights back down slowly and repeat for 10-15 reps.

Title: Cuban press
Desc: The Cuban press is an exercise that targets the muscles of the shoulders, rotator cuff, and upper back. It combines a shoulder external rotation with a dumbbell press, training multiple muscles and motions in a single sequence. It can be performed standing, or as a more difficult variation face-down on an incline bench. It is usually performed with relatively light weight as part of a dynamic warm-up for upper-body lifting.
Muscles: Anterior Deltoid, Rotator Cuff, Upper Back
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Rotate your arms to externally rotate the shoulders, then press the dumbbells overhead while keeping your elbows slightly bent. Lower the weights back to shoulder height and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Reverse Flyes With External Rotation
Desc: The Reverse Flyes with External Rotation targets the rear deltoids and upper back. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, hinge at the hips, and keep your back flat. With your palms facing each other, raise the weights out to the sides while rotating your arms externally, ensuring your elbows are slightly bent. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement before lowering back down.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, hinge at the hips, and keep your back flat. With palms facing each other, raise the weights out to the sides while rotating your arms externally. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top, then lower back down for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm side lying rear fly
Desc: The single-arm side lying rear fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the rear deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement lying on a bench, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Lie on your side on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand. Keep your body straight and your head supported. Raise the dumbbell towards the ceiling, focusing on squeezing the rear deltoid. Lower it back down slowly and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell upright row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell upright row is a popular movement for building stronger and bigger traps and shoulders. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout, since it involves both body parts. It is generally performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your side. Pull the dumbbell up towards your chin, keeping your elbow high and close to your body. Lower it back down and repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch arms.

Title: Dumbbell Scaption
Desc: The Dumbbell Scaption is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the weights in a 'V' shape at a 30-degree angle from your body, keeping your thumbs pointing up. Lift the dumbbells to shoulder height while maintaining a slight bend in your elbows, then lower them back down.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the weights in a 'V' shape at a 30-degree angle from your body, keeping your thumbs pointing up. Lift to shoulder height, then lower back down for 8-12 reps.

Title: See-Saw Press (Alternating Side Press)
Desc: The See-Saw Press (Alternating Side Press) is a shoulder exercise that engages the deltoids and triceps. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other to your shoulder, alternating sides in a smooth motion. Keep your core engaged and maintain a stable stance throughout the exercise.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other to your shoulder. Alternate sides in a smooth motion, keeping your core engaged for 8-12 reps.

Title: Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Incline Shoulder Raise focuses on the front and lateral deltoids. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides at a 45-degree angle until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down. Ensure you keep your back pressed against the bench and maintain control throughout the movement.
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides at a 45-degree angle until they reach shoulder height, then lower them back down. Keep your back pressed against the bench for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm half-kneeling shoulder press
Desc: The single-arm half-kneeling shoulder press is a popular exercise to target the deltoid muscles while also developing strength and stability in the core and hips. Balance can be a challenge, which is one reason why this movement is generally trained lighter than standing single-arm shoulder presses. The half-kneeling press can be used as an accessory lift for the shoulder press or bench press, or simply as a technique to make shoulder presses stricter and more athletic.
HowTo: Start in a half-kneeling position with one knee on the ground and the opposite foot flat on the floor. Hold a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height, palm facing forward. Engage your core and press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: Dumbbell Clean And Jerk
Desc: The Dumbbell Clean and Jerk is a full-body exercise that combines a clean and a jerk movement. It targets multiple muscle groups, including the legs, shoulders, and core. Start by lifting the dumbbells from the ground to shoulder height in a clean motion, then explosively press them overhead in a jerk motion.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells to the ground. In one explosive motion, lift the dumbbells to shoulder height in a clean motion. From there, press the dumbbells overhead in a jerk motion, fully extending your arms. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell shoulder press with body rotation
Desc: The dumbbell shoulder press with body rotation is a twist on the traditional dumbbell shoulder press. Rather than pressing straight overhead, you twist your torso and hips to the side during each rep. It hits the deltoid muscles just like a shoulder press, but adds a challenge to the core, hips, and back muscles. Due to the potential balance challenge of twisting and pressing at the same time, it is commonly performed with light to moderate weights.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. As you press the dumbbells overhead, rotate your torso and hips to one side, then return to the starting position as you lower the weights back down. Alternate sides with each rep to engage your core and improve stability.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Military Press
Desc: The Dumbbell Military Press is a shoulder exercise that focuses on building strength in the deltoids and triceps. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height in a controlled manner and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Standing Dumbbell Arnold Press
Desc: The Standing Dumbbell Arnold Press is a variation of the traditional shoulder press that engages the front deltoids more effectively. Start with the dumbbells held in front of you at chest level, palms facing you. As you press the dumbbells overhead, rotate your palms to face forward, then reverse the motion as you lower them back.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at chest level, palms facing you. As you press the dumbbells overhead, rotate your palms to face forward. Lower the dumbbells back to chest level while reversing the rotation of your palms, and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Fix Dumbbell Single-Arm Snatch
Desc: The Dumbbell Single-Arm Snatch is a dynamic exercise that develops power and coordination. Begin with a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. In one explosive motion, lift the dumbbell off the ground, extending your hips and knees, and pull it overhead with one arm, finishing with your arm fully extended.
HowTo: Start with a dumbbell on the ground between your feet. Bend at the hips and knees to grasp the dumbbell with one hand. In one explosive motion, extend your hips and knees while pulling the dumbbell up, keeping it close to your body. As the dumbbell reaches shoulder height, pull it overhead with one arm, finishing with your arm fully extended. Lower the dumbbell back to the ground and repeat.

Title: Paul Carter Rear-Delt Fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your chest against the pad, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your arms extended downwards. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The standing dumbbell shoulder press is a classic deltoid-builder (especially the front deltoids) that’s ubiquitous in gyms around the world. Performing the move standing up as opposed to seated allows for more weight to be used.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height in a controlled manner and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: FYR Single-Arm Dumbbell Press
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press builds shoulder muscle but with two major differences from the standard seated dumbbell shoulder press. It’s done one arm at a time, as well as standing, which may allow more weight to be used.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of reps. Switch arms and repeat.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Tempo L-Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell seesaw shoulder press
Desc: The dumbbell seesaw shoulder press is an exercise targeting the deltoids and triceps. The difference between this movement and the alternating shoulder press is that both dumbbells keep moving throughout each rep, rather than having one weight be stationary while the other moves. This piston-style pressing increases time under tension and may allow you to complete more total reps than with alternating reps.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press both dumbbells overhead simultaneously while keeping them moving in a seesaw motion. Lower them back to shoulder height and repeat, ensuring continuous movement.

Title: FYR Dumbbell front raise to lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell front raise to lateral raise combines two exercises that build and strengthen the middle deltoids and the anterior deltoids of the shoulders.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it back down. Immediately raise the other dumbbell out to the side to shoulder height. Alternate between the two movements.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Arnold Press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder/movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press, hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. Rotate your palms away from you as you press the dumbbells overhead. Lower them back to shoulder height while rotating your palms back towards you. Repeat.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Military Press to Dumbbell High Pull to V-up
Desc: The FYR Dumbbell Military Press to Dumbbell High Pull to V-up is a compound exercise that targets the shoulders, upper back, and core. Begin by standing with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead in a military press motion, then lower them back to shoulder height. Transition into a high pull by pulling the dumbbells up towards your chin, engaging your upper back. Finally, drop into a V-up by lowering your torso and legs while keeping your arms extended, then lift your legs and torso to form a 'V' shape. This sequence enhances strength and stability across multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead in a military press motion. Lower them back to shoulder height, then pull the dumbbells up towards your chin for a high pull. Finally, lower your torso and legs while keeping your arms extended, then lift your legs and torso to form a 'V' shape. Repeat the sequence.

Title: FYR Dumbbell Thruster
Desc: The dumbbell thruster, which begins with a squat and ends with an overhead press, works the entire body at once in a single fluid motion. This exercise is often performed with kettlebells, but dumbbells work great, too.
HowTo: Start in a standing position holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Perform a squat, lowering your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. As you rise from the squat, press the dumbbells overhead in one fluid motion. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell hang snatch
Desc: The dumbbell hang snatch is an explosive exercise that builds full-body power and targets the muscles of the hips, back, and shoulders. Performing the movement from the hang position, rather than from the ground, emphasizes explosive hip and upper-body power. It can be performed for low reps with a focus on power and speed, or for higher reps to build muscle or as part of a metabolic conditioning circuit.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand, arms hanging at your sides. Bend at the hips and knees to lower the dumbbells to just above your knees. Explosively extend your hips and pull the dumbbells up, catching them overhead as you stand up. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Surfer sprawl
Desc: The surfer sprawl is an explosive bodyweight exercise that targets multiple muscle groups across the upper and lower body. It is similar to a burpee, but instead of jumping at the top, you end in a "surfer position," alternating sides with each rep. It can be performed for time or reps in any fat-loss or athleticism-focused circuit or workout. The surfer position offers a unique way to challenge the body by staying in a low position rather than standing up after the plank.
HowTo: Start in a standing position. Lower into a squat, placing your hands on the ground. Jump your feet back into a plank position. From the plank, jump your feet back towards your hands and rise into a low surfer position, alternating sides with each rep.

Title: Dumbbell clean and press
Desc: The dumbbell clean and press is a full-body movement that targets both the lower and upper body. The clean utilizes the muscles of the hips, legs, glutes, back, and biceps, while the press utilizes the shoulders and triceps. It can be trained in low to moderate reps for strength, or for higher reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, for muscle building or metabolic conditioning.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Bend your knees slightly and hinge at the hips to lower the dumbbells to your knees. Explosively extend your hips and legs to lift the dumbbells to shoulder height, then press them overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Standing One-Arm Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm standing shoulder press builds shoulder muscle but with two major differences from the standard seated dumbbell shoulder press. It’s done one arm at a time, as well as standing, which may allow more weight to be used.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Engage your core and press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of reps before switching arms.

Title: Incline Front Dumbbell Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell front raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders
HowTo: Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight but not locked. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Dumbbell lateral raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the medial or middle head of the deltoid muscle. It's a staple strength-training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper-body training days. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline Rear-Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Incline Bench Rear Dumbbell Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Keeping a slight bend in your elbows, lift the dumbbells out to the sides until they are at shoulder level. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together, then lower the dumbbells back down.

Title: Dumbbell front raise and press
Desc: The dumbbell front raise and press combines two upper-body moves into one challenging sequence targeting the deltoid muscles. It's a simple way to boost your heart rate while getting a good upper-body pump, and is a natural fit in time-efficient upper-body or circuit training.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your thighs. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height, then press them overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height and then back to your thighs, repeating the sequence.

Title: Rotator cuff warm-up
Desc: The rotator cuff warm-up is a simple exercise targeting the rotator cuffs through weighted shoulder external rotation. It's a classic way to warm up the shoulder prior to sports or training, as well as a common rehab movement. The rotator cuffs are a notorious injury-prone structure in the shoulders of Major League pitchers and other athletes. This is a movement most commonly done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding a light dumbbell in each hand with your elbows bent at 90 degrees. 2. Stand or sit with your back straight and feet shoulder-width apart. 3. Slowly rotate your shoulders outward, raising the dumbbells to shoulder height while keeping your elbows bent. 4. Hold for a moment at the top, then return to the starting position. 5. Perform 8-12 reps for 2-3 sets.

Title: Seated Lateral Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raiseis an iconic exercise for developing the shoulders. If you’ve ever worked out with weights, chances are you’ve done this move at some point. Proper execution is paramount to avoid injury.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, resting at your sides. 2. Keep your back straight and core engaged. 3. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 4. Lift until your arms are parallel to the ground, then lower back to the starting position. 5. Aim for 10-15 reps for 3-4 sets.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell arc row
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell arc row is an exercise for building the latissimus dorsi, or lat, muscles of the back. This variation has more of an arcing shape than the traditional single-arm dumbbell row, which may increase the mind-muscle connection and hit the back from a different angle. You probably won't be able to go as heavy on this as on a traditional row.
HowTo: 1. Start by placing a dumbbell in one hand and positioning yourself in a staggered stance. 2. Bend forward at the hips while keeping your back straight. 3. With your arm extended down, pull the dumbbell in an arcing motion towards your hip, squeezing your back muscles. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 5. Perform 8-12 reps, then switch sides.

Title: Incline Rear Delt Raises - Gethin Variation
Desc: The incline dumbbell reverse fly is an upper-body exercise targeting the posterior or rear deltoids, as well as the postural muscles of the upper back. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Let your arms hang straight down, palms facing each other. 3. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Aim for 10-15 reps for 3-4 sets.

Title: Incline Dumbbell Y Raise
Desc: The Incline Dumbbell Y Raise targets the shoulders, specifically the deltoids, by raising dumbbells in a Y formation while lying on an incline bench.
HowTo: 1. Lie on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with your arms extended above your head in a Y formation. 3. Keeping your arms straight, lower the dumbbells out to the sides in a controlled manner. 4. Raise the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Perform 10-15 reps for 3-4 sets.

Title: HM Bent-Over Rear-Delt Fly
Desc: The HM Bent-Over Rear-Delt Fly focuses on the rear deltoids and upper back, performed by bending over and raising dumbbells out to the sides.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Bend at the hips and knees, keeping your back straight. 3. With your palms facing each other, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position. 5. Aim for 10-15 reps for 3-4 sets.

Title: HM Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The HM Dumbbell Shoulder Press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength, performed by pressing dumbbells overhead while seated or standing.
HowTo: 1. Sit or stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing forward. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height. 4. Keep your core engaged and back straight throughout the movement. 5. Perform 8-12 reps for 3-4 sets.

Title: HM Single-Leg Overhead Dumbbell Press
Desc: The HM Single-Leg Overhead Dumbbell Press challenges balance and stability while strengthening the shoulders, performed by pressing a dumbbell overhead on one leg.
Muscles: Deltoids (Anterior and Lateral Heads), Core Muscles
HowTo: 1. Stand on one leg with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and maintain balance. 3. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to shoulder height. 5. Perform 8-12 reps, then switch to the other leg.

Title: 6 Way Shoulder Raise
Desc: The 6 Way Shoulder Raise is an exercise designed to target the shoulder muscles, particularly the deltoids. It involves raising the arms in various directions to enhance shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: To perform the 6 Way Shoulder Raise, stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand. Raise your arms in six different directions: front raise, lateral raise, and diagonal raises both left and right, followed by a reverse fly. This comprehensive movement targets all parts of the shoulder.

Title: Seated dumbbell lateral raise
Desc: The seated dumbbell lateral raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the medial or middle head of the deltoids. Performing it on a bench helps enforce strict form and eliminate swinging or using momentum to move the weights. Lateral raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms at your sides. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, lift the dumbbells out to the sides until your arms are parallel to the floor. Lower the weights back to the starting position. Focus on controlled movements to avoid swinging.

Title: AM Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the weights back to shoulder height. Keep your back straight and engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: AM Dumbbell Side Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. Lower them back down to the starting position. Focus on using your shoulder muscles rather than momentum.

Title: AM Front Raise
Desc: The alternating dumbbell front raise is an isolation movement that targets the shoulders. By using one arm at a time, you can use more weight than when you use both arms at once. Bodybuilders use this exercise to zero in on the front shoulders, but the simple movement also makes it great for people new to lifting weights.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at your thigh. Raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arm straight. Lower it back down and repeat with the other arm. Alternate arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: UP Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. With a slight bend in your elbows, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are parallel to the ground. Lower them back down to the starting position. Focus on using your shoulder muscles rather than momentum.

Title: UP Seated Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: The seated dumbbell shoulder pressis an exercise for building muscle and strengthening the shoulders, particularly but not exclusively the front heads. The triceps also assist. Some lifters feel that using dumbbells versus a barbell reduced injury risk.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower the weights back to shoulder height. Keep your back straight and engage your core throughout the movement.

Title: AA Incline Bench Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The AA Incline Bench Dumbbell Reverse Fly is an exercise that targets the upper back and rear deltoids. It is performed on an incline bench, using dumbbells to perform a reverse fly motion, which helps improve posture and shoulder strength.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand. With your arms hanging down, lift the dumbbells out to the sides in a reverse fly motion until your arms are parallel to the ground. Lower them back down slowly. This targets the rear deltoids and upper back.

Title: CM Forward Shoulder Press
Desc: The CM Forward Shoulder Press is an exercise that targets the shoulders and triceps. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height, and press upward until your arms are fully extended. Lower back to the starting position.
