HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height, and press upward until your arms are fully extended. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell Halo
Desc: The Dumbbell Halo is a shoulder mobility exercise. Hold a dumbbell with both hands and move it around your head in a circular motion, keeping your core engaged and maintaining a stable stance. This exercise helps improve shoulder flexibility and stability.
HowTo: Hold a dumbbell with both hands and move it around your head in a circular motion, keeping your core engaged and maintaining a stable stance.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Scap Raise
Desc: The Standing Dumbbell Scap Raise targets the upper back and shoulders. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent, focusing on squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: Holman Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Overhead Press is a compound exercise that primarily works the shoulders and triceps. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height, and press the weight overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower back to the starting position.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a barbell or dumbbells at shoulder height, and press the weight overhead until your arms are fully extended. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Slow Weighted Half Jack to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Weighted Half Jack to Overhead Press combines a half jumping jack with an overhead press. Start in a standing position, perform a half jack by stepping out to the side while raising the weights overhead, then return to the starting position.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, perform a half jack by stepping out to the side while raising the weights overhead, then return to the starting position.

Title: Holman Slow Arnold Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Arnold Press is a variation of the shoulder press that engages multiple shoulder muscles. Start with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing you. As you press the weights overhead, rotate your palms to face forward. Lower back to the starting position.
HowTo: Start with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing you. As you press the weights overhead, rotate your palms to face forward. Lower back to the starting position.

Title: Holman Boat Arnold Press with Feet Push-Out
Desc: The Holman Boat Arnold Press with Feet Push-Out is a challenging core and shoulder exercise. Sit in a boat position with your legs extended and hold dumbbells at shoulder height. As you press the weights overhead, push your feet out, engaging your core.
HowTo: Sit in a boat position with your legs extended and hold dumbbells at shoulder height. As you press the weights overhead, push your feet out, engaging your core.

Title: Holman Dumbbell Hip Drive to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Dumbbell Hip Drive to Overhead Press is a dynamic exercise that combines a hip drive with an overhead press. Start in a standing position with dumbbells at your sides. Perform a hip drive by thrusting your hips forward while pressing the weights overhead.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with dumbbells at your sides. Perform a hip drive by thrusting your hips forward while pressing the weights overhead.

Title: Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Renegade Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Squat Thrust to Alternating Renegade Triceps Press combines a squat thrust with a renegade row, focusing on core stability and upper body strength. Start in a plank position, perform a squat thrust, then alternate pressing each arm back while stabilizing your body.
HowTo: Start in a plank position with your hands under your shoulders. Perform a squat thrust by jumping your feet towards your hands, then jump back into the plank position. Alternate pressing each arm back while stabilizing your body.

Title: Holman Cheer Press
Desc: The Holman Cheer Press is an overhead press variation that emphasizes shoulder stability and strength. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, press weights overhead while engaging your core, and maintain a strong posture throughout the movement.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold weights at shoulder height, and press them overhead while engaging your core. Maintain a strong posture throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Left Arm Press with Right Arm Hold
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Press with Right Arm Hold involves pressing a weight with the left arm while holding a weight in the right arm at shoulder height. This exercise enhances unilateral strength and core stability.
HowTo: Stand with a weight in your left hand. Press the weight overhead with your left arm while holding a weight in your right arm at shoulder height. Keep your core engaged for stability.

Title: Holman Right Arm Press with Left Arm Hold
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Press with Left Arm Hold is similar to the left arm press but focuses on the right arm. Press a weight overhead with the right arm while holding a weight in the left arm at shoulder height.
HowTo: Stand with a weight in your right hand. Press the weight overhead with your right arm while holding a weight in your left arm at shoulder height. Engage your core for stability.

Title: Holman Left Front Raise with Right Hold
Desc: The Holman Left Front Raise with Right Hold targets the shoulders and upper back. Raise a weight in the left arm to shoulder height while holding a weight in the right arm at your side.
HowTo: Stand with a weight in your left hand. Raise the weight in your left arm to shoulder height while holding a weight in your right arm at your side. Keep your posture upright.

Title: Holman Right Front Raise with Left Hold
Desc: The Holman Right Front Raise with Left Hold is a shoulder exercise where you raise a weight in the right arm to shoulder height while holding a weight in the left arm at your side.
HowTo: Stand with a weight in your right hand. Raise the weight in your right arm to shoulder height while holding a weight in your left arm at your side. Maintain a strong posture.

Title: Holman Alternating Front Raise to Side Raise
Desc: The Holman Alternating Front Raise to Side Raise combines two movements to work the shoulders. Raise weights in front of you, then transition to raising them to the side, alternating arms.
HowTo: Stand with weights in both hands at your sides. Raise one weight in front of you to shoulder height, then lower it and raise the other weight to the side. Alternate between front and side raises.

Title: Holman Heavy Right Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Right Arm Overhead Press focuses on building strength in the right shoulder. Press a heavy weight overhead while maintaining proper form and engaging your core.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a heavy weight in your right hand. Press the weight overhead while keeping your core engaged and maintaining proper form.

Title: Holman Heavy Left Arm Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Left Arm Overhead Press is a strength exercise that targets the shoulders, triceps, and upper chest. It involves pressing a weight overhead with the left arm while maintaining a stable core and proper posture.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Press the dumbbell overhead with your left arm, keeping your elbow close to your ear. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Right Arm Heavy Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Right Arm Heavy Overhead Press is a unilateral strength exercise focusing on the right shoulder, triceps, and upper chest. It requires pressing a weight overhead with the right arm, emphasizing stability and control.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your right hand. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Press the dumbbell overhead with your right arm, keeping your elbow close to your ear. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Right Diagonal Lunge to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Right Diagonal Lunge to Overhead Press combines a lunge with an overhead press, targeting the legs, glutes, shoulders, and core. This dynamic movement enhances strength and coordination.
HowTo: Begin by standing with your feet shoulder-width apart. Step your right leg diagonally back into a lunge while simultaneously pressing a dumbbell overhead with your right arm. Ensure your left knee does not go past your toes. Return to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Left Arm Heavy Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Left Arm Heavy Overhead Press is an exercise that isolates the left shoulder and triceps by pressing a weight overhead with the left arm, promoting strength and muscular balance.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in your left hand. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Press the dumbbell overhead with your left arm, keeping your elbow close to your ear. Lower the weight back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Weighted Palms-In Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Weighted Palms-In Overhead Press is a variation of the overhead press where the palms face each other. This exercise targets the shoulders and triceps while reducing strain on the shoulder joints.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your palms facing each other. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Press the dumbbells overhead while keeping your palms facing inwards. Lower the weights back to shoulder height and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell racked carry
Desc: The dumbbell racked carry involves carrying dumbbells for time or distance, while holding them close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: Stand tall and hold a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, elbows tucked in. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Walk forward while keeping the dumbbells close to your shoulders, focusing on stability and control. Continue for the desired distance or time.

Title: Dumbbell clean and push-press
Desc: The dumbbell clean and push-press is a full-body movement that targets both the lower and upper body. The clean utilizes the muscles of the hips, legs, glutes, back, and biceps, while the push-press utilizes the shoulders and triceps. It differs from the clean and press in that the push-press allows you to use lower-body momentum to power through the most difficult part of the press. It can be trained in low to moderate reps for strength, or for higher reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, for muscle building or metabolic conditioning.
Muscles: Shoulders, Triceps, Legs, Glutes, Back, Biceps
HowTo: Start with a dumbbell on the floor between your feet. Hinge at your hips and grasp the dumbbell with both hands. Clean the dumbbell to your shoulders by extending your hips and pulling the weight up. Once at shoulder height, dip slightly and then press the dumbbell overhead using your legs for momentum. Lower the dumbbell back to your shoulders and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Total Fitness Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: Stand tall with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Engage your core and maintain a straight posture. Walk forward while holding the dumbbells at your sides, keeping your shoulders back and down. Focus on maintaining a steady pace and good form for the desired distance or time.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell racked carry
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell racked carry involves carrying a single dumbbell for time or distance, while holding it close to the shoulders in a front-racked position. Similar to a dumbbell farmer's carry, it can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in one hand, resting it close to your shoulder in a front-racked position. 2. Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine. 3. Begin walking forward while keeping the dumbbell close to your body. 4. Continue walking for the desired distance or time, then switch arms and repeat.

Title: Jordan Shallow Dumbbell Pull-Over
Desc: The Jordan Shallow Dumbbell Pull-Over is an effective exercise for targeting the chest, triceps, and lats. To perform this exercise, lie on a bench with your upper back supported and feet flat on the ground. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest, arms extended. Slowly lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping a slight bend in your elbows, then raise it back to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with your upper back supported and feet flat on the ground. 2. Hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest, arms extended. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell back over your head while keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 4. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The dumbbell lateral raise is an upper body isolation exercise for building shoulder strength and muscle. It's a staple strength training move and is a great option for accessory work on upper body training days. This exercise particularly focuses on the lateral or medial head of the deltoid, making them appear wider and more developed.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keep your elbows slightly bent and raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell shadow boxing
Desc: Dumbbell shadow boxing is a more advanced version of a popular conditioning exercise. By adding a pair of lightweight dumbbells, you can greatly increase the challenge to both the shoulders and cardiovascular system.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a lightweight dumbbell in each hand. 2. Begin moving your arms in a punching motion while maintaining a light bounce in your legs. 3. Alternate punches while keeping your core engaged and maintaining proper form.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Farmer's Carry
Desc: The dumbbell farmer's walk or carry is an exercise with roots in competitive strongman training, but which is also popular in CrossFit and functional training. It can be a challenging finisher to any workout, or work well in fat-loss circuit training or as an accessory movement to heavy lifts like the deadlift.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Engage your core and maintain a neutral spine. 3. Begin walking forward while holding the dumbbells at your sides. 4. Continue walking for the desired distance or time.

Title: King Maker Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The standing dumbbell shrug is a popular movement to build and strengthen the trapezius muscles. It’s a often trained on a bodybuilding-style shoulder or back training day, but can also work well in full-body or strength-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Stand upright with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Keep your arms straight and lift the dumbbells up towards your shoulders by shrugging your shoulders. 3. Hold the contraction for a moment, then lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Alternating Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Alternating Dumbbell Front Raise is a great exercise for building shoulder strength and stability. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arm straight, then lower it back down and repeat with the other arm. This exercise can be performed for a set number of repetitions or time.
HowTo: 1. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. 2. Raise one dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arm straight. 3. Lower it back down and repeat with the other arm. 4. Continue alternating arms for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Dumbbell Reverse Fly is designed to strengthen the rear deltoids and upper back. Begin by bending at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement, then lower back to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, holding a dumbbell in each hand with your arms hanging down. 2. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent. 3. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbells back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Front Raise primarily targets the anterior deltoids. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The Dumbbell Lateral Raise focuses on the lateral deltoids. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift the weights out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift the weights out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows.

Title: 30 Shoulders Dumbbell Shrug
Desc: The Dumbbell Shrug targets the trapezius muscles. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing at the top before lowering back down.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift your shoulders towards your ears, squeezing at the top before lowering back down.

Title: 30 Shoulders Incline Face-Down Dumbbell Reverse Fly
Desc: The Incline Face-Down Dumbbell Reverse Fly works the rear deltoids and upper back. Lie face down on an incline bench, hold a dumbbell in each hand, and raise the weights out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Lie face down on an incline bench, hold a dumbbell in each hand, and raise the weights out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The Seated Dumbbell Front Raise targets the anterior deltoids. Sit on a bench with back support, hold a dumbbell in each hand at thigh level, and raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with back support, hold a dumbbell in each hand at thigh level, and raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.

Title: 30 Shoulders Seated Dumbbell Side Raise
Desc: The Seated Dumbbell Side Raise focuses on the lateral deltoids. Sit on a bench with back support, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift the weights out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with back support, hold a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, and lift the weights out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, maintaining a slight bend in your elbows.

Title: 30 Shoulders Neutral-Grip Arnold Press
Desc: The Neutral-Grip Arnold Press targets the entire shoulder area. Sit or stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. Rotate your palms away as you press the weights overhead, then reverse the motion to return.
HowTo: Sit or stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height, palms facing you. Rotate your palms away as you press the weights overhead, then reverse the motion to return.

Title: 30 Shoulders Standing Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The Standing Dumbbell Upright Row primarily targets the shoulders and traps. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs, and lift the weights up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, hold a dumbbell in each hand in front of your thighs, and lift the weights up towards your chin, keeping them close to your body.

Title: MetaBurn 3-Way Shoulder Raise
Desc: The MetaBurn 3-Way Shoulder Raise is a versatile exercise targeting the shoulders, incorporating three different angles to effectively engage the deltoid muscles. It helps improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Raise the dumbbells to the front at a 45-degree angle, then to the side, and finally overhead, ensuring to engage your core and maintain a stable posture throughout.

Title: MetaBurn Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Dumbbell Overhead Press is a powerful upper body exercise that targets the shoulders, triceps, and upper chest. It involves pressing dumbbells overhead, enhancing shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to the starting position.

Title: MetaBurn Single-Leg Arnold Press
Desc: The MetaBurn Single-Leg Arnold Press is a dynamic shoulder exercise that combines balance and strength. By performing the Arnold press on one leg, it challenges stability while targeting the deltoids and core.
HowTo: Stand on one leg while holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead while maintaining your balance on the standing leg, then lower them back to shoulder height.

Title: RG Forward-Leaning Dumbbell Upright Row
Desc: The RG Forward-Leaning Dumbbell Upright Row is an effective exercise for building shoulder and upper back strength. Leaning forward slightly while lifting dumbbells helps engage the trapezius and deltoids.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Lean forward slightly from your hips, keeping your back straight. Pull the dumbbells up towards your chest, leading with your elbows, then lower them back down.

Title: RG Alternating Seated Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The RG Alternating Seated Dumbbell Lateral Raise is a shoulder exercise that targets the lateral deltoids. By performing the raise alternately while seated, it minimizes momentum and focuses on muscle engagement.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight, holding a dumbbell in each hand at your sides. Raise one dumbbell out to the side until your arm is parallel to the floor, then lower it back down. Alternate with the other arm.

Title: RG Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press
Desc: The RG Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press is a fundamental exercise for building shoulder strength. Sitting while pressing dumbbells overhead helps isolate the shoulder muscles and provides stability during the movement.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your back straight, holding a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbells overhead until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back to shoulder height.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Clean and Jerk
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Clean and Jerk is a full-body exercise that combines strength and explosive power. It involves lifting dumbbells from the ground to the shoulders and then pressing them overhead, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in each hand. Squat down to lift the dumbbells from the ground to your shoulders, then explosively press them overhead, extending your arms fully.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Cross-Body Front Raise
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Cross-Body Front Raise is an isolation exercise that targets the front deltoids. By raising the dumbbell across the body, it enhances shoulder stability and strength while improving coordination.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. Raise the dumbbell across your body to the opposite shoulder height, then lower it back down. Repeat with the other arm.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Front Raise
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Front Raise targets the anterior deltoids and upper chest. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, palms facing your thighs. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. Lower back down and repeat.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, palms facing your thighs. Raise the dumbbells in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Dumbbell Lateral Raise
Desc: The FYR2 Dumbbell Lateral Raise focuses on the lateral deltoids. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, palms facing your body. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower back down and repeat.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at your sides, palms facing your body. Raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they reach shoulder height, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. Lower back down and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Lateral Raise Hold
Desc: The FYR2 Lateral Raise Hold is an isometric exercise for the shoulders. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand and raise them to shoulder height with arms extended. Hold this position for a specified duration to build endurance in the deltoids.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand and raise them to shoulder height with arms extended. Hold this position for a specified duration to build endurance in the deltoids.

Title: FYR2 Seesaw Dumbbell Military Press
Desc: The FYR2 Seesaw Dumbbell Military Press is a compound shoulder exercise. Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other to shoulder level, alternating the movement in a seesaw fashion.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. Press one dumbbell overhead while lowering the other to shoulder level, alternating the movement in a seesaw fashion.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Halo
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Halo is a dynamic shoulder exercise. Hold a single dumbbell with both hands and move it around your head in a circular motion, engaging your core and shoulders throughout the movement.
HowTo: Hold a single dumbbell with both hands and move it around your head in a circular motion, engaging your core and shoulders throughout the movement.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Overhead Press
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Overhead Press is a strength exercise for the shoulders and triceps. Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.
HowTo: Stand with a dumbbell in one hand at shoulder height. Press the dumbbell overhead until your arm is fully extended, then lower it back to the starting position.

Title: Car driver
Desc: The car driver is a variation of the plate front raise exercise where the lifter holds a weight plate in front of them and twists it from side to side, similar to a steering wheel. It targets the muscles of the shoulders, the front or anterior deltoids in particular, but is also challenging to the core and upper-back muscles. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: Hold a weight plate in front of you with both hands. Twist the plate from side to side, similar to turning a steering wheel, engaging your shoulders, core, and upper back.

Title: Arnold press
Desc: Named after the iconic bodybuilder and movie star, the Arnold press adds rotation to a classic shoulder press. It allows the hands to rotate naturally, while also hitting all three heads of the deltoids in one motion. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Start with the dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing you. As you press the weights overhead, rotate your palms to face forward, then lower back to the starting position.

Title: Front Plate Raise
Desc: The plate front raise is a variation of the dumbbell front raise where the lifter holds a weight plate between two hands, rather than using a dumbbell, barbell, or other weight. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout, or as part of an upper body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands in front of your thighs. Raise the plate in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight. Lower it back down to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Battle ropes
Desc: Battle ropes are an explosive training tool that involves moving the rope in waves with the other end of the rope anchored at ground level. There are many different types of waves, but the most common is alternating waves with the left and right hands. The battle ropes can be performed for short bursts as power training, for longer durations as cardiovascular training, or as a component of a conditioning or fat-loss circuit.
HowTo: Anchor one end of the battle rope to the ground. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding one end of the rope in each hand. Alternate raising and lowering your arms to create waves in the rope. Perform for a set duration or number of repetitions, focusing on maintaining a strong core and proper form.

Title: Seated rear delt fly
Desc: The seated rear delt fly is an upper-body exercise that targets the real deltoid of the shoulder. By performing the movement seated, it eliminates momentum from the rest of the body. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with your feet flat on the ground. Hold a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended downward. Keeping your elbows slightly bent, raise the dumbbells out to the sides until they are level with your shoulders. Slowly lower them back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Circus Bell
Desc: The Circus Bell is an exercise that involves balancing on one foot while lifting the opposite leg and arm, mimicking the act of a circus performer. It enhances stability, coordination, and core strength.
HowTo: Stand on one foot and lift the opposite leg and arm simultaneously, balancing your body. Hold this position for a few seconds, focusing on stability and core engagement. Switch sides and repeat.

Title: Landmine Linear Jammer
Desc: The linear jammer is an explosive pressing movement performed using an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The linear jammer involves pressing the weight into the air, then catching it with the other hand. The movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges, for lower reps with a focus on explosive pressing power, or for higher reps.
HowTo: Stand facing the landmine device with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grip the barbell with both hands at shoulder height. Explosively press the barbell overhead while extending your legs and hips. Catch the barbell with the opposite hand as it comes down, and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Crucifix
Desc: The Crucifix is an exercise that targets the upper body and core, where the individual lies on their back and lifts their arms and legs to form a 'T' shape, engaging the muscles in the shoulders and abdomen.
HowTo: Lie on your back with your arms and legs extended. Lift your arms and legs simultaneously to form a 'T' shape, engaging your core and shoulder muscles. Hold for a few seconds, then lower back to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Bar shoulder extension stretch
Desc: The bar shoulder extension stretch is a technique to increase overhead mobility (known as shoulder flexion) and thoracic extension with the help of a bar or other stable object. It is often used as part of a warm-up before upper-body training.
HowTo: Stand or kneel and hold a barbell or stable object behind your back with both hands. Keeping your arms straight, lift the barbell upwards and backwards to increase shoulder flexion and thoracic extension. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, then return to the starting position.

Title: Chair Upper Body Stretch
Desc: The Chair Upper Body Stretch is a gentle stretch performed while seated in a chair, designed to improve flexibility in the upper body, particularly the shoulders and chest, by reaching the arms overhead and leaning to the sides.
HowTo: Sit in a chair with your back straight. Reach your arms overhead and lean to one side, feeling the stretch in your side and shoulder. Hold for a few seconds, then switch to the other side. Repeat for several repetitions.

Title: Sled Reverse Flye
Desc: The Sled Reverse Flye is an exercise that targets the upper back and shoulders. It involves pulling a sled backward while performing a flye motion with the arms, helping to improve shoulder stability and strength.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, grasp the sled handles, and pull the sled backward while extending your arms out to the sides in a flye motion. Focus on engaging your upper back and shoulders throughout the movement.

Title: Plate shoulder circle big to small
Desc: The Sled Overhead Backward Walk is a functional exercise that focuses on building strength in the legs and shoulders. It involves walking backward while pushing a sled overhead, enhancing coordination and stability.
HowTo: Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold a weight plate in both hands, and perform large circular motions with your arms, gradually making the circles smaller. Ensure to engage your shoulders and maintain a stable core throughout the exercise.

Title: Sled Overhead Backward Walk
Desc: The Log Lift is a strength training exercise that targets the entire body, particularly the legs, back, and shoulders. It involves lifting a log from the ground to shoulder height, promoting functional strength and power.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, bend at the hips and knees to grasp the log on the ground. Lift the log by extending your hips and knees, bringing it to shoulder height while keeping your back straight and core engaged.

Title: Log Lift
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, grasp the log with both hands, and lift it from the ground to shoulder height, ensuring to keep your back straight and engage your legs and core throughout the lift.

Title: Standing suspended rear delt fly
Desc: The standing suspended rear delt fly is a bodyweight movement targeting the shoulders and upper back using a suspension strap system or gymnastic rings. It can be performed for time or reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for an upper-body strength workout, or in the workout itself either in traditional muscle-building rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: Attach suspension straps or use gymnastic rings, lean forward slightly, and pull your arms back in a flye motion while keeping your elbows slightly bent. Focus on squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement.

Title: Waiter's carry
Desc: The waiter's carry is a type of loaded carry that targets the core, shoulders, and upper back. A weight is raised overhead with a single arm before the lifter begins walking in that position. It resembles a waiter carrying a tray overhead—hence the name. It can be performed for time or distance.
HowTo: Stand tall, hold a weight overhead with one arm, and walk forward or backward while maintaining a stable core and straight posture. Switch arms as needed to balance the workout.

Title: Towel dumbbell front raise
Desc: The towel dumbbell front raise is a variation of the dumbbell front raise that involves hanging a dumbbell from a towel held in the hands. It could also be performed with a kettlebell or weight plate. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: Hold a towel with a dumbbell hanging from it in both hands, and raise the dumbbell in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. Lower it back down with control and repeat.

Title: Reach-roll-lift combo
Desc: The reach-roll-lift combo is a mobility drill for the upper back and shoulders. It can be part of a dynamic warm-up for upper-body workouts, or as postural training anytime.
HowTo: Start in a standing position, reach forward with one arm, roll your torso to the side, and lift your arm overhead. Alternate sides to complete the combo, focusing on mobility and control throughout the movement.

Title: Upright Row - Gethin Variation
Desc: The barbell upright row is a barbell exercise that builds stronger and bigger traps. Many lifters combine this move with either their back or shoulder workout since it involves both body parts.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with an overhand grip. 2. Pull the barbell up towards your chin, keeping it close to your body. 3. Raise your elbows to shoulder height, squeezing your traps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the barbell back down to the starting position in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Squat Press Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Squat Press Shoulder Press - Gethin Variation combines a squat with a shoulder press to engage multiple muscle groups, including the legs, shoulders, and core. This exercise enhances strength and stability, making it a great addition to any workout routine.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Perform a squat by bending your knees and lowering your body. 3. As you rise from the squat, press the barbell overhead. 4. Lower the barbell back to shoulder height as you descend into the next squat. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Plate lateral raise
Desc: The plate lateral raise is an exercise targeting the side heads of the shoulder muscles or deltoids. It closely resembles the more popular dumbbell lateral raise, but is performed with light plates, making the movement slightly more difficult. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a shoulder or upper-body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a plate with both hands in front of your thighs. 2. Raise the plate out to the side, keeping your arms straight and lifting to shoulder height. 3. Squeeze your shoulder muscles at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the plate back down to the starting position in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Standing Military Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The military press is a compound movement used to build size and strength in the shoulders. It was once contested as a fourth powerlift, but is rarely competed anymore. However, being able to press a significant weight overhead remains a popular marker of upper-body strength. The military press can be trained as a strength lift or in traditional muscle-building rep ranges as part of full-body, shoulder-focused, or upper-body training.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and press the barbell overhead until your arms are fully extended. 3. Lower the barbell back down to shoulder height with control. 4. Keep your back straight and avoid arching your lower back during the movement. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Bent-over plate rear delt raise
Desc: The bent-over plate rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, or deltoids. You can also use dumbbells or other light weights for a similar effect. This movement is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up or as a high-rep burnout movement on a shoulder or back day.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the hips and knees, holding a plate in each hand with your arms hanging down. 2. Raise the plates out to the side, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 3. Lift until your arms are parallel to the ground, keeping a slight bend in your elbows. 4. Lower the plates back down to the starting position in a controlled manner. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm landmine press
Desc: The single-arm landmine press is an upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The angle of a landmine press is usually somewhere between an incline press and a military press, and the movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding one end of a barbell anchored in a landmine device. 2. Press the barbell upward with one arm, keeping your core engaged. 3. Lower the barbell back down to shoulder height with control. 4. Ensure your movements are slow and controlled to maximize muscle engagement. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions before switching arms.

Title: Plate front raise
Desc: The plate front raise is a variation of the front raise where the lifter holds a weight plate between two hands, rather than using a dumbbell, barbell, or other weight. It can provide variety in a shoulder-focused muscle-building workout or as part of an upper-body or full-body circuit.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weight plate with both hands in front of your thighs. 2. Raise the plate in front of you, keeping your arms straight, until it reaches shoulder height. 3. Hold for a moment at the top, then lower the plate back down to the starting position. 4. Maintain a slight bend in your elbows throughout the movement. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Holman Slow Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Slow Overhead Press focuses on controlled movements to build shoulder strength and stability. This exercise emphasizes proper form and slow tempo, ensuring maximum muscle engagement and reducing the risk of injury.
HowTo: 1. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell at shoulder height. 2. Engage your core and press the barbell overhead slowly, focusing on controlled movement. 3. Lower the barbell back down to shoulder height with a slow tempo. 4. Ensure proper form throughout the movement to maximize muscle engagement and minimize injury risk. 5. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Plate Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Plate Front Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, particularly the anterior deltoids. To perform this exercise, hold a weight plate with both hands at hip level, then raise it in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. This movement helps improve shoulder strength and stability.
HowTo: To perform the 30 Shoulders Plate Front Raise, hold a weight plate with both hands at hip level. Raise the plate in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. Lower it back down to hip level and repeat.

Title: Single-arm landmine push-press
Desc: The single-arm landmine push-press is an explosive upper-body exercise that uses an angled barbell anchored at floor level in a landmine device. It can also be performed by sticking a barbell in the corner of a room, preferably in a towel to protect the walls. The angle of a landmine press is usually somewhere between an incline press and a military press, and the movement focuses primarily on the muscles of the shoulders or deltoids. It can be trained in traditional muscle and strength-focused rep ranges or for higher reps.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm landmine push-press, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold the end of a barbell anchored in a landmine device with one hand. Bend your knees slightly, then explosively press the barbell overhead while extending your legs. Lower it back down and repeat.

Title: Single-arm cable front raise
Desc: The single-arm cable front raise is an isolation exercise targeting the anterior and medial deltoids or shoulder muscles. The single-arm version of this movement allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip will be a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm cable front raise, stand next to a cable machine with the cable set at the lowest position. Grasp the handle with one hand and raise it in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. Lower it back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Cable Internal Rotation
Desc: The Cable Internal Rotation is an exercise designed to strengthen the rotator cuff muscles and improve shoulder stability. To perform this exercise, stand next to a cable machine with the cable set at elbow height. Hold the handle with the arm closest to the machine, keeping your elbow bent at 90 degrees. Rotate your arm inward towards your body, then return to the starting position. This exercise is beneficial for athletes and individuals looking to enhance shoulder health.
HowTo: To perform the Cable Internal Rotation, stand next to a cable machine with the cable at elbow height. Hold the handle with the arm closest to the machine, keeping your elbow bent at 90 degrees. Rotate your arm inward towards your body, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated face pull
Desc: The seated face pull is a cable exercise targeting the shoulder muscles, particularly the rear delts, and the muscles of the upper back. This can help build healthier shoulders and posture, and increase shoulder stability. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of a dynamic warm-up for an upper-body workout or in the main part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the seated face pull, sit at a cable machine with the pulley set at upper chest level. Grasp the rope attachment with both hands, palms facing each other. Pull the rope towards your face while keeping your elbows high, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly
Desc: The single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear deltoids. It is a great way to isolate this area of the shoulder and attack each side independently. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm bent-over cable rear delt fly, stand next to a cable machine and set the pulley at the lowest position. Bend at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, and grasp the handle with one hand. With your arm slightly bent, raise it out to the side until it is parallel to the ground, then lower it back down. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Seated cable shoulder press
Desc: The seated cable shoulder press is a multijoint machine-based exercise that focuses on the deltoid or shoulder muscles, as well as the triceps. It's most common in muscle-building workouts and rep ranges, usually 8-12 reps or more.
HowTo: To perform the seated cable shoulder press, sit at a cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles with both hands at shoulder level. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended, then lower them back down to shoulder level. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing face pull
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: To perform the standing face pull, stand in front of a cable machine with the pulley set at upper chest level. Grasp the rope attachment with both hands, palms facing each other. Pull the rope towards your face while keeping your elbows high and squeezing your shoulder blades together, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Standing cable rear delt row
Desc: The standing cable rear delt row primarily targets the rear deltoids. This movement also hits the traps, rhomboids, and biceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Stand facing the cable machine, grasp the handles with both hands. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables towards your chest, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing Low-Pulley Deltoid Raise
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back, and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper body or shoulders-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Stand next to the cable machine and grasp the handle with one hand. 3. With a slight bend in your elbow, raise the cable out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Standing crossed-cable rear delt fly
Desc: The standing crossed-cable rear delt fly is an isolation exercise for the rear deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulleys to a high position. 2. Stand in the center of the cable machine, grasping the handles with both hands. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables out to the sides in a reverse fly motion. 4. Squeeze your shoulder blades together at the peak of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable Shoulder Press
Desc: The Cable Shoulder Press is an effective exercise for building shoulder strength and stability. It targets the deltoid muscles and allows for a controlled movement using a cable machine.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low or mid position. 2. Stand facing away from the cable machine and grasp the handles at shoulder height. 3. Press the cables overhead until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower the cables back to shoulder height. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Alternating Cable Shoulder Press
Desc: The Alternating Cable Shoulder Press is a variation of the shoulder press that emphasizes unilateral strength and stability. It engages the deltoids while allowing for a greater range of motion and balance.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low or mid position. 2. Stand facing away from the cable machine and grasp the handles at shoulder height. 3. Press one cable overhead while keeping the other at shoulder height. 4. Alternate arms, pressing one at a time. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Cable Seated Lateral Raise
Desc: The Cable Seated Lateral Raise is designed to isolate the lateral deltoid muscles. By using cables, this exercise provides constant tension throughout the movement, enhancing shoulder development.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Sit on a bench with back support, grasping the handle with one hand. 3. With a slight bend in your elbow, raise the cable out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Single-arm lying cable front raise
Desc: The single-arm lying cable front raise is an isolation exercise for the shoulders, performed lying on the back, either on a bench or the ground, and lifting the cable over the torso one arm at a time. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Lie on your back on a bench or the ground, holding the cable handle in one hand. 3. With a slight bend in your elbow, lift the cable over your torso until your arm is fully extended. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each side.

Title: Lying cable front raise
Desc: The lying cable front raise is an isolation exercise for the shoulders, particularly the front deltoids. It is performed lying on the back, either on a bench or the ground, with the cable lifted over the torso. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of a shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Lie on your back on a bench or the ground, holding the cable handle in both hands. 3. With a slight bend in your elbows, lift the cable over your torso until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly lower back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable Rear Delt Fly - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing crossed-cable rear delt fly is an isolation exercise for the rear deltoids. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the Cable Rear Delt Fly, stand facing the cable machine with the pulleys set at shoulder height. Grasp the handles with both hands, crossing them in front of your body. With a slight bend in your elbows, pull the cables out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: One-Arm Cable Side Raise - Gethin Variation
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back, and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper body or shoulders-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the One-Arm Cable Side Raise, stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. Grasp the handle with the hand furthest from the machine. Keep your body straight and raise the cable handle out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch sides.

Title: Rope Face Pull - Gethin Variation
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: To perform the Rope Face Pull, stand facing a cable machine with the rope attachment set at upper chest height. Grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. Step back to create tension in the cable. Pull the rope towards your face, separating the ends of the rope as you do so, and squeeze your shoulder blades together. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Lying cable lateral raise
Desc: The lying cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise that targets the medial or middle deltoid muscle of the shoulders. It is most common in muscle-building shoulder or upper-body workouts, usually in higher rep ranges of at least 8-12 reps per set.
HowTo: To perform the Lying Cable Lateral Raise, lie on your side on a bench with the cable machine on the side you are lying on. Grasp the handle with the hand on top. Keeping your elbow slightly bent, raise the cable handle upwards until your arm is parallel to the ground. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch sides.

Title: Cable seated row
Desc: The cable seated row is a popular exercise to train the muscles of the upper back, including the lats (latissimus dorsi), traps, rhomboids, and rear deltoids, using a cable stack. It also targets the biceps to a lesser degree. The cable row can work well in a variety of rep ranges but is most popular in muscle-building workouts or as an accessory movement for strength workouts.
Muscles: Lats, Traps, Rhomboids, Rear Deltoids, Biceps
HowTo: To perform the Cable Seated Row, sit on the cable machine with your feet on the platform and grasp the handle with both hands. Keep your back straight and pull the handle towards your abdomen, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Slowly extend your arms back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Single-arm cable lateral raise
Desc: The single-arm cable lateral raise is an isolation exercise targeting the shoulders, specifically the medial deltoid. This movement also hits the traps and upper back and allows you to focus on each side independently. Because grip is a limitation, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the Single-Arm Cable Lateral Raise, stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. Grasp the handle with the hand furthest from the machine. Keep your body straight and raise the cable handle out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps, then switch sides.

Title: UP Cable Face Pull
Desc: The standing face pull is an isolation exercise primarily targeting the rear deltoids, traps, and upper back. It is most often performed with a rope attachment.
HowTo: To perform the UP Cable Face Pull, stand facing a cable machine with the rope attachment set at upper chest height. Grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. Step back to create tension in the cable. Pull the rope towards your face, separating the ends of the rope as you do so, and squeeze your shoulder blades together. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: AA Cable Leaning Side Raise
Desc: The AA Cable Leaning Side Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, specifically the lateral deltoids. To perform this exercise, stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. Grasp the handle with the hand furthest from the machine and lean away from the machine at a slight angle. Keep your body straight and raise the cable handle out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.
HowTo: To perform the AA Cable Leaning Side Raise, stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at the lowest position. Grasp the handle with the hand furthest from the machine and lean away from the machine at a slight angle. Keep your body straight and raise the cable handle out to the side until your arm is parallel to the ground. Lower the handle back to the starting position and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: 30 Shoulders Bent-Over Low Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The Bent-Over Low Cable Reverse Fly targets the rear deltoids and upper back. Stand bent at the hips with a cable in each hand, pulling the cables out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent.
HowTo: Stand bent at the hips with a cable in each hand. Pull the cables out to the sides while keeping your elbows slightly bent.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Rope Face Pull
Desc: The Cable Rope Face Pull is an excellent exercise for shoulder health and stability. Using a cable machine, pull the rope towards your face while keeping your elbows high, focusing on squeezing the shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Using a cable machine, pull the rope towards your face while keeping your elbows high. Focus on squeezing the shoulder blades together.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Straight-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The Cable Straight-Bar Front Raise primarily targets the anterior deltoids. Stand facing the cable machine and raise the straight bar in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.
HowTo: Stand facing the cable machine and raise the straight bar in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your arms straight.

Title: 30 Shoulders Cable Straight-Bar Upright Row
Desc: The Cable Straight-Bar Upright Row is great for building shoulder and upper back strength. Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and pull the straight bar up to your chin, keeping your elbows above your wrists.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and pull the straight bar up to your chin, keeping your elbows above your wrists.

Title: 30 Shoulders High Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The High Cable Reverse Fly focuses on the rear deltoids and upper back. Stand facing the cable machine with the cables set high, and pull the cables out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.
HowTo: Stand facing the cable machine with the cables set high. Pull the cables out to the sides, squeezing your shoulder blades together.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Bent-Over Cable Reverse Fly
Desc: The Single-Arm Bent-Over Cable Reverse Fly isolates the rear deltoid of one arm at a time. Bend at the hips with one hand on a bench for support, and pull the cable out to the side with the other arm.
HowTo: Bend at the hips with one hand on a bench for support. Pull the cable out to the side with the other arm.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Cable Front Raise
Desc: The Single-Arm Cable Front Raise allows you to focus on one shoulder at a time. Stand side-on to the cable machine and raise the cable straight in front of you to shoulder height.
HowTo: Stand side-on to the cable machine and raise the cable straight in front of you to shoulder height.

Title: 30 Shoulders Single-Arm Leaning Cable Lateral Raise
Desc: The Single-Arm Leaning Cable Lateral Raise targets the lateral deltoid. Lean away from the cable machine and raise the cable out to the side, keeping your arm straight and focusing on the shoulder.
HowTo: Lean away from the cable machine and raise the cable out to the side, keeping your arm straight and focusing on the shoulder.

Title: RG 3-Way Single-Arm Rear Delt Cable Fly
Desc: The RG 3-Way Single-Arm Rear Delt Cable Fly is an exercise targeting the rear deltoids, performed by pulling the cable in three different directions to enhance shoulder stability and muscle development.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to the lowest position. 2. Stand with your side facing the cable machine, holding the handle with one hand. 3. Pull the cable out to the side at shoulder height, keeping your elbow slightly bent. 4. Return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: RG Single-Arm Cross-Body Cable Front Raise
Desc: The RG Single-Arm Cross-Body Cable Front Raise is an exercise that focuses on the anterior deltoid, performed by raising a cable across the body to build shoulder strength and improve muscle definition.
HowTo: 1. Set the cable pulley to a low position. 2. Stand with your side facing the cable machine, holding the handle with one hand. 3. Raise the cable across your body to shoulder height, keeping your arm straight. 4. Lower back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch sides.

Title: Smith machine shoulder press
Desc: The Smith machine shoulder press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoid muscles. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the Smith machine so that the bar is at shoulder level. 2. Sit down and grip the bar with a shoulder-width grip. 3. Press the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to shoulder level. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine shoulder press
Desc: The machine shoulder press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoid muscles. It approximates the motion of a free-weight shoulder press, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Many such machines also allow you to choose between different grips and grip widths. Machine shoulder presses are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or shoulder-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the machine so that the handles are at shoulder level. 2. Sit down and grip the handles with a shoulder-width grip. 3. Press the handles upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the handles back to shoulder level. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Reverse Machine Flyes
Desc: The machine rear delt fly is an exercise targeting the rear head of the shoulder muscle or deltoids, as well as the muscles of the upper back. It's sort of the reverse of the machine chest fly, and is sometimes performed on the same machine, but facing the opposite direction. Because it targets such small muscles, this exercise is usually performed with light weight for high reps, such as 10-15 reps per set or more.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat of the machine so that your chest is against the pad. 2. Grip the handles with your arms extended in front of you. 3. Pull the handles outward and back, squeezing your shoulder blades together. 4. Return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm Smith machine upright row
Desc: The single-arm Smith machine upright row is an upper-body exercise targeting the muscles of the traps and shoulders. This movement is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or shoulder-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Set the bar of the Smith machine to a comfortable height. 2. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the bar with both hands. 3. Pull the bar up towards your chin, keeping your elbows high. 4. Lower the bar back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Machine Lateral Raise
Desc: The Machine Lateral Raise is a strength training exercise that isolates the lateral deltoid muscles, performed on a machine to lift the arms outward to the sides, promoting shoulder width and strength.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the machine so that the handles are at your sides. 2. Sit down and grip the handles with your arms at your sides. 3. Lift the handles outward to the sides until your arms are parallel to the ground. 4. Lower the handles back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith machine behind-the-neck press
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-neck press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoids. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Adjust the seat height of the Smith machine so that the bar is at the back of your neck. 2. Sit down and grip the bar with a wide grip. 3. Press the bar upward until your arms are fully extended. 4. Lower the bar back to the starting position behind your neck. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Smith Machine Behind-The-Neck Press - Gethin Variation
Desc: The Smith machine behind-the-neck press is a machine-based exercise targeting the deltoids. The Smith machine mimics a barbell but provides more stability. This movement can be programmed in low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle and strength endurance. It is often performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of a shoulder or upper-body focused workout.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar at shoulder height. Position yourself under the bar, gripping it with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lift the bar off the rack and lower it behind your neck, keeping your elbows pointed down. Press the bar back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your deltoids.

Title: 30 Shoulders Leg Press Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Leg Press Shoulder Press is a compound exercise that targets the shoulders and legs. It involves pressing a weighted platform with your legs while simultaneously pressing overhead with your arms, engaging multiple muscle groups.
HowTo: Sit on the leg press machine with your back against the pad and feet on the platform. Press the platform away using your legs while simultaneously pressing the handles overhead with your arms. Lower the platform back towards you while controlling the weights, ensuring to engage your shoulders and legs throughout the movement.

Title: 30 Shoulders Machine Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Machine Shoulder Press is an isolation exercise that focuses on the shoulder muscles. Using a shoulder press machine, you push the handles upward to strengthen the deltoids and triceps.
HowTo: Sit on the shoulder press machine with your back supported. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. Grip the handles and press them upward until your arms are fully extended. Slowly lower the handles back to the starting position, focusing on the contraction of your shoulder muscles.

Title: 30 Shoulders Pec-Deck Reverse Fly
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Pec-Deck Reverse Fly is an exercise that targets the rear deltoids and upper back. It is performed on a pec-deck machine, where you pull the arms back in a reverse fly motion.
HowTo: Sit on the pec-deck machine with your chest against the pad. Grasp the handles with your arms extended in front of you. Pull the handles back in a reverse fly motion, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Return to the starting position with control, ensuring to focus on the rear deltoids and upper back.

Title: 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Behind-The-Head Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Behind-The-Head Press is a shoulder exercise that utilizes a Smith machine to press the barbell behind the head, effectively targeting the deltoid muscles.
HowTo: Set the Smith machine bar at a comfortable height behind your head. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the bar behind your head until your elbows are at about a 90-degree angle. Press the bar back up to the starting position, engaging your deltoids.

Title: 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Shoulder Press
Desc: The 30 Shoulders Smith Machine Shoulder Press is a strength training exercise that targets the shoulders. It involves pressing a barbell upward using a Smith machine, providing stability and control.
HowTo: Adjust the Smith machine bar to shoulder height. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and grip the bar with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lift the bar off the rack and press it upward until your arms are fully extended. Lower the bar back to shoulder level with control, focusing on your shoulder muscles.

Title: Handstand push-up
Desc: The handstand push-up is an exercise targeting the shoulders, although other muscles assist in the completion of the reps. It is common in both CrossFit workouts and advanced bodyweight or calisthenics training. Given the degree of difficulty, beginners will need to progress to this move.
HowTo: Begin in a handstand position against a wall for support. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your head nearly touches the ground. Press back up to the starting position, keeping your core engaged and body straight throughout the movement. Progress to freestanding handstand push-ups as you gain strength.

Title: Upward Stretch
Desc: The Upward Stretch is a flexibility exercise aimed at improving the range of motion in the upper body. It involves reaching upward with both arms to stretch the shoulders, chest, and back.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Reach both arms upward, extending through your fingertips. Hold the stretch for a few seconds, feeling the stretch in your shoulders, chest, and back. Repeat the movement for several repetitions to improve flexibility.

Title: Shoulder Circles
Desc: Shoulder circles involve rotating the shoulders in a circular motion to improve flexibility and mobility in the shoulder joints.
HowTo: Stand or sit comfortably with your arms relaxed at your sides. Slowly lift your shoulders towards your ears, then roll them back and down in a circular motion. Repeat for several repetitions, then switch directions.

Title: Cross-body shoulder stretch
Desc: The cross-body shoulder stretch targets increased flexibility in the shoulders. It is a common inclusion in upper-body dynamic warm-ups prior to training or sports, but can also be performed anytime to "limber up" the upper body.
HowTo: Stand or sit upright. Bring one arm across your body at shoulder height. Use the opposite arm to gently pull the extended arm closer to your chest, feeling a stretch in the shoulder. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch arms.

Title: Arm circle
Desc: The arm circle is a non-weighted exercise targeting the shoulders. It involves extending your arms to the sides and drawing small circles in the air with your hands. It is common in warm-ups for both training and athletics, and is often performed simply until someone feels a burn, rather than for a set amount of reps.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Extend your arms out to the sides at shoulder height. Begin to make small circles with your hands, gradually increasing the size of the circles. Continue for 15-30 seconds, then reverse the direction.

Title: Seated Front Deltoid
Desc: The seated front deltoid exercise targets the front part of the shoulder muscles while sitting, providing stability and focus on the deltoids.
HowTo: Sit on a bench or chair with your back straight. Hold weights in both hands at your thighs. Raise the weights in front of you to shoulder height, keeping your elbows slightly bent. Lower back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Shoulder Raise
Desc: Shoulder raises are performed by lifting weights or arms upward to strengthen the shoulder muscles, particularly the trapezius.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding weights in both hands at your sides. Raise your shoulders upward towards your ears, then lower them back down. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Hand Stand Push-Up
Desc: The handstand push-up is an exercise targeting the shoulders, although other muscles assist in the completion of the reps. It is common in both CrossFit workouts and advanced bodyweight or calisthenics training. Given the degree of difficulty, beginners will want to progress to this move.
HowTo: Begin in a handstand position against a wall. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your head nearly touches the ground. Push back up to the starting position. If you're a beginner, practice kicking up to the wall and building strength with pike push-ups first.

Title: Wall walk
Desc: The wall walk is a challenging exercise that works the entire body. From a push-up position, the hands walk back as the feet walk up the wall, then the whole movement is reversed. This is not for beginners, who will need to progress to this exercise.
HowTo: Start in a push-up position with your feet against a wall. Walk your hands back towards the wall while simultaneously walking your feet up the wall. Once you reach the desired position, reverse the movement to return to the starting position. Ensure you have sufficient strength and control before attempting.

Title: Return Push from Stance
Desc: Return push from stance is an exercise that involves pushing from a standing position, engaging the shoulders and arms for strength and stability.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with your feet shoulder-width apart. Bend your knees slightly and push through your heels as you engage your shoulders and arms to push forward. Focus on maintaining a strong core and controlled movement.

Title: Wall shoulder tap
Desc: The wall shoulder tap is a bodyweight shoulder exercise that is a popular movement for gymnasts, cheerleaders, and other athletes who need to spend a lot of time in dynamic handstand movements. Beginning in a handstand position with toes touching the wall, one hand is raised to touch the opposing shoulder. This continues in alternating fashion for the duration of the set.
HowTo: Begin in a handstand position with your toes touching the wall. Alternate raising one hand to touch the opposite shoulder, continuing this movement for the duration of the set.

Title: Bear crawl shoulder tap
Desc: The bear crawl shoulder tap is a variation of the bear crawl that involves touching the opposing shoulder while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and core challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Start in a bear crawl position with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. While maintaining a stable core, lift one hand to touch the opposite shoulder, then return it to the ground. Alternate sides for the desired duration.

Title: Shadow boxing
Desc: Shadow boxing is an exercise typically used in combat sports and fighting. However, it can also make a great cardio session for anyone to implement in a fast-paced circuit or as active rest. It is usually performed for time or rounds.
HowTo: Stand in a fighting stance and throw punches into the air, moving your feet to simulate footwork. Maintain a light bounce and keep your core engaged. Perform for a set time or rounds.
