Title: Bear crawl fire feet
Desc: Bear crawl fire feet is a variation of the bear crawl that involves running in place while in a static bear crawl hold. It adds an extra coordination and full-body challenge to an already intense full-body movement that targets the cardiovascular system as well as a wide range of muscle groups. It can be done as a full-body warm-up, or as part of a bodyweight circuit or flow.
HowTo: Begin in a bear crawl position. While holding this position, run in place by alternating your knees towards your chest, keeping your hands on the ground and your core engaged.

Title: Wall sprawl
Desc: The wall sprawl is a bodyweight exercise targeting the shoulders, although numerous other muscles are recruited to complete the exercise. From an all-fours position, you kick up onto the wall, then back down. It's a serious cardiovascular challenge that is usually performed as part of a fat-loss or athleticism-focused workout.
HowTo: Start in an all-fours position. Kick your feet up towards the wall while pushing your hips forward, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Bent Over Shoulder Y
Desc: The lying rear delt Y works the shoulders, specifically the rear heads. The range of motion differs from the lying rear delt fly. At the midpoint, the arms and torso form a Y—hence the name.
HowTo: Bend at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, holding light dumbbells or weight plates. Raise your arms in a Y shape, keeping your elbows slightly bent, then lower them back down. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Shoulder L
Desc: The bent-over shoulder rotation is an upper-body exercise that helps strengthen the muscles around the rotator cuff for a stable shoulder joint. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the shoulders. It can be performed with body weight, light dumbbells or weight plates, or bands.
HowTo: Bend at the hips and hold light dumbbells or weight plates. Rotate your arms outward while keeping your elbows close to your body, then return to the starting position. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Shoulder Dislocation Stretch-Dowel
Desc: The Shoulder Dislocation Stretch with a dowel is an effective exercise for improving shoulder mobility and flexibility. To perform this stretch, hold a dowel or a similar object with both hands, arms extended in front of you. Slowly raise the dowel overhead and behind your head while keeping your arms straight. Ensure to maintain a comfortable range of motion and avoid any pain. This stretch can help alleviate tightness in the shoulders and promote better range of motion.
HowTo: Hold a dowel or similar object with both hands in front of you, arms extended. Slowly raise the dowel overhead and behind your head while keeping your arms straight. Return to the starting position and repeat, ensuring a comfortable range of motion.

Title: TBS Inverted Row
Desc: The Smith machine inverted row is a bodyweight exercise targeting the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) and upper back, using the bar of the Smith machine to hang and pull from. You can change the bar height to customize the difficulty level and desired angle of the row. This variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more.
HowTo: To perform the TBS Inverted Row, set the bar of the Smith machine to a height that allows you to hang underneath it with your body straight. Grip the bar with both hands, slightly wider than shoulder-width apart. Engage your core and pull your chest towards the bar, squeezing your shoulder blades together at the top of the movement. Lower yourself back down with control and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: PVC Shoulder Stretch
Desc: The PVC Shoulder Stretch is a mobility exercise that helps improve shoulder flexibility and range of motion. To perform this stretch, hold a PVC pipe or a similar object with both hands, wider than shoulder-width apart. Raise the pipe overhead and then lower it behind your back while keeping your arms straight. Return to the starting position and repeat.
HowTo: To perform the PVC Shoulder Stretch, hold a PVC pipe with both hands wider than shoulder-width apart. Raise the pipe overhead, keeping your arms straight. Lower the pipe behind your back while maintaining straight arms, feeling the stretch in your shoulders. Return to the starting position and repeat for several repetitions.

Title: Shoulder T
Desc: The bent-over plate rear delt raise is an exercise targeting the rear heads of the shoulders, aka deltoids. You can also use dumbbells or other light weights for a similar effect. This movement is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up, or as a high-rep burnout movement on a shoulder or back day.
HowTo: To perform the Shoulder T, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a plate or light weights in each hand. Bend at the hips with a slight bend in your knees, keeping your back straight. Raise the weights out to the sides in a 'T' position, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Lower the weights back down and repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: HM Arm Circle
Desc: The HM Arm Circle is a dynamic warm-up exercise that helps to increase blood flow to the shoulders and improve mobility. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms out to the sides. Make small circles with your arms, gradually increasing the size of the circles. Perform for 30 seconds in one direction, then switch to the opposite direction.
HowTo: To perform the HM Arm Circle, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and extend your arms out to the sides at shoulder height. Start making small circles with your arms, gradually increasing the size of the circles. Continue for 30 seconds in one direction, then switch and perform for another 30 seconds in the opposite direction.

Title: HM Shoulder Stretch
Desc: The HM Shoulder Stretch is a static stretch aimed at increasing flexibility in the shoulder area. To perform this stretch, stand or sit comfortably, then bring one arm across your body at shoulder height. Use the opposite arm to gently pull the arm closer to your chest, feeling the stretch in the shoulder. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: To perform the HM Shoulder Stretch, stand or sit comfortably. Bring one arm across your body at shoulder height. Use your opposite arm to gently pull the arm closer to your chest, feeling the stretch in your shoulder. Hold this position for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: HM Shoulder Stretch on Floor
Desc: The HM Shoulder Stretch on Floor is a variation of the shoulder stretch performed while seated on the floor. Sit with your legs crossed or extended in front of you. Reach one arm overhead and bend it at the elbow, allowing your hand to touch your upper back. Use the opposite hand to gently push down on the elbow, enhancing the stretch. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: To perform the HM Shoulder Stretch on Floor, sit on the floor with your legs crossed or extended in front of you. Reach one arm overhead and bend it at the elbow, allowing your hand to touch your upper back. Use your opposite hand to gently push down on the elbow to enhance the stretch. Hold for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: HM Shoulder Tap
Desc: The HM Shoulder Tap is a core stability exercise that also engages the shoulders. Start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders. While maintaining a stable core, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder, then return to the plank position. Alternate sides for a set number of repetitions.
HowTo: To perform the HM Shoulder Tap, start in a plank position with your hands directly under your shoulders and your body in a straight line. While keeping your core stable, lift one hand to tap the opposite shoulder. Return to the plank position and alternate sides for a set number of repetitions.

Title: HM Hand-On-Wall Stretch
Desc: The HM Hand-On-Wall Stretch is a shoulder stretch that targets the chest and shoulder muscles. Stand facing a wall and place one hand on the wall at shoulder height. Slowly turn your body away from the wall to feel a stretch in the shoulder and chest area. Hold for 15-30 seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: To perform the HM Hand-On-Wall Stretch, stand facing a wall and place one hand on the wall at shoulder height. Slowly turn your body away from the wall, feeling a stretch in your shoulder and chest area. Hold this position for 15-30 seconds, then switch sides.

Title: HM Jumping Arm Circle
Desc: The HM Jumping Arm Circle is a dynamic warm-up exercise that involves jumping while performing circular arm movements to increase shoulder mobility and prepare the upper body for physical activity.
HowTo: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Jump while extending your arms out to the sides, making circular motions with your arms. Focus on keeping your shoulders relaxed and engaged as you jump.

Title: Kipping Clapping Pull-Up
Desc: The Kipping Clapping Pull-Up is an advanced pull-up variation that combines a kipping motion with a clap at the top of the movement, enhancing upper body strength and coordination.
HowTo: Start by hanging from a pull-up bar with an overhand grip. Engage your core and initiate a kipping motion by swinging your legs. As you reach the top of the pull-up, clap your hands together before returning to the starting position.

Title: Holman Kneeling Overhead Press to Donkey Kick
Desc: The Holman Kneeling Overhead Press to Donkey Kick is a strength exercise that targets the shoulders and core, performed from a kneeling position and incorporating a donkey kick for added glute engagement.
HowTo: Kneel on the ground with a dumbbell in each hand. Press the weights overhead while keeping your core tight. After the press, perform a donkey kick by extending one leg back while maintaining the overhead position. Alternate sides.

Title: Floor angel
Desc: The floor angel is a stretch targeting shoulder mobility and activation of the shoulder stabilizer muscles. It also targets a range of postural muscles in the upper back.
Muscles: Deltoids, Rotator Cuff, Upper Back Muscles
HowTo: Lie flat on your back with your arms extended out to the sides at shoulder height. Slowly slide your arms up and down against the floor, maintaining contact with the ground, to create a 'snow angel' motion.

Title: Shoulder extension stretch
Desc: The shoulder extension stretch is focused on bringing more flexibility to the shoulder joint. It increases range of motion in shoulder extension, or moving the arms behind the back. It can be performed as part of a warm-up or mobility and flexibility work post-workout or anytime.
HowTo: Stand tall and clasp your hands behind your back. Gently pull your arms away from your body while keeping your shoulders down, feeling the stretch in your shoulders and chest. Hold for 20-30 seconds.

Title: Backward Medicine Ball Throw
Desc: The Backward Medicine Ball Throw is a power exercise that involves throwing a medicine ball backward to develop explosive strength in the legs and core.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a medicine ball at chest level. Bend your knees slightly and then explosively throw the ball backward, using your legs and core to generate power.

Title: Medicine ball scoop throw
Desc: The medicine ball scoop throw is an explosive exercise targeting the abdominals and hips. It can be performed for lower reps with a focus on power or for higher reps with a focus on fat loss and conditioning. It begins in a semi-squat position holding a medicine ball, which then gets "scooped" up and thrown overhead in one continuous movement.
HowTo: Start in a semi-squat position with a medicine ball held at your chest. Quickly extend your legs and hips while scooping the ball up and throwing it overhead in one fluid motion.

Title: Standing Two-Arm Overhead Throw
Desc: The Standing Two-Arm Overhead Throw is a full-body exercise that enhances coordination and power by throwing a weighted object overhead while standing.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a weighted object with both hands. Raise the object overhead while engaging your core, then throw it forward with power, following through with your arms.

Title: Incline face-down bar front raise
Desc: The incline face-down bar front raise is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders. Because it is performed face down on an angled bench, it has a greater range of motion than standing or upright-seated raises and hits the shoulders from a different angle. Raise variations are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder-focused training.
HowTo: Lie face down on an inclined bench with a barbell in your hands. Keep your arms straight and lift the barbell in front of you to shoulder height. Lower the barbell back down with control. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: Incline anti-gravity shoulder press
Desc: The incline anti-gravity shoulder press is an upper-body exercise targeting the shoulders and upper back. It works the rear delts and upper-back muscles isometrically to hold the weight up, while dynamically training the lateral and front delts. Because of the challenge of holding the weight up, this press variation is usually performed with relatively light weights for moderate reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or shoulder training.
Muscles: Anterior Deltoids, Lateral Deltoids, Posterior Deltoids, Upper Back
HowTo: Sit on an inclined bench with a light weight in each hand. Press the weights overhead while keeping your core engaged. Hold the weights at the top for a moment before lowering them back down. Perform 8-12 reps.

Title: 30 Shoulders EZ-Bar Front Raise
Desc: The 30 Shoulders EZ-Bar Front Raise is an exercise that targets the shoulder muscles, specifically the anterior deltoids. To perform this exercise, stand upright holding an EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing down. Raise the bar in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight, then lower it back down with control.
HowTo: Stand upright holding an EZ-bar with both hands, palms facing down. Raise the bar in front of you to shoulder height while keeping your arms straight. Lower it back down with control. Perform for several reps.

Title: Side Wrist Pull
Desc: The Side Wrist Pull is an exercise designed to strengthen the forearm and wrist muscles. To perform this exercise, extend one arm in front of you with the palm facing up. Use the opposite hand to gently pull back on the fingers of the extended arm, feeling a stretch in the wrist and forearm. Hold for a few seconds and switch sides.
HowTo: Extend one arm in front of you with the palm facing up. Use the opposite hand to gently pull back on the fingers of the extended arm, feeling a stretch in the wrist and forearm. Hold for a few seconds, then switch sides.

Title: Elbow Circles
Desc: Elbow Circles are a mobility exercise that helps improve flexibility and range of motion in the elbow joint. To perform this exercise, stand or sit comfortably and extend your arms out to the sides. Make small circles with your elbows, first clockwise and then counterclockwise, for several repetitions.
HowTo: Stand or sit comfortably and extend your arms out to the sides. Make small circles with your elbows, first clockwise for 10-15 repetitions, then counterclockwise for the same amount.

Title: Kneeling Arm Drill
Desc: The Kneeling Arm Drill is a stability and strength exercise that focuses on the shoulders and core. Begin in a kneeling position with your hands on the ground in front of you. Engage your core and lift one arm straight out in front of you, keeping your body stable. Alternate arms for several repetitions.
HowTo: Begin in a kneeling position with your hands on the ground in front of you. Engage your core and lift one arm straight out in front of you, keeping your body stable. Alternate arms for several repetitions.

Title: Bent-over shoulder rotation
Desc: The bent-over shoulder rotation is an upper-body exercise that helps strengthen the muscles around the rotator cuff for a stable shoulder joint. It is usually performed as part of a dynamic warm-up for the shoulders. It can be performed with body weight, light dumbbells or weight plates, or bands.
HowTo: Bend forward at the hips with a slight bend in your knees. Hold light dumbbells or weight plates in each hand. Rotate your shoulders by lifting the weights out to the sides and then back to the starting position. Repeat for several reps.

Title: Band overhead triceps press
Desc: The band overhead triceps press is a dynamic arm exercise utilizing a looped exercise band. It could also be performed with an exercise band with handles. It targets the triceps muscles and can be performed for time or reps, either in traditional muscle-building rep ranges such as 12-15 reps per set, or higher rep ranges such as 30, 50, or more.
HowTo: Stand with a looped exercise band overhead. Grasp the band with both hands and press it upward, extending your arms fully. Lower the band back down to the starting position with control. Perform for time or 12-15 reps.

Title: Band overhead triceps extension
Desc: The band overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps that uses the dynamic resistance of the band. The overhead position of the arms targets the long head of the triceps. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: To perform the band overhead triceps extension, secure a resistance band under your feet and hold the other end with both hands. Raise your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. Lower the band behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend your arms back to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Band straight-arm pull-down
Desc: The band straight-arm pull-down is a non-gym or at home variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: To perform the band straight-arm pull-down, anchor a resistance band above your head. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and slightly bend your knees. With straight arms, pull the band down towards your thighs, engaging your lats and upper back. Slowly return to the starting position. Aim for 8-15 reps.

Title: Band skullcrusher
Desc: The band skullcrusher is a variation of the popular bench exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the band skullcrusher, lie on your back with a resistance band secured under your upper back. Hold the ends of the band with your arms extended above your head. Bend your elbows to lower the band towards your forehead, then extend your arms back to the starting position. Perform for moderate to high reps.

Title: Single-arm band kick-back
Desc: The single-arm band kick-back is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm band kick-back, anchor a resistance band at a low point. Bend forward slightly at the hips and hold the band in one hand. Keep your elbow close to your body and extend your arm back, squeezing the triceps at the top. Return to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Incline EZ-bar skullcrusher
Desc: The incline EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the incline EZ-bar skullcrusher, lie on an incline bench and hold an EZ-bar with a close grip above your head. Lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position. Perform for moderate to high reps.

Title: Decline Close-Grip Bench To Skull Crusher
Desc: The Decline Close-Grip Bench to Skull Crusher is a compound exercise that targets the triceps and chest. It involves performing a decline bench press with a close grip, followed by a skull crusher movement to further isolate the triceps. This exercise helps build strength and mass in the upper body.
HowTo: To perform the decline close-grip bench to skull crusher, lie on a decline bench and hold a barbell with a close grip. Lower the bar to your chest, then press it back up. After the press, transition into a skull crusher by lowering the bar towards your forehead and extending back up. Perform for moderate to high reps.

Title: Bench Press - Powerlifting
Desc: The Bench Press - Powerlifting is a fundamental strength training exercise that focuses on building upper body strength, particularly in the chest, shoulders, and triceps. In powerlifting, the bench press is performed with a specific technique to maximize strength and is often a competitive lift. Proper form includes a controlled descent and explosive ascent.
HowTo: To perform the bench press for powerlifting, lie on a flat bench and grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the bar to your chest in a controlled manner, then press it back up explosively. Keep your feet flat on the ground and your back arched slightly. Focus on proper form and aim for your competition weight.

Title: Behind-the-head skullcrusher
Desc: The behind-the-head skullcrusher is a variation on a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. In this version, instead of the bar coming down lightly to the forehead, the bar tracks over the top of the head without touching it. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout. If a straight bar is uncomfortable for your wrists or elbows, try using an angled EZ-bar.
HowTo: To perform the behind-the-head skullcrusher, lie on a bench and hold a barbell or EZ-bar with a close grip above your head. Lower the bar behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Standing barbell overhead triceps extension
Desc: The standing barbell overhead triceps extension is an isolation movement targeting the triceps. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. This movement is generally performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arms-focused portion of a workout. If holding a straight bar bothers the wrists or elbows, it can alternately be performed with an EZ-bar or neutral-grip bar.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a barbell with both hands above your head. Lower the barbell behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position to complete the rep.

Title: Reverse-grip bench press
Desc: The reverse-grip bench press is a popular barbell exercise targeting the chest, triceps, and forearms. The main difference between this exercise and the standard bench press is that the grip is underhand, not overhand. This helps target both the upper chest and the triceps. This lift can feel awkward at first, so go light and don't be afraid to use a spotter.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell positioned above your chest. Grip the barbell with an underhand grip, slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Bench Press with Chains
Desc: The Bench Press with Chains is a variation of the traditional bench press that incorporates chains to increase resistance at the top of the lift. This exercise targets the chest, triceps, and shoulders, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: Set up a barbell on a bench press station. Attach chains to the barbell. Lie on the bench and grip the barbell with your hands slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest, then press it back up, feeling the added resistance from the chains.

Title: Floor Press
Desc: The Floor Press is a strength training exercise that involves lying on the floor and pressing a barbell or dumbbells from the chest. It primarily targets the chest and triceps while minimizing shoulder strain.
HowTo: Lie on the floor with a barbell or dumbbells held above your chest. Lower the weights until your elbows touch the floor, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: One Arm Floor Press
Desc: The One Arm Floor Press is a unilateral exercise that involves lying on the floor and pressing a dumbbell with one arm. This exercise helps improve strength and stability in the shoulder and engages the core.
HowTo: Lie on the floor with a dumbbell in one hand. Press the dumbbell from your chest straight up until your arm is fully extended. Lower it back down to your chest to complete the rep.

Title: Pin Presses
Desc: Pin Presses are performed by setting a barbell on pins at a specific height and pressing it upward. This exercise focuses on the top portion of the lift, targeting the triceps and shoulders, and is great for building lockout strength.
HowTo: Set a barbell on pins at a height just above your chest. Grip the barbell and press it upward until your arms are fully extended. Lower the barbell back to the pins to complete the rep.

Title: JM Press With Bands
Desc: The JM Press With Bands is a variation of the JM Press that incorporates resistance bands to increase tension throughout the movement. This exercise targets the triceps and is effective for building strength and muscle size.
HowTo: Attach resistance bands to a barbell and set it up on a bench. Lie on the bench and grip the barbell. Lower the barbell to your chest, then press it back up, feeling the resistance from the bands throughout the movement.

Title: JM Press
Desc: The JM Press is a hybrid exercise that combines a skull crusher and a close-grip bench press. It primarily targets the triceps and is performed by lowering the bar to the forehead and pressing it back up.
HowTo: Lie on a bench and hold a barbell above your chest with a close grip. Lower the barbell towards your forehead by bending your elbows, then press it back up to the starting position.

Title: Floor Press with Chains
Desc: The Floor Press with Chains is a variation of the traditional floor press that incorporates chains to increase resistance at the top of the movement, enhancing strength and stability.
HowTo: Lie on your back on the floor with your knees bent. Hold the chains attached to the barbell at shoulder width. Press the barbell upwards until your arms are fully extended, then lower it back down until your elbows touch the floor.

Title: Reverse Band Bench Press
Desc: The Reverse Band Bench Press uses bands to reduce the weight at the bottom of the lift, allowing for a greater range of motion and assisting in building strength in the bench press.
HowTo: Set up a barbell on a bench and attach bands to the barbell and the rack. Lie on the bench with your feet flat on the ground. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width. Lower the barbell to your chest, allowing the bands to assist at the bottom, then press back up to the starting position.

Title: Decline Barbell Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The decline EZ-bar skullcrusher is an upper body isolation exercise targeting the triceps.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench and hold an EZ-bar with an overhand grip. Extend your arms above your head, then lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows. Keep your upper arms stationary and extend back to the starting position.

Title: AM Skullcrusher
Desc: The EZ-bar skullcrusher is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The EZ-bar is used more often than a straight bar. As for the name, that’s worst-case scenario. The bar should actually come down behind the head. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper body or arms-focused workout. No need to chase a 1RM on this move!
HowTo: Lie on a bench or the floor with an EZ-bar held above your chest. Lower the bar behind your head by bending your elbows while keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Close-Grip Bench Press
Desc: The 30 Arms Close-Grip Bench Press focuses on targeting the triceps and inner chest by using a close grip, emphasizing strength and muscle development in these areas.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a barbell in your hands, positioned above your chest with a close grip. Lower the barbell towards your chest, keeping your elbows close to your body. Press the barbell back up to the starting position.

Title: 30 Arms Barbell Skullcrusher
Desc: The 30 Arms Barbell Skullcrusher is an exercise aimed at isolating the triceps, performed by lowering a barbell from an extended position above the head to the forehead.
HowTo: Lie on a bench or the floor with a barbell held above your head. Lower the barbell towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: FYR2 Sprawl Over Kettlebell
Desc: The FYR2 Sprawl Over Kettlebell is a dynamic exercise that combines a sprawl with a kettlebell movement, enhancing agility, strength, and cardiovascular fitness.
HowTo: Start in a standing position with a kettlebell on the ground in front of you. Perform a sprawl by dropping into a plank position, then quickly return to your feet and lift the kettlebell overhead or perform a swing.

Title: Dumbbell floor press
Desc: The dumbbell floor press is a multijoint pressing exercise performed lying on the floor. It can be performed either with the knees bent or flat. The floor press limits the range of motion you would achieve with a regular dumbbell bench press, but still targets the chest, triceps, and anterior delts. This allows you to press more weight than in a dumbbell bench press, and perhaps put less stress on the shoulders.
HowTo: Lie on your back on the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. Hold the dumbbells above your chest with your arms extended. Lower the dumbbells until your elbows touch the floor, then press them back up to the starting position.

Title: Seated triceps press
Desc: The seated triceps press is a popular arm-building exercise that targets the triceps with a single dumbbell held by both hands, extending it up behind your head. While you can go surprisingly heavy on this movement, it is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout. If you're going heavy, having someone help get the weight into position is a good idea.
HowTo: Sit on a bench with back support, holding a dumbbell with both hands above your head. Keep your elbows close to your head and lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Tricep Dumbbell Kickback
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is an isolation move from a bent-over position used to increase size and strength of the triceps.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, holding a dumbbell in one hand. Bend forward at the hips while keeping your back straight. With your elbow close to your body, extend your arm back, squeezing the triceps at the top. Return to the starting position.

Title: Standing Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Standing Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps muscles. Stand upright with a dumbbell held in both hands above your head, arms fully extended. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position by extending your elbows.
HowTo: Stand upright with a dumbbell held in both hands above your head, arms fully extended. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Raise the dumbbell back to the starting position by extending your elbows.

Title: Double-arm triceps kick-back
Desc: The double-arm triceps kick-back is a popular movement to increase size and strength of the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Bend forward at the hips with a dumbbell in each hand. Keep your elbows close to your body and extend both arms back simultaneously, squeezing the triceps. Return to the starting position.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell triceps extension is a popular exercise targeting the triceps one side at a time. It targets all three heads of the triceps, but when performed with the arm overhead, it can be especially effective at building the long head of the triceps. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps, at least 8-12 reps per set, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand. Extend your arm overhead, then lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow. Extend your arm back to the starting position. Switch arms after completing the set.

Title: Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Decline Dumbbell Triceps Extension is performed on a decline bench to emphasize the long head of the triceps. Lie on a decline bench and hold a dumbbell in each hand above your head. Lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend your arms back to the starting position.
HowTo: Lie on a decline bench holding a dumbbell in each hand above your head. Lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: Dumbbell skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell skullcrusher is a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your chest. Lower the dumbbells towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Extend your arms back to the starting position.

Title: One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The One Arm Pronated Dumbbell Triceps Extension targets the triceps with a focus on unilateral strength. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended overhead. With your palm facing forward, lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow, then extend your arm back to the starting position. Switch arms after completing the set.
HowTo: Stand or sit with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended overhead. With your palm facing forward, lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbow. Extend your arm back to the starting position. Switch arms after completing the set.

Title: One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The One Arm Supinated Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an isolation exercise targeting the triceps. It involves holding a dumbbell in one hand with a supinated grip (palm facing up) and extending the arm overhead, focusing on the contraction of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Start by holding a dumbbell in one hand with a supinated grip (palm facing up). 2. Extend your arm overhead while keeping your elbow close to your head. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down to the starting position, focusing on the contraction of the triceps. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Seated Bent-Over Two-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension is performed while seated, leaning forward slightly. It involves holding two dumbbells with both hands behind the head and extending the arms upward, effectively targeting the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench and lean forward slightly. 2. Hold two dumbbells behind your head with both hands. 3. Extend your arms upward, pressing the dumbbells overhead. 4. Lower the dumbbells back behind your head and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Tate Press
Desc: The Tate Press is a triceps exercise performed lying on a bench. It involves holding dumbbells with a neutral grip and lowering them towards the chest before pressing them back up, emphasizing the triceps and the inner chest.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, using a neutral grip. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your chest, keeping your elbows tucked in. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, focusing on your triceps and inner chest. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Standing Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension is performed seated with one arm bent behind the head holding a dumbbell. The exercise focuses on extending the arm upwards to work the triceps effectively.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench and hold a dumbbell with one hand behind your head, elbow bent. 2. Extend your arm upwards, pressing the dumbbell overhead. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down behind your head. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions, then switch arms.

Title: Seated Bent-Over One-Arm Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The Dumbbell Tricep Extension with a Pronated Grip involves holding a dumbbell with palms facing down and extending the arms overhead. This variation targets the triceps while also engaging the shoulders.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench and hold a dumbbell with a pronated grip (palms facing down) above your head. 2. Extend your arms overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 3. Lower the dumbbell back down behind your head. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Dumbbell Tricep Extension -Pronated Grip
Desc: The PJR Pull-Over is a unique exercise that combines elements of a triceps extension and a pullover. Lying on a bench, you hold a dumbbell with both hands, lower it behind your head, and then pull it back over your chest, effectively working the triceps and lats.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench and hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head while keeping your elbows bent. 3. Pull the dumbbell back over your chest, engaging your triceps and lats. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: V-sit with overhead triceps extension
Desc: The V-sit with overhead triceps extension is a hybrid movement that trains the abdominal and triceps muscles simultaneously. It can address multiple muscle groups in a time-efficient muscle-building or circuit-style workout, while also providing a cardiovascular challenge.
HowTo: 1. Sit in a V-sit position with your legs raised and bent at the knees. 2. Hold a dumbbell overhead with both hands. 3. Extend your arms upward while maintaining the V-sit position. 4. Lower the dumbbell back down and repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: PJR Pull-Over
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench and hold a dumbbell with both hands above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head while keeping your elbows bent. 3. Pull the dumbbell back over your chest, engaging your triceps and lats. 4. Repeat for the desired number of repetitions.

Title: Paul Carter Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The single-arm triceps kick-back is an isolation move from a bent-over position used to increase size and strength of the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Begin by bending forward at the hips with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Keep your back straight and your core engaged. 3. With your elbow close to your body, extend your arm back, squeezing your triceps at the top of the movement. 4. Lower the dumbbell back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Single-arm dumbbell skullcrusher
Desc: The single-arm dumbbell skullcrusher is a triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. Skullcrushers are usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arms-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in one hand, arm extended above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbell towards your forehead by bending your elbow. 3. Keep your upper arm stationary and only move your forearm. 4. Press the dumbbell back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Dumbbells-together incline bench press
Desc: The dumbbells-together incline bench press is an exercise targeting the pectoral muscles, particularly the upper pecs. Squeezing the dumbbells together forces the chest muscles to work hard during the entire press. This press variation is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of upper-body or chest-focused training.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held together above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells together towards your chest, keeping them squeezed. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position, maintaining the squeeze. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Incline dumbbell overhead triceps extension
Desc: The incline dumbbell overhead triceps extension is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in each hand, arms extended above your head. 2. Lower the dumbbells behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Keep your upper arms stationary and only move your forearms. 4. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell Crush Press
Desc: The Dumbbell Crush Press is an effective exercise that targets the chest and triceps. It involves lying on a bench while holding dumbbells above your chest, then bringing them together in a 'crushing' motion before returning to the starting position.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held above your chest with palms facing each other. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your chest while keeping them together. 3. Press the dumbbells back together above your chest in a 'crushing' motion. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Hovering Renegade Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Hovering Renegade Triceps Press is a challenging exercise that combines a plank position with a triceps press. It engages the core while targeting the triceps, requiring stability and strength.
HowTo: 1. Start in a plank position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Engage your core and keep your body straight. 3. Lower one dumbbell towards your chest while stabilizing with the other arm. 4. Press the dumbbell back up while maintaining your plank position. 5. Alternate arms for the desired number of reps.

Title: Holman Heavy Triceps Press to Overhead Press
Desc: The Holman Heavy Triceps Press to Overhead Press is a compound exercise that works the triceps and shoulders. It starts with a triceps press and transitions into an overhead press, providing a comprehensive upper body workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell in each hand at shoulder height. 2. Press the dumbbells overhead while engaging your triceps. 3. Lower the dumbbells back to shoulder height, performing a triceps press. 4. Transition smoothly between the triceps press and the overhead press. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Total Fitness Close-Grip Dumbbell Press
Desc: The close-grip dumbbell bench press puts a spin on a mainstay of workout enthusiasts worldwide. It’s a classic move for building a bigger, stronger chest. The difference here is that the dumbbells are held closer together.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand, held close together above your chest. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your chest while keeping them close. 3. Press the dumbbells back up to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell row to triceps kick-back
Desc: The dumbbell row to triceps kick-back is a dumbbell complex that combines two movements that collectively target the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi), upper back, and triceps. It also isometrically targets the core, hamstrings, and glutes. It is usually performed one rep of each movement at a time, although you could perform more reps of each, or increase the reps in successive rounds (e.g., 1 rep in round 1, 2 reps in round 2, etc.). No matter how you structure the sets and reps, it is a time-efficient way to hit two crucial upper-body muscles in any workout.
HowTo: 1. Start in a bent-over position with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a dumbbell row by pulling the weights towards your torso, engaging your lats and upper back. 3. Lower the dumbbells back down. 4. Transition into a triceps kick-back by extending your arms back while keeping your elbows stationary. 5. Return to the starting position and repeat.

Title: Rolling triceps press
Desc: The rolling triceps press is a dynamic triceps exercise that is popular as a bench press accessory movement among powerlifters. It can be done in traditional muscle-building rep ranges, such as 8-12 reps per set, or for very high reps of 50-100 reps per set to boost triceps size and strength. It can be performed on a bench or on the floor if a bench is unavailable.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench or the floor with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Start with your arms bent at 90 degrees. 3. Press the dumbbells up while keeping your elbows close to your body. 4. Lower the weights back down to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: MetaBurn Skullcrusher to Ab Crunch
Desc: The MetaBurn Skullcrusher to Ab Crunch is a compound exercise that targets the triceps and core. Begin by lying on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Perform a skullcrusher by lowering the dumbbells towards your forehead, then extend your arms back to the starting position. Immediately follow this with an ab crunch by lifting your upper body towards your knees, engaging your core throughout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Perform a skullcrusher by lowering the dumbbells towards your forehead, keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 4. Immediately follow with an ab crunch by lifting your upper body towards your knees. 5. Engage your core throughout and repeat.

Title: FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The FYR2 Single-Dumbbell Triceps Extension is an effective exercise for building tricep strength. Stand or sit with a single dumbbell held overhead with both hands. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend back to the starting position, keeping your elbows close to your head.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a single dumbbell held overhead with both hands. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your elbows close to your head. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Arms Overhead Dumbbell Triceps Extension
Desc: The 30 Arms Overhead Dumbbell Triceps Extension focuses on the triceps while also engaging the shoulders. Stand or sit with a dumbbell held overhead with both hands. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend back to the starting position, ensuring to keep your core tight.
HowTo: 1. Stand or sit with a dumbbell held overhead with both hands. 2. Lower the dumbbell behind your head by bending your elbows. 3. Extend back to the starting position, keeping your core tight. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Arms Dumbbell Skullcrusher
Desc: The 30 Arms Dumbbell Skullcrusher is a targeted exercise for the triceps. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. Lower the dumbbells towards your forehead by bending your elbows, then extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on squeezing the triceps at the top.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench with a dumbbell in each hand. 2. Lower the dumbbells towards your forehead by bending your elbows. 3. Extend your arms back to the starting position, squeezing the triceps at the top. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: 30 Arms Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The 30 Arms Dumbbell Kick-Back is an isolation exercise for the triceps. Bend at the waist with a dumbbell in each hand, elbows bent at 90 degrees. Extend your arms back while keeping your elbows stationary, then return to the starting position, ensuring to engage the triceps throughout.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the waist with a dumbbell in each hand, elbows bent at 90 degrees. 2. Extend your arms back while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Return to the starting position. 4. Engage the triceps throughout and repeat.

Title: 30 Arms BFR Dumbbell Kick-Back
Desc: The 30 Arms BFR Dumbbell Kick-Back utilizes blood flow restriction (BFR) to enhance muscle growth. Bend at the waist with a dumbbell in each hand, elbows bent at 90 degrees. Extend your arms back while keeping your elbows stationary, then return to the starting position, focusing on the contraction in the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Bend at the waist with a dumbbell in each hand, elbows bent at 90 degrees. 2. Extend your arms back while keeping your elbows stationary. 3. Return to the starting position, focusing on the contraction in the triceps. 4. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Dumbbell saw triceps skullcrusher
Desc: The dumbbell saw triceps skullcrusher is a variation of the classic skullcrusher triceps exercise that has been a staple of bodybuilders for decades. It combines a dumbbell skullcrusher with a dumbbell shoulder press. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the Dumbbell Saw Triceps Skullcrusher, lie on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand. Start with the dumbbells above your forehead, then lower them towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. As you lower the weights, rotate your wrists to bring the dumbbells inwards, resembling a saw motion. Press the dumbbells back to the starting position while engaging your triceps.

Title: Chain Handle Extension
Desc: The Chain Handle Extension is an exercise that targets the triceps by extending the arms while holding onto a chain handle, emphasizing the long head of the triceps for improved strength and definition.
HowTo: To perform the Chain Handle Extension, stand or kneel while holding onto the chain handle with both hands. Extend your arms downward, keeping your elbows close to your body. Focus on squeezing the triceps as you fully extend your arms, then slowly return to the starting position. Maintain control throughout the movement to maximize triceps engagement.

Title: Sled Overhead Triceps Extension
Desc: The Sled Overhead Triceps Extension involves using a sled to perform overhead extensions, effectively isolating the triceps while stabilizing the core, making it an excellent exercise for building triceps strength.
HowTo: To perform the Sled Overhead Triceps Extension, attach a sled to a cable or resistance band. Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, grasp the handles, and lift them overhead. Keep your elbows close to your head and extend your arms upward, focusing on contracting the triceps. Lower the sled back to the starting position with control.

Title: Body Triceps Press Using Flat Bench
Desc: The bodyweight triceps press is an arm movement that involves performing overhead presses in a face-down position on a Smith machine or other raised bar. It is a surprisingly difficult movement that hammers all three heads of the triceps and can easily be scaled upward or downward in difficulty by moving the bar.
HowTo: To perform the Body Triceps Press Using Flat Bench, lie face down on a flat bench with your arms extended overhead holding onto a bar. Lower the bar towards your forehead by bending your elbows, keeping your body stable. Press the bar back up to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps throughout the movement.

Title: Suspended Triceps Press
Desc: The Suspended Triceps Press is performed using suspension straps, allowing for a unique angle of resistance that engages the triceps and stabilizing muscles, enhancing overall upper body strength.
HowTo: To perform the Suspended Triceps Press, adjust the suspension straps to a suitable height. Stand facing away from the anchor point, holding the straps with your palms facing each other. Lean forward slightly and lower your body by bending your elbows, keeping them close to your sides. Press back to the starting position, engaging your triceps and stabilizing muscles.

Title: Seated triceps push-down
Desc: The seated triceps push-down is a triceps exercise that is performed with a rope attachment. The seated position helps eliminate the use of momentum. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the Seated Triceps Push-Down, sit on a bench with a rope attachment connected to a cable machine. Grasp the rope with both hands, elbows close to your body. Push the rope downwards by extending your arms, focusing on squeezing your triceps at the bottom of the movement. Slowly return to the starting position with control.

Title: Machine triceps extension-
Desc: The machine triceps extension is a popular exercise to build size and strength in the triceps muscles. It approximates the motion of a free-weight skullcrusher, but uses a selectorized weight-stack or plate-loaded machine. Machine triceps extensions are often done for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of the upper-body or arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: To perform the Machine Triceps Extension, sit on the machine with your back against the pad. Adjust the seat height so that the handles are at shoulder level. Grasp the handles and extend your arms downward, focusing on contracting your triceps. Slowly return to the starting position, maintaining control throughout the movement.

Title: Holman Overhead Weighted Triceps Press
Desc: The Holman Overhead Weighted Triceps Press is a variation of the triceps press that incorporates weights overhead, focusing on the triceps while also engaging the shoulders and core for stability.
HowTo: To perform the Holman Overhead Weighted Triceps Press, stand with your feet shoulder-width apart and hold a weight overhead with both hands. Lower the weight behind your head by bending your elbows, keeping your upper arms stationary. Press the weight back to the starting position, focusing on engaging your triceps and maintaining core stability.

Title: 30 Arms Weighted Triceps Dip
Desc: The 30 Arms Weighted Triceps Dip is an effective exercise for targeting the triceps muscles. To perform this exercise, start by sitting on the edge of a bench or platform with your hands positioned beside your hips. Place a weight plate or dumbbell on your lap for added resistance. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground, then push back up to the starting position. Ensure to keep your elbows close to your body throughout the movement for maximum effectiveness.
HowTo: To perform the 30 Arms Weighted Triceps Dip, start by sitting on the edge of a bench or platform with your hands beside your hips. Place a weight plate or dumbbell on your lap. Lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground, then push back up to the starting position, keeping your elbows close to your body.

Title: Cable V-bar push-down
Desc: The cable V-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It utilizes an angled bar, which can allow you to move heavier weights more comfortably than a straight bar or rope. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the cable V-bar push-down, attach a V-bar to a high pulley. Stand facing the machine and grasp the V-bar with both hands. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. Slowly return to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Reverse Grip Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: To perform the reverse grip triceps pushdown, attach a straight bar to a high pulley. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip (palms facing up). Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. Slowly return to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Kneeling cable triceps extension
Desc: The kneeling cable triceps extension is a single-joint exercise meant to isolate the triceps muscles using a high pully on a cable stack and a bench. It can also be performed in a tall-kneeling stance from a low pully. It is most commonly used in muscle-building triceps or arm workouts.
HowTo: To perform the kneeling cable triceps extension, kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. Grasp the handle with both hands and pull it down behind your head. Extend your arms to lift the handle back to the starting position, keeping your elbows close to your head. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm cable triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm cable triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves driving a handle attached to a cable stack overhead to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the single-arm cable triceps extension, attach a handle to a low pulley. Stand with your side to the machine and grasp the handle with one hand. Extend your arm overhead, then lower it back to the starting position. Keep your elbow close to your head. Aim for 8-12 reps per arm.

Title: Dip Machine
Desc: The dip machine is a machine exercise that mimics a triceps dip, a bodyweight exercise performed on parallel bars or on a pull-up and dip station. It targets the triceps first, but also stretches and strengthens the chest and shoulders. Dips with a triceps focus are usually performed with an upright torso, the knees bent and crossed, and the arms close to the body. Dips can be performed for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.
HowTo: To use the dip machine, adjust the seat height and sit down with your back against the pad. Grasp the handles and lower your body by bending your elbows until your upper arms are parallel to the ground. Push back up to the starting position. Perform for low reps for strength or higher reps for muscle growth.

Title: Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The cable V-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It utilizes an angled bar, which can allow you to move heavier weights more comfortably than a straight bar or rope. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the triceps pushdown, attach a V-bar to a high pulley. Stand facing the machine and grasp the V-bar with both hands. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. Slowly return to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Low cable overhead triceps extension
Desc: The low cable overhead triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves lying on a bench and then driving the rope handle to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: To perform the low cable overhead triceps extension, lie on a bench with your head at the end closest to the cable machine. Grasp the rope handle attached to a low pulley. Extend your arms overhead, then lower the handle behind your head. Return to the starting position. Aim for 8-12 reps.

Title: Lying cable triceps extension
Desc: The lying cable triceps extension is an isolation exercise performed lying on either a bench or the floor. This movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps for a burn and pump as part of an arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie on a bench or the floor with a cable machine positioned above you. 2. Grasp the cable handle with both hands. 3. Keeping your elbows stationary, lower the handle towards your forehead. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on contracting the triceps. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Low Cable Triceps Extension
Desc: The Low Cable Triceps Extension is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps muscles. It is performed using a cable machine, where you pull the cable downwards while keeping your elbows close to your body. This exercise helps to build strength and definition in the triceps.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with the pulley set at a low position. 2. Grasp the cable handle with one hand, keeping your elbow close to your body. 3. Pull the handle downwards, extending your arm fully. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Cable overhead triceps extension
Desc: The cable overhead triceps extension is a cable exercise performed in a seated position, targeting the triceps muscles. While it hits all three heads of the triceps, the overhead position helps to target the long head in particular. The seated position helps eliminate the use of momentum. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on a bench with a cable machine positioned behind you. 2. Grasp the cable handle with both hands and lift it overhead. 3. Keeping your elbows close to your head, lower the handle behind your head. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on the triceps contraction. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm low cable triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm low cable triceps extension is a single-joint isolation exercise for building the triceps. It involves driving a handle attached to a cable stack overhead to full extension. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at a low position. 2. Grasp the cable handle with one hand. 3. Pull the handle back while keeping your elbow stationary, extending your arm fully. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Incline cable straight-bar triceps extension
Desc: The incline cable straight-bar triceps extension is a single-joint arm exercise performed on an incline bench. This incline position offers a great stretch and range of motion, potentially targeting the long head of the triceps more than some other triceps exercises. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Lie back on an incline bench with a cable machine positioned above you. 2. Grasp the straight bar attachment with both hands. 3. Lower the bar towards your forehead while keeping your elbows stationary. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on the triceps contraction. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Paul Carter Overhead Rope Triceps Extension
Desc: The rope overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps and using a cable stack with a rope handle. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, like at least 8-12 reps or higher.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment set at a high position. 2. Grasp the rope with both hands and pull it overhead. 3. Keeping your elbows close to your head, lower the rope behind your head. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position, focusing on the triceps contraction. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: TBS Rope Cable Push-Down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand in front of a cable machine with a rope attachment set at a high position. 2. Grasp the rope with both hands, keeping your elbows close to your body. 3. Push the rope downwards, fully extending your arms. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps.

Title: Single-arm cable triceps kick-back
Desc: The single-arm cable triceps kick-back is an isolation exercise that targets the triceps. This is a common burnout move performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or more, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Stand next to a cable machine with the pulley set at a low position. 2. Grasp the cable handle with one hand. 3. Bend forward slightly and extend your arm back, keeping your elbow stationary. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for the desired number of reps, then switch arms.

Title: Incline cable rope triceps extension
Desc: The incline cable rope triceps extension is a single-joint arm exercise performed on an incline bench. This incline position offers a great stretch and range of motion, potentially targeting the long head of the triceps more than some other triceps exercises. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Set an incline bench at a comfortable angle. 2. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 3. Sit on the bench with your back against it, holding the rope with both hands. 4. Extend your arms straight up above your head. 5. Slowly lower the rope behind your head while keeping your elbows close to your ears. 6. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 7. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip (palms facing up). 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Kneeling Cable Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The kneeling cable triceps extension is an single-joint exercise meant to isolate the triceps muscles, using a high pully on a cable stack and a bench. It can also be performed in a tall-kneeling stance from a low pully. It is most commonly used in muscle-building triceps or overall arms workouts.
HowTo: 1. Kneel in front of a cable machine with a high pulley. 2. Grasp the handle with both hands and pull it down to your forehead level. 3. Keep your elbows stationary and extend your arms upward, isolating the triceps. 4. Slowly lower the handle back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable Overhead Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The overhead triceps extension is an isolation exercise that is performed with a cable. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand with your back to the machine, holding the rope with both hands above your head. 3. Keep your elbows close to your ears and lower the rope behind your head. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Reverse-Grip Cable Triceps Pushdown - Gethin Variation
Desc: The reverse-grip cable straight-bar push-down is a twist on the popular cable straight-bar push-down. The difference has to do with how the hands are positioned holding the bar: the palms facing up rather than down. Because grip will be a limiting factor, this movement is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps per set or higher.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with an underhand grip (palms facing up). 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable Triceps Extension - Gethin Variation
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope down until your arms are fully extended. 4. Slowly return to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Single-arm incline triceps extension
Desc: The single-arm incline triceps extension is a dumbbell exercise targeting the triceps. The incline angle helps to target the long head of the triceps in particular. This exercise is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Sit on an incline bench with a dumbbell in one hand. 2. Extend your arm above your head, keeping your elbow close to your ear. 3. Slowly lower the dumbbell behind your head. 4. Extend your arm back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps on each arm.

Title: Triceps Overhead Extension with Rope - Gethin Variation
Desc: The overhead triceps extension is an isolation exercise that is performed with a cable. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps as part of the arm-focused portion of a workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand with your back to the machine, holding the rope with both hands above your head. 3. Keep your elbows close to your ears and lower the rope behind your head. 4. Extend your arms back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable rope push-down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Cable straight-bar push-down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Straight-arm bar pull-down
Desc: The straight-arm bar pull-down is a variation of the straight-arm lat pull-down performed using a cable stack machine. It can either be performed in an athletic upright stance, or slightly bent over. It both stretches and contracts the muscles of the lats (latissimus dorsi) as well as providing additional activation to the other upper back muscles and the core. Because the triceps are also isometrically involved in the movement, it is usually performed for higher reps, such as 8-15 reps or more.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand upright or slightly bent over, facing the machine. 3. Grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 4. Keeping your arms straight, pull the bar down towards your thighs while engaging your lats. 5. Hold for a moment at the bottom, then return to the starting position. 6. Repeat for 8-15 reps.

Title: AM Rope Triceps Pushdown
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: AM Bar Triceps Push-Down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: Rope overhead triceps extension
Desc: The rope overhead triceps extension is a single-joint exercise focused on the triceps that uses a cable stack with a rope handle. The overhead position targets the long head of the triceps in particular. Many lifters save this move for last in their triceps workout, performing it for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the low pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand with your back to the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Raise the rope overhead, keeping your elbows close to your head. 4. Lower the rope behind your head by bending your elbows, then extend your arms back to the starting position. 5. Repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: UP Rope Push-down
Desc: The cable rope push-down is a popular exercise targeting the triceps muscles. It's easy to learn and perform, making it a favorite for everyone from beginners to advanced lifters. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a rope handle to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the rope with both hands, palms facing each other. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the rope downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: UP Triceps Extension Straight-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The cable straight-bar push-down is a popular gym exercise for targeting the triceps. It is usually performed for moderate to high reps, such as 8-12 reps or more per set, as part of an upper-body or arm-focused workout.
HowTo: 1. Attach a straight bar to the high pulley of a cable machine. 2. Stand facing the machine and grasp the bar with both hands, palms facing down. 3. Keep your elbows close to your body and push the bar downwards until your arms are fully extended. 4. Squeeze your triceps at the bottom of the movement. 5. Slowly return to the starting position and repeat for 8-12 reps.

Title: LD Cable One-Arm Upright Row
Desc: The LD Cable One-Arm Upright Row is an exercise targeting the shoulders and upper back. It involves pulling a cable with one arm while maintaining a stable stance, focusing on controlled movement to engage the deltoids.
HowTo: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grasp the cable handle with one hand, keeping your elbow close to your body. Pull the cable upwards towards your shoulder, focusing on engaging your deltoids. Lower the cable back to the starting position in a controlled manner.

Title: 30 Arms Underhand Cable Straight-Bar Push-Down
Desc: The 30 Arms Underhand Cable Straight-Bar Push-Down is a triceps exercise performed using a cable machine. It emphasizes the triceps by pushing down a straight bar with an underhand grip, ensuring full extension and contraction of the muscle.
HowTo: Stand facing the cable machine with your feet shoulder-width apart. Grasp the straight bar with an underhand grip, keeping your elbows close to your body. Push the bar down until your arms are fully extended, then slowly return to the starting position, maintaining control throughout.

Title: 30 Arms Single-Arm Reverse-Grip Cable Push-Down
Desc: The 30 Arms Single-Arm Reverse-Grip Cable Push-Down targets the triceps using a cable machine. By utilizing a reverse grip, this exercise allows for a different angle of resistance, enhancing muscle engagement in the triceps.
